The shape of flight
The shapes of things that fly have always been
determined by the materials they are made of.
Feathers form wings that are basically
alike for all birds—and membrane forms an
entirely different wing for insects. It takes
thousands of years, but nature improves its
materials and shapes, just as technology
improves the materials and shapes of aircraft.
But here, the improvements in materials are so
rapid that designs become obsolete almost as
soon as they are functional.
Today, our aeronautical designers and missile
experts work with types of materials that
didn't exist just a few short years ago.
Steels are probably the most important examples:
United States Steel has just
developed five new types of steel for the
missile program. They are called "exotic"
steels because they have the almost unbelievable
qualities necessary for unearthly flights.
The shape and the success of our space birds
depend on steel. If you would like to get facts
about the wide range of career possibilities
in the steel industry, write to United States Steel,
Personnel Division, Room 2316, 525 William
Penn Place, Pittsburgh 30, Pennsylvania.
USS Is a registered trademark
(JJSS) United States Steel

OCTOBER, 1959


The Big Book Racket
Once each semester an unchanging drama appears
without fail on the local scene under titles ranging
from "The Big Book Racket" to "Money, Money,
Whose Got the Money?" From time to time the
plot varies from an art known as misleading adver-
tising to an extreme known in the auto industry as
planned obsolesence. Although this is "legitimate
theater" and nothing dishonest is implied, the fact
remains that the performance costs the captive aud-
ience thousands of extra dollars each year.
Of course, what has been referred to somewhat
in jest is nevertheless an important and expensive
process that each student faces at least twice each
year—the buying and selling of books. At first this
process might be passed off lightly but the fact that
15,000 students buy $30 worth of books each semes-
ter—both conservative estimates—reveals a business
that probably surpasses the million dollar a year
mark. But of course, this itself proves nothing—any
person has the right to operate a profitable business.
On the other hand things such as misleading adver-
tising and new editions, which were hinted at in
the opening paragraphs and are elaborated on be-
low, change the situation somewhat. A number of
these factors when combined might well be labeled
"the unplanned conspiracy of publishers, bookstores,
and authors."
The first part of this plot, which is probably more
irritating than anything else, starts with the well-
published advertisement of one local establishment
that reads "we buy books whether used again or
not." It is somewhat of a mild shock to the unsus-
pecting student to find that this ad is often backed
up—for twenty-five cents. There is the possibility
that the book may be worth no more than that but
this is not what the ad leads one to believe.
Now let us shift our thoughts to those men who
we could not do without—the authors—and a pro-
cess known as planned obsolesence in the auto in-
dustry but which goes under the title of the new
edition in the book business. We are in no way
indicting the large majority of faculty members
who are attempting to improve their books but in-
stead the minority who come out with new editions
of texts after two or even one year. Again it is
somewhat of a shock to find that in many of these
cases only the problems have been changed.
However, these situations are only minor prob-
lems compared to the unexcusable lack of foresight
used by some departmental staffs in deciding to use
a text book and then dropping it after one or two
semesters (when no change in the scope and aim
of the course is made). There is no need to list
any of the many specific examples of this situation
since most students who have been here for several
years have already been caught by this "big switch"
once, twice, or even three times. Often the state-
ment is made that it is impossible to evaluate a text
until after it has been used, but this seems to be a
rather lame excuse. Several days spent in checking
the proposed text carefully, possibly with the aid
of several students who have just completed the
course, would be of great help in evaluating a new
book. Or if it is imperative to use the book in a
class why not test it during summer school so that
relatively few students are affected.
Then comes the question of ever-rising book costs.
Of course, no one outside the business can say
whether they are justified or not. Even with the
figures before us this question might remain un-
answered. Nevertheless, the book stores and pub-
lishers may actually be cutting their own throats.
The inefficient and ineffective Student Book Ex-
change may be an indication of things to come. On
the engineering scene the establishment of a special
buy-sell bulletin board put up by one of the ME
student groups may be the forerunner of depart-
mental book exchanges operated by technical so-
cieties or departmental honoraries.
Taken individually these factors may seem un-
important but taken together they form an almost
unbeatable opponent. Only recently have steps such
as those mentioned above been taken. Still the future
is not bright. Against persuaders such as the new
edition, etc. the captive audience will continue to
return for performance after performance.
Barry L. Peebles

Rene Descartes... on the light of reason
"Hence we must believe that all the sciences are
so interconnected, that it is much easier to study
them all together than to isolate one from all the
others. Therefore, if anyone wishes to search out
the truth of things in earnest, he should not select
any one special science; for all the sciences are con-
joined with each other and interdependent: let
him think only about how to increase the natural
light of reason, not in order to solve this or that
difficulty of a scholastic nature, but that his under-
standing may direct his will to its proper choice in
every contingency of life."
&lt;— RegulcB ad Directionem Ingenii, 1629

LONG GERMANIUM DENDRITES, grown by a new technique developed in the Westinghouse
Solid State Physics Laboratory, are here inspected by Dr. A. I. Bennett, research physicist.
The Solid State Lab helps you when
your idea needs a new semiconductor
The Solid State Physics Laboratory helps Westinghouse
engineers exploit the rich phenomena of the solid state.
Problems are solved in low temperature and semicon-
ductor physics, and magnetic and ferroelectric materials.
If an engineer's idea requires a new kind of semicon-
ductor, this group may be able to develop it for him.
This laboratory is staffed by 27 Ph.D.'s, 4 M.S.'s,
and 7 B.S. junior engineers. Here's one way it ties in
with work at operating divisions:
The Air Arm Division is now developing super-
miniaturized electronic systems
Our Youngwood plant is designing the new devices
needed for these systems
The Solid State Physics Lab is perfecting a method
for growing the dendritic material needed to make
these devices
The young engineer at Westinghouse isn't expected to
know all of the answers. Our work is often too advanced
for that. Each man's work is backed up by specialists—
like the men in this Solid Stale Physics Lab. Even tough
problems are easier to solve with this kind of help.
If you've ambition and real ability, you can have a
rewarding career with Westinghouse. Our broad product
line, decentralized operations, and diversified technical
assistance provide hundreds of challenging opportunities
for talented engineers.

TECHNOLOGY

FOR
TOMORROW
Sputniks, transistors, H-bombs . . . these were
big achievements of the Fabulous Fifties. Now
on the eve of a new decade a Technic senior
editor examines a few of the breakthroughs,
changes, and discoveries . . . including those
events "just around the corner" and some "long
shots" . . . that will make the Sixties the most
important ten years in history.
by BARRY L. PEEBLES
Associate Editor
On October 4, 1957 a long slender
missile rose from a remote launch-
ing pad deep within the Soviet Union
destined to place in orbit around the
earth a small metallic sphere—which
soon become known the world over as
Sputnik I.
This event—more than any other—
symbolizes the rapidly expanding and far
reaching growth of technology during
the Fifties.
Now in the final months of 1959 and
on the eve of a new decade the big ques-
tion is: What is the forecast during the
Sixties for this technological era that
was born with the demands of World
War II and grew with the boom of the
Fifties?
This is the question that will be ex-
amined in the following paragraphs.
Problems Arise
Of course, certain problems arise when
one attempts to look into the future and
predict the unpredictable. As there were
in the Fifties, there should be a number
of unbelieveable and unpredictable ad-
vances or discoveries during the Sixties.
These might be compared to such totally
unforseen events in the Fifties as the fall
of the parity principle in physics, the
discovery of radiation bands around the
earth, the discovery of tranquilizers, or
the development of the "area rule" for
design of supersonic aircraft.
On the other hand observers in 1949
could be fairly sure that such things as
commercial jet flights, color TV, ther-
monuclear explosions (H-bomb), nu-
clear powered submarines, and transistors
10
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


would become a reality during the Fifties.
A glance at the chart on page 20 shows
many other advances and leaves little
doubt that these past ten years have
been one of the most important periods,
if not the most important, in the history
of the world. But this brings back the
original question about the Sixties—
where do we go from here?
The answer: Bigger, better, and more
technological expansion and growth than
any time in history. The big reason: the
United States will spend more for re-
search and development in the coming
decade than the total it has spent in all
the years combined since 1776. What's
more, this amount—which will top
$120,000,000,000— is more than double
the amount spent during the so-called
"fabbulous" Fifties. There should be no
doubting that this doubling of funds for
the backbone of progress—research and
development—will bring more scientific
and technical surprises in the Sixties than
ever dreamed of in the Fifties.
With these figures in mind let's take
a closer look at just what we can expect
in the Sixties — including those things
just "around the corner," others that are
likely in the mid-Sixties and also some
"long shots" for the late Sixties.
Consumer Goods
Most people, in their role as consumers,
have more interest in the applications of
recent breakthroughs to products they
can buy in the store. Many recent soon-
to-come applications — such as thermo-
electricity, ultrasonics, electroluminesence
—surely will have a direct bearing on
the lives we live, so let's see how and
when.
Without a doubt the early Sixties will
see at least one of three energy conver-
sion systems—-thermoelectricity, thermo-
ionic conversion, fuel cells—used in
practical applications. Most advanced of
the three is thermoelectricity (Technic,
Feb. 1959), mainly due to the efforts of
Westinghouse. Using special alloys and
semiconductors it is now possible to di-
rectly convert heat to electricity without
any moving parts. Of course, the effi-
ciency of about 10% that is obtained is
much too low to compete with commer-
cial power generators of today but it
might be high enough for small auxiliary
plants or for use in remote locations.
The big hope is that someday thermo-
electricity will be adapted for use with
nuclear reactors.
General Electric, on the other hand,
sees a limited future in thermoelectricity
and is placing its money on a thermo-
ionic converter—a device that "boils
electrons off" a heated metal surface to
provide an electric current. Little is
known of its possibilities but they do
not look especially bright at the present.
Still another company, Union Carbide,
is working on a third energy converter,
the fuel cell. This device uses a fuel
such as hydrogen or alcohol which is
passed over a catalytic surface to cause
combustion and a current flow. Early
indications are that "fuel cells" already
have an efficiency comparable to storage
batteries.
Another development that is already
being used in industry and should soon
have consumer application is ultrasonics
(Technic, Jan. 1957). Ultrasonic de-
vices use a very high frequency sound
vibration (inaudible) for such purposes
as cleaning and drilling. Westinghouse
expects to have a ultrasonic dishwasher
ready in the early sixties with clothes
washers not too far behind.
By far one of the brightest possibili-
ties—and one that has been talked about
for some time—is the use of electro-
luminesence {Technic, Feb. 1957) in
wall panels for light, heat, and even
cooling. These panels use a thermoelec-
tric principle opposite to that mentioned
before. In this case electric current
passed through a junction of two metals
causes heat to flow from one side to the
other. Thus a room can be either heated
or cooled. Light is also given off from
some of these semiconductor materials
when electrons return to their original
position after being boosted to a high
energy level. Westinghouse reports that
not only will electroluminesence make
possible walls that take care of all
heat, light, and air conditioning but it
will also pave the way for large mural
type wall TV screens (but not until the
late Sixties).
Almost bound to be extended is the
long line of synthetic fibers that started
with orlon in 1950, dacron in 1953 and
continued with such things as acrilin,
verel, zafran, etc. Next in line: kodal,
teron, and hundreds of others.
Development of food irradiation has
been sluggish up till now—mainly be-
cause industry has been dragging its feet
—but should pick up soon with the Army

MOHOLE
The Mohole ... a hole to the Moho . . . was
first proposed in jest but is now being backed
by the world's leading scientists.
by ROCKY STONE, '60E
Ever hear of AMSOC—the American
Miscellaneous Society? Probably not,
since AMSOC has less than 50 members
and no dues, records, laws, officers or
regular meetings. Meetings that do occur
are usually held at Washington parties
if there is a two member quorum present.
Typical agenda topic: How to tow Ant-
arctic icebergs north and use the melted
water to irrigate southern California.
It appears that AMSOC was founded
and kept alive by a group of alphabet-
weary scientists merely for the laughs it
provided. That is, until one problem be-
gan to gain international interest and the
backing of the National Academy of
Sciences. The project: Drilling a hole
through the earth's crust, through the
Mohorovicic Discontinuity (or Moho as it
is called) and into the earth's mantle—-
which comprises more than 80% of the
earth. True to form, AMSOC has labeled
the projected hole the MOHOLE.
Receives Support
Shortly after the first mention of this
project at a typical AMSOC meeting it
suddenly received the support of the
International Union of Geodesy and Geo-
physics, the National Academy of Sci-
ences, and the National Science Founda-
tion. Committees were cjuickly formed
and preliminary studies made. Available
equipment was studied and funds were
secured. The result: MOHOLE will be a
reality during the early or mid-Sixties.
At first it may appear that someone—
namely AMSOC—has succeeded in liter-
ally pulling the wool over someone's eyes.
Such is not the case because there are
several very sound and important scien-
tific reasons for drilling a MOHOLE.
The main one is, of course, to find out
just what the mantle is composed of and
validate certain theories about the earth's
interior. A second and intermediate, but
equally important, reason is to obtain a
fabulous history book covering two bil-
lion years by studying a continuous core
sample of sediment if the MOHOLE is
drilled through the ocean floor (as it
will be).
However, before the immense import-
ance of these reasons can be compre-
hended or the method of reaching the
Moho understood, a small amount of
background information is necessary.
First of all, it is true that a great deal
of information is known about the earth's
crust and its interior—but most of the
information is based on indirect evidence.
For example, astronomy gives informa-
tion about mass, density, and moment of
inertia; geology, the distribution, compo-
sition and movements of the internal
structure; physics, the strength, conductiv-
ity, and plasticity. Radiochemistry, seis-
mic, magnetic, and heat-flow studies all
provide additional information about the
mantle but again by indirect means.
Grand Hypothesis
From all of this information the geo-
physicist has come up with a grand hy-
pothesis combining all of this informa-
tion. What it boils down to is this: The
crust is composed of thick, comparatively
light sheets of granite about 20 miles
thick (the continents) separated by thin-
ner denser basalt about 2l/2 miles deep
(the ocean basins). Even though the
ocean basins are covered by 2y2 miles
of water and Yj mile of sediment it can
be seen why the MOHOLE will be drilled
here—the crust is thinner and the Moho
is closer to the surface.
Turning back to the grand hypothesis,
we find that beneath the crust and sep-
arated from the crust by the Moho —
named for Seismologist A. Mohorovicic
who discovered it in 1919—is the mantle,
a layer of silicates and nickel-iron about
1800 miles deep. The core, which is

posed mainly of nickel-iron.
This was not always man's conception
of the earth's interior, however. For many
years it was believed that the center of
the earth was liquid because volcanoes
spewed forth molten lava. Lord Kelvin
squelched this theory when a study of
tides led him to believe that the center
was solid instead of liquid and was
actually more rigid than steel. He added
that the center had probably once been
liquid, cooled to a solid and was still
cooling.
Now, however, some modern geophys-
ists believe that the earth is actually heat-
ing up instead of cooling down. Meas-
urements of heat flow to the surface and
of radioactivity may mean that more heat
is being generated by radioactive ma-
terials than is being lost at the surface.
This is type of question that the MO-
HOLE may answer.
Objectives
With this background let's review in
more detail the principle objectives of
the MOHOLE project and then examine
the methods and problems of drilling a
hole two miles deeper than any hole ever
drilled before. Briefly the objectives
could be stated as follows:
1) obtain samples of the mantle and
deep crust for chemical and phys-
ical analysis — including mineral
composition, radioactive content,
density, conductivity, etc.
2) Obtain exact depths, thickness, and
characteristics of the boundaries.
3) Discover the unexpected.

4) Take a continuous core sample of
the sediment.
Elaboration of this final objective would
be well worth while for in the words of
the Moholemen, "These sediments may be
the most fabulous history book of all
time; they could contain an uninterrupted
record of the earth's development for
two billion years." First of all, this his-
tory book can give the magnetic history
of the earth since tiny particles of mag-
netic minerals line up with the earth's
field as they settle. Second, the core will
show the climatic history of the earth by
measuring the core's calcium carbonate
content. Since the solubility of calcium
carbonate varies with temperature a direct
relationship with the earth's climate can
be obtained.

Third, and most important, will be the
paleontograph (fossil) study of the core.
Today such studies give man a fairly
complete record of life back to the start
of the Cambrian or Paleozoic era (about
515 million years ago). However, in rela-
tion to the estimated two billion year
life of the earth, the 515 million years
studied is relatively small. It is quite
possible that the deep-sea sediments con-
tain the rest of the record.
Also, it is always possible that the drill-
ers will strike a point at the bottom edge
of the sediment where atmosphere and
water caused the first erosion and then
the first sedimentation. Underneath this
first sediment may be a moonlike surface,
possibly filled with meteorite craters, that
was the face of the earth before the
atmosphere as present.
Where, How, When
Turning now from the theoretical back-
ground and the main objectives, the big
questions are where, how and when.
The "where" is definitely going to be
over an ocean basin because, as men-
tioned, the crust is thinner and the Moho
is closer to the surface that it is on the
continents. Even with the problems of
drilling from a barge it will be easier
than trying to drill through a 20 mile
granite crust on one of the continents.
The exact location should be one where
some seismic gravity and heat-flow stud-
ies had been made. It should also be
one that is relatively free of rough water,
hurricanes, freezing surface, etc. To the
experts this brings to mind at least two
locations—one about 200 miles North of

THERMOCOUPLE
The direct conversion of nuclear energy to
electrical energy is now possible with this new
device.
by RAY IKOLA, '62E
Early this spring a group at the Los
Alamos Scientific Laboratory, with
the assistance of a U-M professor, paved
the way for interplanetary space travel
and economical nuclear power plants
with the development of a device that,
for the first time, converts nuclear energy
directly to electricity.
This device, known as the plasma
thermocouple and developed with the aid
of Robert W. Pidd of the physics de-
partment, is based on the principle of the
fairly common temperature-measuring
thermocouples with one big exception—
the junction of two metals in the ordi-
nary thermocouple is replaced by a
junction of a metal and gas. However,
before looking into the operation of this
device it might be well to first review
the underlying principles of thermo-
couples.
Thermocouples Not New
Thermocouples have been in use now
for quite some time. Currently they are
used mainly for temperature measure-
ment and control. The thermocouples
used up to this time, however, have con-
sisted of two different metals joined
together at two ends. One junction is
heated while the other junction is kept
cool. This set of conditions causes an
electric current to flow in the circuit. The
strength of the current produced is de-
pendent on the properties of the metal
used and the difference in temperature
between the hot and cold junctions. Since
the strength of the current is dependent
on the temperature difference, the ther-
mocouple is readily adapted to purposes
of temperature measurement simply by
measuring the variations in the current
as the temperature at one of the junctions
changes. For a more complete discussion
of thermoelectricity, the reader is referred
to the February, 1959 issue of the Mich-
igan Tecbnic.
Gas Replaces One Metal
The plasma thermocouple operates on
the same principle as the conventional
bi-metallic devices. However, one of the
metals is replaced by cesium gas. What
is the advantage of the cesium gas re-
placement? The advantage stems from
the fact that every metal has a certain
characteristic thermal driving force which
is known as the "thermoelectric power."
The driving force of the cesium gas

versity, Ray is working toward a
B.S. degree in electrical engineer-

Being an EE major, it is natural

Likewise, he has been a staff an-

complete plasma thermocouple, approx-
imately twice actual size, as it was used
in the Los Alamos experiment to pro-
duce electric power directly from fission
heat.
(plasma) is about 1,000 times greater
than any other metal. This means that
the plasma thermocouple is able to be
operated much more efficiently than the
conventional thermocouples.
The actual construction of the plasma
thermocouple is simplicity itself. In out-
ward appearance it resembles an empty
frozen fruit juice can. Suspended in the
center of this can is a small rod about
one-fourth inch in diameter and three-
fourths inch long which contains uranium
carbide. Surrounding this source of pow-
er is the ionized cesium gas. Between
the outer shell and the plasma is another
shell which contains a circulating oil
coolant. See Fig. 1. To put the thermo-
couple into operation, it is placed in the
core of a nuclear reactor. The neutron
flux causes uranium fission in the center
of the can, thereby heating it to a high
temperature. The circulating coolant near
the outside of the can keeps the plasma
at a relatively low temperature. Thus, the
basic requirements of a thermocouple are
met and electricity is produced.
Surprising Results
The thermocouple was first tested on
April 4, 1959. At that time its perform-
ance completely surpassed all expectations
of the scientists. It had been expected
that enough power would be produced
by the test device to light an electric bulb
for a few minutes. However, the life of
the thermocouple was almost twelve
hours. The open circuit voltage was 3.S
volts and it had a short circuit current
between 30 and 40 amperes.
It is seen, then, that electrical energy
can be produced directly from nuclear
energy through the use of this plasma
thermocouple. But you may ask, wherein
does the advantage of this device lie?
Basically the advantage is one of size
and cost of a power source. The elimi-
nation of the boilers and turbine-gener-
ators that are found in today's nuclear
power plants obviously reduces the size
and at the same time reduces the cost
of the power plant.
To emphasize the importance of this
development Dr. Pidd stated shortly after
the first test that, "The plasma thermo-
couple will cut by perhaps one-half the

present cost of building power reactors;
pave the way for interplanetary space
travel because of the possible tremendous
reduction in fuel deadweight loads now
necessary to propel a rocket into space;
enable satellites to have a small but
comparatively powerful and long-lasting
source of electricity with which to tele-
meter data back to earth; and have great
significance in submarine propulsion."
However, Dr. Pidd also emphasized that
it would probably be from three to five
years before a commercial reactor utiliz-
ing this process could be constructed
because there is usually that much of a
lag between science and engineering.
Development of the plasrna thermo-
couple was a three year project at Los
Alamos led by the rocket propulsion re-
search division. The men primarily re-
sponsible for its success are group leader
George Grover, Duane Roehling, and
Earnest Salmi of the Laboratory staff,
and Dr. Pidd who served as a consultant
to the project.
Although the plasma thermocouple is
still in the development stage, it should
have great economic significance in the
future because of the huge power reserves
of uranium which are available. At any
rate it surely must be classed as a major
scientific feat—the first direct conversion
of nuclear energy to electrical energy.

AT MONROE . . .

i'-iURMI

Private enterprise will soon complete this new-
est addition to America's many peaceful appli-
cations of atomic energy.
by JAY SKLAR, '60E
18
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


explored areas of nuclear physics
gave the United States, by the end of
World War II, the most powerful weapon
ever devised. Since the horrendous ex-
plosions at Hiroshima and Nagasaki,
scientists have continued these studies
with renewed effort trying to develop
techniques whereby the tremendous heat
which brought destruction to Japan could
bring peaceful power to the whole
world. Work has progressed rapidly. To-
day there are several nuclear-powered
reactors in operation, and scores in the
planning stages. By 1961, Michigan will
have its first reactor for commercial pur-
poses. This, the Enrico Fermi Fast Breed-
er Reactor, will be producting steam for
the generation of electricity.
Non-Profit Groups
To complete construction and to carry
on operation of such a frontier venture,
the Power Reactor Development Com-
pany was formed. This group, a non-
profit membership corporation, is re-
sponsible for the reactor portion of the
Fermi Plant. With this responsibility, it
will own and operate the nuclear section.
The membership list includes fourteen
electric power companies and seven man-
ufacturing firms.
Sharing in the reactor portion of the
work is Atomic Power Development As-
sociates, Inc. This is another non-profit
group located in New York State. The
principal function of this organization is
to carry out research, to produce a reactor
design, and to develop and test the re-
actor proper. Plans set forth by them will
serve as basis for the construction work
carried out by Power Reactor Develop-
ment Company. Even after the reactor
is operational, ADPA will continue its
research in order that construction and
operating experience gained from the
Fermi Reactor could be applied to future
power reactor designs.
A third organization engaged in the
Enrico Fermi Reactor project is the De-
troit Edison Company. As an electric
power company, it will build, own, and
operate a conventional 150,000 kilowatt
steam turbine generator facility adjacent
to the PRDC-owned reactor plant. The
steam produced in the nuclear reactor
will be purchased by Detroit Edison and
utilized in the turbine generator. Then
the electricity produced will be distributed
to customers over the existing power
system.
Finally, the Atomic Energy Commis-
sion will have certain responsibilities.
From their work with other power re-
actors, they will bring experts for con-
sultation and assistance in training per-
sonnel. Other authorities in such work
will do some research and development
including the critical experiment and
necessary radiation tests. To assist the
project financially, the AEC will furnish,
free of charge, a five year supply of
fuel. Lastly, their reprocessing plants will
be available to render partly-consumed
fuel available for further use.
In order that the reader may under-
stand the relative magnitudes of the con-
tributions, the following cost table 's
included.

Located at Lagoona Beach on the west-
ern Lake Erie shore near Monroe, Mich-
igan, the Enrico Fermi Reactor is nearing
completion. Considering that it is fi-
nanced by private rather than givern-
ment funds, it is surprising that the
purpose of the project is not to produce
electricity on a competitive basis with
coal-produced power, but rather to gain
insight into the techniques and problems
of generating electricity from nuclear
fuel. In a recent stockholder's letter,
Detroit Edison states, 'We believe that
the experience gained in its design and
construction is of inestimable value to
your Company and to all those associated
with this great research and development
effort." It thus appears that private cap-
ital sees enough future in nuclear power
plants to carry on extensive research in
the hope that such plants will become
commonplace more rapidly.
Several Kinds
There are several kinds of nuclear
power reactors. Of these, the breeder
type is one of the more promising, and
it is on the breeder principle that the
Fermi Reactor will operate. Many ex-
perts consider the fast breeder reactor the
most hopeful type for economical nuclear
generation of electricity. This is because
it alone permits full utilization of the
potential heat energy in the nuclear fuel.
In addition, it increases the supply of
fissionable material by producing or
"breeding" a new atomic fuel—pluton-
ium. Lastly the fast breeder reactor uses
the abundant U*38 and thorium fuels.
The thermodynamic cycle is identical
to that of many other experimental and
commercial reactors. Heat produced by
the nuclear reactions occuring in the
reactor core is transferred by conduction
to a primary cooling loop of liquid
sodium. Since this loop passes through
the inside areas of the nuclar pile, the
sodium will be contaminated with radio-
active particles. To assure harmless oper-
ation of the plant, a secondary sodium

the transfer of heat to the secondary

the steam to high temperatures and pres-
sures. Since the generator is of the "once-
through type," steam leaving the gener-

sodium loop.
For the first two years, PRDC will
supply over a million pounds an hour
of steam at 600 psi and 755°F to Detroit
Edison. The latter company will return
water under pressure and at 400 °F.
After this initial period, the quantity,
pressure and temperature will be raised
as the heat output of the reactor is in-
creased.
The core, blanket, and control rods
are arranged in a cylinder eighty inches
in diameter and seventy inches long.
Called subassemblies, these 91 rods are
of various materials depending on their
function. The core rods are of U"8 and
U235. Outside the core is a radial blanket
formed by rods of U238. Last are son^e
steel subassemblies which make up a
thermal shield. Interspersed throughout
these various subassemblies are the con-
trol rods. Many of the rods are tubular
and are interconnected in order that the
sodium coolant may flow through them.
Since the coolant flows directly through
the region where atomic reactions are
occuring, high efficiency is achieved. This
efficiency is enhanced by the high tem-
perature, low pressure cooling system.

Control Rods
As mentioned above there are ten con-
trol rods in and around the reactor
core. They are composed of Boron 10
which has neutron-absorbing properties.
Therefore the operator, by positioning
the rods properly may control the reac-
tion rate. Only two of the control rods
are used for this purpose, however. The
remaining eight are for emergency oper-
ation in the event a runaway reaction
occurs. Should this happen, a scram"
shutdown is carried out. The eight safety
rods have been fitted into barrels and
locked, vertically poised for use. Should
such a shutdown be necessary, gravity
and coil springs accelerate the safety rods
into the core. Once the "scram" button
is pressed, the rods can be in position
within one second.
Core and blanket subassemblies, con-
trol rods and the thermal shield are all
contained in a two-inch thick stainless
steel inner reactor vessel. The thickness
is required for strength, but is also useful
in partially reducing radiation.
Neutron shielding is performed by the
two rows of steel thermal shield rods in-
side the inner reactor vessel and by
permanent concrete cylinders adjacent to
this.
Outside the inner reactor vessel is a
secondary containment vessel. Between
the two are structural members to sup-
port the reactor vessel, the neutron shield-
ing, a gamma ray shield, and neutron
flux counters. The latter are a good in-

W.E. DEFENSE PROJECTS ENGINEERS are often faced with challenging assign-
ments such as systems testing for the SAGE continental air defense network.
ENGINEERS explore exciting frontiers
at Western Electric
If guided missiles, electronic switching systems and
telephones of the future sound like exciting fields
to you, a career at Western Electric may be just
what you're after.
Western Electric handles both telephone work
and defense assignments ... and engineers are
right in the thick of it. Defense projects include the
Nike and Terrier guided missile systems ...
advanced air, sea and land radar ... the SAGE
continental air defense system ... DEW Line and
White Alice in the Arctic. These and other defense
jobs offer wide-ranging opportunities for all kinds
of engineers.
In our main job as manufacturing and supply
unit of the Bell System, Western Electric engineers
discover an even wider range of opportunity. Here
they flourish in such new and growing fields as
electronic switching, microwave radio relay, min-
iaturization. They engineer the installation of tele-
phone central offices, plan the distribution of equip-
ment and supplies . .. and enjoy, with their defense
teammates, the rewards that spring from an engi-
neering career with Western Electric.
Western Electric technical fields include me-
chanical, electrical, chemical, civil and industrial
engineering, plus the physical sciences. For more
detailed information pick up a copy of "Consider a
Career at Western Electric" from your Placement
Officer. Or write College Relations, Room 200D,
Western Electric Company, 195 Broadway, New
York 7, N. Y. And sign up for a Western Electric
interview when the Bell System Interviewing Team
visits your campus.

TELEPHONES OF THE FUTURE-Moking telephone products for the
Bell System calls for first-rate technical know-how. Tomorrow's
telephone system will demand even more imaginative engineering.

and the
POWER STATE
In this prize-winning essay the implications of
the power state are examined in light of an-
cient truths.
by MICHAEL J. PICHEL, '60E
Men of the earliest civilizations had
some premonition of the implica-
tions and consequences of human intel-
lect. According to the Book of Genesis,
man was forbidden to eat the fruit of
the tree of knowledge. Man ate from the
tree, gained his intellect, and was pun-
ished. A Greek myth tells of Prometheus
(Forethought), who stole fire from the
heavens, gave it to man, and was pun-
ished. In Prometheus Bound, the only
extant play of Aeschlus' Prometheus Tril-
ogy, Prometheus describes himself:
I am the huntsman of the
mystery,
The great resource that taught
technology.
The secret font of fire put in
the reed,
And given man to minister his
need.1
Aeschylus somehow had seen the hand-
writing on the wall; for Prometheus, the
"huntsman," a searching intellect, and
source of technology is crucified by the
power of Zeus. Perhaps at this point we
should look more closely at the Prome-
theus Bound.
Prometheus Bound
The reader, or viewer, of the Prome-
theus Bound finds himself gripped by a
sense of history taking place on the edge
of the world. Prometheus is shackled
to a cliff in a desolate gorge by the ab-
stract figures: Might and Force. Prome-
theus' situation quite literally prohibits
him from action, and as though his bond-
age were symbolic of the fact that his
strength had never been a physical one,
our attention is focused on his intellect.
Prometheus suffers because his "love of
mankind was too strong,"2 and, although
he is a god who can defy gods, the
spectator identifies with him.
The shackling of Prometheus, symbol
of intellect and technology, can be viewed
as the "crucifixion of intellectual man,"
and Prometheus becomes a symbol of in-
tellectual man's suffering. The Controller
(Power) and Executive (Force) were
sent by Zeus (symbol of the dictator, the
tyrant, the power state in any of its many
forms) to carry out this crucifixion. Zeus
is punishing Prometheus for stealing fire
from the heavens, and giving it to man-
kind; however, according to the myth,
Zeus is bound for a marriage, a son of
which will overthrow him.3 Therefore,
he needs the Foresight of Prometheus
to tell him which marriage to avoid.
Zeus' method for obtaining the knowl-
edge he needs is to employ more and
more force. Prometheus, "the great re-
source," closes the channels of informa-
tion. The conflict between Zeus and
Prometheus is, therefore, an allegory of
the self-defeating character of power
system which are based on power alone.
The power state has no long-term fu-
ture in a scientific world. Only when it
listens to Prometheus, frees and honors
him can it become stabilized. In doing
so it changes its perspective from tyran-
ny and dictatorship towards a state ruled
upon the consent of the governed.4
Soviet Power State
If we look at the Soviet power state
today we might see the beginnings of
such a stabilization and change of per-
spective. One could see in Stalin the
image of Zeus, isolated and trusting no
one except his Power and Force; yet to-
day we see the tremendous scientific
achievements of the Russians, seemingly
Promethean gifts. Concededly these tech-
nological advances are, to a very great
extent, material symbols of Power and
Force; yet they are based on scientific
knowledge, "the great resource that
taught technology." Simple strength was
subjugated to the procedures of science.
In the extant fragments of Prometheus
Unbound, the second play of the Prome-
theus Trilogy, Zeus and Prometheus, af-
ter 30,000 years of suffering, are recon-
ciled. A compromise between force and
reason is effected; Prometheus learning
the need for some degree of authority
and order, and Zeus learning mercy and
justice.
The subjugation of strength to the pro-
cedures of science (reason) in the U.S.S.R.
may be the embryo of such a reconcil-
iation and compromise. For, in this pow-
er state there is now a group of intel-
IX
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


of freedom in their scientific endeavors.
These are "huntsmen of the mystery."
Their Promethean science requires pre-
vision and long-term calculation. Their
power state has, in at least one respect,
learned a Promethean lesson; for in order
to obtain the knowledge it needs it has
given this group a position of honor,
rather than send Force and Power to
extract the knowledge.
This position of honor, although it
may owe its existence to expediency, has
become real. These scientific individuals
are respected not only by their fellow
men but also by their power state. The
power state cannot avoid this respect be-
cause it realizes that its security, its very
continuance of power depends on the
Promethean intelligence of the scientist.
Here is the beginning of a stabilization
and change of perspective. The power
state has mellowed somewhat, and learned
a Promethean lesson.
Doctor Zhivago
We know that this mellowing and re-
spect is quite restricted. The power state
has given honor only where it could see
an immediate gain for itself. Boris Paster-
nak was, in fact, dishonored by the state
■when, in Doctor Zhivago, he attempted
to teach a Promethean lesson by express-
ing fears and disillusionment concerning
the revolution and the Soviet totalitarian
state which evolved after the revolution."'
However, we know that the scientists, the
intellectuals, will not (for they cannot)
restrict their prevision or long-term cal-
culations to their technological develop-
ment. Their calculations must consider
all dimensions, both scientific and non-
scientific, if they are really to be long-
term.
The short-term calculation concentrates
on one's private interest, the immediate
moment. As the range of one's thoughts
extend the mind asks itself, "What will
this momentary utility mean to my fur-
ther utility, tomorrow and the day after
tomorrow?" This process extends until
the mind imagines the many other rela-
tionships in which "I" will be involved,
and predicts the many actions of others
on which "my" needs will in turn de-
pend. The perspective extends, if pushed
far enough in time length, to the point
where it takes in the city, state, family
of states, and the estate of the unborn.
The conclusion would seem to be that
if man cares to prethink far enough, his
forethought becomes increasingly moral
and philanthropic in its direction.'5
This conclusion is borne out by such
men as Descartes, Alfred North White-
head, Bertrand Russell, Einstein, Pauling,
and all "huntsmen of the mystery" whose
Promethean science required prevision
and long-term calculation. Like Prome-
theus, the scientist has given us fire, "the
technological flame." He has transformed
the heat of the "flame" into power, first
power from steam, power from chemical
reaction, and then the scientist (chemist,
physicist, engineer, and mathematician)
was able to release the heat (energy)
contained in the nucleus of the atom.
This was heat far too great for use. The
"Firegivers" saw that man had never
been able to control the gift with steady
hands, always letting it burn and destroy
him. Fire in the forge was used to make
spears and swords; chemical combustion
was first widely used as gunpowder; the
internal combustion engine carried arm-
ored tanks, airplanes, and warships; and
finally all of the temperatures, all of the
destructive devices that had gone before
were exceeded in the climactic flash and
unimaginable release of energy over Hiro-
shima.
"We shook the tree of knowledge, and
out fell the bomb.7
The source of technology could not
take back his gift, nor did he wish to;
for he was still the "huntsman." Like
Prometheus he realized the implications
of the "flame." "Long since I looked the
issue full in the face,"8 and so he tried
to give mankind direction, other than
technological, in order that his "flame"
could be safely used.
The Promethean scientist thus becomes
a philosopher, a moralist, an altruistic
individual, because his prevision and long-
term calculation tell him of an impend-
ing danger, a danger which is often non-
existent in the short-term view.
We can see this evolution in Linus
Pauling, who has probed deeply into "the
secret fount," and has given us a more
complete, basic, logical concept of the
"nature of the chemical bond." Pauling
received a Nobel Prize for this work.
Like Prometheus, he has seen an im-
pending danger, and is attempting to
warn and direct mankind concerning the
long-term effects of radioactivity, caused
by testing and continued use of atomic
explosions.
Pauling and others like him have met,
and are still meeting, obstacles. The state
(political obstacles) and even his fellow
scientists (social obstacles) would prefer
that he restrict his efforts to the task of
predicting the behavior of physical mat-
ter; just as the Chorus tells Prometheus:
"Your wits do wander in your sore
despite."9
Crucifixion
We see that Prometheus' crucifixion,
"the crucifixion of intellectual man," is
not only inflicted by Zeus (the state) but
also by the Chorus (his fellow men).
The crucifixion becomes symbolic of so-
ciety's resistance to its own intellectuals.
Thus the Promethean myth warns, not
only of the conflict between Intellect and
the political power state, but also of the
conflict between Intellect and what may
be called "the social power state."
This "social power state" refers to:
the discipline of society by means of its
customs and mores, the relations between
(Continued on page 48)
Michael J. Pichel, a senior in the chemical engineering de-
partment, was the winner of the 1958-59 Cooley Essay contest.
"Mike," who is a graduate of Walnut Hills High School in
Cincinnati, has had several interesting summer jobs but the
most challenging was working on the creation and development
of a silk-screening ink base. As a senior this year, Mike is serious-
ly considering doing graduate work in his field before going to
work in industry.
On campus Mike has concentrated on one main activity—
the Folklore Society—which he feels is one of the most enjoy-
able and relaxing groups he has participated in.

OCTOBER, 1959


ACTIVITIES
For freshmen and upperclassmen alike the
Technic surveys the many engineering activi-
ties.
by MAX LEGATSKI, '6IE
In every division of Michigan's Engi-
neering College there are individuals
seeking "that little bit extra" from their
stay at the University. For those students
having the ambition and the desire to
broaden themselves both technically and
socially, extra-curricular activities are in-
valuable.
For the benefit of upperclassmen as
well as the incoming freshmen, the
Technic presents a sketch of the engi-
neering activities offered at Michigan.
Students interested in one or more of the
following activities should contact a fac-
ulty advisor, a club officer, or a member
of the department affiliated with the ac-
tivity of their interest.
The Engineering Council
The Engineering Council is the co-
ordinating body of the College of Engi-
neering. Its membership consists of mem-
bers at large who are appointed by a
committee of the Council, representatives
of all the technical societies, the editors
of the Michigan Technic and the Arch,
the president of the Engineering Honor
Council, the president of the four Engi-
neering Classes, the president of Tau
Beta Pi, and representatives of honorary
organizations.
Last year the Council sponsored a fac-
ulty evaluation, a dance (Playboy's
Prance), a plaque for the late Dean
George Granger Brown, and Engineers
week-end which was held primarily for
the benefit of residents of the local area
and prospective students. It has also
created a committee to study and make
recommendations to the various societies
on how they can more effectively serve
their purposes and increase membership.
Through these efforts the Council in-
tends to stimulate among other things a
better knowledge of industry and of engi-
neering as a profession.
Officers for this year are Armin Jocz,
President; Rog Barnes, Vice-President;
Charles Hoops, Treasurer; and A. Jenels-
hoff, Secretary.
The Honor Council
The Engineering Honor Council, ad-
ministrators of the Honor Code, has two
main responsibilities — educational and
judicial.
Concerning the educational responsi-
bilities, it is the duty of the Honor Coun-
cil to see that the engineer is made aware
of the many benefits of the Honor Code
and that he understands the mechanics
of its operation. Along this line the
Honor Council carried out an extensive
"educational" program last year, includ-
ing the erection of a bulletin board in
the new Student-Faculty Lounge which
illustrated in detail the benefits of the
Code.
Judicial duties require that the Council
hear cases of reported violations of the
Honor Code, decide on the merits of the
case, and levy a penalty if the student
is guilty. Decisions of the Honor Council
are reviewed by a faculty board, though
no decision has ever been reversed.
The Honor Council is made up of eight
voting members, an alternate member,
and a non-voting ex-officio representative
from Vulcans. Four regular members and
an alternate are chosen each semester.
Technic
The Technic is the oldest engineering
college magazine in America, being en-
tered as second-class matter in 1882.
Though "old and wise," the Technic is
always in need of fresh ideas and new
blood. There is plenty of room for new-
comers.
Many students think that they have to
be a Sinclair Lewis or a Shakespeare to
be on the staff. Actually, although good
writers are always needed, there are many
jobs on the staff which require completely
different types of talent. To mention a
few, there are advertising, circulation,
and illustration. No matter what you're
good at, there's room for you at the
Technic.
Added attractions are the annual steak
dinner held each spring, the annual of-
fice party, and the picnic which is planned
for the near future.
Present editor-in-chief of the Technic
is Chuck Hildebrandt. Senior editors are
Barry Peebles, Mary Ellen DuVall, and
Ron Tesarik. Interested students should
contact Personnel and Public Relations
Director Grace Koepcke or drop by the
office at 3077 East Engineering Building.
Executive Boards
The Executive Boards are the elected
governing and administrative bodies ot'
the freshman, sophomore, and junior
classes in the College of Engineering.
Primarily the Boards organize and spon-
sor activities and projects that will bene-
fit their class. In addition the Boards act
as a liaison body between the students
and the administration.
The Junior Board is busy working out
plans for this year. Included in last year's
activities were an exhibit for Engineer's
Week-end, a sweatshirt sale, and a Cine-
ma Guild movie sponsorship. Ground-
work for this year's plans is still being
laid.
The Arch
The Arch, now starting its fourth year
of publication, is printed with the fol-
lowing objectives in mind: first, to keep
students abreast of College of Engineer-
ing current events, and second, to create
better school spirit.
Copies are distributed free of charge

TO ASK THE ALCOA RECRUITER
WHEN HE VISITS MICHIGAN
Here's What You May Want to Ask About Opportunities at Alcoa
1. Where can I go in Alcoa with my type of degree?
2. In what part of the country would I be located?
3. What kinds of training programs will I participate
in at Alcoa?
-4. What are my starting salary prospects?
5. Will Alcoa pay my moving expenses?
6. What are my chances for advancement with Alcoa?
And Here's What We Answer:
1. There are openings at Alcoa each year for graduates
with many types of degrees. Graduates in mechanical,
metallurgical, electrical, industrial, chemical and civil
engineering have a wide choice of opportunities in engi-
neering, production, research, development or sales
engineering. There also are openings for chemists for
research and for business administration and liberal
arts graduates in accounting and sales.
2. Geographical location will depend on your field. New
engineering, production and accounting employees are
assigned to one of 30 Alcoa operating locations through-
out the nation. New sales engineering and sales ad-
ministration employees, after completing a six-month
training program, go to one of Alcoa's 72 sales offices.
If your field is sales development or process develop-
ment, you will be located in New Kensington, Pa., or
Cleveland, Ohio. Main research laboratories are located
in New Kensington, with branches in Cleveland, East
St. Louis, 111., Massena, N. Y., and Chicago.
3. Alcoa has a training program for each new employee.
Engineering and production training involves orienta-
tion and rotation of assignments for approximately one
year. Sales training is conducted in sales offices and in
nine plant locations over a six-month period. Account-
ing training calls for rotation of assignments for 18 to
24 months.
•4. Alcoa's starting salaries are competitive with those
of other companies. An initial salary is established for
a basic four-year degree. Additional credit is given for
outstanding personal qualifications, advanced educa-
tional training, military service and previous work ex-
perience. Future salary progress is based on your own
performance and growth potential.
5. Alcoa pays transportation and moving expenses for
you and your family. This applies to your first and all
subsequent assignments.
6. Alcoa personnel policies assure individual recogni-
tion for you. They include regular performance apprais-
als, individual opportunity for advanced management
training, confidential and individual salary considera-
tion and promotion entirely from within the company.
If you'd like to find out more about employment oppor-
tunities with Alcoa, contact your placement officer to
arrange a campus interview. Mutual interest will result
in further interviews at an Alcoa location. For more
details immediately, write Manager, College Recruit-
ment, 810 Alcoa Building, Pittsburgh 19, Pa., for the
new booklet, A Career for You With Alcoa.

Indirect Areas
Turning now from consumer applica-
tions to more indirect but equally im-
portant areas we look fiist at medicine,
which may hold the key to the future.
Indeed it is as impossible to predict what
will happen in medicine in the next dec-
ade as it was to predict the discovery of
tranquilizers in 1954 or that we would
have a polio vaccine as early as 1955.
Still we know that much time and
money is being spent in such fields as
artificial substitutes for body organs,
bones and membranes. Without a doubt
these will become more and more com-
monplace as time goes on. However, the
big hope rests on possible advances in
the treating and possible cure for heart
disease, cancer, and mental illness. Cures
or even major breakthroughs are at the
best only "long shots" but the hopes of
millions of people ride on these long
shots.
By and far the most striking and head-
line catching advances will come in the
field of space technology. As the Sput-
nik I symbolized the Fifties, a man in
space will probably symbolize the Six-
ties. Today we've just crossed the thres-
hold with an almost unlimited number of
possibilities ahead of us. At the present
it's only a matter of time before the flight
of the X-15, probes to the moon and
Mars, and operational ICBM's. All of
these things should be things of the
past by late 1961. The million-pound-
thrust rocket engine should also be a
reality by that time.
Looking further ahead the mid-Sixties
should see one of the Mercury Astronauts
go up in a satellite and return. Flyable
space ships and possible moon landings
should come in the late sixties. In addi-
tion, these advances in space technology
will make possible such things as world
wide communications systems using satel-
lite relay stations and accurate long-term
weather forecasts using TV pictures of
(Continued from page 13)
the cloud cover as seen from a satellite.
While continuing to spend enormous
amounts to help man survive in space
researchers will not neglect the survival
of the majority of us still here on earth.
For example, one research field that
seems unimportant now but may be a
lifesaver in the years to come is the
economical conversion of salt water to
a usable fluid. A recent announcement
of an 800 mile pipe line from Northern
California to the Los Angeles area drives
home the importance of this research.
Next Month
Institute of Science and Technol-
ogy—An examination of 1ST,
the rapidly growing research
arm of the University that will
serve the community, state and
nation.
Kiwi A—The world's first nuclear
rocket engine, the Kiwi A, is
a prototype of the rocket en-
gine that will lift 100,000
pounds payloads into space.
Gyroscopes—They form the basis
for the complex gryrocompass-
es that guide the atomic subs
under the polar ice and moon
rockets into outer space.
Fall of Parity — Physicists were
shocked when the parity prin-
ciple, one of their foundation
stones for years, was disproved.
Already Congress has authorized the De-
partment of Interior to spend ten million
dollars on five experimental conversion
plants—probably using a plastic mem-
brane that will let water pass through but
not the salt.
Nuclear Energy
Less likely to produce results in the
Sixties are the attempts to build com-
mercially competitive nuclear power
plants—a step that will eliminate wor-
ries of running out of conventional fuels.
Now or in the near future a half-dozen
or so nuclear plants such as those at
Shippingport, West Virginia and Monroe,
Michigan (see page 50 for an article on
this reactor) will be in operation. These
plants probably will never be commer-
cially competitive, however. Those to fol-
low these prototypes may possibly attain
this goal in the late Sixties.
The big dream in this area is the har-
nessing of fusion or thermonuclear en-
ergy for practical use. Much work is be-
ing done in this area but the enormous
problems to be met make it a "very long
shot." Along this line Dr. Edward Tel-
ler, father of the H-bomb, has suggested
the use of an underground nuclear explo-
sion to trap the heat and convert it to
usable power. Going further he points
out the possible use of these bombs in
blasting new harbors or shaking oil loose
from shale. However, a great deal of
work in "cleaning up" these bombs re-
mains before such common uses of nu-
clear power will be practicable.
Two types of materials that are quite
common in our daily lives—metals and
plastics—are wide open for big advances
although none can be predicted. The rea-
son the big opportunity exists is that de-
velopment in many field is being held
back due to the lack of suitable materials,
particularly metals. Each year the alloys
get a little stronger or a little more heat
resistant, etc. but no big advances have
been made in recent years. In the words
of Fortune magazine, "The problem in
metallurgy is easy to state: there has as
yet been no major breakthrough in metals
comparable to the transistor in electron-
ics, mylar in high polymers, or nuclear
fission in energy creation."
The work in plastics has been going
along more rapidly than in metals and
the early Sixties should find the tough
linear polyethylenes and polypropylenes
reaching large volume production and
start replacing metals in many jobs.
Basic Particles
Advancement in metals may be speed-
ed considerably by a better understanding
of basic particles and atomic structure.

Purity Plus — Hughes Products Division engineer checks
semiconductor materials to insure purity.

Exit cones capable of withstanding temperatures of 6000° F.
represent one example of advanced engineering being performed
by the Hughes Plastics Laboratory.
an atomic clock in orbit
To test Einstein's general theory of relativity, scien-
tists at the Hughes research laboratories are devel-
oping a thirty pound atomic maser clock (see photo
at lejt) under contract to the National Aeronautics
and Space Administration. Orbiting in a satellite,
a maser clock would be compared with another
on the ground to check Einstein's proposition that
time flows faster as gravitational pull decreases.
Working from the new research center in Malibu,
California, Hughes engineers will develop a MASER
(Microwave Amplification through Stimulated
Emission of Radiation) clock so accurate that it
will neither gain nor lose a single second in 1000
years. This clock, one of three types contracted
for by NASA, will measure time directly from the
vibrations of the atoms in ammonia molecules.
Before launching, an atomic clock will be syn-
chronized with another on the ground. Each
clock would generate a highly stable current with
a frequency of billions of cycles per second. Elec-
tronic circuitry would reduce the rapid oscillations
to a slower rate in order to make precise laboratory
measurements. The time "ticks" from the orbiting
clock would then be transmitted by radio to com-
pare with the time of the clock on earth. By meas-
uring the difference, scientists will be able to check
Einstein's theories.
In other engineering activities at Hughes, research
and development work is being performed on such
projects as advanced airborne systems, advanced
data handling and display systems, global and spa-
tial communications systems, nuclear electronics,
advanced radar systems, infrared devices, ballistic
missile systems...just to name a few.
The rapid growth of Hughes reflects the continuous
advance in Hughes capabilities—providing an ideal
environment for the engineer or physicist, whatever
his field of interest.

Courtesy of Scientific American
This diagram shows a cross-section of the drilling apparatus used to investigate
the Mohole. Operations are carried out aboard the Cuss I, ocean oil-drilling
barge.
San Juan, Puerto Rico where the water
is 14,000 feet deep and Moho is down
another 18,000 feet. Another point is
near the Equator due south of San Diego.
The "how" will most likely be ac-
complished with slightly modified off-
shore oil exploration equipment. In par-
ticular the Moholemen have their eye on
a 3000 ton barge with a 98 foot derrick
called the Cuss I, which is named for
the Continental, Union, Shell, and Su-
perior oil companies that built and used
it in early off-shore exlorations.
The exact procedure should be essen-
tially the following: The barge is anch-
ored from six points at the specified
location. Already suspended below the
barge (but above the ocean floor) is a
prefabricated landing base.
The next step is to lower the drill
pipe through the landing base (still sus-
pended) and then drill a hole several
hundred feet deep using sea water as a
drilling fluid.
Then using the drill pipe as a guide,
the landing base is lowered and cemented
in place on the ocean floor at the top
of the hole. Next a drill casing (or riser-
piper as it is known) which rises a
short distance above the sea bottom is
guided down by special guide cables and
floatation tanks and connected to the
landing base.
Finally a flexible pipe from the riser
to the barge permits the drilling mud
to be circulated and drilling to proceed
in a fairly conventional manner.
This explanation makes the operation
sound relatively simple. Actually this is
not the case and numerous problems and
difficulties are expected. For example all
pipes and cables must be tapered so
their weight does not exceed their tensile
strength at the water's surface.
Other problems include finding highly
corrosion-resistant equipment, developing
good coring techniques for use at deep
depths, constructing instruments that are
small enough to be lowered down the
drill pipes, and of major importance—-
how to get all the pipes and lines down
without a hopeless snarl.
As far as the "when" is concerned,
nobody is really sure. Initially, and in
the near future, a hole will be drilled in
about 10,000 feet of water to get the
bugs out of the operation. Next a hole
in 16,000 feet will be tried in order to
get experience in deeper water and make
fairly good sedimentary studies. Finally,
sometime in the mid-Sixties, the AMSOC
dream should become a reality — a
MOHOLE will be drilled.
And there is little doubt that the hole
will become a reality for in the words
of the Moholemen," the
MOHOLE project appears to be scien-
tifically sound, technically feasible, and
economically reasonable.

Provide Engineers
Greater Opportunity for
Space-Age Advancement
Young engineers, particularly, will be interested in the new
opportunities created by Chance Vought's recent realignment
into five divisions.
Today, for every Vought engineer, there is a division to
make fullest use of his talents and to speed his personal
advancement. And, of course, he is backed by the four other
divisions whose balanced activities add security to his
company and his future.
Vought's realignment was the result of considerable study
of both company capabilities and new business opportuni-
ties. The move intensifies a diversification program which
began early in 1959. It specifically gears this progressive,
42-year-old aircraft firm for the challenges and opportunities
of the age of space.

I ELECTRONICS
i
B
RANGE
SYSTEMS

ASTRONAUTICS DIVISION
Vought is taking fullest advantage of its existing capabilities
and is drawing on 12 years' experience in the missile field to
obtain broader responsibilities in the race for space. Concen-
tration will be on advanced vehicles for space exploration,
and on ballistic and anti-ballistic missile systems.
Under a current contract, Vought is readying the four-stage
Scout research rocket and its launcher for the National
Aeronautics and Space Administration. Also, Vought and
other members of the Boeing team are participating in the
development of the Dyna-Soar boost-glide vehicle in compe-
tition for an Air Force contract. In the human factors of
flight, Vought is taking the lead with its orbital flight
simulator and space-oriented Cockpit Laboratory.
AERONAUTICS DIVISION
Weapons of many types will take shape here. For example:
new generations of manned aircraft and atmospheric mis-
siles, and devices for antisubmarine warfare. Systems to
support these weapons, and subcontracting assignments are
other Aeronautics activities.
Among this division's current contracts: a Navy order for
development of an environmental protection and escape
capsule for aircraft pilots. Other work includes production
contracts for three versions of F8U Crusader aircraft, study
contracts in submarine detection and classification, and
subcontracts for military and commercial aircraft assemblies.
ELECTRONICS DIVISION
Vought electronics will be developed, manufactured and
marketed in increasing volume. Military systems under devel-
opment include antennas and related electronics, ground
support electronics and antisubmarine warfare apparatus.
RESEARCH DIVISION
In a new Research Center, scientists of this division will mine
new knowledge from many fields. Basic research is planned
into astronautics, undersea warfare, the life sciences (relat-
ing to human factors of flight), electrogravities and other
areas. As it evolves into applied research, this advanced
work will materially support other Vought divisions.
RANGE SYSTEMS DIVISION
Twelve years* experience in remote base operation qualifies
Vought for additional business in this new field. The Range
Systems team will establish and operate test ranges and test
equipment for missiles and space vehicles.
Genesys Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary company,
intensifies Vought's diversification into commercial elec-
tronics. Company emphasis is on automation, and its key
personnel are engineers experienced in the fields of
electronics, computers, magnetic memory, and associated
electro-mechanical devices.
You live at a discount in Dallas
In Texas there is no state income tax and no local or state
sales taxes. Low school and property levies add to your
savings. Home construction costs — as well as house and
apartment rentals — are below the national average. Fuel
costs are negligible, and most groceries cost less.
Dallas has grown faster since 1950 than any other U. S. city.
One reason is the city's wealth of entertainment and cultural
centers. Another reason is the attractive cost of living.

tion about new Vought activities, and how you can start
your career with one of Vought's five divisions. Please
address inquiries to:

Chameleon Satellites
Space satellites may soon lay claim to
the chameleon"s valuable ability of chang-
ing its color for protection.
The idea involves the application of a
heat sensitive coating for satellite skins
to control internal temperature while the
vehicle is whirling through space.
Devised by Rudolf X. Meyer, a scien-
tist at Space Technology Laboratories,
the coating will change color thereby
controlling the heat absorption and radi-
ation qualities of the satellite. The idea
is based on the well-known phenomenon
that light colors reflect heat while dark
ones absorb it.
Meyer stated that by applying his new
coating the temperature inside the ve-
hicle's shell would automatically be kept
uniform. As the temperature of the satel-
lite increases, its skin would become light
in color, thereby allowing more heat to
be reflected into space. Should the pay-
load's internal temperature take a down-
ward turn, the skin would become dark
in color, thereby absorbing more radia-
tion.
The nuclear simulator pictured at the
right is used to duplicate and solve
problems that might arise aboard the
N. S. Savannah when it goes to sea. The
operators console in the background
duplicates every detail of the control
pannel that will be on board the Savan-
nah.
According to Meyer, the coating can
either take the form of a paint-like sub-
stance or a plastic applied in several
layers. He stated that he found about 35
substances while carrying out preliminary
research which have this "chameleon"
ability at the required temperature level.
For instance, one particular coating
changes with increasing temperature from
red to yellow. In the case of polymer
compounds, use is made of the reversible
transition from the sol state to the gel
state as the temperature increases.
While the first application of the in-
vention will go to aid the U. S. effort
in conquering space, little imagination is
needed to think of the many uses such
a substance could be put to here on earth.
Temperature control in homes, autos,
airplanes and a host of other such appli-
cations come readily to mind. It is not
too fantastic to think of treating cloth
with such a substance for far more coni-

and glass walls which would in effect
have blinds built right into them are just
a few of literally thousands of uses for
such a substance.

A radically new design in large capacity
elevated water storage tanks for munici-
pal and industrial use has been devel-
oped by a division of Union Tank Car
Company.
Known as the Aquatore and resem-
bling a huge "doughnut in the sky"
the new tank eliminates the unsightly
struts and tie-rods required on conven-
tional tanks.
Major advantages of the Aquatore, the
largest water tower design to use only
a single supporting column, are 1) clean
distinctive appearance; 2) lower mainte-
nance costs; 3) a more constant water
pressure; and 4) no pump house needed.
Although there is no limit to the ca-
pacity in which the Aquatore can be
constructed, 3 million gallons is ordinar-
ily considered the largest practical ca-
pacity for most applications. Graver Tank
expects most of its sales to be in the
1 million to 3 million gallon capacity
range.
Dimensions for a typical Aquatore with
a capacity of 1,500,000 gallon capacity
would include a torus tank 94 feet in
diameter and 34 feet in height (head
range); and a column diameter of 46
feet at the ground narrowing to 23 feet
at the tank. The height of the central
supporting column is dependent on the
water pressure required, local terrain and
other factors although a normal column
height is 100 feet.

Nuclear Simulator
A training simulator that responds ex-
actly as does an atomic propulsion plant
will play an essential part in practice
drills for officers of the world's first nu-
clear-powered merchant ship, N.S. Savan-
nah. Designed and constructed by the
Westinghouse Electric Corporation under
contract to the Maritime Administration,
the simulator contains an analog com-
puter as a central element.
The system is installed in a classroom
building at Lynchburg College in Lynch-
burg, Va., where a training program is
being conducted for the Maritime Ad-
OCTOBER, 1959
37


ministration by the Babcock &amp; Wilcox
Company. Babcock &amp; Wilcox is design-
ing, building, and supplying the nuclear
propulsion system for the Savannah.
Among the trainees will be five senior
deck officers, one of whom will be
selected by the Maritime Administration
to captain the Savannah.
Arnold Viener, engineering manager
for nuclear instrumentation of the West-
inghouse power control and communica-
tions department has explained that train-
ees will operate the control console of
the simulator precisely as though they
were aboard ship, taking orders from the
"bridge" represented by the instructor's
desk.
The student operators wil start up the
nuclear power plant, stand watches, simu-
late emergency drills, and perform all
of the functions necessary to the oper-
ations of the ship's atomic engine. A
total of 54 switches will enable the in-
structor to cause "malfunctions" or mock
situations for the trainees to deal with
at the controls of the console. At the
instructor's desk are controls for a chart
recorder which transcribes data to be used
in evaluating the performance of the stu-
dent operators. When plotted on the strip
chart, variations in pressures, tempera-
tures, and other variables reveal the speed
and accuracy of the student's responses.
Pushbutton Phone
A pushbutton telephone device that
may eventually replace the rotary dial as
the link between the user and the tele-
phone switching machine is being devel-
oped at Bell Telephone Laboratories.
Pushbutton calling has been made feas-
ible by modern electronic devices, such
as the transistor, applied in an extensive
development program. Engineers have
designed complex equipment to adapt
An experimental model of a pushbutton
telephone being developed ai Bell Tel-
ephone Laboratories, shown here, makes
use of new electronic devices which in-
clude the transistor. This particular de-
sign combines many features that pro-
mote the greatest accuracy and are
most preferred by users.
central office switching to pushbutton sig-
nals. At the same time, the appearance
and operation of the pushbutton tele-
phone have, in so far as possible, been
tailored to suit people's preferences and
capabilities, as revealed in laboratory
tests.
To place a call on a pushbutton phone,
the user simply presses buttons instead
of turning a fingerwheel. As each button
is pressed, two simultaneous musical tones
are generated and transmitted to the cen-
tral office. The tones, which can be heard
on the receiver, are similar to those now
heard in some localities when long-dis-
tance calls are made.
This is, in effect, a new language,
different from the language the dial uses
in directing calls through the switching
system to their destinations.
The present switching system—which,
nationwide, comprises the world's largest
computer—docs not yet understand this
new language. But because of the greater
speed and convenience of the pushbutton
system, effort has been directed toward
making the system bi-lingual. An array
of mechanical-electronic equipment, ap-
propriately called a "translator," has been
developed for the purpose of adapting
existing central offices.
Simultaneously, research has been un-
dertaken to discover which kind of push-
button set people would like most and
could use most rapidly and accurately.
This is known as designing for the hu-
man factor—suiting the machine to the
human.
Hundreds of persons—including deli-
cately manicured women, stubby-fingered
he-man types, and nearsighted persons—
have helped engineers at the Laboratories
find out which button arrangements, size
and "feel" might be best.
The selected arrangement of ten but-
tons — one for each digit — consists of
three horizontal rows of three each, plus
the zero or "operator" button at the
bottom.

How to get steel tubes to harness highest
steam pressures and temperatures
IN constructing Philadelphia Electric Company's revolu-
tionary new Eddystone power plant, engineers had to
harness the highest combination of pressure and steam
ever achieved in a central station with 5,000 psi at 1,200° F.
This called for superheater tubes (see diagram above) of a
special stronger steel never before used in steam power
plants. No one had ever succeeded in piercing this tougher
steel to make seamless steel tubing.
The problem was given to Timken Company metal-
lurgists, experts at piercing steels for 40 years. And they
turned the trick. They made the steel for the platen and
finishing super-heaters with the alloying elements in just
the right balance for perfect piercing quality. They pierced
20 miles of tubes free from both surface ana internal flaws.
Timken Company metallurgists and Timken steels have
solved all kinds of tough steel problems. They can help
you on problems you may face in industry.
And if you're interested in a career with the leader in
specialty steels . . . with the world's largest maker of
tapered roller bearings and removable rock bits . . . send
for free booklet, "Better-ness and Your Career at the
Timken Company". Write Manager of College Relations,
The Timken Roller Bearing Company, Canton 6, Ohio.
