SPACE TECHNOLOGY Fellowships have been estab-
lished in recognition of the great scarcity of scientists
and engineers who have the very special qualifications
required for work in Systems Engineering, and of the
rapidly increasing national need for such individuals.
Recipients of these Fellowships will have an oppor-
tunity to pursue a broad course of graduate study in
the fundamental mathematics, physics, and engineering
required for careers in these fields, and will also have
an opportunity to associate and work with experienced
engineers and scientists.
Systems Engineering encompasses difficult advanced
design problems of the type which involve interactions,
compromises, and a high degree of optimization
between portions of complex complete systems. This
includes taking into account the characteristics of hu-
man beings who must operate and otherwise interact
with the systems.
The program for each Fellow covers approximately
a twelve-month period, part of which is spent at Space
Technology Laboratories, and the remainder at the
California Institute of Technology or the Massachu-
setts Institute of Technology working toward the Doc-
tor's degree, or in post-doctoral study. Fellows in good
standing may apply for renewal of the Fellowship for a
second year.
ELIGIBILITY The general requirements for eligibility
are that the candidate be an American citizen who has
completed one or more years of graduate study in
mathematics, engineering or science before July. 1960.
The Fellowships will also be open to persons who have
already received a Doctor's degree and who wish to
undertake an additional year of study focused specifi-
cally on Systems Engineering.
AWARDS The awards for each Fellowship granted will
consist of three portions. The first will be an educa-
tional grant disbursed through the Institute attended
of not less than $2,000, with possible upward adjust-
ment for candidates with family responsibilities. The
second portion will be the salary paid to the Fellow for
summer and part-time work at Space Technology Lab-
oratories. The salary will depend upon his age and
experience and the amount of time worked, but will
normally be approximately $2,000. The third portion
will be a grant of $2,100 to the school to cover tuition
and research expenses.
APPLICATION PROCEDURE For a descriptive
booklet and application forms, write to Space
Technology Laboratories Fellowship Committee.
Completed applications together with reference
forms and a transcript of undergraduate and
graduate courses and grades must be transmitted
to the Committee not later than Jan. 20, I960.

The Raytheon Graduate Program has been established
to contribute to the technical development of scientists
and engineers at Raytheon. It provides the opportunity
to selected persons employed by Raytheon, who are
accepted as graduate students by Harvard University,
Massachusetts Institute of Technology and California
Institute of Technology, to pursue at Raytheon's ex-
pense, regular courses of study leading to a master's
or doctor's degree in science or engineering in the institu-
tion of their choice.
The Program requires, in general, two or three semesters
of study, depending on circumstances, with the summer
months spent in the Company's research, engineering, or
manufacturing divisions. It includes full tuition, fees,
book allowances and a salary while at school. Students
are eligible for health, accident, retirement and life insur-
ance benefits, annual vacation and other privileges of
full-time Raytheon employees.
To be considered for the Program, applicants must have
a bachelor's degree in science or engineering, and should
have outstanding student records, show technical prom-
ise, and possess mature personal characteristics. They
may apply for admission to the Program in anticipation
of becoming employees of Raytheon.

interest in the field of Naval Architecture
and Marine Engineering. Open to any

this goal in three ways—preparation of

technical paper on some aspect of Naval
Arch or Marine Engineering. Upon de-
livery of the paper the student is voted
to full membership.

groups. Vulcans have also set up a schol-
arship fund to aid a worthy student.

• A missile's main engine runs only for a few
seconds. To supply electric and hydraulic power for
control during the entire flight a second power plant
is necessary. The AiResearch APU (accessory power
unit) which answers this problem is a compact, non
air-breathing, high speed turbine engine. The unit
pictured above develops 50 horsepower and weighs
30 pounds. The acknowledged leader in the field,
AiResearch has designed, developed and delivered
more accessory power units than any other source.

and the
POWER STATE
the group and the individual, the values
which society places on the actions of the
individual.
We have tended to confuse social dis-
cipline with self-discipline. As the Chorus
told Prometheus, "Your wits do wander
. . ," tha "social power state has told,
and still tells, the individual to specialize
in a particular region of thought. In this
way the individual adds to the sum of
knowledge in his particular field; his
field or profession progresses, but it pro-
gresses within limitations. This has the
effect of keeping the individual and his
profession isolated. His calculations are
restricted in their origin and effects. Thus
it becomes difficult for these calculations
to be Promethean or long-term.
The "social power state" advocates this
specialization because of the extremely
large quantity of knowledge which must
be assimilated by the scientific individual
(Continued from page 23)
before he becomes useful as the "resource
. . . (of) technology." However, the time
required to assimilate the sum of the
knowledge in one scientific field is so
great that often the remainder of the edu-
cation must be treated scientifically. The
relation of science to its environment
(art, history, literature, philosophy, etc.)
becomes obscure. The implications and
consequences of our science are not known
unless the many non-scientific dimensions
(political, social, moral, etc.) are con-
sidered. We see why the ability of the
scientific intellect is impared.
The Embryo
If we now look back to the "embryo"
of reconciliation between Force and Reas-
on in the Soviet Union, we see that the
isolation and carefully specialized educa-

pediment to Promethean foresight. The
Soviet power state, in its short-term view,
seeing the possibility of producing con-

as Zeus, and as all of the power states
that followed Zeus, learned, of the neces-

We too must realize the value of Pro-

cialization and its effect on the Prome-
thean foresight should be carefully eval-
uated. Also, we cannot allow mass "cruci-

occurred during the "Red Scare" of the
early 1950's. Actions such as the removal
of J. Robert Oppenheimer from the Gen-
eral Advisory Committee of the A.E.C.
caused, and will continue to cause, the
scientific intellect to avoid philosophical
problems.
The responsibility for the continued
existence of our Promethean intellect lies,
not only on the state and society, but
also on the individual. He must acquire
the basis for valid long-term calculations
so that he is able to recognize the im-
plications and social consequences of his
science. He must be able to advise those
who would now crucify him.

The young lady wheeled her car into
the service station, slammed on the
brakes, and dashed inside. In a few
minutes she came back, and said brightly:
"Boy, were my hands dirty!"
A broadway producer was seeking to
interest a dress manufacturer in backing
a show. He took him to a rehearsal.
One leggy lass after another appeared be-
fore him in scanty rehearsal costumes.
The merchant gaped intently, but all he
said was an occasional "Phooey."
The producer, annoyed, finally said,
"Here I show you some of the most
beautiful girls in the world, and all you
do is sit there and say 'Phooey'."
"I wasn't thinking of the girls," said
the merchant sadly, "I was thinking of
my wife."
I think that I shall never see.
A girl refuse a meal that's free;
A girl with hungry eyes not fixed
Upon a drink that's being mixed;
A girl who doesn't like to wear
A lot of junk to match her hair;
But are loved by guys like me
Cause darn if I will kiss a tree.
The new inmate at the "happy house"
kept claiming he was Napoleon. All rea-
soning to talk him out of his delusion
was fruitless. He still insisted that he
was the Little Emperor. In an effort to
bring him to his senses, the warden had
him put in with an incurable lunatic
who also thought that he was Napoleon,
hoping at least one of the two might
be helped. Eagerly, the next morning
the warden had the new inmate brought
to his office to find out if the therapy
had worked. "Well, Herman," asked the
warden, "do you still think you're Na-
poleon?" "No," answered Herman hap-
pily, "Josephine."
* * *
Little Jackie entered first grade, where
his teacher was a very well-proportioned
young lady who enjoyed very loose-fitting
blouses. One evening, several hours after
school was over, she was having dinner
in a restaurant when Jackie and his par-
ents came in.
"Daddy," the kid yelled, and all the
diners turned toward him, "There's Miss
Smith. You shoulda been in school to-
day. She leaned over too far, and one
of her lungs fell out."
Overheard at a sorority meeting:
"I'm getting married."
"How careless of you."
Two junior size "cats" were loitering
on a street corner, when one said to the
other:
"How old is you?"
"Ahs five," was the reply. "How old
is you?"
"Ah don't know," said the first.
"You don't know how old you is?"
"Nope."
"Does women botha' you?"
"Nope."
"Youse fo'."
The lady was stepping from the
shower and was about to reach for a
towel when she caught sight of a win-
dow washer taking in all of her charms.
She was too stunned to move, just star-
ing at the man.
"Watcha lookin' at lady," he finally
asked. "Aincha never seen a window
washer before?"

dilation of the rate at which the reaction
is proceeding inside the core. One chief
purpose of the secondary containment
vessel is to hold the liquid sodium in
case a leak should develop inside the
reactor.
When the reactor is in operation, elec-
tricity will be generated almost continu-
ously. However, refueling will be re-
quired weekly and ten to twenty hours
must be set aside for this procedure. The
fuel inside the reactor must be removed
and taken to laboratories for reconstitu-
tion. As part of their contribution to the
project, the AEC will carry on this oper-
ation. New fuel is then, of course, put
into place. Because of the radiation, spe-
cial material handling equipment is re-
quired to place the radioactive materials
in special storage containers. Mechanical
hands are used and the operations are
observed through television circuits.
Construction Under Way
Construction of the reactor plant is
well under way at the present time. The
reactor vessel has been delivered and the
cooling system is in place. Preliminary
tests are being run on these portions. Soon
these components wil be turned over to
PRDC and the testing program will con-
tinue. By late 1961, the reactor will have
been brought up gradually to design
capacity. The generating station is also
proceeding as planned; it should be op-
erational by September, I960.
Although it appears that substantial
proportions of the nation's electricity will
not be produced from nuclear fuels for
many years, it is certain that some day
this means of production will be a com-
mon one. Even today there are many
areas outside this country where nuclear
reactors are economically feasible. How-
ever, as a pioneer in nuclear engineering,
this country is responsible for these times
and places. As a step in the perfection
of nuclear power reactors, the Enrico
Fermi Reactor is being built.

OCTOBER, 1959


I AM AN ENGINEER. In my profession I take pride, but without vain-
glory; to it I owe solemn obligations that I am eager to fulfill.
As an Engineer, I will participate in none but honest enterprise. To
him that has engaged my services, as employer or client, I will give the ut-
most of performance and fidelity.
When needed, my skill and knowledge shall be given without reser-
vation for the public good. From special capacity springs the obligation to
use it well in the service of humanity; and I accept the challenge that this
implies.
Jealous of the high repute of my calling, I will strive to protect the
interests and the good name of any engineer that I know to be deserving;
but I will not shrink, should duty dictate from disclosing the truth regard-
ing anyone that, by unscrupulous act, has shown himself worthy of the
profession.
Since the Age of Stone, human progress has been conditioned by the
genius of my profesional forbears. By them have been rendered usable to
mankind Nature's vast resources of material and energy. By them have
been visualized and turned to practical account the principles of science and
the revelations of technology. Except for this heritage of accumulated ex-
perience, my efforts would be feeble. I dedicate myself to the dissemina-
tion of engineering profession in all its arts and traditions.
To my fellows I pledge, in the same full measure I ask of them, in-
tegrity and fair dealing, tolerance, and respect, and devotion to the stan-
dards and the dignity of our profession; with the consciousness, always,
that our special expertness carries with it the obligation to serve humanity
with complete sincerity.
Published by Engineers' Council for Professional Development
29 West 39th Street, New York 18, N. Y.

A RESUME IS A TWO-PARTY AFFAIR
Throughout your engineering career, the name
of the first employer appearing on your resume
can be as significant as your education. But, in
selecting that first employer, you should also
consider his resume.
ITT is the largest American-owned world-wide
electronic and telecommunication enterprise.
To give you an idea of the breadth of our
activity . . . there are 80 research and manu-
facturing units and 14 operating companies in
the ITT System playing a vital role in projects
of great national significance in electronics
and telecommunications research, development,
production, service and operation.
The scope and volume of work entrusted to us
by industry and the government opens a broad
range of highly diversified engineering and
technical positions in all areas of our work ...
from tiny diodes to complex digital computer
systems and a massive network of global
communications.
In addition to the opportunities for work and
association with distinguished engineers and
scientists, our graduate education tuition re-
fund program encourages engineers to continue
their formal training . . . and the facilities
for graduate work near ITT locations are
superior.
This is an all too brief resume. It would be
hard to associate yourself with a company that
offers the engineer greater choice of assign-
ment. Write us about your interests — or see
our representatives when they visit your
campus.

Compiled by DAVE McCORY '61 LSA
The summer suntans are fading, and
going to class is again becoming par-
tially automatic. Now that your minds are
nimble from a month's "study", see
what you can do with the Teasers. The
first one involves a carpenter who doesn't
belong to a union, and the last is a little
square. When the professor leaves the
room, turn the page and work as fast as
you can.
(1). A carpenter agrees to work under
the following conditions: He is to be
paid at the rate of $5.50 a day for his
work, while he must pay at the rate of
$6.60 a day for lost time. At the end of
30 days he has paid out as much as he
received. How many days did he work?
(2). From among 36 guilty persons
there were 6 whom an ancient judge
wished to punish. He wanted to free to be without solution: Divide a square
the rest if it could be done with an into a number of smaller squares, no
appearance of impartiality. He arranged two of them equivalent.
all 36 in a circle and punished every (Teasers answers on page 56)
tenth. In what place did he put the 6
victims?
(3). What is the least number of
standard weights needed to weigh every
whole number of pounds from 1 to 40?
(It is understood that the weighing ma-
chine is the simple equal-arm balance.)
(4). A boatman must carry a wolf, a
goat, and a cabbage across a river in a
boat so small that he can take only one
at a time. Furthermore, he must be on
hand to keep the wolf from the goat, and
the goat from the cabbage. How shall
he do it?
(5). Here is a problem long thought
TECHNOLOGY
This understanding may get a big boost
in I960 when 25-bev accelerators at
Brookhaven National Laboratory and at
Geneva, Switzerland take over the work
of the 2.5 bev Brookhaven Cosmotron
and the 6 bev Berkley Bevatron. These
new machines should provide a clearer
image and understanding of the elemen-
tary particles. Although a comprehensive
theory of elementary particles—similar
to the Quantum Theory of the Twenties
—may still be in the future in 1969,
man's concept of the sub-nuclear universe
should be greatly clarified and/or
changed.
Going to an opposite extreme—the
real universe—we find that man may
soon have a much better and clearer un-
FOR
TOMORROW
(Continued from page 28)
derstanding of astrophysical theory. This
will come about due to larger and better
radio telescopes which are being devel-
oped rapidly.
Finally, one last area that should be
mentioned is electronics and computers.
The Fifties saw rapid growth in this
field with the development of the tran-
sistor in 1951, of masers in 1954 (Tech.
nic, May 1959), the widespread devel-
opment of electronic gear for missies,
and the building of bigger and bigger
computers. The Sixties will see this
growth continued and by the late Sixties
we should have super computers with
near-brainlike attributes.
In the preceding paragraphs an at-
tempt has been made to preview some
of the developments of the Sixties. Many
others are listed on the chart on page
20. Still others, as the experience with
the Fifties shows, are totally unpredict-
able. Yet there has been enough indica-
tion to show the tremendous expansion
of technology to come. However, no one
can say what limits will be reached.
This same thought was expressed by
N. N. Semenov, the 1956 Nobel prize
winner in chemistry, when he said, "It
is hard to imagine at what breathtaking
speed the capacity of man to master the
forces of nature may advance in the
future." But regardless of the speed
there is no doubt that the Sixties will
indeed be the Years of Decision.

It takes more than pressing a button to send a giant rocket on its way.
Actually, almost as many man-hours go into the design and construction
ot the support equipment as into the missile itself. A leading factor in the
reliability of Douglas missile systems is the company's practice of including
all the necessary ground handling units, plus detailed procedures for system
utilization and crew training. This complete job allows Douglas missiles like
THOR, Nike HERCULES, Nike AJAX and others to move quickly from test
to operational status and perform with outstanding dependability. Douglas
is seeking qualified engineers and scientists for the design of missiles,

Once upon a time there was a traveling
salesman who pulled up at a country
farmhouse about dusk. The farmer's
daughter came out to see what he wanted.
"Any brushes today?" he asked.
"No," she replied, "but won't you
spend the night? Father isn't here."
"No thanks," he answered and drove
off.

A kiss is a noun because it's common
and proper.
It's a verb because it's active and passive.
It's a pronoun because she stands for it.
It's an adverb because it makes an ex-
planation.
It's a conjunction because it brings to-
gether and connects.
It's an interjection because it shows
strong feeling.
It's a preposition because it has an object.
A bosom companion sometimes turns
out to be a false friend.

THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC



Mechanical Engineering
Mechanical Engineering is essential to virtually every industry and to every phase of technology. As
a result, it offers the widest range of opportunity and endeavor available in engineering today. In turn, this
requires that the mechanical engineer receive a broad and basic education which provides him with a
depth and breadth of understanding of the basic fundamentals—a background that characterizes mechan-
ical engineers and explains their ability to perform in all of the fields of engineering.
It is because of his wealth of technical background that a mechanical engineer finds such a wide
range of opportunities available. His education includes basic science and mathematics courses, non-tech-
nial courses, as well as a number of courses which my be termed engineering science.
Mechanical engineering courses at Michigan are directly supported by a number of laboratories in
which the student gains not only a background in particular areas, but also a general knowledge of
the scientific approach to engineering problems and the use of essential mechanical and scientific equip-
ment.
While the mechanical engineering curriculum, of necessity, must be broad and inclusive, there is
sufficient flexibility, even at the undergraduate level, to permit course work in particular areas of interest,
such as the automotive field, internal combustion engines, heat and power, metal cutting and manufactur-
ing, product design, and materials.

ATOMIC POWER and DETROIT EDISON
A vast new source of energy—from the atom—is
of major interest at Detroit Edison. The advances
already made indicate that the electric power
industry is on the threshold of exciting new
developments in atomic electric power.
Detroit Edison personnel are playing a leading
role in these developments. One such project is
the Enrico Fermi Atomic Power Plant near
Monroe, Michigan. Here many of our men are
assigned to the Power Reactor Development
Company and the Atomic Power Development
Associates in the design and construction of the
world's largest breeder reactor. This is but one
example of many scientific pioneering achieve-
ments which provide continuing challenges to
young engineers in the electric power industry.
THE DETROIT EDISON COMPANY
Detroit 26, Michigan
NOVEMBER, 1959


Reversal
During a recent convention at Pennsylvania State
College, the editors of the Technic happened into a
conversation with the editors of the City College of
New York Vector (an engineering college maga-
zine.) The subject of discussion covered a vast area
which included shop talk, curriculum, future jobs,
and eventually pin pointed on the attitude of the
student body toward the Engineers. Being aware of
the presence of a negative attitude here on campus
(in the respect that Engineers are looked down
upon), we were completely taken by surprise to dis-
cover that our situation was not prevalent on their
campus, but to a good degree quite the opposite.
"Why should the Engineer be looked up to?" this
question stirred over and over in our minds. To be
quite frank, we know the answer and have known
it for quite some time but the thought never occurred
that we should cite it to motivate our cause and
advance our profession.
The Engineering student is entering into a pro-
fession as diverse in occupational fields as the uni-
verse is huge. This fact alone indicates that the
Engineer must possess the qualities of intelligence,
originality, abstractness, self-discipline, and fear-
lessness of the unknown. Many hours of vigorous
studying fill his typical day as the Engineer prepares
in the basic foundation of his field. This huge study
load steals the Student Engineer away from many
pleasurable hours of leisure; but without this self-
sacrifice, he would never be able to contribute to the
profession that is mainly responsible for our high
standard of living and our rapid economic advance-
ment over the past century. But yet, there are those
who would criticize.
Present in this great university is a pronounced
negative attitude toward Engineering that reflects
the ignorance of those who bear it. The Engineer-
ing student's chief critic does not lie within himself,
as it should, but in the student body as a whole.
This is of course due to the fact that the engineers
are an almost separate body and easily sterotyped.
As in the game of chess, the defensive player is
seldom the victor; I therefore shall not attempt to
defend the biased criticisms that indiscretely pop up,
but rather discuss the merits of the Engineer.
The Engineer possesses individuality and he must,
for problems occur every day that necessitate his
unique solution. However, individuality is not con-
tained only in his work, but in just about everything
the engineer is concerned with, his dress, his per-
sonality, his car, the books he reads, the friends he
chooses, etc. This individuality is not the so-called
"Mass Individuality" that is so prevalent on campus.
I mean that individuality which is possessed by those
persons who would never dream of being considered
anything near common nor would they ever be with-
out their Harvard Green Book Bag, their trench
coats and sneakers, their unopened book of poetry,
and their cramped-up foreign auto.
The Engineer is a master of the art of common
sense. "Common Sense" has been sneaking around
since the age of man to occassionally stand out in
the men who are extremely observant and crafty.
Now, "Common Sense" has out done himself; it
seems that he has sired a whole breed of men and
those be the Engineers. These endowed individuals
show common sense in most every respect. That little
extra ability in economics, scientific matters, mechan-
ical, social, etc. puts their university rivals to shame.
A good example of the Engineers common sense is
displayed in his dress. Being that there is a lack of
femininity around engine school (females being
the only reason that Lit. students try to dress sharp),
and with nobody left to impress but Profs., the
Engineer uses good economic sense in wearing
easily launderable clothes. Also engine labs are not
noted for their absolute sterile conditions.
In discussing the Student Engineer, one must not
loose sight of his career. Engineering is still young
and striving for that professionalism already attained
by our doctors and lawyers. A young man is wise to
enter Engineering. The field is growing; the future
looks bright; the demand is high; and the security
is plentiful. Wise is he to have made that decision
rather than waste his time in the social schools being
capable, on graduation, only of knowing the differ-
ence between the Kingston Trio and Mozart with a
mastery of the cork screw sandwiched between.
These are but a few of the more obvious reasons
why Engineers should be held in esteem. So Gentle-
men, take stock of yourselves—what you do, what
you are capable of, and what you do not do, and by
all means do not sell yourself short.
Charles R. Hildebrandt

Westinghouse mathematicians Burnham Moffat and Dr. Richard Durstine check on an electronic
computer working out solutions to a heat transfer problem for the company's Atomic Power Division.
The Mathematics Department helps you to use
high-speed computers to solve your problem
The Mathematics Department helps Westinghouse
engineers take advantage of modern methods of mathe-
matics and new developments in this field. If new tech-
niques are needed to use a digital computer for solving
an engineer's problem, these men will develop them.
This department, the second of its kind in American
industry, is staffed by 15 Ph.D.'s, 3 M.S.'s, and 6 B.S.
mathematicians. Among other accomplishments, it is
credited with developing OPCON, an electronic brain
for optimizing control of processing systems. OPCON
won for Westinghouse the 1958 Industrial Science
Achievement Award of the A.A.A.S.
Supporting the work of about 150 other mathemati-
cians with operating divisions, the Mathematics Dept.
is actively studying industrial logistics (called OR or
Operations Research by some), fatigue of metals (pio-
neering work using statistical techniques), equipment
and system design, and a variety of other challenging
problems.
The young engineer at Westinghouse isn't expected to
know all of the answers. Our work is often too advanced
for that. Each man's work is backed up by specialists—
like the men in this Mathematics Dept. Even tough
problems are easier to solve with this kind of help.
If you've ambition and real ability, you can have a
rewarding career with Westinghouse. Our broad product
line, decentralized operations, and diversified technical
assistance provide hundreds of challenging opportuni-
ties for talented engineers.

more good jobs at Du Pont

HOW LONG WILL IT STAY BRIGHT AND SHINY?
That depends, for the most part, on its
finish. The most dazzling cars on the road
today wear gleaming coats of Du Pont
■'Lucite"* acrylic lacquer. For "Lucite"
stays bright and beautiful three times longer
than the best conventional finishes.
Like hundreds of other products de-
veloped through Du Pont research, "Lucite"
has created all kinds of new jobs. Jobs in
the laboratory. Jobs in production. And
jobs in sales and marketing. Good jobs
that have contributed substantially to the
growth of Du Pont and the prosperity of
our country.
It's an old story. But it's truer today
than ever. For the very nature of our busi-
ness makes research pay off, giving us the
courage to "obsolete" products when better
ones are found. This is probably why our
sales have increased more than tenfold dur-
ing the last twenty-five years. And for every
dollar we have spent on research during
these years, we have been able to invest
three in new production facilities.
What does all this have to do with you?
* "Lucite" ie Du Pout's registered trademark for its acrylic lacquer.
For qualified bachelors, masters, doctors,
career opportunities are greater today at
Du Pont than ever before. There is an in-
teresting Du Pont future for metallurgists,
physicists, mathematicians, electrical and
mechanical engineers, and other technical
specialists, as well as for chemists and chem-
ical engineers.
You probably won't discover a "Lucite,"
nylon or neoprene, or develop a revolu-
tionary new process, your first year. No-
body expects you to. But you will be given ,
responsibility from the very start, along',
with training that is personalized to fit your
interests and special abilities. Our advance-
ment policies are based on the conviction
that you should wrork at or near the top of
your ability. For as you grow, so do we.
If you would like to know more about
career opportunities at Du Pont, ask your
placement officer for literature. Or write
E. I. du Pont de Nemours &amp; Co. (Inc.),

NUCLEAR
ROCKET
ENGINE
With the hope of lifting 50-ton payloads into
outer space in the near future, scientists are
now turning to nuclear power as the best
method available.
by BARRY E. PEEBLES, '60E
A Kiwi-A experimental nuclear
reactor like the one pictured here
went into operation recently. The
reactor is designed to determine
whether atomic energy can thrust
a rocket into outer space. The
railroad car can be controlled re-
motely.
(World Wide Photos, Inc.)
THE TIME: Early July, 1959. THE
PLACE: Jackass Flat, Nevada. THE
OBJECT: A large tuba-appearing ap-
paratus known as Kiwi A. THE MIS-
SION: Test firing of the world's first
nuclear rocket engine.
This was the setting on a deserted
desert plain as a remote-controlled
locomotive slowly maneuvered into posi-
tion the Kiwi A — a two story high
maze of pipes, wires, and metal mounted
on a special railroad car chassis. Then
with the locomotive at a safe distance,
scientists two miles away in a concrete
blockhouse made final hurried checks
before pushing the button to activate the
uranium bearing fuel plates and the
pressurized liquid hydrogen.
Minutes later the results were known.
Although the Kiwi A, like the legendary
flightless Kiwi bird of New Zealand,
was not meant to rise even an inch off
the ground the mission was hailed as an
unqualified success. To the men from the
sponsoring Atomic Energy Commission
and the scientists of the Los Alamos
research team, who developed the Kiwi
as part of the overall Project Rover, there
was no doubt about it: nuclear powered
space ships will and must replace today's
chemical combustion rockets if big pay-
loads are to be put into outer space.
Closer Look
At first this statement might be passed
off as remarks by slap-happy scientists
gleeful over the success of their project.
However, a closer look behind this state-
ment shows that the chemical rockets,
powerful as they are, will soon reach
the limit of their development, which
falls short of what will be needed to lift
100,000 pound payloads into outer space.
For this reason it might be well, before
looking closer at the Kiwi A and its own
problems, to examine the limitations that
face today's rocket engine designers.
First of all, it should be pointed out
that a rocket, whether nuclear or chem-
ical, is nothing more than a heat engine
which uses a special nozzle to convert
the heat energy to kinetic propulsion
energy. This conversion is accomplished
as hot gas escapes through the nozzle
and expands very rapidly. This expansion
causes the velocity of the gas to be in-
creased tremendously. It follows naturally
that as the velocity of the gas increases
the performance of the rocket does like-
wise.
From tests and studies made in recent
years scientists have determined that
there are only two basic factors that affect
the gas velocity (and therefore the rock-
ets performance). These factors are the
NOVEMBER, 1959
17


molecular weight of the gas. The space-
men know that as the temperature goes
up and the molecular weight goes down
the gas velocity increases.
Chemical Rockets
This point leads us to the chemical
combustion rockets used in today's mis-
siles. The rocket engines for such mis-
siles as the Atlas and Jupiter are oper-
ating in the 5000°F range, which is
approaching the highest temperature ob-
tainable by combustion. On the other
hand, the fuels for these missiles usually
have a molecular weight of 19—with
the lowest level possible without lower-
ing the combustion temperature is nine.
When an optimum point of these two
factors—molecular weight and combus-
tion temperature — is reached the gas
velocity will be about 13,000 ft/sec.
Of course, larger and larger engines
can be built. In fact, a rocket with a
million pound thrust is being developed
now. But with the enormous amount of
space needed for fuel storage there is
considerable doubt whether or not the
payload would even come close to that
of a nuclear rocket of the same or smaller
size.

Shown above and on the opposite page
is a weight comparison of the possible
rocket types needed to lift a 100,000
pound payload into outer space. The
first, at the far left, shows a two stage

of the Tecbnic, is a senior in I.E.
and is planning to work for a
Master's in Business Administra-
tion next year.
After four years at Michigan,
Barry can list a number of activi-
ties he has participated in besides
the Tecbnic, including being the
Junior and Senior class President,
General Chairman of Engineers
Weekend, and a member of Tri-
angles and Vulcans Honoraries.
However, Beep (as he is known
in the Technic office) claims his
most enjoyable achievement is be-
ing married to his wife, Lois.

nuclear and chemical rocket. The center
illustration depicts a one stage nuclear
rocket—which probably will be more
reliable than a combination nuclear-
chemical rocket since no stage separa-
tion is necessary. The main drawback to
chemical rockets is shown in the last
illustrations—namely they must be al-
most 5 times as heavy as a nuclear
rocket to lift the same payload.

THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


«?-^

Nuclear Rocket Engine
With these facts in mind let's turn
now to the nuclear rocket engine—how
it operates, its advantages over a chem-
ical combustion engine, and some of the
problems that must be conquered.
15
mi f lion
lbs.

This rocket is the largest needed to
carry a 100,000 pound payload and is
of the four stage, solid propellant type.
Because of its weight (165 million lbs.),
it is the least efficient type for space
travel.
The Kiwi A
Basically, the Kiwi A, and its sister
engines to follow, work like this: Hydro-
gen is stored in liquid form at 820°F.
From the tanks it is forced under high
pressure (1000 lbs./sq. in.) between a
large number of reactor fuel plates which
are impregnated with uranium. In this
reactor the gas is heated as high as the
reactor can stand and then ejected.
Almost immediately we can see one
of the major advantages of this system—
namely that the gas used in hydrogen
which has a molecular weight of one
(the lower the M.W. the higher the
velocity). This alone means that a re-
actor operating at 4000°F can expel
gases at 25,000 ft/sec or nearly twice as
fast as the optimum chemical combustion
rocket.
In addition the nuclear reactor can
furnish heat at almost unlimited tempera-
tures if materials are developed to go
with it. What's more, there is no need
to worry about having exact fuel com-
positions because, in the words of the
Kiwimen, hydrogen or helium will work
perfectly "without regard to chemical
combustion characteristics." The possibil-
ities leave one almost breathless.
Although the Kiwi A test was un-
doubtedly a success there are a number
of problems to be surmounted before a
nuclear-powered rocket leaves the earth.
The principal one is the control of the
flow of hydrogen so it exactly balances
the production of energy by the reactor.
If the flow should be too slow the engine
might melt in seconds. On the other
hand, if it is too great the engine could
be blown to bits. However, the Kiwi
success seems to indicate that this prob-
lem has been licked.
Temperatures
The mentioned operating temperature
of 4000°F actually turns out to be some-
what of a barrier even though it is 1000
degrees lower than that used in today's
rockets. The difference is that in chem-
ical combustion engines most of the heat
is confined to the gas and the shell is
Igggfe^-
kept cool by in-flowing gas which acts
as a heat exchanger. However, in the
nuclear reactor engine heat is generated
in the core by the "fissioning of the
uranium incorporated into its fuel plates."
This means that for a 4000 °F gas the
core will be about 4800 °F.
Immediately the problem of materials
becomes paramount. From a limited choice
of materials graphite seems to be the
best pick. Graphite retains its strength at
4800 °F, but this strength is low and it
is subject to rapid erosion. It may be
sufficient, however, to last the one or
two minutes before the payload is free
of the earth's gravity.
The scientists have also encountered a
major problem in the design of the re-
actor. They would like to have just as
many fuel plates as possible because as
the number goes up it reduces the
amount of heat that must pass through
a given area in a given time.
But this improvement creates another
problem—namely the greater surface area
causes a greater drop in pressure and at
the same time increases the drag on the
reactor. For example with 1000 pounds
of gas and a 10,000 pound core there
may be as much as 300,000 pounds drag
on the reactor. Making it worse, the
rocket will probably undergo an acceler-
ation of 10 g, or in other words a
10,000 pound engine will "weigh" 100,-
000 pounds. These two factors mean a
400,000 pound force on the structure.
While withstanding this load the struc-
ture must still be light, take a very small
space, and be able to stand high temper-
atures.
It is now obvious from the above
discussion that many and varied prob-
lems exist in the design and construction
of a nuclear-powered rocket engine. The
Kiwi A test indicates, however, that we
have already conquered partially or com-
pletely a great many of the problems
involved, although the AEC refuses to
indicate to what extent. The one fact
that remains is that a nuclear engine is
possible and necessary if 50 ton payloads
are to be lifted into outer space.

From Toy To
Guidance System
Hollywood couldn't have written a better suc-
cess story for the tiny gyros — they have pro-
gressed from a mere child's toy to an important
element in the guidance system of today's mis-
siles, planes, and nuclear subs.
by JOHN MARSHALL, '62E
Just a few miles from St. Petersburg,
Florida, lies a plain white concrete
building that looks like a small factory.
From afar the building and grounds
surrounding it give the impression of
normalcy but a venture up close reveals
a moat and an armed guard. As would
be expected the guard and the moat are
there to protect, but the moat, unlike
the guard who protects against "animal"
intruders, protects against an unseen but
nevertheless present interloper, vibration.
The little white building is actually a
factory which produces one of the United
States' most valuable instruments. This
instrument, which is the size of a soup
can, is the hermetic integrating gyro-
scope, usually called Mr. HIG. Without
Mr. HIG our Atlases, Jupiters, Thors,
Nautiluses, Skates, etc., would be a pile
of junk. Mr. HIG guides all the missiles
and submarines of today and will be the
super-brain of tomorrow.
Most people today know little about
the gyroscope (gyro for short), and even
then this knowledge is limited to the
toy they had when they were young.
What they tend to remember most, how-
ever, was the ability of the toy gyro to
remain in almost any position, as long
as its center wheel remained spinning.
Unfortunately, the wheel always slowed
down and stopped within a short time
due to the gyro's major enemy, friction.
Friction!!
For many generations scientists tried
in vain to create a gyro that was virtually
frictionproof. They failed basically be-
cause they didn't understand many under-
lying principles of gyroscopic action and
because tolerances and instruments were
of a lower caliber than those of today.
The major breakthrough came during or
shortly after the Korean War when Dr.
C. S. Draper of MIT developed the
"floating gyro." His gyro wheel was
about the size of four fifty-cent pieces
placed on top of each other and it spun
in helium at 24,000 revolutions per min-
ute in a container the size of a large egg.
This container in turn floated in another
container filled with a heavy molasses
like fluid. Thus the gyro was virtually
weightless and friction was at a minimum.
This is Mr. HIG.
Right after Mr. HIG was developed,
the Department of Defense turned him
over to Minneapolis-Honeywell, a lead-

THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


solving many basic difficulties, Minneap-
olis-Honeywell built the small white fac-
tor)' near St. Petersburg. Since a gyro is
extremely vibration-sensitive, all vibra-
tions had to be eliminated from the
production room. Wet ground conducts
vibrations and a truck or train rumbling
by or the pounding of waves in the Gulf
of Mexico some ten miles away could
have caused chaos. M-H solved this vi-
bration problem by building the factory
on ponderous piles and then digging a
moat which would drain away every
possible drop of water. The insides of
the factory are truly astounding. The
production rooms are kept at "positive
pressure." This means that air pressure
outside is lower than inside so that stray
dust particles tend to be blown from the
room. The rooms are probably the most
perfectly air conditioned rooms in the
world. The men who work on the pro-
duction line, all master watchmakers,
have to wear sterilized garments just like
those of surgeons. No one may smoke
or even use a pencil or eraser. No gauze
masks are worn on the production line
but instead, the supersensitive gyros are
protected from human breath moisture by
glass shields.
Once assembled, Mr. HIG must pass
certain tests. One is to detect movements
3,000 times slower than the motion of
the hour hand of a watch. A second is
to develop no more friction than the
amount needed to stop a boy on a sled
coasting down a slope which drops one
foot in every 1,000 miles, and a third
is to be able to detect the slightest angles
of deviation from its course.
Principles Involved
As mentioned before, not too many
people know or understood the princi-
ples underlying gyroscopic action. So
that those who want to know more about
gyros won't have to go to the library
and find that the author has all the books
out, the basic ideas of the gyro are dis-
cussed in the next few paragraphs!
Gyro Properties
Any spinning mass exhibits certain
traits known as gyroscopic characteristics.
By definition, when such a spinning mass
is designed and mounted in a manner
making these characteristics usable, the
device is called a gyroscope.
The gyro's spinning mass is normally
referred to as the rotor or the wheel or
gyro element. The "bracket" holding the
rotor shaft is known as a gimbal. Normal-

(Courtesy Sperryscope, publication of Sperry Rand Corporation).
This view inside the "Navigation Island" shows an exact duplicate of a "Polaris"-
missle firing submarine's navigation center. Sperry specialists are shown check-
ing intricate equipment and gyros.
ly this gimbal will be a complete ring
or something approaching a sphere.
Remember the "gyroscopes" mentioned
earlier in the paper that you knew as a
child . . . the dime (dollar) store
variety? Like most everyone else, you
were probably fascinated by the perform-
ance of one of these gadgets. Pulling a
string wound around its rotor shaft set
it spinning, and while spinning, it
seemed to defy the law of gravity as
though it had a mind of its own. For
instance, when placed on the edge of a
glass with its rotor spinning around a
horizontal axis it would remain there as
though something were holding it up.
If the glass were tilted slightly, it would
move slowly around the edge of the glass
with its rotor shaft remaining horizontal
rather than following the tilt of the glass
as one might consider normal. In this
action that simple device exhibited the
two primary phenomena of a gyro:
1. It has stability of its own in space.
2. When something tries to move it,
it resists, but moves instead around an
axis 90° to the appplied force. This
movement is called precession.
Stability in Space
Stability in space is readily explained
by Newton's first Law of Motion. This
basic law of physics states in part, "a
body in motion remains in uniform mo-
tion in a straight line, unless acted upon
by an unbalanced external force." For
example, if a disc rolled along a flat
surface, it will continue to roll in a
straight line until it loses speed. Inertia

OF
PARITY
After years of use the world over, one of the
fundamental laws of physics has been dis-
proved.
by IRVING SALMEEN, '63E
It isn't very often that an event occurs
in the field of science that upsets the
very foundation upon which the laws
of science are based. But this is exactly
what has happened in the field of phys-
ics. A basic law—known as the parity that much of physics will have to be
principle or the conservation of parity— rewritten. However, before we can un-
has failed. This failure, which is as sig- derstand how and why this principle
nificant as would be the overthrow of failed, let us first see what parity is.
conservation of energy and matter, means
Irving Salmeen, a graduate of
the Iron Mountain Senior High
School, was a member of the Key
Club, Debate Team, and the bas-
ketball Team. Irving's interest in
writing originates from high school
where he was on the Year Book
staff and school paper.
During his spare time in college
Irving follows his interest in Pho-
tography, Hi-Fi, and Modern Art.

The principle of parity can be stated
in the following manner: any process
which occurs in nature also occurs as it
is seen in a mirror. In other words,
nature is mirror symmetric; there is no
distinction made between right and left.
According to this law, any motion, action,
or event which can be observed in a
mirror also occurs in nature. To put it
more concisely, the laws of nature are
invariant under reflection.
Math Concept
Strictly speaking, parity is a mathe-
matical concept, very difficult to put into
physical terms, which defines certain
characteristics of the so-called wave func-
tions of quantum physics. It describes
the wave characteristics and represents
their position in space. The variables of
the function are those coordinates that
are used to locate spacial positions. If
the sign of one of the coordinates is
changed from say a plus to a minus, this
22
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


it appears as a reflection of the system
in a mirror. If the wave function remains
unchanged when the sign of one of its
coordinates is changed then it is said that
the wave has "even" parity. If the wave
function is changed, then the wave has
"odd" parity. Thus, parity has two val-
ues, odd or even. In an isolated system
this parity is constant, it never changes.
To put it another way, we say that parity
is conserved.
In an article of this nature it is im-
possible to explain the mathematical prin-
ciples and terms of parity; however, we
can explain the concept of right-left
mirror symmetry. As an example let us
take a perfectly-balanced uniform bar
supported in the exact center by a pivot.
(See figure 1.) We know that under
these conditions this bar will not tip but
let us prove it using mirror symmetry
or the parity principle. This bar can do
one of three things: 1. it can tip counter-
clockwise, 2. it can tip clockwise, 3. it
will remain in balance and not tip at all.
(See figure 2.). If the bar moves as in
statement one, the mirror image will
have motion "a". To obey parity the
mirror image must have the same motion
as the real object. We can see in the
diagram that the image motion is not the
same, thus statement one violates parity
and cannot be the correct motion. The
same reason applies to statement two.
Only the conditions of statement three
make it possible for the mirror image and
the real object to be identical. Therefore,
by the parity principle only statement
three is correct.
Another example is an object with
spirality. In such an object the direction
of motion is associated with a sense of

rotation. In a mirror the image has op-
posite spirality; hence, by the parity
principle it must exist in nature. We
know from experience that both types
of spirals do exist. To illustrate this, look
at figure 3- The mirror can be placed in
one of two positions, horizontal or verti-
cal. When the mirror is in the horizontal
position the sense of direction of the
spiral is changed and the sense of rota-
tion is unchanged. In the other position
the opposite is true, the rotation is
changed and the direction is unchanged.
Since both conditions exist, parity is
conserved.
One more example to illustrate parity
is the case of the crystal molecule; the
tetrahedral molecule in particular. (Figure
4.) No matter how the molecule is
rotated, the mirror image cannot be made
to look like the original. Therefore, both
molecules must exist in nature. Indeed,
we find this to be true in the quartz
crystal. Both molecular configurations are
found in a sample of quartz. There are
no differences in physical properties of
the two crystals, they are identical.
Weak Interactions
Until the recent startling events it ap-
peared that the indescernability between
an object and its mirror image was un-
contestable. All previous experience had
shown that there was no distinction be-
tween the looking glass world and the
real world. But certain baffling events
which occurred duing the newly dis-
covered "weak interactions" caused Tsung
Dao Lee of Columbia and Chen Ning
Yang of the Institute for Advanced Study
at Princeton to suggest that on the scale
of weak interactions, parity was not con-
served. Like other physicists, Lee and
Yang had been puzzling about the be-
havior of two recently discovered parti-
cles. These were the tau and theta mesons,
members of a group of particles known
as K particles. Tau and theta particles
are formed in certain nuclear collisions
and in a time of about 10'8 seconds
they decay. The tau disintegrates into
three pi mesons and the theta into two
pi mesons. The baffling part of this was
that in every property except the mode
of decay these two particles were ab-
solutely identical. Was it possible that
these two particles were one and the
same? Other particles were known to
have different modes of decay. However,
in the case of these particles the con-
servation of parity stood in the way. The
tau meson decayed into a pair of pi
mesons with "odd parity" while the
theta decayed into three pi mesons with
"even parity". The conservation of parity
said that the tau and the theta must be
different particles since they had different
parity. In other words, the mirror images

AT
MICHIGAN
As computers and computing continue to have
increased importance on our lives the Techn/c
surveys the computer situation at Michigan.
by CARL PAGE, '60E
In the past decade, computers have
made a spectacular impact upon the
processes of applied mathematics in sci-
ence, engineering, and business. If the
education of the prospective leaders in
the fields of science, engineering, and
business is to keep pace with develop-
ments in the fields themselves, then it
must include some information about
computers. The University of Michigan
has responded to the challenge of com-
puter education perhaps more extensively
than any other educational institution in

the nation. No less than four depart-
ments of the Engineering College, one
of the Business Administration School
and one of the College of Literature,
Science and the Arts, are offering courses
in some phase of computers. Moreover,
the Rackham School of Graduate Studies
offers a graduate program in computer
engineering for those who wish to spe-
cialize in the design of digital computers.
However, the impact of computers up-
on the University student has been more
widespread than just a few new courses
in a catalog. The Department of Chem-
ical and Metallurgical Engineering began
a program last semester of evening lec-
tures about GAT, an algebra-like lan-
guage which can be used to communicate
with one type of computer, the IBM 650,
which was then part of the University
The IBM engineer here repairs a tape
unit.
of Michigan Statistical Computing Lab-
oratory. Over 200 undergraduate students
in the department attended the lectures,
which were climaxed with a closed cir-
cuit TV demonstration of a rocket prob-
lem being run on the University's IBM
650. Since the GAT translator or com-
piler program system was used, it was
not necessary for the students to become
familiar with the internal command
scheme of instruction of the computer.
Other departments, such as Civil Engi-
neering, have had special lectures on the
use of computers on problems of their
area.
The Chemical and Metallurgical stu-
dents were invited to use the computer,
rather than a slide rule, for any lengthy
calculations they might encounter during
their regular class work. They were re-
quired to punch their own cards, (as all
students are) for input to the machine,
but the problems were run on the com-
puter for them by laboratory assistants.
Many of the students used the computer,
a few claiming to have solved problems
which have never been solved before. As
was stated above, they used GAT, a form
of compiler program. Before going on,
let us clarify the various approaches in
communicating with a digital computer.
We will assume in the following dis-
cussion that input to the computer is in
the form of punched cards.
24
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


Digital computer users have three
usual ways of communicating the prob-
lem they wish to solve to the computer.
They may prepare their problem in basic
machine code, that is, in a numerical code
which is built into the machine for simple
arithmetic operations or logical oper-
ations in the machine. Usually the ma-
chine code is a number associated with
two numbers which give the location (or
address of the operand and the address
of the next instruction in the memory of
the computer. (One may think of each
cell or address in the machine as a place
to put numbers in the form of magnetic
spots.) For example, consider this in-
struction from the IBM 650:
Location on magnetic drum 1400;
operation code 60; operand 1951;
next operand 1956.
60 is the operation meaning "place a
number into the device called the upper
accumulator"; 1951 is the address of the
operand; 1956 is where the machine
should pick up the next instruction. If
the storage location 1956 on the mag-
netic drum contains the instruction:
10 1966 0014
the machine will do 10, that is, add into
the upper accumulator the number which
is stored at the location 1966, then go
on to the address 14 for the next in-
struction. Since the accumulator now con-
tains the sum of the numbers which are
in 1951 and 1966 let us store it some-
where for future references. The code for
store upper accumulator on the IBM
650 is 11, so we punch on a card to be
"read" electrically into location 14:
11 0600 0069
and the accumulator is stored in location
0600 while the machine picks up the
number in 0069 for the next instruction.
In the early days of computers, (5-10
years ago) most programming was done
in machine code. However, only a small
fraction of machine users do problems
in machine code today.
Automation Programming
One reason computers were originally
built was to take care of problems which
were long, tiresome, routine, and imbued
with trivial detail. But programming a
computor using direct machine code for
a long problem is long, tiresome, routine,
and imbued with trivial detail. So it was
not too long before computor program-
mers began to invent schemes whereby

the machine might be used to assist in
the programming. Two types of schemes
are widely used today. One is an assem-
bly program method which is a symbolic
extention of machine code and is con-
sequently somewhat easier to use than
machine code. Assembly programs usually
generate one machine instruction per in-
put. The other main type of system is a
compiler program which generates several
machine codes for one input statement.
Some compilers allow input which looks
almost like algebra or a language, and
they are especially useful for problems
which evaluate many complicated formu-
las.
Let us take the simple example of
taking two numbers, adding them, and
then storing them somewhere in an as-
sembly program SOAP II and then in
GAT, a compiler, both of which are
used on the IBM 650
SOAP II, which stands for "Symbolic
Optimum Assembly Program" is a com-
puter program which accepts instruction-
like inputs. But these inputs have alpha-
betical symbols instead of numeric codes,
and symbolic addresses instead of fixed
numeric addresses. Let us consider this
illustration:
The operator handles all information
at the console. He then can translate
this to the mathematical board behind
the panel.

WORD2 STU SUM GO ON

{machine code)
60 1951 1956
1956 10 1966 0014
0014 11 0600 0069
The symbols WORD 1, WORD 2,
SUM, FIRST, NEXT, and GO ON have
no meaning except to specify a location
in the machine. Everywhere that the sym-
bols appear first, the machine defines
them with some fairly arbitrary address.
But in the example above, every time
one uses the symbol "SUM" the machine
will grind out machine code with the

NEW U-M
RESEARCH GROUP
Off to a fast start, the Institute of Science and
Technology should soon have an important
effect on local and state-wide scientific and
industrial growth.
by BRYAN WHIPPLE, '61E
The automation of ten years from
now, I am convinced, will be so com-
plex and ingenious that it will challenge
the most highly-trained scientific experts
in the world. ... I am convinced that
within a short span of years most of the
world's manufactured goods will be
turned out in highly automated factories,
wherever these factories are located.
There is no law of nature that says
those factories are going to be in Mich-
igan, but by meeting the challenge we
can see to it that they are.
These were the words of U-M physics
professor H. R. Crane, addressing a
gathering in Detroit. The challenge he
referred to was "the meeting of some
of the present critical needs for highly
trained scientists and engineers and the
development of sufficient skilled man-
power to put the state in the foreground
of forthcoming technological advances."
The proposal for meeting this need
which Professor Crane was supporting
was the newly-conceived University of
Michigan Institute of Science and Tech-
nology.
Goals of 1ST
First announced at a Regent's meeting
late in 1957, the manifest goals of the
new Institute are:
1. To serve as a center for scientific
and technological instruction, research
and service on the collegiate and post-
graduate level. The Institute would be
staffed by U-M faculty members and out-
standing new men who could be at-
tracted to the University.
2. To set up and administer a system
of grants for undergraduate and graduate
students who desire to devote themselves
to teaching or to research in the fields
of technology and science. This would be
based on a most thorough and careful
talent search of the State of Michigan.
3. To carry on research in methods
of increasing the effectiveness and extent
of scientific education at all levels.
4. To co-operate with other educa-
tional institutions in the state, both pub-
lic and private, in the encouragement of
scientific and technological research and
instruction. Staff members and nationally-
known scientists would be given time
from teaching duties to work with other
colleges and universities, high schools,
and elementary schools in an effort to
stimulate and encourage interest in ca-
reers in science.
5. To seek the co-operation of busi-
ness and industry in furthering the pur-
poses of the Institute, especially as they
relate to future industrial and business
development in the state. In particular,
it would provide leadership and guidance
for programs designed to train technical
personnel to supplement the work of
professional engineers and scientists and
also to retrain others temporarily dis-
placed by advancing technological pro-
cesses.
The Institute arose from a special re-
port to University President Hatcher by
the U-M Science Advisory Committee,
which noted in its report that the Amer-
ican nation is not producing enough
highly trained people to maintain leader-
ship in the kind of world which scien-
tific advances are creating. Recognition
must be given to the fact that intellect,
ability and brain power are national
assets which can no longer be wasted in
the face of Soviet competition, the com-
mittee said.
Not Crash Program
The committee emphasized that the
Institute was not a "crash program"
occasioned by the Russian sputnik appear-

The proposed project will consist of a three-story and basement laboratory wing connected by a passage to a six-
story and basement office wing. The building will contain (1) laboratories for electrical energy and electronics
engineering projects; (2) laboratories for projects and studies in chemical engineering, atomic energy, high
temperature metallurgy, botany, biological chemistry and physiology; (3) 25 faculty offices; (4) 12 institute,
executive and business offices; (5) six seminar rooms; (6) six classrooms; (7) five staff conference rooms; and (8)
service and mechanical rooms.
The building will be located on the north campus adjoining the College of Engineering facilities and research and
teaching laboratories assigned to nuclear engineering and physics. The proposed building will have a gross floor
area of about 110,000 square feet and a volume of 1,430,000 cubic feet.

At the time of Professor Crane's
speech early this spring, the fate of the
Regents' proposal was still considerably
uncertain. His view of the value of the
Institute was perhaps more practical, for
he emphasized the benefits which might
accrue to the business of the state through
the operation of a training center for top-
notch engineers and industrial scientists.
Professor Crane said that an invest-
ment of five million dollars through the
Institute over a five-year period "could
bring forth 50 million dollars from the
federal government in research projects,
and that, further, the results of these
projects could bring 500 million dollars
in new industry. I do not think this is
dreaming at all, because it is a chain
reaction that has already happened in
other places."

Michigan Lags
Professor Crane pointed to Michigan's
lag behind other states in the area of
basic research. He said that New York
has six times as many physicists engaged
in research as Michigan, California five
times more, Massachusetts, New Jersey,
and Pennsylvania have three times more,
and that Illinois, Ohio, and Connecticut
are also out ahead.
The ratio applies all too closely to
related fields, and Federal funds spent
on such research are certainly admin-
istered preferentially to these states with
large numbers of researchers engaged in
fundamental work.

During July this year the Institute of
Science and Technology became a little
more real with the approval by the
Regents of a set of by-laws, adoption
of a budget, and the appointment of a
director.
Named to the post of director was

years ahead. He then co-ordinates the develop-
ment of plans to meet future needs with the
various engineering groups involved. Bill calls it
"management engineering."
Bill is married, has three youngsters and owns

to do it can be mighty important. Choosing a
Bell Telephone career was the best decision I ever
made. I don't know where an ambitious young
fellow can find more or better chances to move
ahead in management."

IBM Engineer Richard R. Booth
explores electronic frontiers
to develop new, faster and
larger storage devices
for tomorrow's computers.

Computing time cut from six months to one day
"My job is to design and develop new, high-speed
storage devices for a powerful new computer that
will perform, in one day, operations requiring six
months on present equipment," said Dick Booth
as he began a typical day recently. A product de-
velopment engineer at the IBM Laboratories in
Poughkeepsie, N. Y., he started his morning with a
conference on a product of great interest to him: a
magnetic core storage device with a nondestructive
read-out feature. For an hour, he discussed with
circuit design engineers the logical devices needed
for the register—such as magnetic core drivers and
sense amplifiers. Should such devices not be avail-
able, the group would work on designs for new ones.
Dick Booth next met with members of the Mag-
netic Materials Group to establish specifications for
the magnetic core memory elements to be used in
the register. He also discussed with the group the
development of equipment to test the memory
elements. "This magnetic core register is based on
an original idea of mine," he explained. "When you
have a worthwhile idea, you will be given a free
hand in proving it out, backed by IBM's resources
— plus the assistance of skilled specialists."

applications."

here at the IBM Laboratory."

Undergraduate Courses
Now that we have given examples of
the three main types of computer pro-
gramming systems, let us sketch quickly
some of the courses available to under-
graduates and graduates interested in
computers:
Math. 73. 1 credit hr. A new course
which teaches a compiler (Fortran or
MAD for the IBM 704) as it illustrates
certain basic features of numerical anal-
ysis, such as numerical integration and
numerical solutions to differential equa-
tions.
Math. 173- 3 credit hrs. An intro-
duction to the computing field contain-
ing the algorithm concept, use of flow
diagrams, Boolean algebra, number sys-
tems with bases other than 10, ele-
mentary logical circuit design, as well as
laboratory work in the three types of
machine programming outlined above.
Math. 174. 3 credit hrs. An extensive
numerical analysis course, with some
problems done on computers.
Philosophy 114. 3 credit hrs. Mathe-
matical logic with some applications to
computers.
Philosophy 113. 3 credit hrs. More

Industrial Engineering 165. 3 credit
hrs. Data processing. A survey of ap-
proximately the same material included
in Math. 173 without the laboratory
programming, from the industrial engi-
neer's viewpoint.
Electrical Engineering 232. Analog
and digital computer technology. Much
of the material presented in Math. 173,
without the programming experience
from the laboratory, presented from the

Electrical Engineering 233. 2 credit
hrs. Theory of switching from a mathe-
matical logical approach whenever possi-
ble.
Electrical Engineering 235. 3 credit

both practical and theoretical topics be-
ing discussed.
Electrical Engineering 238. 3 credit
hrs. Usually offered in the summer, this
course is a survey of most of the topics
covered also in Math. 173.
Business Administration School: Statis-
tics 150. 3 credit hrs. Data processing
and programming from the business
viewpoint. It includes machine code and
an assembly program, but does not usually
discuss compiler programs.
Of the above courses, eight of them
presuppose no computer experience:
Math. 73, Math. 173, Stat. 150, I.E.

SERVES BUSINESS
THR0U6H
ELECTRONICS

RCA Electronics creates the "501" to streamline the paper work
of business —it reads, writes, figures and remembers on tape
Much of today's traffic jam in paper
work is being eliminated by electronic
data processing. But to build a system
that would be practical and economical
for even medium-sized organizations
was a job for electronic specialists.
To solve the problem, RCA drew on
its broad experience in building com-
puters for military applications and
combed its many laboratories for the
latest electronic advances that could
help. The result was the RCA "501"
high-speed electronic data processing
system—the most compact, flexible, and
economical ever built. It is a pioneer sys-
tem with all-transistor construction for
business use.
The "501" cuts out paper work bottle-
necks for many government agencies
and businesses, from stock brokerage
firms to public utilities, banks, insurance
companies, and steel mills.
It "remembers" millions of letters,
numbers, and symbols that are "read"
onto its magnetic tapes by such things
as punch cards and paper tapes. In a
fraction of a second, it can do thousands
of calculating, sorting, and comparing
operations—and checks each step.
Finally, it writes such things as bills, re-

ports, payrolls in plain English at 72,000
characters per minute.
This economical and practical answer
to an acute business problem is another
way RCA Electronics is helping to sim-
plify the growing complexity of business.

(Continued from page 23)
of the decay of these particles were not
identical, therefore they must be different
particles.
The question lingered: why were the
two particles identical in every way ex-
cept this one? It was Lee and Yang who
proposed a solution to the problem. They
boldly suggested that in the case of these
particles the law of parity was not obeyed.
It has been observed that these decays
of the tau and theta were of a class of
newly discovered "weak interactions".
These are nuclear interactions in which
the forces involved are very weak, weaker
even than the force that binds the elec-
trons of an atom. It was suggested by
Lee and Yang that while parity might
hold for all other realms, it need not
hold for the world of tau and theta
decay and other weak interactions.
The Experiment
To verify their theory, they proposed
an experiment. The tau and theta dis-
integrations were too short-lived to ob-
tain satisfactory results. However, the
beta decay of atomic nuclei also belongs
to the group of weak interactions. These
beta decays have a much longer life
time; measured in seconds or even years
depending on the material. Lee and
Yang's proposal for the experiment was
to align the spins of a beta emitting)
nucleus and then observe whether or not
the beta particles were emitted along
a preferred direction. The direction
would have no significance. If parity were
obeyed in this experiment, then it was
expected that the particles would be
emitted equally in all directions. Let us
apply the parity principles and see what
would happen.
In a mirror the spinning nuclei would
rotate in the same sense. However, if
the beta particles were emitted in a pre-
ferred direction, the direction of emission
would be reversed in the image. (Figure
5.) In figure five, if the particles are
emitted along a preferred direction the
mirror image is reversed (situation marked
wrong). This violates parity; to conserve
parity the electrons must be emitted in
both directions to make the mirror image
coincide with the real object. As was
found out in the experiment the mirror
image contradicted the actual situation.
Parity was not conserved!
The experiment was carried out in the
National Bureau of Standards laboratory

in Washington, D.C, by C. S. Wu of

Cobalt 60 decays and emits an electron

magnetic field was applied to align cer-

remaining nuclei which brought them
into line parallel to the magnetic field.
Under this arrangement the nuclei were
kept oriented for 15 minutes.

NOVEMBER, 1959
37


AND
RESEARCH
by BARRY E. PEEBLES, '60E
A quick trip through the portals and
hallways of the U-M buildings and re-
search establishments brings us in rapid
succession to such topics as the dedica-
tion of U-M's new 85-foot radio tele-
scope, a study of automation and ob-
solescence, the "flare patrol", and a few
interesting notes on the education and
faculty scene. So without further ado
let's be off to Peach Mountain and the
new telescope
Telescope Dedicated
Development of instruments like the
University of Michigan's new, 85-foot
steerable radio telescope, which was dedi-
cated in October, should lead to a rapid
accumulation of astrophysical knowledge
in the next few years.
At the dedication ceremonies for the
10-story high telescope U-M Prof. Fred
T. Haddock said the instrument can be
used "to track continuously an active
region on the sun and measure the posi-
tion and possible movement of sources
of centimeter wave emission in the sun's
atmosphere.
A professor of both astronomy and
electrical engineering, Haddock directs
the U-M radio astronomy project. Dis-
cussing the potential value of studies
conducted with the radio telescope, he
continued:
"In studying solar radio bursts we ob-
tain information on a variety of natural
physical processes which may be at work
in other radio sources. This should lead
to a deeper understanding of the physics
of very high temperature gases in mag-
netic fields. A gain in understanding may
in turn prove useful in the design of
hydrogen fusion power sources, space
propulsion engines, or man-made radio
generators, for example.
"The non-solar phase of our research
program . . . This phase involves centi-
meter wavelength studies of planets and
cosmic radio sources.
"Radiation in the centimeter wave-
length band has been measured from the
planets, Venus, Jupiter, Mars, and Saturn
by other U.S. groups. With the master
receiver developed at the U-M's Willow
Run Laboratories it is hoped that we
will be able to detect emission from the
planet Uranus."
Accepting the radio telescope on be-
half of the University, Vice President for
Research Ralph A. Sawyer noted the
device will serve "not only as a unique
and powerful research tool, but also as
a laboratory for the training of graduate
students in astronomy."
The telescope, located at Peach Moun-
tain, about 16 miles northwest of Ann
Arbor, Sawyer said might have been
placed in another location, freer of
electromagnetic disturbances, had it not
been viewed as an important addition to
the U-M's educational program.
Professor D. L. Kafz, chairman of the
C-M Department, was recently named
the Engineer of the Year by the Mich-
igan Society of Engineers. Professor Katz
is also serving as the national chairman
of A.S.C.E. this year.
Automation and Dignity
Automation and obsolescence should
be viewed more as a measure of man's
progresses and less as a cause for con-
cern, says Aarre K. Lahti, University of
Michigan professor of design.
"Obsolescence, to me, is a measure of
learning and automation is a measure of
human dignity. The more rapidly we
learn, the faster our present concepts,
ideas and output become obsolete," he
says.
"Too many things are becoming ob-
solete at a terrifying rate in our day. It
isn't so much that we are 'shooting
through the roof where this pace is con-
cerned, as that we are 'finally leveling
off' and 'getting going'."
"A repetitive activity reproduceable by
machines is below the dignity of human
performance," Lahti continues. "Our so-
38
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


ciety can no longer afford the luxury of
unskilled labor. We are faced with the
long overdue task of boosting our ob-
jectives upward—that is, the unskilled
must become the skilled, the skilled must
become the technicians. Those at the top
must scurry to broaden their activities to
meet greater responsibility for human
welfare and to find new philosophies
for living."
Flare Patrol
A minute-by-minute watch of the sun
is being maintained by University of
Michigan astronomers studying solar
flares. The flares are believed to be more
guilty than sunspots of causing the
"jamming" of short-wave radio signals.
The flare patrol work began during
the International Geophysical Year
(IGY) and now is conducted under a
National Science Foundation grant. Prin-
cipal investigator is Orren C. Mohler
(Ph.D), professor of astronomy and
assistant director of the U-M McMath-
Hulbert observatory at Lake Angelus near
Pontiac.
Continuation of the program is part
of a long-term, world-wide effort to
clarify some of the relationships between
solar phenomena and numerous terrestrial
effects, among the most conspicuous of
which are severe disturbances in long
distance wireless and wired communica-
tion.
The connection between sunspots and
flares is not yet accurately understood,
but it is known that sunspots accompan-
ied by flares are the most effective—but
not the only—source of radio interfer-
ence.
It is believed that the flares inject
"puffs" of energy into the earth's at-
mosphere, with an adverse effect on
short-wave and telegraphic communica-
tion. The form of this energy has not
been identified, but astronomers theorize
it could be x-radiation, ultraviolet light,
or actual streams of ions. An ion is an
atom which has gained or lost an electron
and which therefore has a positive or
negative charge.
Whatever its form, the energy dis-
turbs the ionosphere, a layer of elec-
Professor Donald L. Katz.
Michigan's recently dedicated 85 foot
radio telescope is now in full use at
Peach Mountain, 18 miles northwest of
Ann Arbor.
trically charged particles about 100 miles
above the earth against which short-wave
signals are bounced in transmitting sig-
nals to great distances.
The disturbance of the ionosphere
causes "storms" in the earth's magnetic
field which can produce large currents
in electric transmission cables. An aurora
borealis is visible evidence of a magnetic
storm.
Observations are made with a special-
ized telescope of French manufacture.
With it, 35-mm pictures can be taken
every half-minute. If the sun is very
active, picture-taking speed can be in-
creased to eight per minute. On a clear
day, about 1,000 shots are made.
Two of the most difficult research
problems are posed by the observation
that not all flares are followed by dis-
turbances on earth, and that the dis-
turbance can follow closely after the flare
or days later. Hence, a significant aspect
of the flare patrol is to work out a way
to determine which flares will affect
earth, and which won't, and, if so, when.
Four University of Michigan Scientists
had roles in the 15th annual National
Electronics Conference held in Chicago
October 12-14.

Processing Techniques" by L. J. Cutrona,
(Ph.D.), E. N. Leith and L J. Porcello
