An Editor of a Top Engineering Publication?
JACK CARROLL, MANAGING EDITOR OF ELECTRONICS MAGAZINE,
ROSE TO A TOP POST IN LESS THAN TEN YEARS
Are Jack Carroll's shoes your size?
"If it's scope you want, try keeping on top of every-
thing that's hot in electronics," says John M. Carroll,
electronics' Managing Editor at McGraw-Hill Pub-
lishing Company.
A Lehigh B.S. graduate in 1950, Jack has become
an industry authority in less than 10 years. "Knowing
that the industry itself is looking to your magazine
for the word on things is the most stimulating part
about it. It's your job to get the thinking of the men
behind everything that's new in the field. You work
with the top of the profession. What engineer can
resist that?"
Wrote in College
In his senior year at Lehigh, Jack got his first real
taste of writing as editor of the college newspaper. He
joined McGraw-Hill as editorial assistant on elec-
tronics in 1950, took a 17-month "leave" in Korea,
then became assistant editor in 1952 and associate
editor in '54.
"By then I'd got my M.A. in physics at Hofstra on
the McGraw-Hill Tuition Refund Plan, where the
company pays half the cost. And since I was pro-
moted to managing editor in 1957, I've been working
after hours on my doctorate in engineering science at
N.Y.U. This is an engineer's outfit. You grow right
along with your industry at McGraw-Hill," says Jack.
"The engineer who chooses a McGraw-Hill career
need have no fear of winding up in a corner on one
part of one project. You work with the new . . . the
experimental . . . the significant. Sitting down with
the leaders of your field is part of the job. Your as-
signment? Interpreting today's advanced thinking for
the rest of your field."
McGraw-Hill Tuition Refund Plan
All of our editors have the opportunity to continue
their education in their chosen fields under the
McGraw-Hill Tuition Refund Plan. Physics, econom-
ics, aerodynamics, and business management are typi-
cal of the courses they may choose.
You May Be The Right Man
How about writing experience? It helps, but if you
like to write—and engineering is your profession—
that's the main thing.
Would you like to learn what opportunities
McGraw-Hill offers in your field? Write for "Careers
in Publishing At McGraw-Hill." Tell us about your
background,, college record, outside activities and
why you seek a career in engineering journalism.
Write to: The Editorial Director, McGraw-Hill
Publishing Co., Inc., 330 West 42nd Street, New
York 36, New York.

NOVEMBER, 1959 41


nuclei, i.e. with or against the magnetic
field. However, the experiment showed
that 40% more beta particles were
emitted in a line against the magnetic
field. It was found that the particles were
emitted up when the spin was turning
in one direction and down when the spin
was in the other direction. Under the
conditions of this experiment parity was
not conserved. Remember that the spin
of the nucleus tells only the sense of
rotation and yet electrons emerged in
a preferred direction. From the fact that
there was a definite "handedness" ex-
hibited by cobalt 60 decay and that there
had not been found in nature the "op-
posite hand", it was concluded that parity
had been overthrown.
The results of this experiment were
verified a few weeks later by another
experiment. This time the decay of the
mu meson was observed.
Figure 6 shows the actual curves from
the cobalt experiment. The scale labeled
"time" is actually a scale of temperature.
The curve marked "gamma anisotrophy"
(Continued from page 34)
tells the fraction of nuclei oriented. The
curve labeled "B asymmetry" tells the
number of beta particles emerging in the
direction of the magnetic field and the
number in the opposite direction. We
can see that there are more in one
direction than in the other.
Advance, Not Setback
As a result of these experiments the
field of weak interactions will be studied
with greater intensity in an attempt to
discover the laws which govern these
reactions. Theoretical physicists have only
begun to investigate the possible impli-
cations of these discoveries. One over-all
lesson was learned from the downfall
of this basic law. This is that all the
great invariant laws of nature such as
the conservation of energy and mass may
be relied upon within the realms of their
application, but they are not necessarily
of universal application. It will be worth-
while for physicists to test to a higher
degree of precision the other laws of
nature, including the conservation of
energy and matter. As fas as scientists
have gone the conservation of energy
has held, even in the weak interactions,
but the question arises: does it hold for
the weakest interaction of all—the force
of gravity?
The discovery of the overthrow of
parity may not be a new, ready made,
theory, but by removing a false theory
it may lead to an explanation of the
behavior of the now 30-plus sub-atomic
particles which are the building blocks
of the whole universe. Other theories
such as special relativity and quantum
theory, which were based on the false
parity principle, should be re-examined.
This possibly could lead to a Unified
Field Theory which Einstein sought. Such
a theory would encompass all the laws of
matter, energy, and the universe and
could lead to a bridge between the micro-
physical world of nuclear physics and the
cosmology. This discovery certainly is
not a setback, rather it is an advance
which has opened the doors to the under-
standing of the physical world.

help airplanes haul
bigger payloads

In an airliner, every pound of weight saved is worth hundreds of dollars
... in revenue-making payload. And in military aircraft, pounds saved mean
added miles-per-hour... or added load carried.
In commercial products ... trucks, cars, materials-handling equipment...
the pounds of dead weight you eliminate by using forgings make money
year-after-year for the operator. The forging process lets you put the metal exactly
where you need it to carry the load, withstand shock or vibration,
endure torsion. And with not a surplus ounce of non-working weight going
along just for the ride.
Forged parts are the designer's friend... strong where strength is needed,
lowest in weight, twice-worked by original rolling of the best metals
plus the hammer blows or high pressures of the forging process.

TECHNIC
SPOTLIGHTS
PROGRESS
Compiled by MAX LEGATSKI, '61E
Work Begins on World's
Biggest Engineering Center
Ground breaking ceremonies for the
United Engineering Center, a multi-mil-
lion dollar, eighteen-story structure to
be erected opposite the United Nations
in New York City, were held Thursday,
October 1, 1959, at 11:00 a.m. Former
President Herbert Hoover, representing
the older generation of engineers, shared
earth-turning honors with a freshman
engineering student from Hawaii, Jerry
Fujimoto, representing engineers of the
future.
To occupy a block between 47th and
48th Streets, on United Nations Plaza
(First Avenue), the Center will house
the headquarters of eighteen major engi-
neering societies with a combined mem-
bership of more than 300,000. Together,
the societies are responsible for a major
part of the nation's technical publications,
industrial standards and engineering con-
ferences.
Mr. Fujimoto, an American citizen of
Japanese extraction, enrolled this fall at
Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Troy,
New York. He is described as a member
of the newest engineering class, entering
the oldest engineering college in the
country from the newest state in the
Union.
Upon applying for admission to RPI,
college officials revealed, Mr. Fujimoto
wrote, "I have set my goal for the very
top and I will seek it with all my might.
There is the likelihood I will not reach
it; but no matter what heights I may
reach, I will be assured that it will be
higher up the ladder than the height I
might have reached if I were satisfied
with mediocrity."
Several thousand persons were invited
to the October 1 ceremonies, including
representatives of foreign engineering
groups. Major excavation work began
later in the month. The new structure,
scheduled for completion in mid-1961,
will be the largest undertaking ever at-
tempted for the engineering profession.
Plans for the Center have been over
eight years in the making. A fund-raising
campaign has already achieved nearly $5
million in contributions from industry
and $3 million in contributions from
individual engineers.
Andrew Fletcher, president of United
Engineering Trustees, the organization
that will own and operate the structure
on behalf of the engineering societies,
said that, "the primary purpose of the
new structure is to provide adequate
working space for the headquarters staffs
of the engineering groups, which carry
on extensive publishing, research and
standardization programs." The second
purpose, he added, "will be to symbolize
the growing strength and growing unity
of the engineering profession."
'Lazy-Susan' Steel Mold
A steel company has borrowed the
principle of the "lazy-susan" serving dish
in building a series of vacuum-sealed
steel ingot molds. The molds are mounted
in a vacuum-drum enclosed turntable,
which rotates each mold in turn beneath
a 30-ton ladle to receive its charge of
steel.
Collapsible Dam
The Los Angeles Department of Water
and Power has invented a collapsible
synthetic rubber tube dam that saves it
about $75,000 worth of water annually.
Water fills the 150-foot-long tube dam,
which is fastened to a channel bottom,
and inflates it about five feet high. When
flood waters reach a given height, the
tube drains and collapses, allowing the
flood to pass.
Offshore Sulfur Mine
The world's first offshore sulfur mine,
seven miles out in the Gulf of Mexico
off Grand Isle, La., will soon begin oper-
ations. An underwater pipeline heated
by pressurized hot water will carry the
molten sulfur to Grand Isle for pro-
cessing and transshipment.
World's Largest Magnet
The world's largest permanent magnet
is scheduled to work in America's atomic
energy program. It will help pump
liquid sodium in a breeder reactor to
be operated by the Argonne National
Laboratory for the Atomic Energy Com-
mission. To be known as the Experi-
mental Breeder Reactor II, this reactor

eering Center. The building, which will
house eighteen engineering societies,
is located on the United Nations Plaza.
will produce electrical power on the
Argonne Idaho Division site at the Na-

Falls, Idaho.
The magnet, made by The Arnold
Engineering Company of Marengo, 111.,
weighs 1720 pounds, and is made of
AInico V material. The overall dimen-

10 inches. It has a gap length of l6]/2
inches and a gap volume of 1584 cubic
inches. The density at the center of the
gap is 1100 gausses. About 500,000
ampere turns were needed to magnetize
the unit.
It is customary to use an electromagnet
in pumping the liquid sodium in this
atomic energy application, but in this
instance a large permanent magnet must
be used because the magnet will be
completely surrounded by the liquid
metal.
The magnet was checked in a 3000
hour test at temperatures up to 750
degrees F. prior to its being put into
service at the Argonne National Labora-
tory.
The sodium used in the reactor acts
as a heat transfer medium or "coolant"
in much the same way as water can be
utilized, but sodium does the job better.
The liquid sodium absorbs heat from
within the reactor, then it is pumped


outside to heat water in a heat exchanger filaments or cathodes through the prin-
or boiler. ciple of electroluminescence.
Lit Up Furniture

Sugar Pipeline
Sugar cane is being moved from field
to factory in pipelines by a Hawaiian
sugar company. Chopped in small pieces,
cane is pumped in water through the
pipe.
Car Periscope
A new automobile rearview mirror—
using a periscope effect—gives a driver
more than twice the view of present
mirrors although the new mirror is only
two inches longer than today's average
one. The periscope uses a 24-inch cylin-
drical lens two inches high, another lens
a 15-inch square mirror and the driver's
mirror. All units, except the driver's
glass are set in the roof of the car.

(Continued from page 21)
is what keeps it rolling in that straight
line. If, instead of rolling, it spins around
an axis through its center, the same
inertia will keep it spinning in its geo-
metric plane of rotation until it loses
speed.
Precession is not so readily explained.
Such an explanation involves a study in
kinetics which is beyond scope of this
article. A ready example may be visual-
ized, however, if you can remember roll-
ing an auto tire by hand. To change the
direction in which the tire is rolled, it
was only necessary to push right or left
at the top ... no one ever had to twist
at that point and certainly no one ever
bent way down to push at the front or
rear. Pushing right or left at the top
brought about a precession of the rolling
tire which changed its direction of roll.
Suppose the gimbal in which the rotor
is mounted is a sealed sphere . . . con-
sider it a rubber ball for purposes of
illustration. Suppose also that this rubber
ball (with the rotor inside) has a neutral
buoyancy in water (it weighs exactly the
amount of an equal volume of water).
These suppositions being true, the ball
will be fully floated, but completely im-
mersed. With the wheel spinning inside,
this ball will have its own stability. If
the axis around which the rotor is spin-
ning (called the spin axis) happens to
point toward a star, it will remain so
aligned as long as the wheel continues
to spin and no external forces are applied
to cause precession. Thus, disregarding
the friction between the water and the
ball (which would actually cause some
precession) the container may be moved
as desired without effect on the position
of the ball. Basically, this simple illus-
tration is analogous to the operation of
a gyro.
The ball in this example represents a
stable object in space. If the water con-
tainer were affixed to an airplane, its
motions would represent the movements
of the airplane; thus the airplane would
move around the stable ball. If some
means of measuring these movements
could be provided, this device might
prove very useful; for example, in de-
termining the airplane's deviations from
straight and level flight. Water, however,
is not conducive to providing any such
measurement means. It is essential, there-
fore, that the motion between container
and ball, as described in the example,
be simulated mechanically. It is seen that
the device is of no practical value as a
means of measuring linear movements.
Gyros measure only rotational move-
ments.
The rotor in the toy gyro mentioned
earlier might be kept spinnnig for several
minutes with a strong pull of the string.
An instrument system, however, must of-
ten operate for hours, and some means
of sustaining wheel rotation must be
provided. In a vast majority of cases,
this means an electric motor. To increase
the gyroscopic effects of the spining mass,
this is an inverted motor (the rotor spins
outside the stator). Air motors, spring
wound motors and a variety of other

A typical demonstration gyroscope
similar to those used in the laboratory,
displays the same properties of naviga-
tion.
means have also been employed, depend-
ing on the detail requirements of the
intended end use.
The string-activated toy gyro ran for
several minutes at most. As its speed of
rotation decreased, the spin axis began
to tip, becoming progressively less stable.
Finally it lost stability completely and
toppled over. From this action, it is ap-
parent that the wheel speed is at least
one factor in the gyro's stability. Actually,
this stability depends on:
1. The speed at which the mass
(rotor) rotates.
2. The amount of mass (effectively
the weight).
3. The radius at which the mass
is rotated.
The net effect of these three factors is
known as the gyro's angular momentum,
normally expressed in gram-centimeter2
per second (e.g., 6.0 x 10r' gm-cm2/sec.).
The higher the momentum, the more
resistance the wheel will have to external
forces. This is often expressed as the
wheel rigidity, stiffness or stability.
Mr. HIG
There are many different types of
gyros but only one will be described . . .
Mr. HIG. Mr. HIG's motor is fully
floated in a special fluid and constrained
in a single axis by means of jewelled
pivots (which establish the precession or
output axis). Mr. HIG is restrained only
by the fluid which tends to impede pre-
cession of the motor housing. This tend-
ency of the fluid to impede precession
is a fixed amount, depending upon the
fluid viscosity, the area, etc. A rate input
to the gyro results in a precession which
overcomes the fluid restraint. However,
for any given input rate (and resultant
precession torque), this fixed restraint
controls the amount of precession as a
function of time (how long the pre-
cession torque is applied). Thus the
displacement of the spin axis (and the
pickoff) is always proportional to the
displacement of the gyro (rate x time =
amount). Thus the gyro receives a rate
input, performs an integration (summing
of rates and times), and produces an
output signal which is proportional to
displacement.
Use of Mr. HIG as a single axis dis-
placement reference involves some ex-
ternal electronics (such as memory cir-
cuits) and his construction is comparably
critical in terms of manufacturing toler-
ances (certain parts have to be polished
to the finess of 1/10,000,000,000 of an
inch — 2,500 times finer than a human
hair).
Today, gyros enable our missiles and
submarines to function properly, but to-
morrow they have even greater possibili-
ties, such as using the rotational move-
ment of electrons to do their work. But
no matter what its form, the gyro is
here to stay.

Sylvania Encourages Scientific Heretics
Who Can Utilize Unique and Unorthodox Thinking in
Making State-of-the-Art Advances in Electronics, Electronic
Countermeasures, Metallurgy, Semiconductors, Radar,

To the young engineer and scientist

who can combine unorthodox percep-

tends a climate of achievement. From
these men, Sylvania foresees a number
of tomorrow's breakthroughs. If your
ambition is to attain your fullest pro-
fessional potential, these facts about
Sylvania —one of the world's fastest
growing industrial organizations —
merit your close attention.
Started as a basement industry
manufacturing incandescent lamps
only 59 years ago, Sylvania today has
23 laboratories and 46 plants located
in 14 states across the nation. These
69 modern facilities afford employ-
ment to over 30,000 people. In the
last 25 years sales have climbed from
$6,000,000 to over i/3 of a billion dol-
lars. Strong as this industrial base is
for the engineer and scientist, it was
substantially reinforced in February
1959 when Sylvania merged with
General Telephone Corporation. The
merger of these two growth com-
panies will:

growth and development
• Add further diversification to al-
ready broad commercial and defense
product lines
• Measurably increase research and
development facilities
• Give Sylvania the benefit of
General Telephone's wide experi-
ence and background in foreign
manufacturing and sales.
Sylvania Prizes Individuality

have long been based on the belief
that the success of the organization
depends upon the personal success of
the individual. The engineer/scientist-
oriented management has given much
thought and study to provide an en-

and creativity. Here you are assigned

frequently reviewed.

Large-Organization Strength

Flexibility

Whether your interests center on

research articles, active participation

meetings of engineering and profes-
sional societies. It has long been

measurable importance to both the
company and the individual, for com-
munication increases comprehension
and scientific curiosity—which are the
forces that spark experimentation and
discovery.

Learn now that society will provide for you. Just because you are you. Just because
you are paying for an education doesn't mean you have to get your money's worth.
Don't be ridiculous. "If the learner hasn't learned," it isn't your fault, surely.
1. GENERAL ATTITUDE—The B.B.A. degree is valuable. Successful grads have made
it so. It is valuable because they produced. Let them keep up the good work, but don't
prepare to rob them of their glory, to increase the value.
2. BE YOUTHFUL—Be young while you can. Why discard those good old high school
days—and ways? Don't grow up until you just have to. People will always be under-
standing and appreciative of your adolescence.
3. DRESS—Be yourself, dress naturally. Those business people can be very stuffy
about sartorial matters. On that first job, they'll probably start you off as a porter any-
way, so' why not look like one?
4. AROMATICS—The pungency of the locker room can be carried with you. A gamey
"athletic" odor is a great personal asset—in class and out, in business and out—and
fast. Carry your own atmosphere—be "aromatic."
5. RELAX, ENJOY IT—A stiff posture restricts absorption. Spread yourself figura-
tively. Chairs in front, occupied or not, are fine for parking feet, thus facilitating relaxation.
6. MENTAL EFFORT—Some say that brain cells, like liquor bottles, can not be used
twice. Save them, coddle them, spare them—in class and out. The mind(?) you save
may be your own.
7. DON'T ANTICIPATE—Who knows what might happen tomorrow—or for that matter
next week, when the paper is due? Don't do it ahead of time—nothing might happen.
Then you'd have no excuse.
8. ACCURACY—Is for the birds. A misplaced decimal point is embarrassing but not
critical. You can always do it right when and if you get a job (on the basis of your ex-
cellant school record, of course).
9. DON'T WRITE, TELEGRAPH—Legibility went out with long underwear. None of the
really big wheels like Napoleon, Hitler, or even Confucius—could write good English.
10. SPELLING—Why bring that up? Phonetics are out, "word picture" didn't work, so
your generation just can't spell. Everyone understands and is so sorry. You are unique
—now don't go and spoil it.
11. LATE PAPERS—Promptness here is a sign of servility. Be independent. Be different.
A few days late shouldn't matter, especially if you use a good standard explanation.
12. BE LATE—A "fashionable" entrance, after everyone else is seated, and the class
is moving along—this calls attention to one, definitely. You can also be so ignorant
about what has gone before and get the spotlight again.
13. ATTEND IRREGULARLY—That's the stuff. Always being there is dreadfully bor-
ing. After all, one meeting is like another and the instructor gets tired of your face, too.
14. BE CONVERSATIONAL—Talk it up. If the old buzzard doesn't make it interesting,
it surely can't be interesting to your neighbor, can it? Competition is good for business,
so why not for business educators?
15. PREPARATION—A dangerous habit. Here again, let's don't anticipate. A heavy
snow might make the work useless. And—the instructor might resent having you come to
class one day knowing what he is talking about.
16. (BUT OTHERWISE) CLAM UP—Don't ever venture an opinion, don't defend a
point; let some other jerk stick his neck out. Remember it may be better to remain silent
and be thought ignorant—than to open one's mouth and remove all doubt.
17. ON YOUR MARK—Don't get left at the post when the bell rings. A rustling of
papers and plopping of books indicates alertness on your part to the hour of parting and
reminds the Professor accordingly.
18. REPETITION—A powerful force. Ii the files show that someone did a good paper
on the topic last year, why should such a gem be discarded? The instructor will never
recognize it if your pal was at MSU.
19. PLAGIARISM—If in preparing a paper you find that some author has said it
better than you can; and a long time ago—don't dull initiative. Let him have his way—
in your paper, too. It should be flattering to him.
52 THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC

Compiled by DAVE McCORY '61 LSA
All of you ambitious scholars (and
even the seniors) should have your mind
limbered up, after the siege of mid-term
exams, so let's see how well you can
do with this month's Tecbnic Teasers.
1. What two numbers composed of
only ones will give the same results by
their addition or multiplication?
2. A boat is carrying cement blocks
in a small pond. It capsizes and the
blocks drop to the bottom of the pond.
The boat is righted and emptied of
water. The question is: Will the level
of the pond rise or drop because of the
blocks on the bottom?
3. A checker board has two squares in
diagonally opposite corners removed. You
have 31 dominos which each can cover
two squares and you are asked to place
them upon the remaining 62 squares on
the checkerboard so that each square is
covered with half of a domino. The
dominos are unfortunately uncuttable.
After trying this task, and I suggest
you do so on paper, you will find it quite
impossible. Now here is the question:
Why is it impossible?
Warning: The answer, although elus-
ive, is very simple, so if you want to
be able to live with yourself, give it a
good try.
4. What is the smallest number in
which the digits are reversed when 2
is added to its double?
5. A number of chickens and horses
are standing in a barn. The total number
of heads and wings equals the number
of feet. What percentage of the total
number of animals are horses?
6. Three Indians, two Crows and one
Blackfoot, were confronted by a tourist.
Now Crows have the habit of always
lying to tourists, but a Blackfoot never
tells a lie. The tourist, aware of these
habits, asked the first of these Indians
his nationality. The Indian replied in a
dialect the tourist could not understand.
So he asked the other Indians what the
first had said. The second replied that
the first had said he was a Crow, but
the third answered that the first had
said that he was a Blackfoot. If you
were the tourist what type of Indian
would you say each was?
7. In ancient times the neophyte in
logic was posed such questions as:
If half of 5 were 3, what would a
third of 10 be?
8. Suppose that you have a bucket
containing a gallon of water and a demi-
john containing a gallon of wine. Meas-
ure out a pint of wine, pour it into the
water, and mix thoroughly. Then measure
out a pint of the mixture from the
bucket and pour it into the demijohn.
At the end of these strange proceed-
ings, have you more or less water in the
demijohn than there is wine in the
bucket?
9. Anyone who pulls out pencil and
paper for this one is disqualified and
must transfer to fine arts. If a brick
balances evenly with three quarters of
a pound and three quarters of a brick,
what is the weight of a whole brick?
Quick!

W. C. Sadler
Walter Clifford Sadler, professor
emeritus of civil engineering, died Wed-
nesday, Oct. 14, at the age of 68.
Professor Sadler joined the U-M fac-
ulty in 1925 as an assistant professor of
civil engineering. He was promoted to
associate professor in 1933 and to full
professorship in 1941.
Very active in civic affairs, he served
as mayor of Ann Arbor for two terms
in the four years, 1937-41. He also was
president of the city council for two
years and alderman for another two
years.

He held four degrees. He attended

and the Civil Engineer (professional de-

Master of Science degree from the Massa-
chusetts Institute of Technology. The
University of Michigan granted him the
Bachelor of Laws degree in 1930.
Professor Ernest Boyce
Prof. Ernest Boyce, professor of mu-
nicipal and sanitary engineering and
chairman of The University of Michigan
Civil Engineering Department, has been
named an honorary member of the Fed-
eration of Sewage and Industrial Wastes
Association.
He received the honorary membership
certificate at a dinner Oct. 14 during the
Association's Annual Meeting in Dallas,
Texas, Oct. 12-15.

a hand in things to come
Probing the atom... for you
The boundless energy of the uranium atom means a brighter future
Every day brings the benefits of atomic energy closer to our
daily living. It presents a whole new field of exploration for scientists all
over the world.
A longer, healthier life is hopefully ahead as radiation is help-
ing doctors learn more about the basic processes of life by revealing how
certain elements are put to work by the body. The controlled rays of the
atom are also being used to pin-point malignant tissues for subsequent treat-
ment. And radiation studies of how plants absorb nutrition from sun and
soil are showing the way to improved food supplies.
These are but a few of the vital jobs being done by radioisotopes
—radioactive materials created in atomic reactors at Oak Ridge, Tennessee
. . . the great atomic energy center operated by Union Carbide for the U. S.
Atomic Energy Commission. The people of Union Carbide will continue
their pioneering research in atomic energy—and in the vital fields of alloys,
carbons, chemicals, gases and plastics—to bring you a brighter future.

chemicals, gases, metals, plastics

UNLIMITED

DUNHAM-BUSH


DEANE KEUCH
Purdue University '53
'eane Keuch, one of 136 Dunham-Bush sales
engineers, knows the advantages of being associated with a
dynamic young company with extensive product lines.
Following his engineering studies at Purdue, Deane joined
Dunham-Bush as a trainee and soon became an application
engineer. After a relatively short time he was assigned his own
territory, working out of the Cleveland area sales office.
In calling on consulting engineers, architects, plant engineers,
wholesalers, contractors and building owners, Deane (like all
Dunham-Bush sales engineers) finds it reassuring to be backed by
his area office and the facilities of Dunham-Bush laboratories.
Equally reassuring is the availability of complete lines. The range
of Dunham-Bush refrigeration products runs from compressors
to complete systems; the range of air conditioning products
extends from motel room conditioners to a hospital's entire air
conditioning plant. The heating line is equally complete: from a
radiator valve to zone heating control for an entire apartment
housing project. The Dunham-Bush product family even includes
specialized heat transfer products applicable to missile use.
If you'd like to know more about the company
that offers "Sales Engineering Unlimited", send for a copy of
"This is Dunham-Bush".
DURHflm/BUSH
AIR CONDITIONING. REFRIGERATION.
HEATING PRODUCTS AND ACCESSORIES
Dunham-Bush, Inc.

S. A.
COMPUTING
AT MICHIGAN
(Continued jrom page 32)
search pays $300 hour for the same fa-
cilities) for work on worthwhile prob-
lems of their own.
The University of Michigan Comput-
ing Center is equipped with an IBM 704
computer and a library of useful sub-
routines of common functions. It also has
extensive peripheral equipment such as
reproducing punches, card punches, card
sorters, an IBM 407 printer, etc. As well
as student problems, the facilities are
used for work of the UMRI, Survey
Research Institute, and other campus re-
search organizations.
From this brief survey of the computer
opportunities at this University, one of
the leaders in the field, it is already
apparent that computers are going to
have an increasingly more profound ef-
fect upon engineering, business, and
science education. Already approximately
1,000 students per year are taking part
in at least one computer-oriented course
at this university. It is likely that the
type of engineering education also is
going to be affected. When one can grind
out exact or nearly exact answers on a
computer, there will be no need for the
crude approximations and rules of thumb
approved by the engineering societies as
good engineering practice. Using com-
puters should force engineers to learn
the most general approaches and will
make it necessary for them to know far
more mathematics.
As the computer field develops, more
and more people will be able to use
computers while knowing fewer and few-
er details of their operation, by using
elaborate compilers like the MAD (Mich-
igan Algorithmic Decoder) which is
being developed for the IBM 704. How-
ever, the people who have problems
which must be done at machine level to
be done efficiently must use an assembly
program and know more and more details
about the machine they are using. And
finally someone must design new larger,
faster machines that may rival or even
surpass the human intellect in some re-
spects. It seems likely that all these
types of people can be educated as an
evolutionary consequent of current edu-
cational policies of the University.

A farmer was driving past an insane
asylum with a load of fertilizer when
an inmate called to him:
"What are you hauling there?"
"Fertilizer," replied the farmer.
"What are you going to do with it?"
"Put it on my strawberries."
"You ought to live here, we get cream
and sugar on ours."

A deaf old lady entered the church
with an ear trumpet. As she was settling
herself in her seat, an usher came over
and whispered, "Listen, madam, one
toot—and out you go!"

A young engineer got a job in a re-
mote mining camp. On his first day off,
he approached the boss and asked: "Say,
boss, what do you folks do around here
for amusement?"
The boss replied, "Well, all of us
usually watch Sam, the cook, drink a
gallon of whiskey, gasoline, and red
pepper juice. It's the funniest thing you
ever saw. Why don't you come along?"
The young engineer was obviously
shocked. "No thanks," he said, "I don't
go for that kind of amusement."
"Well," answered the boss, "I sure
wish you'd come. We really need six men
for this thing."
"Why is that?" asked the new man.
"Some of the boys have to hold Sam.
He don't go for that kind of amusement
either."
Three small boys were sitting on a
curb. One had a model airplane; one a
fire engine, and one was reading Es-
quire. An elderly gentleman stopped and
asked what they wanted to be when they
grew up.
The first said, "An airplane pilot."
The second, "A fireman."
The third boy, looking up from his
magazine, replied, To heck with the
details, I just want to grow up."
* * *
"Now sir. You've applied for a job
as switchman. What would you do if
you saw two trains approaching on the
same track?"
"I'd throw the lever and switch one
onto another track."
"And if the lever was jammed?"
"I'd turn the signals to red by hand."
"And if the signals were jammed?"
"I'd grab a red flag and run out on
the track.'"
"And if the engineer didn't see you?"
"I'd send for my sister."
"Your SISTER? What could she do?"
"Nothing. She loves to watch train
wrecks."
* * *
Once upon a time there were three
bears. One morning they came down to
breakfast and Papa Bear looked at his
bowl and cried, "Someone's eaten my
porridge."
Baby Bear looked at his bowl and
cried, "Someone's eaten all my porridge."
"Sit down and shut up," said Mama
Bear. "It ain't poured yet."

Sign in front of crematorium: "We're
Hot for Your Body."

Prof, (in the middle of a joke) —
"Have I ever told the class this one
before?"
Class (in a chorus)—-"Yes!"

laugh this time."

METALS...the challenging heart of tomorrow's progress
Today the metals industry is poised at the
threshold of its most exciting advances. New
needs for metals yet undreamed of . . . revo-

niques . . . new modifications and applications
of the basic metals ... all spell opportunity
for enterprising young metallurgists and engi-
neers. Now is the ideal time to enter this chal-
lenging field, and lay the foundation for a
richly rewarding career.
Bridgeport Brass Company offers a uniquely
thorough and diversified grounding in all as-
pects of metals from A to Z . . . Aluminum to
Zirconium. Here you will find a training pro-
gram second to none in the industry, designed
to give you a broad Company-wide perspective
that will aid you materially in selecting your
permanent assignment.
To maintain its leadership in metals tech-
nology, Bridgeport is embarking on a major
program of expansion and product diversifi-
cation that will provide practically unlimited
opportunities for professional achievement and
rewards. To learn what this can mean to your
future, ask your placement director for a copy
of "Careers in Metals with Bridgeport Brass",

THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


The word space commonly represents the outer, airless regions of the universe.
But there is quite another kind of "space" close at hand, a kind that will always
challenge the genius of man.
This space can easily be measured. It is the space-dimension of cities and the
distance between them ... the kind of space found between mainland and off-
shore oil rig, between a tiny, otherwise inaccessible clearing and its supply
base, between the site of a mountain crash and a waiting ambulance—above all,
Sikorsky is concerned with the precious "spaceway" that currenUy exists be-
tween all earthbound places.
Our engineering efforts are directed toward a variety of VTOL and STOL
aircraft configurations. Among earlier Sikorsky designs are some of the most
versatile airborne vehicles now in existence; on our boards today are the ve-
hicles that can prove to be tomorrow's most versatile means of transportation.
Here, then, is a space age challenge to be met with the finest and most practical
engineering talent. Here, perhaps, is the kind of challenge you can meet.
QJKORSKY
AIRCRAFT

dress Mr. Richard L. Auten, Personnel Department.
One of the Divisions of United Aircraft Corporation

best student, aged seven.

I have altogether?"
"Personally," answered Tommy, "I
don't think you can do it."

was black.

The analyst was concerned about the
results of a Rorschach Test he had just
given, for the patient associated every
ink blot with some type of sexual ac-
tivity.
"I want to study the results of your
test over the week-end," he said. "Then
I'd like to see you again on Monday
morning."
"OK, Doc," the man agreed. And
then as he was slipping on his coat, he
said, "I'm going to a stag party tomor-
row night. Any chance I might be able to
borrow those dirty pictures of yours?"
* * *
"Professor," said the engineer in search
of knowledge, "will you try to explain
to me the theory of limits?"
"Well, John, assume that you have
called on a pretty woman. You are seated
at one end of the divan and she is
seated at the other. You move halfway
toward her. Then you move half of the
remaining distance toward her. Again
you reduce the distance separating you
from her by 50 per cent. Continue this
for some time. Theoretically, you will
never reach the girl. On the other hand,
you will soon get close enough to her
for practical purposes."
* * *
"Now children," said the kindergarten
teacher, "we'll draw what we'd like to
be when we grow up."
At the end of twenty minutes everyone
handed in a picture except little Butch
McGurk. His paper was blank.
"Why Butch," remonstrated the teach-
er, "isn't there anything you want to be
when you grow up?"
"Sure teacher," replied little Butch.
"I'd like to be married, but I don't know
how to draw it."

The occupants of a parked car were
completely engrossed in each other when
the beam of a policeman's flashlight
struck them. "What are you doing in
there?" he demanded.
"Nothing," came the masculine reply.
"Okay then, Mac," said the cop. "You
come out here and hold the flashlight."

Civil Engineering
Sanitary Engineering concerns that branch of Civil Engineering dealing
with the development of water supplies and the subsequent treatment and
distribution of this water, as well as the collection and disposal of storm run-
off, domestic sewage, and industrial wastes.
As population trends continue upward, problems in this area become ex-
tremely complicated. The photo above shows a culture cell in which basic
biological principles are being studied in an effort to develop new techniques
for the disposal of sewage.

The house guests were assembled with
their hosts in the living room after din-
ner, when the five-year-old daughter of
the host appeared suddenly in the room,
her clothes dripping with water. She
could scarcely articulate, so great was her
emotions, and her parents rose in con-
sternation as she entered.
"You—you," the little girl babbled,
pointing to the male of the house guests,
"You're the one who left the seat up!"

1st Award-S4,000-Student Class
Niels Jorgen Gimsing, Hattensens Alle 11, Copenhagen, Denmark
Technical University of Copenhagen (Graduate)
and
HanS NyVOld, Ulrikkenborg, Alle 62, Lyngby, Denmark
Technical University of Denmark (Graduate)
These students won $9,000 for bridge designs
American Bridge Division of United States Steel
recently awarded $44,000 in world-wide competition
for the best designs of small steel bridges. Professional
engineers and college engineering students partici-
pated. Designs came in from 50 states and 40 foreign
countries. From these entries, 15 winners were chosen,
eight professional awards and seven student awards.
They were selected under the supervision of the
American Institute of Steel Construction. The judges
were prominent consulting engineers and architects.
They judged the designs on the basis of originality,
economy, appearance and the utilization of steel. The
bridges had to carry two-lane traffic over a four-lane
interstate highway in accordance with AASHO stand-
ards. In addition to the winners, many of the designs
entered were so outstanding that they will be pub-
lished later.
Bridge design is a good example of what can be
done with steel and imagination. But, it's only one
example. There are thousands of other uses for steel
. . . and it takes thousands of men to make and sell
steel. If you want to know about engineering oppor-
tunities at U.S. Steel, write to United States Steel, 525
William Penn Place, Pittsburgh 30, Pennsylvania.
USS is a registered trademark
(USS) United States Steel

into the
nature of things
At the General Motors Research Laboratories, physicists employ
radioactive isotopes and other ultra-modern techniques and tools
in their search for new scientific knowledge and an understanding
of the many laws of nature that continue to perplex mankind.
Although a lot depends on a man's ability, enthusiasm and
growth potential, there's every chance for advancement in
many fields for General Motors scientists and engineers. There's
virtually no limit to opportunity at GM. Fields of work are
as varied as radioactive isotope research, astronautics, auto-
mobiles, aircraft engines and inertial guidance systems—to
mention but a few.
If you wish to pursue postgraduate studies, GM offers financial
aid. And since each GM division is autonomous yet related,
you can grow in two directions—up through your own division,
or to the side to other divisions.
For an exciting, rewarding career, see your Placement
Officer or write to General Motors, Salaried Personnel Place-
ment, Personnel Staff, Detroit 2, Michigan.
GENERAL MOTORS

DECEMBER, 1959


Payola - Right or Wrong?
Headlines cry our "Quiz Program Rigged,"
"Disc Jockeys accept payola," "Bribery." Sensation-
alist journalism of our big newspaper recently dealt
a devastating blow to Big Business by indicating
that they made suckers of American Radio and TV
Public. Retaliating legislators have lent their support
to the public with angered threats of preventive
legislation to cure what is purely an ethical problem
and should be solved accordingly.
First, what is the question? It is not easily de-
fined for it has many diverse implications, but in
the writer's mind it may be summed up as follows.
Should John Q. Public be hoaxed into accepting non-
partisan reports which are in actuality, commercials
of Big Business! False advertising is not meant here,
for that is carefully controlled by product legislation
similar to the Pure Food and Drug Act; however,
the question does imply that by sponsor identifica-
tion, that Big Business is a great guy and you should
buy his product irregardless of its merits.
There are many different ways in which this hoax
is pulled. The record industry has seemed to have
gone off on a little separate tangent in the respect
that it has bribed the disc jockeys, who in turn, play
their records so as to introduce them to the public.
This eliminates much of the time delay between man-
ufacturing and the top 40 positions, but however,
has little effect on the record being a hit. Now, how
much different is that in comparison than the engi-
neer who accepts gifts and is wined and dinned by a
vendor who wishes to get his recommendation
for a public or private contract, is a long estab-
lished custom in big business? And just how much
persuaded is that politician, who has been receiving
gifts for many years, in giving contracts to the
company to which he is most familiar. All these
different types of friendly persuading, fall under the
same ethical question of just how much should one
take in gifts before it is considered bribery. Do not
be too harsh in enswering this question, for you
some day will most certainly be put in this position
with all its advantages.
Second, what can be done about hoaxing the
public and the partisan-non-partisan reports. Those
who advocate powerful legislation now have
a solid stepping stone on which to base their argu-
ments for preventive legislation. It is apparent that
these legislators may not take the question any
further than the control of the Federal Communica-
tions Commission. Now is the time to decide wheth-
er that is sufficient, or should legislation go still
further in the prevention of all types of hoaxes,
bribery, and dealing that might cause the public to
be mislead. Are not all types of cheating the public
just as bad or has some imaginary line been drawn?
However, if legislation does try to cover the com-
plete question, it will never succeed. The cry of
"Civil Rights Trespassing" will rise from the land
and good legislation may be caught up with
the leftest legislation and be swept down that whirl-
pool of bad law.
No, the answer is not in preventative legislation,
but rather in the education of the people, so that
they maw recognize the ethical question; this ac-
complished, the public may use its buying power
and other influences in reflection of their opinion,
and in so doing, rather assures itself that any future
occurances would be greatly curtailed. It is obvious,
that an alert people of strong ethical and moral
convictions need not suffer the humilitation of con-
stant hoaxes.
Charles R. Hildebrandt

For many years the accepted theory of color has stated that all colors must be present to pro-
duce a full spectrum in an object such as a transparent slide projected on a screen. Now,
however, it has been discovered that by using two black and white slides taken with different
colored filters and projecting them on a screen simultaneously through their filters, a full color
picture is observed. This month's cover designed by Barbara Finocchi illustrates this theory.

Provide Engineers
Greater Opportunity for
Space-Age Advancement
Young engineers, particularly, will be interested in the new
opportunities created by Chance Vought's recent realignment
into five divisions.
Today, for every Vought engineer, there is a division to
make fullest use of his talents and to speed his personal
advancement. And, of course, he is backed by the four other
divisions whose balanced activities add security to his
company and his future.
Vought's realignment was the result of considerable study
of both company capabilities and new business opportuni-
ties. The move intensifies a diversification program which
began early in 1959. It specifically gears this progressive,
42-year-old aircraft firm for the challenges and opportunities
of the age of space.

p,
[electronics


ASTRONAUTICS DIVISION
Vought is taking fullest advantage of its existing capabilities
and is drawing on 12 years' experience in the missile field to
obtain broader responsibilities in the race for space. Concen-
tration will be on advanced vehicles for space exploration,
and On ballistic and anti-ballistic missile systems.
Under a current contract, Vought is readying the four-stage
Scout research rocket and its launcher for the National
Aeronautics and Space Administration. Also, Vought and
other members of the Boeing team are participating in the
development of the Dyna-Soar boost-glide vehicle in compe-
tition tor an Air Force contract. In the human factors of
flight, Vought is taking the lead with its orbital flight
simulator and space-oriented Cockpit Laboratory.
AERONAUTICS DIVISION
Weapons of many types will take shape here. For example:
new generations of manned aircraft and atmospheric mis-
siles, and devices for antisubmarine warfare. Systems to
support these weapons, and subcontracting assignments are
other Aeronautics activities.
Among this division's current contracts: a Navy order for
development of an environmental protection and escape
capsule for aircraft pilots. Other work includes production
contracts for three versions of F8U Crusader aircraft, study
contracts in submarine detection and classification, and
subcontracts for military and commercial aircraft assemblies.
ELECTRONICS DIVISION
Vought electronics will be developed, manufactured and
marketed in increasing volume. Military systems under devel-
opment include antennas and related electronics, ground
support electronics and antisubmarine warfare apparatus.
RESEARCH DIVISION
In a new Research Center, scientists of this division will mine
new knowledge from many fields. Basic research is planned
into astronautics, undersea warfare, the life sciences (relat-
ing to human factors of flight), electrogravities and other
areas. As it evolves into applied research, this advanced
work will materially support other Vought divisions.
RANGE SYSTEMS DIVISION
Twelve years' experience in remote base operation qualifies
Vought for additional business in this new field. The Range
Systems team will establish and operate test ranges and test
equipment for missiles and space vehicles.
Genesys Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary company,
intensifies Vought's diversification into commercial elec-
tronics. Company emphasis is on automation, and its key
personnel are engineers experienced in the fields of
electronics, computers, magnetic memory, and associated
electro-mechanical devices.
You live at a discount in Dallas
In Texas there is no state income tax and no local or state
sales taxes. Low school and property levies add to your
savings. Home construction costs — as well as house and
apartment rentals — are below the national average. Fuel
costs are negligible, and most groceries cost less.
Dallas has grown faster since 1950 than any other U. S. city.
One reason is the city's wealth of entertainment and cultural
centers. Another reason is the attractive cost of living.

POLLUTION
SOLUTION
With industrial firms, autos, and homes spew-
ing forth increasing quantities of chemical re-
agents, air pollution is becoming a very serious
problem.
by PATRICIA SOROKIN, '63 LSA
Since January I, 1946, nearly
30,000 installations of new heat-
ing, power and mechanical equip-
ment, having a value of $14,000,-
000, have been made in Cincinnati
in compliance with the technical
requirements of the smoke ordi-
nance for cleaner and safer opera-
tion.
In 1948 in the small town of
Donora, Penn. twenty people died
and thousands became ill as a result of
a combination of air pollution and fog,
or smog as it is now known. Similar
incidents occured in London in both
1948 and 1952 when several thousand
people died.
These facts lead one to ask, "what
has happened to man's clean, fresh air?
Why has the atmosphere suddenly been
contaminated by foreign matter?" The
answer lies in the fact that man has
made great technological advances in in-
dustrial might. For years man has
worked for convenience and ease in his
daily life by developing highly complex
industrialization. And as a result indus-
try, autos, and homes pour new poison-
ous gases into the air each day. Some
are detrimental and others aren't harm-
ful in themselves but become so when
activated by sunlight.
Most of the poisons of air pollution
are a direct result of combustion of one
type or another. For example in New
York alone, thirty million tons of coal
are burned annually releasing 1.5 billion
tons of SO, plus two million tons of
H..SO, and other pollutant vapors. This
is only one of many types of combus-
tion carried on annually in a city. Ac-
cording to Dr. Leslie A. Chambers, di-
rector of research for the Los Angeles
Air Pollution Control District, there are
six types of combustion responsible for
the noxious gases produced in most com-
munities. Dr. Chambers has summarized
his findings as follows:
Smog Effects
As it was indicated in the opening
paragraph it has been found that air
pollution presents many perils to health.
Bengprene, an air pollutant, is a cancer
producing agent in the lung, esophagus,

13


eases and chronic bronchitis are also di-
rectly associated with air pollution. But
death and illness are just one of the
effects of smog.
Sunlight acting upon gasoline exhaust
with nitrogen oxides serving as a catalyst
yield ozone which causes excessive crack-
ing of rubber and irritation of the eyes,
nose, and throat. Petroleum refining en-
volves the combustion of fuel which
yields sulfur dioxide pollutants. Sulfur
dioxide in turn reacts with the air giving
off sulfur trioxide and sulfuric acid va-
pors. SOo injures sensitive plants such
as flowers and corrodes metals such as
steel. Sulfuric acid mist reduces visibility
considerably and causes fog to pervade.
Burning fuel daily in homes results in
sootfall which deteriorates paint and
causes extensive cleaning bills.
Industry at Fault?
For decades, industry has been called
the chief instigator of air pollution
problems. Back in the late 1600's the
inhabitants of London complained of in-
dustrial contamination of air. Ever since
then, whenever the problem arose, in-
dustry has received a great deal of dese-
crating publicity.
Even today, we constantly meet such
cases. In Baton Rouge, the city is trou-
bled by petrochemical fumes. Down in
Florida, phosphate mining spreads dam-
aging fluorides to fruit crops. Out in the
West in Colorado and Utah, the fresh
air is polluted with uranium clouds and
in Buffalo, New York, the steel mills
create foul air problems. Even on the
west coast Oregon farmers are suing
an aluminum company for damages to
crops and animals.
From coast to coast the sounds re-
sound of the evils which industry is
putting into the air. Yet, the major
blame for air pollution today does not
lie with the industrial producers them-
selves, but with the citizens.
The major cause of air pollution is
each individual home across the coun-
try. For people have no way of
filtering the foreign matter which is
released from the combustion of coal,
fuel oil, or trash. Exhaust fumes from
automobiles are the second greatest con-
tributors to the problem, followed finally
by industrial pollution itself.
Action!!
Because of this great alarm about the
number of contaminants being placed in
the atmosphere, people began to take
action. As a result, many municipalities
and counties set up boards and com-
mittees to solve their problems. Next the
states took a hand in solving the prob-
lems in their particular areas.
It was in 1950 that the first federal
Air Pollution Conference was held. In
1954, the White House informally sug-
gested that the Secretary of the Depart-
ment of Health, Education, and Wel-
fare set up an Ad Hoc Interdepart-
mental Commission. It was to be com-
posed of representatives from the de-
partments of Agriculture, Commerce,
Defense, Interior, and the National Sci-
ence Foundation. The idea was approved
and put into effect. The first meeting
was held November 16, 1954 and the
Surgeon General of the United States
Public Health Service was appointed
chairman.
For a year they could do little. But
then in 1955 a federal legislative act

was passed so that this committee could
officially carry out a program of re-
search and technical assistance under the
supervision of the Secretary of Health.
Education, and Welfare with the Surgeon
General directing the work.
The first thing the committee did was
to define air pollution: "Community air
pollution is the presence in the ambient
atmosphere of substances put there by
the activities of man in concentrations
sufficient to interfere directly or indi-
rectly with his comfort, safety, or health,
or with the full use and enjoyment of
his property. In general, it does not
refer to the atmospheric pollution cred-
ited to employment in areas where work-
ers are employed, nor is it concerned
with airborne agents of communicable
disease, nor with overt or covert acts
of war."
With this definition in hand, to-
gether with an appropriation of not more
than five million dollars annually, the
committee set up its program which con-
tained five set undertakings.
1. To undertake research—individ-
ually or co-operatively;
2. To encourage cooperative activi-
ties between state, local, and
federal agencies;
3. To collect and disseminate infor-
mation on the subject;
4. To conduct investigations and to
survey specific problems con-
fronting various state and mu-
nicipal governments;
5. To make grants and enter into
contracts for research, training,
and demonstation projects;
With these tools in hand the prob-
lem is being tackled. Despite the im-
pressiveness of the federal government's
work, it is only one-fifth of what is
being done nationally. For four-fifths of
air pollution control is being conducted
on state and municipal levels.
The federal government can't promul-
gate air pollution standards, issue regu-
lations, or engage in the enforcement of
any existing anti-pollution measures.
They spend four-fifths of their time and
money on research and a fifth of their
annual appropriation goes into technical
assistance and training grants.
On the state level each government
is working on the particular problems
in their area. New York, New Jersey,
and Connecticut have joined forces in
fighting pollution by forming a singular
air pollution control board. Since their
respective problems are almost identical,
they use similar techniques in solving
them.

THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


being done on the municipal level. An
outstanding example is Los Angeles.
There, a multimillion-dollar project is
under way and oil refineries in the
area have cut their pollution 80% at
a cost of 33 million dollars.
Research
However, tracking down air pollution
and relating specific effects is by no
means an easy task. It requires money,
patience and time plus a host of spe-
cialists such as engineers, analytical
chemists, scientists, meteorologists, train-
ed weathermen, doctors, statiticians and
cost accountants. With these facts in
mind, let's examine a few of the results
and methods of the various research
groups.
Through research the contaminants
have been classified into two groups. The
first consists of visible particles in which
there are some thirty odd chemicals in-
cluding: CI, Fl, Nitrates, SO,, As, Ba,
Be, and Bi. Invisible gaseous and va-
porous particles head the second group.
This, in turn, is broken down into in-
organic materials such as oxides of S,N,
and CO and organic materials, as hydro-
carbons, aldehydes, and ketones.
There are over 230 air sampling sta-
tions in city and rural areas across the
country. Here air samples are collected.
Delicate and complicated mechanisms
are used to gather and analyze these
substances. Particles are sucked into a
modified vacuum cleaner device which
collects 700,000 cubic feet of air in
twenty-four hours. The opening is a
vertical one to avoid conflicting winds.
Solids and liquids fall into different
compartment after passing through fil-
ters. The solid specimens are collected
on 6 square inch filter sheets made of
glass fibers. These specimens are then
carefuly bundled and sent on to an
analytical laboratory. The mixture of gas-
eous air must be packed in an air-tight
container before being forwarded.
At the laboratory, solid samples are
carefully weighed and cut into pieces
for different analyzing processes while
the organic and inorganic gases are sep-
arated from their mixtures by passing
them through various solvents. The next
step involves subsequent fractionation
and detailed analysis. In some cases, ex-
aminations by infrared spectroscopy are
also conducted.
Such research has brought many un-
knowns to light after a careful tabula-
tion of recent findings and a com-
parison with statistics gathered at an


Over a period of years, this residential area in Columbus, Ohio was freed from a
great air pollution situation.
earlier date.
From there research scientists can
now predict what will happpen when
certain pollutants are in the area and
certain weather conditions are arising.
This is of great benefit to farmers for
they have been instructed on what to
do in various cases and this results in
saving many dollars worth of crop dam-
age.
But the problem still isn't completely
under hand. For by 1970, the popula-
tion will have increased 25% and in-
dustrial activity will have doubled. This
will result in more burning, more in-
complete combustion, and more garbage
in the sky. Four fields of concentrated
study offer possible results for future
researchers. They are:
1. Greater field investigations and
statistical studies aimed at a better un-
derstanding of air pollution and its in-
fluence on geographical distribution of
diseases and death. Surveys are now
being conducted in California and Ten-
nessee.
2. Associations between air pollution
and the respiratory system must be ex-
plored further. A new device to test
lung functions under various conditions
has just been patented and will be of
great use in their field of research.
3. A more concentrated study of air
pollution and its resulting cancerous and
cardiac effects could bring down the
death rate in these two ailments. Such
research is now being carried out in Los
Angeles, California and London, Eng-
land.
4. Last, but not least, the biological
and chemical impact of specific pollutants
must be studied intensely to prohibit
further damage to humans and their
property.
Only when a better understanding
has been gained in these particular areas
will man be able to relax and stop
worrying about the problems he has
brought upon himself through his search
for industrial might.

A radical new theory has been proposed by
Edwin Land, developer of the Polaroid camera,
may soon replace the classical theory of color.
by JAY SKLAR, '60E
Almost three hundred years ago, a
man named Isaac Newton pur-
chased a toy glass prism at a Stourbridge
Fair. Six years later, in 1672, he pub-
lished the results of his experimentation.
With the piece of glass he had refracted
a white light beam and had discovered
that it could be split into seven com-
ponent colors: violet, indigo, blue, green,
yellow, orange and red. Each of these
component colors was refracted or bent
a certain degree as it passed through
the glass. Moreover, Newton found that
a specific color would always be refracted
through a specific angle when passing
through the same prism.
In addition to these refractive laws,
Isaac Newton discovered several laws for
mixing colors. If the light of any two
colors is mixed, the result was a light
intermediate in color between the two.
This rule, and its more recent corollary
that any color could be matched by add-
ing various proportions of three "additive
primaries", have become the basis for
many color applications. Photography,
lithography, and television are the most
common.
Classical Theory Overthrown?
However, this basic work, while cer-
tainly correct, has led to generaliz-
ations which have been shaken thor-
oughly by the experimentation of Edwin
Land, developer of the Polaroid Land
camera. Four years ago, Land took
two black and white transparencies, pic-
turing identical objects, but with slight
variations in grey density and projected
them through individual projectors on the
same screen. In front of one beam he
placed a red filter. In front of the other,
he placed nothing. After the two images
were aligned, Land observed to his
amazement, something the old laws did
not predict. Classical color theory would
dictate that a pink image would be visi-
ble. Instead, he saw a full-color image
containing reds, blues, and yellows. With
this astounding bit of evidence, he went
to work trying to narrow the speculation
on the cause of this phenomenon to a
few basic points.
Before continuing the experiments
themselves, Land set out to search the
literature for some previous experience
of this same observation. Although the
findings were not many, it seems that
several men had seen the same result in
less conclusive form and had therefore
passed it off as "eye fatigue." If only
they had pursued their observations fur-
ther, the problem would probably be
solved today.
The earliest record of anything to this
effect was the observation by Goethe,
the artist, that under red-orange light
conditons, that is, a sceen lit by sunset,
shadows displayed a distinct blue. Later,
in 1774, Benjamin Thompson showed
that these colors were not merely illusions,
but always appeared when a yellow-
orange light and a white light simultan-
eously illuminated a screen. In the earlier
part of the present century, it was found
that three men had discovered and had
patented a technique for color movie
projection by a method equivalent to
those now being investigated. At that
time, however, these contradictions of
Newtonian spectroscopy were passed off
again as "eye fatigue", and experts in
the field of color took no notice.
Closer Look
Let us now look more closely at Dr.
Land's observations and his further ex-
periments. We will not be able to form
any conclusions, however. After centuries
of conviction that a theory was correct,
experts in color are rejecting their old
ideas. But they, and we, cannot take up
a new theory quickly. Only after long
experiments and much discussion can
such conclusions be drawn.
As mentioned previously, Land took

transparent celluloid. But these two
transparencies are not identical. Upon
careful observation, one will find that
some of the areas in one photograph
appear lighter than the corresponding
areas of the second. Other areas have
the reverse correlation. However, both
have no color. The darker areas merely
serve to block off part of the light trying
to pass through the film.
To systematically determine which of
two identical areas on the two trans-
parencies is to be darker and which
is to be lighter, Land relied on photo-
graphic filters. In the first experiment
he used one red and one green filter.
Anyone familiar with amateur photog-
raphy will recall that if a red filter
is used, all red portions of the scene
will appear white on the black and
white film. If a green filter is used,
the green areas will appear white. Hence
two transparencies of the form desired
for Land's work could be made by the
use of filters.
According to the electromagnetic
theory, red light has a longer wave-
length than green light. Therefore
Land called the transparency exposed
with a red filter before the camera the
long record. Similarly, he called the
other transparency the short record.
Since green filters pass the whole spec-
trum except red, the short record con-
tains an impression of the remaining
colors.
With these two pieces of film, Dr.
Land was able to produce a full color
image. Putting the long record into a
projector, he threw the image onto a
screen with a red filter. On the screen
was a scene in red and black areas. In
another projector he placed the short
record. This was projected with white
light and no filter. The scene appeared
in black and white. Finally, after care-
fully aligning the two images, he ob-
served the same scene, not in shades
of pink as would be expected by old
color ideas, but in full color.
Wondering still if the observations
were merely illusions or "eye fatigue",
Land took photographs of his images.
Since color films are quite faithful in

More Proof
For more definite proof, he went to
the spectroscope and tried to observe
which wavelengths were present. Because
of the white light from the projector,
all wavelengths were detected even though
there was a prevalence of red wavelengths
due to the red projector.
Many skeptic still doubted that they
were seeing a real full-color image, but
instead thought that the memory was
playing a trick on the eye, telling it that
lemons are always yellow, etc. But in a
clever experiment, Land proved this
could not be. He merely reversed the
long and short records. The result was
a corresponding reversal of the colors:
lips were green and grass was red.
To this point in his work, Edwin
Land had merely investigated work that
had been done previously but which had
been neglected. His experiments served
to reopen the field and to attract atten-
tion to the problem of color perception
by the human eye.
With this much evidence, one might
conclude that the projection of the short
image with white light supplies to the
screen all wavelengths except those of
the red. When the red projection is
added, all colors are theoretically present
and a full color image might somehow
appear.
However, Land made another experi-
ment which made such a conclusion im-
possible. Instead of lighting the short
record with white light, he used a pro-
jector with an orange light. Again he
observed a full color picture.
This was very strange indeed. The
combination of red and orange lights
stimulated the eye to see a full gamut
of color. At this point, Land began to
wonder how close the projector lights
could be in wavelength if the effect was

THE SYNTHETIC
METAL
A Du Pont plastic, known as Delrin, may soon
herald the end of the Age of Metals.
by BENSON P. SHAPIRO, '63E
After thousands of years the Age of
Metals may be coming to a close.
A synthetic substitute for many metals
has finally been discovered and is now
being produced by DuPont, under the
name Delrin, principally for competition
with metals.
Although a synthetic, Delrin resem-
bles a metal in many ways, having a
higher tensile strength and dimensional
Benson Shapiro, a freshman in
chemical engineering, is a gradu-
ate of Saugus (Mass.) High School.
While there Ben was President of
the Debating Club, a member of
the Boys Club Cabinet, and won
second place in the annual Science
Fair.
Ben lists as his main hobby
sleeping but points out that he has
had little of it since coming to
Michigan.

stability than many common metals. Its
melting point, 347 °F, is lower than
that of most metals, and it has a crysta-
line structure which resembles that of
the metals.
Chemically Delrin is known as a su-
perpolyoxymethylene. The generic name
for the chemical group to which it be-
longs is acetal resins. Delrin is one of
the many polymers of formaldehyde. Its
molecules usually contain over one thou-
sand nonomeric units of formaldehyde.
Formaldehyde is almost always in the
form of polymers of low molecular
weights (60-300). In fact, when re-
search into formaldehyde was begun,
one of the most difficult problems was
to discover a method of forming and
storing formaldehyde in a reasonably
pure monomeric state.
Accidental Discovery
Formaldehyde polymers, in the form
of resins, were accidentally discovered
by a Russian chemist, Alexander Butle-
rov, about one hundred years ago. The
low molecular weight polymers which
he made were soluble in dilute acids
18
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


next development in the research into
the chemistry of formaldehyde did not
occur until 1920. In that year, the Ger-
man Nobel prize winner, Staudinger,
polymerized formaldehyde by dissolving
it in ether. The product was unstable,
causing Staudinger to conclude that the
resin was useless.
DuPont entered the picture in 1929
when one of its research chemists, Wal-
lace Carothers, commenced research into
formaldehyde and its allied chemicals.
This research culminated in the discovery
of nylon. Research into the formaldehyde
polymers was then discontinued until
1947. In 1947, a thirty-two year old
research chemist, Archie Barkdoll, started
basic research into monomeric formalde-
hyde for DuPont. Barkdoll's main prob-
lem was to produce and store pure mono-
meric formaldehyde. He accomplished
this most difficult feat by making and
storing the formaldehyde at —19 C. In
June of 1949, Robert N. MacDonald, a
thirty-three year old Ph.D., took over
the project. The research then became
a joint operation of the Polychemicals
and Central Research Departments of
DuPont. The Polychemicals Department
is concerned with production and engi-
neering. Central Research, as the name
implies, is the Research division of Du-
Pont. This combination made it possible
for engineers, applied scientists, and re-
search scientists to pool their knowledge
and experience.
In 1952, DuPont accelerated the Del-
rin research and development program.
The work force was increased to sixty
men, the budget to one million dollars
for six months. Again the researchers
were plagued by problems. Delrin re-
tained the characteristic odor of formal-
dehyde. Stabilization and retension of
color had to be increased. Stabilizing the
plastic also removed the unpleasant odor.
As these and many other problems were
solved, more thought was given to the
problem of marketing the final product.
Delrin received the best market sur-
vey program of any plastic yet developed.
Two-hundred and fifty companies were
asked to evaluate Delrin in five-hundred
different uses. This intensive survey in-
dicated that a fertile field existed for
the formaldehyde polymer.
In order to efficiently administer the
program, which was fast becoming a
marketing project, rather than a research
project, the program's manager had to
be changed. Therefore, in 1956 Jack
Manning, a DuPont salesman, became
product manager.

Thomas Risk of Ford receives a molded blank of Delrin from Jack Manning, head
of the Delrin sales program.
Production
The patent on Delrin was issued on
October 31, 1956. Then things began
to happen fast. In November of 1956
planning for the production plant was
begun. In less than a year money for
the construction of the plant was grant-
ed. The normal pilot plant stage of
production was eliminated since DuPont
was anxious to begin production. A full-
sized plant was scaled up directly from
large size laboratory equipment and ex-
periments. Full-scale production was
scheduled for mid-autumn of 1959. This
production will take place in a fifteen-
million dollar plant at Parksburg, Penn-
sylvania. Initial production is expected
to be in the vicinity of fifteen million
pounds per year.
Delrin will be marketed in the form
of small pellets. It can be injection
molded, blow molded, or extruded. It
can be molded on equipment which is
now in use throughout the plastics in-
dustry. This eliminates the necessity of
making large capital outlays for special
machinery.
It can be extruded in any thickness
and shape. It can also be extruded as
a coating onto paper or fabric.
Delrin may well have a greater im-
pact on the economy of the world than
any other previous plastic. Most plastics
are characterized by an outstanding
property. For example, nylon is impor-
tant as a plastic because of its tensile
strength. In another case, the acrylics,
such as Lucite and Plexiglass, are char-
acterized by their optical properties. In
contrast, Delrin has no true strong point
like the other plastics. Instead, it pos-
sesses a battery of good points, none
of which is outstanding. This variety of
good points makes Delrin a competitor
in many fields, some of which, up to
now, have not felt the impact of the
new synthetics.
Many of Delrin's properties generally
resemble those of the other plastics, but
are better in most respects. It is solvent
resistant, especially to hot or salt water,
which makes it suitable for waterfront
uses. It is a nonconductor of electricity.
Many consumer goods could be among
its uses since it is odorless, tasteless,
and nontoxic.
In other respects Delrin closely re-
sembles the metals. It has high tensile
strength, dimensional stability, and fa-
tigue endurance. It is hard to bend,
and recoils after being bent. Its melting
point is well defined at 347°F. This
means that it is not affected by boiling
water. Like a metal, it is highly crystal-
ine. Its crystallinity can be controlled.
Delrin, as all things, has drawbacks.
It is stained by hot coffee, a situation
which somewhat restricts its use in the
food-processing industry. It is adversely
affected by strong acids and bases. An-
other drawback is the fact that ultra-
