HIPPARCHUS
His determination lead him to many discoveries
pertaining to the motion of the Earth, Moon,
and Sun.
by CHARLES MASSER, '62E
Down through the ages history has
given us many people who stand
out from all the rest. Especially in the
realms of science, we find men who
devoted their lives in the search for
truth and understanding of the world
we live in. One such man was Hippar-
chus, a Greek mathematical astronomer
whose search for the truth lead him
to many enlightening discoveries which
are now taken to be common knowl-
edge.
First Appearance
Greek mathematical astronomy made
its appearance in about the sixth or fifth
century B.C. The history of early Greek
astronomy was obtained from the few
pieces of original writings that have
been preserved down through the ages.
Chuck Masser, a native of De-
troit, Michigan, is enrolled in En-
gineering Mechanics at Michigan.
During his four years at Cooley
High School he was a member of
the Astronomy Club, Math Club,
and president of the Science Club.
Chuck's main interest outside
school is amateur astronomy. This
interest is backed up by the fact
he is a member of the Detroit
Astronomical Society, and has
built his own six-inch reflecting
telescope.

Most of all of our knowledge of Hip-
parchus was preserved by the great
Egyptian astronomer Ptolemy. He refers
very frequently to Hipparchus and often
quotes him verbatim. Ptolemy praised
his predecessor very highly, calling him
a man loving his work and loving the
truth.
Hipparchus, whose work can be com-
pared to Newton's for importance, was
born in Bithynia about 190 B.C.
Through his seventy years of life he
advanced the study of mathematical
astronomy more than any other per-
son in history. It is believed that he
was not a student of the Alexandria
School, but during the early part of his
career he visited there several times for
the purpose of observing the heavens.
He did most of his work on the island
of Rhodes where he had built an observ-
atory. Rhodes is an island in the Aegean
Sea off the Southwest coast of Turkey
with an area of 542 square miles.
Mathematics
One important debt that we owe
Hipparchus is his formulation of trig-
onometry. He used this new tool sys-
tematically for astronomical purposes
and for computing a table of chords.
After devising a method of representing
20
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


Alpha Draeonla
Polaris
the heavens in one plane he used his
new invention to divide the heavens
by lines of latitude and longitude using
as reference a circle containing 360 de-
grees.
He then did the same for the in-
habited world dividing it into zones of
latitude and longitude, and using these
co-ordinates systematically established a
position for each locality. For the de-
termination of longitudes he suggested
the observation of eclipses from differ-
ent points; the difference in local times
would give the difference of longitudes.
Precession of Equinoxes
During his lifetime Hipparchus made
large numbers of observations both at
the School of Alexandria and at his
observatory at Rhodes. He collected
these records and catalogued them for
the purpose of helping his successors,
and for comparing them with the work
of previous observers. He collected rec-
ords that went back beyond the Alex-
andria School to the ancient Greeks of
the sixth century B.C. Hipparchus even
had records that went back to the ancient
Babylonian period. One day while he
was comparing his observations with
those of Aristyllus and Timocharis,
whose observations preceded Hipparchus
by about 150 years, he noticed that the
stars were slipping back around the
ecliptic. This could only be explained
by the movement of the equinoxes in
the apparent direction of the stars,
which is east to west. "This is due to
the revolution of the Earth's pole
around the pole of the ecliptic in a
In the Epicycle Theory the small circular
orbit (epicycle), the center of which re-
volves on the circumference of the
larger circular orbit called the deferent.
The Earth is located at the center of the
deferent.

Besides rotating and revolving, the Earth has an oscillating motion like that of a
top slowing down. This is due chiefly to the pull of the moon. Each slow oscillation
takes 26,000 years. Because of this motion the North Pole traces a circle in the
sky, pointing to different stars as it moves in its circuit. Thus 3,000 years ago Alpha
Draconis was the pole star. In 14,000 A.D. Vega will be the pole star and other
constellations will shift accordingly. The southern cross will then be visible
all over this country.
period of 26,000 years in a direction
opposite to that of the Earth's revolu-
tion around the Sun. A consequence is
that the Sun, in its annual journey
around the sky in the ecliptic, returns
to each equinoctial point a little earlier
each year with respect to the stars, so
that the equinoxes occur slightly sooner
than they otherwise would. The move-
ment has thus received the name, pre-
cession of the equinoxes."1
Hipparchus took special notice of the
1Peter Doig, A Concise History of Astron-
omy (New York: Chapman and Hill, 1950),

our Sua

star Spica, the brightest star in the con-
stellation of the Virgin. He noticed
from the observations of Aristyllus and
Timocharis that Spica became further
separated from the autumnal equinox
by an angle of two degrees in 150 years.
This is equivalent to 48 seconds of arc
per year, which is within five per cent
of the correct value of 50.3 seconds of
arc per year.
Star Catalogue
In the year 134 B.C. a bright comet
appeared near the chief star Antares in
the constellation Scorpio. It is believed
with the appearance of this comet Hip-
parchus began to form a catalogue of
stars. By the time it was finished he
had a list of 1080 stars, giving the
celestial latitude and longitude of each
and classifying each star according to
six magnitudes of brightness. It was
during the completion of his catalogue
that Hipparchus noticed that there was
a change in longitude of the stars. Long-
itude is the arc of the ecliptic measured
eastward from the vernal equinox to
the foot of the great circle passing
through the poles of the ecliptic and
the star in question.

BELTS
The recently discovered Van Allen radiation
belts, which circle the earth, may have an im-
portant effect on man's space effort.
by RICHARD KARPINSKI, '62E
Then the door opened. The director
walked in with the packet contain-
ing the data. Men who had been noisily
speculating on the results hushed now.
Had they made a great discovery? Had
the experiment confirmed theory? Or had
it been another failure? Had some small
but vital part got out of adjustment and
thrown off the whole study?
These may have been some of the
thoughts in the mind of scientists at
the State University of Iowa as they re-
ceived the reports from Explorer I, the
first U.S. earth satellite. As the data was
examined they did find that at low alti-
tudes, the radiation reported by the
satellites agreed well with the reports
from other sources. However, at higher
altitudes, radiation seemed to drop off
altogether. From this, the scientists con-
cluded that either they had better begin
looking for reasons or that the instru-
ments had simply failed.
Neither Explanation
Neither explanation seemed very
likely, though; the force required to de-
flect normal cosmic rays from the area
in question would be much greater than
the magnetic force field of the earth
was thought to be, and the instruments
reported normally on repeated lower-al-
titude passes.
Now the first thing a scientist does
when confronted with a problem like
Richard Karpinski, a transfer
from Michigan Tech, is a sopho-
more in Engineering Math. While
at Tech Dick was named to Phi
"** *"
Eta Sigma, the freshman honor so-
citey.
As a student at Mumford High
H« £►&gt;
in Detroit, Dick was active in the
Math Club and the Chess Club. His
^C^\*
interests include science fiction,
archery, and cycling.
sfv\\
this is to get more and more complete
data. The aid of another satellite was
enlisted and Explorer III was put into
orbit with a duplicate set of instruments,
namely a Geiger tube and scaling me-
chanism, temperature and micrometeorite
detectors, and high and low power radio
transmitters, with the addition of a
small tape recorder to fill in the gaps
in the orbit which were not directly
over one of the eleven tracking stations.
The tapes from this new moon only
seemed to verify the reports from the
other. At low altitudes the expected re-
sults were obtained, as altitude increased
sharply until suddenly about a thousand
miles above the surface of the earth
the radiation count fell to nearly zero
and stayed there until the satellite re-
turned to the lower altitudes.
Then came the first break: One of
the men who had recently been work-
ing at calibrating the instruments re-
called the forgotten fact that a Geiger
tube will fail to operate at all under
intense radiation. The reason for this is
that after each pulse the tube registers,
a slight pause is required to rebuild
the potential of the tube. This "dead
time" was on the order of l/10,000th
of a second per impulse for the tubes
used in Explorers I and III. When the
rate of particles exceeds this point, the
tube puts out only a fraction of the
normal signal strength. The scaler could
only use signals of one-eighth normal
strength or more so that beyond the
critical points no values at all would
be recorded. This critical point was cal-
culated at about 35,000 counts per sec-
ond with the above dead time.

22
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


the conversation, one of the men broke
out with the comment, "Space is radio-
active!", which is rather inaccurate but
illustrative. Now they knew they had
discovered the intense bands of radia-
tion following the earth's magnetic lines
of force that physicists had speculated
on as long as fifty years ago. No one,
however, had predicted the great power
and speed of the particles found.
With the new interpretation of data,
the men could begin to map the Van
Allen radiation belt, as it became known
in honor of one of the scientists at Iowa.
The data from Explorers I and III gave
good contours only for the very bottom
of the high radiation area. Next? More
and better information.
A fourth Explorer went up with a
different payload of instruments, includ-
ing two smaller Geiger rubes, which
were less efficient and scaled down more
to record higher counts and one of which
was shielded with lead to check the
power of particles. The payload also
contained equipment to measure the
total energy received and a selective
counting apparatus to count electrons of
over 65,000 electron volts and protons
of over 10 mev (million electron volts).
Excellent Information
Excellent information provided by
Explorer IV allowed the researchers to
plot the radiation levels up to 1300
miles above the earth and 50 degrees
either side of the magnetic equator.
Toward the poles the belt seemed to
dip into the upper atmosphere perhaps
causing the Northern and Southern
Lights. However, the upper bounds of
the belt were still uncertain and two
general theories were developed: most
of the men at Iowa felt that one band
would describe the situation well, but
one man, Carl Mcllwain, the man who
had offered the solution to the first puz-
zle of the lack of readings in the belt,
held out for the two band theory which
would include an outer banana-shaped
band fully covering a smaller bean-
shaped band both centered over the mag-
netic equator. This theory actually fit the
contours more closely, but now more
and better information was needed.
This time Pioneers I and III carried
equipment to check radiation on their
attempted lunar probes. The reports
from I were spotty but they did show
that the belt or belts extended for thou-
sands of miles upward as expected. Pio-
neer III, however, fell short of the moon
and cut through the area twice, report-
DECEMBER, 1959
ing constantly to the stations on earth.
Not only did it show how far out the
radiation continued but it proved con-
clusively that there were in fact two
well-defined belts, as Mcllwain had pre-
dicted.
The Belts
After all of these reports were an-
alyzed a fair picture of the belts was
obtained including the constituency of
both bands. The outer band seems to be
composed of electrons and protons
trapped from the sun. Their energy is
comparatively low. Hence the band,
which is thousands of miles thick and
has its center some six thousand miles
above the earth, should pose little dif-
ficulty for the space traveler.
The inner band, however, is another
matter. Only 1500 miles up and com-
paratively thin, its particles have ener-
gies in the hundreds of mev and can
penetrate inches of metal. One would
acquire a lethal does of radiation in
about five hours in this zone and the
amount of shielding needed to protect
one would be prohibitive. At the mo-
ment, it seems that one would just have
to either miss the belt completely by-
taking off from polar regions or else
blast through at top speed and endure
it. Neither prospect is very comforting
and taking off from the pole has the
added disadvantage of the fact that
these areas would be dangerous during
solar flare-ups as charged particles are
attracted strongly to the poles.
Dr. Fred Singer of the University of
Maryland has an interesting solution to
this problem. He proposes to put a big,
heavy, metal satellite into orbit within
this belt. Since the particles in question
travel at speeds approaching that of
light, making the pole to pole round
trip in less than two seconds, the belt
should be completely destroyed in a
matter of months.
Whether this could be done depends
in part on the rate of particles joining
the band and where they come from.
Dr. Singer believes the particles come
from atmospheric molecules smashed by
cosmic rays. Electrons and protons from
these collisions would not have the
energies required of the particles in the
belt, but neutrons are also released and
the Singer estimates that one in a mil-
lion of these would decay into high
energy proton-electron pairs which would
then inhabit the belt. Other scientists,
however, say this could only account for
very small fraction of the particles
needed to sustain the belt.

Project Argus
Soon after discovery of the belts some
people began wondering if possibly still
another belt could be created by man.
Consequently Project Argus had been
conceived.
An atomic bomb (fission) was known
to be a good source of the huge quan-
tities of high energy particles that would
be required for such a presumtuous ex-
periment using the whole earth as a

■?*■ Three atomic explosions 5O0mi
1 up sent electrons racing hack and
torth aloito, magnetic meridians
laboratory. Project Argus therefor plan-
ned to explode three small, 1.5 kiloton
bombs in the upper atmosphere. (A 1.5
kiloton bomb has an explosive power
equal to 1500 tons of TNT.)
As the armed forces were in charge
of this experiment, they checked the
possibilities of building such a strong
radiation belt that atomic warheads on
missies would be set off before they got
to the ground. As it turned out, this
would be almost impossible to do, would
be highly unstable, and warheads could
be easily protected from it. However,
the experiment was carried through and
yielded valuable information on the
stability of the natural belts. It also
proved the hypothesis that the Aurora
Borealis and its southern counterpart
Aurora Australis, the Northern and
Southern Lights, were indeed caused by
the radiation belts.
The bombs were exploded on sched-
ule and filled out the whole belt in a
matter of about an hour. The belt
caused by the first bomb was compara-
tively weak. The other two bombs,
though, produced a very strong belt
which lasted for days. The belt pro-
ceded to show itself visibly in both
hemispheres as beautiful displays of
aurora.
The Aurora itself is the "death
march of the particles." It is caused by
the collisions of the high energy par-
ticles that make up the radiation belts
with the gas molecules of the upper at-
mosphere. Each collision slows the par-
ticle down a little until finally it drops
out of the radiation belts entirely. This
explains the variation in auroral activity
with sunspot activity as the belts are at
least in part supplied with particles by
the sun.
Another point of interest is that
Project Argus interfered with radio
communications, blanking them out com-
pletely in some cases. Here, however,
the customary military secrecy prevented
full use of the experiment by failing
to notify radio operators to be on the
lookout for strange phenomena. The in-
formation that was gathered was suffi-
cient to point to a more useful evalua-
tion of the effect of sunspot activity on
radio communications, through the radi-
ation belts, anyway.
So as we cross over the threshold of
the space age the startling discovery of
the belts has answered many questions
but it has also asked many more.

ANOTHER WAY RCA
SERVES DEFENSE
THROUGH
ELECTRONICS

To our missile experts, "is it ready" is al-
most as important as "how far can it go."
For retaliatory power, missile crews must
be able to launch a maximum number of
missiles in rapid fire order.
America's intercontinental ballistic mis-
sile, the Atlas, had already proved itself
for distance on a 5500-nautical-miIe range.
But checkout and launching took several
hours. So the next step in turning the mis-
sile into an operational weapon was to
make it ready for quick action. RCA was
selected to build an electronic system that
would radically reduce the countdown
time at the Atlas Operational Bases now
under construction.
Now, in a matter of minutes, this elabo-
rate electronic system can determine if
any part needs attention—or signals that
the missile will be ready to go.
This automatic checkout equipment
and launch control system for the Atlas is
one more of the many ways in which RCA
Electronics works to strengthen our
national defense.

especially when evaluated in compari-

Important Fact
As mentioned, probably the most im-
portant fact in the "report from 128-
H" is the fact that the average salary
accepted by 238 B.S. candidates last year
was $508 a month. This figure becomes

THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


in 1957-58 and $465 in 1956-57. In
other words, the general upward demand
for engineers that started in the early
fifties is still continuing, and, in fact,
is increasing at an even greater rate.
This last fact is brought out even
more strongly by the fact that in 1957-
58 there were 349 offers for regular em-
ployment while during the past year,
1958-59, there were 702 offers for em-
ployment. This would seem to indicate
that the demand for engineers almost
doubled during the year. It is interesting
to note that while there was a general
increase in offers for grads from all
branches of engineering the big jumps
were in electrical, aero, and mechanical
where the offers jumped from 79 to
206, 62 to 120, and 88 to 164 respec-
tively. Although these figures partially
reflect the country's recovery from the
recession they also indicate that the de-
mand for engineers will continue to in-
crease as our technological development
seeks new and wider horizons.
Two B.S. Degrees?
Turning to another important area
—whether or not to get two B.S. de-
grees—we find that it was generally
more profitable to do so this year than
last with the salaries accepted jumping
to $541. Grads receiving M.S. degrees
also jumped from $563 to $598 while
Pr.D. salaries went from $717 to $821.
Of interest to most engineers is where
they are going to work—geographically
speaking. As expected, Michigan and the
Mid-west get most of the M-grads but
California and the golden sun collared
20% of last year's class. The percentages
for the various locations are shown on
the accompanying chart.
One last note should be of great in-
terest to undergrads who are on the
lookout for summer jobs. Despite ru-
mors to the the contrary the summer job
picture is not rosy, in fact, it is down-
right poor. The fact is that only 21
undergrads received summer jobs through
the placement office. This may be some-
what of a shock since at least that many
are in attendance at most of the group
summer employment "interviews." In
other words, if you want a summer job
you're going to have to dig for it your-
self.
So with these facts and conclusions as
guideposts the Tecbnic wishes the up-
coming grads good luck and . . . happy
hunting.

Automatic systems developed by instrumentation
engineers allow rapid simultaneous recording
of data from many information points.

Frequent informal discussions among analytical
engineers assure continuous exchange of ideas
on related research projects.

Under the close supervision of an engineer,
final adjustments are made on a rig for
testing an advanced liquid metal system.
and what they d&lt;
The field has never been broader
The challenge has never been greater
Engineers at Pratt &amp; Whitney Aircraft today are concerned
with the development of all forms of flight propulsion
systems—air breathing, rocket, nuclear and other advanced
types for propulsion in space. Many of these systems are so
entirely new in concept that their design and development,
and allied research programs, require technical personnel
not previously associated with the development of aircraft
engines. Where the company was once primarily interested
in graduates with degrees in mechanical and aeronautical
engineering, it now also requires men with degrees in
electrical, chemical, and nuclear engineering, and in physics,
chemistry, and metallurgy.
Included in a wide range of engineering activities open to
technically trained graduates at all levels are these four
basic fields:
ANALYTICAL ENGINEERING Men engaged in this
activity are concerned with fundamental investigations in
the fields of science or engineering related to the conception
of new products. They carry out detailed analyses of ad-
vanced flight and space systems and interpret results in
terms of practical design applications. They provide basic
information which is essential in determining the types of
systems that have development potential.
DESIGN ENGINEERING The prime requisite here is an
active interest in the application of aerodynamics, thermo-
dynamics, stress analysis, and principles of machine design
to the creation of new flight propulsion systems. Men en-
gaged in this activity at P&amp;WA establish the specific per-
formance and structural requirements of the new product
and design it as a complete working mechanism.
EXPERIMENTAL ENGINEERING Here men supervise
and coordinate fabrication, assembly and laboratory testing
of experimental apparatus, system components, and devel-
opment engines. They devise test rigs and laboratory setups,
specify instrumentation and direct execution of the actual
test programs. Responsibility in this phase of the develop-
ment program also includes analysis of test data, reporting
of results and recommendations for future effort.
MATERIALS ENGINEERING Men active in this field
at P&amp;WA investigate metals, alloys and other materials
under various environmental conditions to determine their
usefulness as applied to advanced flight propulsion systems.
They devise material testing methods and design special
test equipment. They are also responsible for the determina-
tion of new fabrication techniques and causes of failures or
manufacturing difficulties.

TECHNIC
SPOTLIGHTS
PROGRESS
Compiled by IRVING SALMEEN, '63E
Automatic Transistor
Production
Scientists at the Westinghouse re-
search laboratories have taken a major
step toward the fast, continuous, com-
pletely automatic manufacture of tran-
sistors and related semiconductor de-
vices.
Dr. S. W. Herwald, Westinghouse
vice-president, research, disclosed that
Westinghouse scientists have constructed
long ribbons of semiconductor devices
by forming them along the surface of
long, thin crystals of germanium about
1/8 inch wide and a few thousandths of
an inch thick. Such construction appears
to make feasible the automatic produc-
tion of transistors and other solid-state
devices directly by machine.
"These devices demonstrated the ulti-
mate usefulness of a revolutionary new
method for growing germanium which
was recently discovered in our labora-
tories," Dr. Herwald said. "This tech-
nique grows the germanium as thin, flat
continuous strips, or dendrites—the exact
form in which it can be used directly
in finished semiconductor devices."
Conventionally, germanium is grown
as a thick, round ingot that requires
costly, time-consuming processing before
useful devices can be produced from it.
In contrast, such devices can be con-
structed directly on the smooth, mirror-
like surfaces of germanium dendrites
exactly as the material is grown.
The development of working devices
from dendrites is being carried out un-
der a $2 million "molecular electronics"
contract recently awarded to Westing-
house by the U. S. Air Force's Air Re-
search and Development Command, Dr.
Herwald reported.
Carried through to the development
of over-all systems, the molecular elec-
tronics concept could drastically reduce
the size, weight, and power consump-
tion of space-age electronic systems. This
concept involves a new understanding
of the basic nature and capabilities of
materials and a new approach—on a
molecular and atomic scale—to the con-
ception, design, and development of
materials that exhibit these capabilities.
* * *
An electronic instrument has been de-
veloped for clinical use in the recording
and analysis of movements of the pupil
of the eye. The measurement of these
pupillary changes provides valuable in-
formation about the condition of the
brain stem. Earlier instruments have in-
volved complex, time-consuming opera-
tions, making them unsuitable for clin-
ical applications.
N. S. Savannah
The nuclear "heart" of the N.S.
Savannah was laid open pictorially by
two television cameras while it generated
energy for the world's first atom-pow-
ered merchant ship.
Passengers in the ship's main lounge
were able to see, via television cameras.
a nuclear reactor working at its mighty-
task of producing steam for the Savan-
nah's conventional turbines. The pulse
or "heart beat" of the reactor also was
relayed over an accompanying audio
hookup.
The 21,000-ton vessel, christened July
21, 1959, by Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhow-
er at the Camden, N. J., yards of the
New York Shipbuilding Corporation, is
designed to run 3 years, or 300,000
miles, without refueling. The vessel was
proposed originally by President Eisen-
hower as a demonstration of "peacetime
use of atomic energy, harnessed for the
improvement of human living."
The reactor is housed in a "contain-
ment vessel" below decks, an area not
open to the 60 passengers the ship ac-
commodates. However, television cam-
eras were mounted so they could be
"panned" to provide a complete view
of the reactor compartment.
By means of a switching system in
the ship's control center, the television
picture of the propulsion unit was trans-
mitted over a closed circuit to a 6-by-8-
foot television projection screen in the
lounge. The cables leading to the cam-
eras were installed through the cham-
ber wall with a special "potting" proc-
ess to prevent any radioactivity from
seeping out from the containment vessel.
It was disclosed that two radiotele-
phone units were to be installed on the
S.nannah to enable passengers to make
ship-to-shore calls. The radio system also
will supply an added safety factor and
32
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


ation.
As an additional feature, the Savan-
nah's closed-circuit television system will
provide entertainment for passengers and
crew. Motion-picture films and other
program material will be fed to television
receivers in the main lounge, the ship's
bar, officers' lounge, and crew's lounge.
Moreover, provision is also made for
equipping 37 staterooms with television
sets.
Motion pictures can be transmitted
to the large main lounge screen as well
and, when the Savannah is close enough
to land, standard entertainment television
broadcasts can be picked out of the air.
Except for its atomic power supply,
which replaces the customary fuel and
boilers, the Savannah is very much like
any modern merchant ship.

A device utilizing miniature photo-

ring within a finger. The device is
helpful in certain medical diagnosis,
where knowledge of the amount of
blood in a limb or organ of a body
is important.
"Pop-up" Program
Polaris has been undergoing "Pop-
up" underwater launching tests since
January 1958, at San Clemente Island,
located 55 miles south of Los Angeles
Harbor.
Earlier Pop-up tests were made with
a dummy of heavy boiler plate construc-
tion which fell back into an elaborate
submerged net system. The prototype

The plumber was introducing the new

"Above all," he said, "you must exer-
cise politeness and tact."
The assistant allowed as how he un-
derstood about politeness but, "What is
tact?"
"Well, son," he replied, "it's this
way. If you walk into a bathroom to
fix a pipe and a young lady is in the
tub, you close the door and say, 'Beg
your pardon, sir' The 'Beg your pardon'
is politeness. The 'sir'—that's tact."

We point with pride to the purity of

A farmer and a professor were shar-
ing a seat on a train. It was getting
lonesome so the farmer started a con-
versation and they soon became a
friendly pair.
Let's have a game of riddles to pass
the time," said the professor, "if I have
a riddle that you can't guess you give
me one dollar or vice versa."
"All right," replied the farmer, "but
since you are better educated than I am,
do you mind if I give you only fifty
cents?"
"OK," replied the professor. "You
go first."
"Well, what animal has three legs
walking and two legs flying?"
"I don't know. Here's your dollar.
What's the answer?"
"I don't know either. Here's your
fifty cents," answered the farmer.

COULD YOU MAKE A BETTER BATHING SUIT?
The suits these girls are wearing are
made of nylon, the first truly synthetic
fiber. It is a product of DuPont re-
search. Pure research. Applied research.
And research in manufacture, research
in product improvement. All require
many types of skills.
You may not discover a new fiber, but
as a technical man you can profit well
anyway. For once a product—any prod-
uct—is discovered, hundreds of technical
men go to work. Pilot plants are de-
signed. Operating procedures are devised.
New plants are built. Manufacturing
methods are improved. Product quality
is worked on, backed by Du Pont's policy:
Let's make it better . . . still better . . .
even better. Discovery is but the start-
ing shot; these later activities are the
game. The players? Men of every tech-
nical specialty.
You'll find a teamwork atmosphere at
DuPont. Others have. Maybe that's
part of the reason half of Du Pont's
profits today come from products un-
heard of twenty-five years ago.
If you join DuPont, the men who have
worked on new products and ways to
make them are the men who will teach
you. You will be given an actual project
assignment almost at once, and you will
begin to learn your job by doing it. Ad-
vancement will come as rapidly as your
abilities permit and opportunities de-
velop. For DuPont personnel policy is
based firmly on the belief in promotion
from within the company strictly on a
merit basis.
For more information about career
opportunities at Du Pont, ask your place-
ment officer for literature. Or write us.
E. I. du Pont de Nemours &amp; Co. (Inc.),
2420 Nemours Building, Wilmington 98,
Delaware.

Better Things for Better Living ... through Chemistry
DECEMBER, 1959
35


IBM scientist Gerald Burns
studies ferroelectrics
to improve understanding
of their basic properties.

A basic research project
"I'm using nuclear resonance to explore ferro-
electrics," says IBM scientist Gerald Burns.
"We're trying to discover how the ions in a ferro-
electric crystal are arranged, and why and how
they change position and structure with tempera-
ture changes. Ferroelectric crystals have a revers-
ible spontaneous polarization . . . that is, they can
be polarized in either of two directions, and, by
the application of an electric field, polarization can
be reversed."
How did Gerry Burns come to work on this prob-
lem? "I started this particular research project be-
cause it was related to other work I had been doing
and I felt it would prove challenging and reward-
ing. Little is known about what goes on in a ferro-
electric crystal—or why. Our basic objectives are
to find out what and why.
"At the planning stage, the project seemed to offer
a great research potential, but none of us was
sure how long the project might last or what its
ramifications might eventually be. It's a good ex-
ample of the basic research done at IBM."

A day at the laboratory
One of the eight scientists in the Ferroelectric Re-
search Group, 26-year-old Gerald Burns began a
recent day by setting up equipment for the first
daily run.
"The experiment is conceptually quite simple," he
explained. "A ferroelectric crystal is placed in the
tank circuit of an oscillator, between the pole
pieces of a large electromagnet. The sample is sur-
rounded by a dewar so that the temperature can be
accurately regulated. Then the magnetic field is
slowly decreased. When the field reaches certain
values, the nuclei in the crystal absorb energy from
the oscillator. The trick is to detect this absorption
which is quite small. Runs at various temperatures
are made, and the temperature dependence of this
absorption is studied.
After setting up the first run, Gerry Burns met
with the head of his group. Together, they dis-
cussed the temperature dependence of the nuclear
quadrupole resonance coupling constants. Several
helpful suggestions were made.
Gerry Burns then talked with chemists who grow
the crystals used in the experiments. They dis-
cussed possible variations in the crystal-growing
method and considered the growth of other crys-
tals in order to broaden the experiments.
Early in the afternoon, he attended a seminar con-
ducted by a visiting professor on the subject of
the atomic structure of solids. Each week, several
such seminars on a variety of technical matters
are given.
After the seminar, Gerry Burns returned to set up
another run at a different temperature. He also
talked to a technician about building a new piece
of equipment to be used in future experiments.

Excellent facilities and programs
"Besides these experiments, I'm also doing some
theoretical calculations in the field of nuclear
quadrupole resonance. The actual computations
were done here at the Laboratory on an IBM 704,
which can perform in minutes computations which
would take weeks if done by other methods.
"This is one of the advantages of working at IBM.
Large-scale high-speed computers are available to
research scientists when needed. Furthermore you
will find your colleagues always willing to help
when you are stumped by a problem. Many of
these men are recognized authorities in their
fields. The exchange is always informative and
often stimulates new ideas and approaches.
"Our Company offers many educational opportu-
nities—both in general education and for ad-
vanced degrees," Gerry Burns said. "As an exam-
ple, engineers and scientists may earn a Master's
Degree in a post-graduate program conducted by
Syracuse University right here in Poughkeepsie.
"We also have a very useful library. Just the other
day I dropped in to pick up some technical papers
I needed as source material for an article. I've al-
ready published one paper on my experiments,"
he noted. "You're encouraged to publish your
findings and to participate in professional society
meetings. It's important for a research man to
work in an atmosphere where independent think-
ing is encouraged and where every effort is made
to facilitate research investigations."

by MURRAY PATTERSON, '60E
Ford Grant
The University of Michigan has been
granted $1,175,000 by the Ford Foun-
dation as one of the first of the new
Foundation grants in science and engi-
neering.
Henry T. Heald, Foundation presi-
dent, announced the program in an
address in Washington, D.C., before the
annual meeting of the American In-
stitute of Consulting Engineers.
The U-M will use the grant for two
new projects.
The major share, $900,000, will be
used to support a U-M experimental
program leading to the wide-spread use
of high-speed computers in engineering
education. While the U-M will direct
this program, a number of faculty mem-
bers of other institutions will be in-
vited to participate.
The remainder, S275.000, is to be
used to strengthen engineering education
by recruiting and maintaining promising
faculty members. The money is to be
used to financially help outstanding doc-
toral candidates who intend to teach en-
gineering to attain their degrees faster,
and to further development of present
faculty members.
Acknowledging the grant, Dean S. S.
Attwood, of the U-M College of En-
ginering said, "We are pleased and ap-
preciative of the Ford Foundation grant
that will enable us to advance the qual-
ity of engineering education, both lo-
cally and in cooperating institutions.
"Certain features of the grant will
attract more young engineers into teach-
ing and speed up their acquisition of
doctoral degrees.
"The grant also introduces students
early in their training to the use of
electronic computers, which will permit
them to study and solve more complex
problems than in the past, and to in-
troduce computer techniques upon grad-
uation into many industrial operations.
Both engineering education and indus-
try will profit."
Details of the computer education
portion of the grant were listed by
Prof. Donald L Kati, chairman of the
Department of Chemical and Metallur-
gical Engineering and chairman of the
Computer Committee of the College of
Engineering.
The aim of the U-M program, Prof.
Katz said, is to ensure that all future
engineering graduates have an acquain-
tance with the use of computers in en-
gineering calculations, just as they have
with other engineering practices.
The Ford grant will help the Uni-
versity to show the way to introducing
engineering students to the use of com-
puters in regular courses early in their
training, probably during their sopho-
more year.

"This campus is one of the few in
the world which embraces professional
groups in practically all areas related
to space technology."
In outlining the faculty strengthening
portion of the grant, the Ford Founda-
tion pointed out that "these years are
particularly crucial to the future of en-

are to add greater scientific and math-
ematical emphasis to the undergraduate
curricula and to increase the number of
students preparing for engineering ca-
reers at all levels. Thus, the recruitment,

qualified faculty personnel is the fore-
most problem of engineering education."
Fallout Food
University of Michigan scientists are
making the nation's first long-term
study of the effect of radioactive fallout
on man's food supply.
In cooperation with the Argonne
Laboratories and seven agricultural ex-
periment stations across the country, they
are trying to draw a "base line" for
measuring the slow rise in radiological
levels in grain and other crops.
Prof. A. Geoffrey Norman of the
U-M Department of Botany reports that
to date only a "fantastically small"
amount of radiation has worked its way
into the nation's farm crops. Although
the level of radiation appears to have
increased between 1949 and 1955, he
adds, it could stabilize fairly soon if no
further nuclear tests are conducted.
With radio-chemical techniques, Pro-
fessor Norman and his colleagues ex-
amine crop samples grown in the same
location at the agricultural experiment
stations.
The U-M study is one of several re-
lated projects designed to trace fallout
from the atmosphere through man's en-
vironment and into the physical being.
New Assistant Dean of the Engineering
School is Dean Arlen R. Hellwarth. He
graduated from the University in 1925
and taught in the Electrical Engineer-
ing department from 1930 to 1933.
Space Aims
University of Michigan work bearing
on space explorations was outlined by
Prof. Wilbur C. Nelson, chairman of
the U-M's Department of Aeronautical
and Astronautical Engineering.
He spoke before the Seventh Trien-
nial Medical Alumni Conference here.
He said that various U-M units are
presently pursuing these projects:
1. Research in nuclear propulsion
and nuclear power generation.
2. Research leading to the instrumen-
tation of a satellite observatory.
3. Initial work leading to meteorolog-
ical satellite instrumentation.
4. Research and development (R
and D) work leading to the instrumen-
tation of a lunar probe for the measure-
ment of lunar atmospheric pressure.
5. Design and development of a 5-
tage, 1,000-mile-altitude sounding rocket
to measure electron density in the
atmosphere.
6. "R and D" work in inertial navi-
gation and long-range radar tracking
and communication.
7. Sponsorship of several extensive
Space Technology Seminars in the new
U-M Institute of Science and Technol-
ogy, under Dr. Robert R. White. These
are to bring leading authorities to Ann
Arbor for lectures and consultation be-
ginning this month.
As for the future, Professor Nelson
said he could say with certainty only
that "the University will become more
deeply engrossed in this fascinating and
vast field of work as time goes on.
"One can certainly predict an increas-
ing interplay between the engineers, the
physical scientists, the life scientists, and
the School of Medicine as our space
program develops.
The new Assistant Dean and Secre-
tary of the College of Engineering is
not a stranger to the University of Mich-
igan. Dean Arlen R. Hellwarth gradu-
ated from the University in 1925 with
a Bachelor of Science in Electrical En-
gineering and a Master of Science in
Mathematics in 1936. During his stu-
dent days he became affiliated with Phi
Kappa Tau and Tau Beta Pi. He taught
in the Electrical Engineering Department
from 1930 to 1933.
Dean Hellwarth left the position of
Assistant to the Director of Employ-
ment at the Detroit Edison in February
1959 after twenty-five years service.
The Assistant Dean sees a need for
greater class spirit and more pride for
the College of Engineering among the
engineering students. He also stresses
the importance of faculty counseling
services for all the students in engineer-
ing throughout their stay at the campus.
Dean Hellwarth points out that invalu-
able help is available from the faculty,
b:yond that provided in the classroom,
if the student will seek it. He hopes,
with student interest and assistance, to
develop opportunities that will help pre-
pare students for their early introduction
to their chosen profession of engineer-
ing.

by RANDOLPH ROGERS, '57J
he scientific world was startled last
week upon disclosure of the discovery
in nature of the last remaining undis-
covered natural element, finally complet-
ing the periodic table.
Natural technetium, atomic number
43, was discovered by a commune of
worker-physicists lead by Prof. Nikolai
Borschtkin of the Akademie Sovietska
Fiz/ki in Novosibrsk, USSR. Heretofore,
technetium had been made only by the
bombardment of molybdenum with pro-
tons accelerated by a cyclotron.
The extent and purity of the Russian
technetium deposits were not revealed
in the Russian radio broadcast announc-
ing the discovery, which was monitored
by the BBC in London.
The Russians have reported at length
on the chemical and mechanical prop-
erties of this new element, whose exist-
ence in nature was previously considered
very doubtful.
Chemically, technetium (symbol Tc,
at. no. 43) occurs virtually 100% in the
isotope with atomic weight 99. It occu-
pies a place in the electromotive series
below lead, and has valences of six and
seven. It is found in the native state,
as the trioxide TcA3, and as the sulfide,
TcS:1. Refining of the native ore is done
mechanically; of the oxide by reducing
with hydrogen or carbon monoxide; of
the sulfide by roasting followed by re-
duction.
Like most of the rare earth metals,
technetium does not form carbonates.
Being a group VIIB element like man-
ganese, it shares many chemical proper-
ties with this metal It forms the weak
pertechnetic acid, HTc04, and the
strongly oxidizing compound KTcO,,,
corresponding to potassium permanga-
nete. Technetium does not have a strong
affinity for the halogens, and while it
forms many intermetallic compounds,
the salts and the oxide are not stable.
Many of the compounds exhibit a pink
color, and the borax bead is pink.
Many uses have been proposed for the
chemical compounds of the new ele-
ment. HTc04 presents interesting pos-
sibilities as an oxidizing agent for solid-
propellant rockets, as it is very easy and
cheap to prepare and handle, and de-
composes at a very regular rate. An
aqueous solution of the chloride or bro-
mide is pressure-sensitive, and will
change color from clear to pale pink to
scarlet as the barometric pressure drops
from 31 to 28 inches of mercury. Small
quantities of the nitrate, chlorate, or
phosphate added to a hydroponics tank
apparently will increase the growth rate
by 20 to 30 percent, and create a high
degree of mutations. Certain organic re-
actions, particularly those encountered in
the synthesis of antibiotics, are catalyzed
very effectively by the metal, its carbide
(Tc4C7) and the intermetallic compound
with vanadium, TcV„.
The properties of the unalloyed metal
are far from spectacular. Crystallizing in
the hexagonal close-packed system, the
metal is dense, soft, and has a very
low elastic modulus. Surprisingly, the
metal behaves as though brittle under
impact loads. A specmen which stretch-
es like rubber when pulled slowly frac-
tures into splinters like glass when
jerked or hammered.
The principal reason for excitement
in metallurgical circles over the new
element is that it forms a hard eutectic-
type intermetallic compound with alu-
minum. This compound, Al,Tc, serves
the same function in aluminum that iron
carbide does in steel. It raises the hard-
ness of the metal when it is present even
in small quantities. Thus a new alloy
containing about 2 percent Al,Tc is to
aluminum what tool steel is to soft fer-
ritic iron.

(Continued from page 17)
to be maintained. In his research shop
he had built what he called a dual image-
illuminating monochromator. With it he
was able to project the long and short
records simultaneously selecting for the
two projecting lights any wavelengths in
the entire visible spectrum.
Using this apparatus, it was found the
eye could recieate the full range of colors
with any two wavelengths in the spectrum
just so that the two were sufficiently far
apart. Moreover, he found that the sep-
aration varied throughout the spectrum
and in some regions could be only three
percent of the total visible variations in
color. Hence, two yellow lights could be
used to achieve the proper effect.
Another unusual observation was that
correct color reproduction did not al-
ways occur when the long recoid was
illuminated by the longer wavelength
and visa versa. In the blue region, the
proper relationship among the colors
occurred only when the long image was
projected with the shorter wavelength.
Using the dual monochromator. Land
was able to develop a chart for pre-
dicting the color produced by any pair
of records. The technique used to do
this is too complex for discussion here,
but the very fact that such a procedure
can be carried out shows the appar-
ent reliability of the observations.
Eye Detection of Color
How then, does the eye detect color?
Land's work seems to point that it is
not through detection of specific wave-
lengths. What means is used instead of
this classical theory is open to broad
speculation.
Two further experiments seems to
suggest a possible theory. Throughout
the work it appeared that there must
be a certain degree color of rendomness
in the presence of colors for a full color
image to be observed. For example, one
could not obtain a solid blue image from
the method if blue was not one of the
illuminating lights. To further test this
idea, a "wedge" filter was placed in
the red projector. The image showed a


Projector for use with the photographs taken with the dual color camera. The filter
in front of the long record is red and there is no filter for the short record.
red area on one side and gradually
faded into a dark area on the other. In
the white projector, another wedge fil-
ter was placed with gradient perpendic-
ular to the wedge in the red projector.
The top of the image was white and
the bottom black. Over the image area,
with both lamps turned on, the entire
range of red and white ratios was
achieved including every one possible
in a full colored image. However in
this case, the ratios were in a strictly
ordered arrangement. Hence there was
no randomness and no color—only a
graded pink wash.
The second experiment involves two
colored images. Although Land used two
special viewers, the result is analogous
to using two dual monochromators. One
image was projected using one pair of
wavelengths; another, with the identical
scene, was projected on an adjacent
screen using a separate pair of wave-
lengths. Both images were visible at the
same time, yet the color in each was
derived from a different pair of wave-
lengths. Hence each is a separate color
world passing on color information in
some yet unknown way to the eye.
Apparently, Land claims, the eye per-
ceives color by comparing longer and
shorter wavelengths. Somewhere in the
visible spectrum is a fulcrum on one
side of which all wavelengths are short
and on the other side long. Experiments
show that in the ordinary sunlit world,
there is such a fulcrum. Land believes
that this fulcrum is automatically de-
termined by the eye in each separate
color world and that it is used to de-
termine the ratios used for color per-
ception in that color world.
How the eye goes about doing this
is still unclear. Land speculates that
many wavelengths are filtered in the eye
and each forms a separate image on the
retina. The brain then determines the
fulcrum wavelength, averages together
all the wavelengths on the long side of
the fulcrum and all those on the short
side, and finally compares the two av-
erages. The ratio of these averages de-
termines what color is perceived.
One thing must be made clear. Land
does not propose a two-color theory of
light. His experiments show that clas-
sical three color theory of perception
does not predict the observed results in
his work. He has demonstrated that the
eye can operate quite well with two
packages of information and that three
colors are not needed for the percep-
tion of the entire visible spectrum. He
has proposed a theory of color percep-
tion which he believes explains his ob-
servations. Nevertheless, before any con-
clusions are drawn, there are many
questions to be answrered; but one thing
is certain. The method of color per-
ception used by the eye is exceedingly
complex and surprisingly unknown.

(Continued from page 19)
violet rays discolor it. Also it is not
flameproof, although it does burn slowly.
Delrin will create fierce competition
for metal castings. The metals which
will be especially vulnerable to this com-
petition are aluminum and zinc in the
form of castings. These metals are pres-
ently used quite widely in the automo-
bile industry. DuPont expects to have
two pounds of Delrin in each auto pro-
duced in the near future. Considering
the tremendous volume of automobile
production, this will amount to a very
sizable market for Delrin, if DuPont
can realize their goal.
Since it is resistant to many normal
solvents, and since it has a compara-
tively high melting point, it will prob-
ably be used to a large extent in the
food-processing industry. In fact, Union
Chain and Manufacturing Company of
Sandusky, Ohio is planning to replace
much of the stainless steel in their food
and brewery processing conveyors with
Delrin.
Zebco of Oklahoma, the world's
largest manufacturer of closed-face fish-
ing reels is planning to take advantage
of Delrin's resistance to salt water by
using it in reels.
Because of its strength, Delrin may
very well find application as gears and
pump impellers.
Costs Not High
At first glance, Delrin appears so ex-
pensive as to make it almost useless
from an economic viewpoint, but upon
scrutiny one begins to realize that it
is actually quite inexpensive. At the on-
set of production, Delrin will cost in
the vicinity of ninety-five cents per
pound, three to seven times higher than
H
I
C=0
i
H
copper, zinc or aluminum. But, the dif-
ference in density between a metal and
Delrin means that a weight-unit of
Delrin will occupy much more volume
than the same weight of a metal. Also
the cost of molding and finishing op-
erations must be considered. The mold-
ing cost of Delrin and the casting cost
of most metals are about equal, but,
when Delrin comes out of the mold, it
is almost a finished product, whereas, a
metal casting must go through many
expensive finishing operations. In addi-
tion, the plastic scrap can easily be re-
melted and remolded.
The general price trend of metals
has been up, whereas that of plastics
has been down. Every plastic now sells
at a lower price than when it was intro-
duced, because larger capacity, and new
processing methods have combined to
result in more efficient production. Del-
rin is far from expensive now, and if
it follows the trend established by other
plastics, it will be much cheaper than
many metals.
It will also find many uses which
will utilize those properties in which
it is more like a plastic than a metal.
These include its electrical properties, and
the fact that it is not toxic.
DuPont is taking a chance by intro-
ducing a plastic which may provide
competition for one of its present prod-
ucts. Nylon is presently being used in
gears and in a few other applications
which are also among the many uses
of Delrin. But, DuPont feels that if
their brand of nylon, Zytel, is to be
replaced by another product, it is best
that it be a product of DuPont rather
than of one of its competitors. Also,
DuPont may be contemplating produc-

(Continued from page 40)
The mechanical properties reported
for the new alloy containing 98 percent
aluminum and 2 percent aluminum tech-
netide are amazing, and will open
doors for aluminum such as the Bes-
semer process did for iron. It has a
tensile strength of 80,000psi. in the
annealed condition and a tensile strength
of 280,OOOpsi. when water quenched.
It may be quenched as rapidly as de-
sired without danger of cracking or em-
brittlement. It has a Rockwell "C" hard-
ness of 88 on the surface and an Re
of 75 at the center of a two-inch rod.
The hardness drops to 85 percent of
these values at 1000° F. and to 70 per-
cent at 2000° F., but the alloy is com-
pletely melted at 2300° F., thus facili-
tating casting. In addition, the new
alloy retains all the lightness and resist-
ance to corrosion of pure aluminum,
giving a strength-to-weight ratio far su-
perior to steel.
The new alloy has about the same
electrical characteristics as aluminum,
but because of its high strength, will

probably find wide use in transmission-
line conductors. Because it excels steel
in hardness, strength, lightness, conduc-

The name for the new alloy suggest-

Nearly 90 percent of the small but grow-
ing production of natural technetium is
slated for production of experimental
leninite, and U. S. spacemen are spec-
ulating on whether leninite components
could have been used in the latest So-
viet rocket.
Although no deposits of natural
techentium are known anywhere in the
free world, there is growing evidence
that some technetium may have been

Compiled by BRYAN WHIPPLE, '61E
1. A* house bill time once more rears
its ugly head around the various uni-
versity residences, no doubt many enter-
prising engineers are casting about for
a quick way to earn some extra cash.
For those few who will be foolish
enough to try to make some extra bread
at a game of chance, the Tcchnic would
like to suggest a curious new kind of
poker, in which it is always possible
for a given player to win:
In this new version of draw poker,
all 52 cards are placed on the table,
face up. The players take turns drawing
poker hands from the cards; that is, the
first player selects five cards for his hand,
then the second selects his hand, and so
forth. After this, each player in turn
is given the opportunity to draw up to
five new cards, or to stand pat. Then
the player with the highest hand wins.
However, since the suits are all equal,
two royal flushes will always tie.
Assuming that the discards are set
aside out of the game during each
hand, what combinations of cards may
the first player draw with complete as-
surance of winning with a pat hand?
* * *
2. A clever farmer contracted with a
suburbanite to plant an orchard in his
backyard. The contract specified that
there were to be five rows of four trees
each, but mention of the total number
of trees was avoided. The farmer ful-
filled the terms of the contract with
only ten trees, and his rows were
straight enough to please the most ex-
acting surveyor. Can you duplicate this
agricultural feat?
* * *
3. Can you arrange the digits 9, 9, 9
in such a way that they equal 20? You
may use any of the customary math
symbols, including decimal points, ex-
ponential notation, addition, subtraction,
etc., signs, and so on, but zeros may
not be used.
4. Now here's one to time yourself on.
If you know the secret, ten seconds is
too much time, but we'll allow a full
minute to greenhorns.
What is the length of the diagonal
of the rectangle under the quarter-circle
arc shown (line AB)?

Last summer at one of the ROTC summer camps one ot
the cadets was sent down to a stream to get some drinking
water for the platoon, but had not been gone long when he
came running back to the camp emptyhanded and panting.
"Sir," he explained, "there's a big alligator in the stream,
and I'm afraid to get the water."
"Don't worry, son," said the sympathetic officer. "That
alligator is probably four times as scared of you as you are
of him."
"Well, sir," replied the cadet, "if that alligator's only
half as scared as I am, that water ain't fit to drink."
An engineer is said to be a man who knows a great deal
about very little and who goes along knowing more and more
about less and less until finally he knows practically every-
thing about nothing; whereas,
A salesman, on the other hand, is a man who knows
very little about a great deal, and keeps knowing less and less
about more and more until he knows practically nothing about
everything.
A purchasing agent starts out knowing practically every-
thing about everything, but ends up knowing nothing about
anything, due to his association with salesmen and engineers.

(Continued from page 21)
Further Measurements
Hipparchus continued his research by
measuring the "Obliquity of the Eclip-
tic." which is the angle between the plane
of the Earth's orbit and that of the Earth's
equator (see plate I). He arrived at the
same result as Eratosthenes, which was
approximately 23 degrees and 27 min-
utes. Hipparchus continued to make
comparisons with the observations of
Aristarchus. He found that the tropical
year, which is the time enclosed by
two successive passages of the Sun
through the Vernal Equinox, was several
minutes too long from the accepted
value of 3654 days. Hipparchus made
a correction on the Tropical Year by
subtracting seven minutes from Aristar-
chus's value. This value was still four
minutes too long, but much of the error
was due to the uncertainty of Hippar-
chus's observations.
After correcting the length of the
year Hipparchus made observations on
the length of the seasons. He found
that the Sun took 186y2 days to travel
from the vernal equinox to the au-
tumnal equinox while it took only
178% days to travel from the autumnal
equinox to the next vernal equinox.
He observed the Moon and found its
orbit to have an inclination of five de-
grees to the ecliptic. He also tried to
find the size of the moon and its dis-
tance from the Earth by using an eclipse

method. He observed the angular diam-
eter of the Earth's shadow on the Moon,
and by comparing this with known an-
gular diameters of the Sun and Moon
he could calculate a proportion between
the distances of the Sun and Moon. He
calculated the distance to the Moon as
almost 59 times the Earth's radius, and
comparing this result to Aristarchus's
theory that the Sun was 19 times further
away than the Moon, Hipparchus con-
cluded that the distance to the Sun was
1,100 times the Earth's radius. This
value, however, is twenty times too
short; the true distance to the Sun is
23,400 times the Earth's radius. As
for the diameter of the Moon, Hippar-
chus found it to be a quarter of the
diameter of the Earth, which has a
diameter of 8,000 miles.
Hipparchus was also an inventor, and
his greatest achievement in this field
was an instrument used for observation-
al astronomy that could find the latitude
and longitude of any celestial body rela-
tive to another body for which the co-
ordinates are known.
Motion of Solar System
Before the time of Hipparchus many
theories were evolved about the motion
of the heavenly bodies. Appolonius of
Perga, who lived from about 250 B.C.
to 200 B.C. suggested that the motion
of the heavenly bodies could be ex-
In the Eccentric Theory point A revolves
around the Earth, and this distance from
the Earth is small.The planet or Sun is
revolving around point A.
plained easier by a combination of cir-
cular motions than by the complicated
theory of the revolving spheres of
Eudoxus. Hipparchus then studied the
movements of the stars and planets and
set forth two theories of circular mo-
tion, that of "eccentrics" and that of
"epicycles." Many of his fellow scien-
ces felt that the theory of the epicycles
was superior to the theory of eccen-
trics. The epicycle theory can easily be
explained. Each heavenly body is said
to move uniformly on a small circular
orbit called an epicycle. The center of
this epicycle then moves uniformly on
a larger circular orbit called the de-
ferent. The Earth is located at the cen-
ter of the deferent. In the theory of the
eccentrics the situation is different For
example, let us look at the Sun. In this
theory the center of the circular orbit
on which the Sun travels moves in a
circular orbit around the Earth, and the
distance to the Earth of this point re-
volving around the Earth is small. Hip-
parchus finally used both of these theo-
ries ,n forming another theory. He was
able with great success to apply his
theory to the movement of the Sun and
Moon, but he could not apply it to the
movement of the planets largely because
of the inadequate numbers of observa-
tions. The charts and tables that Hip-
parchus constructed for the Sun and
Moon, however, enabled his successors
to predict the times of a Moon eclipse
within an hour or two, and eclipses of
the Sun somewhat less accurately. How-
ever, these predictions were much more
accurate than ever before possible.
These are many of the achievements
of Hipparchus, one of the greatest as-
tronomers that ever lived. Throughout
his life he was searching for answers
that would give him a better under-
standing of how our universe ticks. Not
only did his work help him in under-
standing but also helped his successor
to uncover answers to many new and
old problems.

not require smokestacks or 'up-takes" to
carry smoke from her boilers.

Engineering Mechanics
Rapid technological developments have brought about an increasing need for engineers exceptionally
well-trained in the basic sciences The need is acute throughout industry and government as well as in
institutions of research and in universities; to help fill this neeed is the purpose of the program in Engi-
neering Mechanics.
Men with training in the field of Engineering Mechanics are sought by companies and institutions of
all kinds, particularly by those working on modern developments. Most young men in the field are engaged
in highly technical work, but many, like other engineers, enter supervision and management.
The major areas of study in the bachelors program are strength of materials, elasticity, plasticity,
dynamics, vibrations, fluid mechancis, and thermo-dynamics. The Department has small but modern labo-
ratories and adequate computer and research facilities. The association of theory with the physical aspects
of the work is very close.
The photograph shows a modern testing machine being prepared for a test. The instructor and student
are adjusting a displacement transducer. The machine is fully instrumented and records stress strain curves
for materials varying from steel to nylon threads. It is capable of automatically cycling the load or stress
between prescribed limits.

ANSWERS TO TEASERS
(Continued jrom page 36)
1. Any of 88 hands may be chosen by
the first player to assure himself of win-
ning. These are: Four tens and any other
card (48 possibilities); three tens and
any of the following pairs from the suit
of the remaining ten: A-9, K-9, Q-9,
J-9, K-8, Q-8, J-8, Q-7, J-6 (40 possi-
bilities). The reasons why these hands
are undefeatable and also preclude any
ties is not apparent at first, but anyone
who knows poker and does a little ex-
perimenting can readily verify this solu-
tion.
2. The trees are planted so as to form
a five-pointed star. One tree is placed
at each change in direction of the out-
side boundary of the star.
3. In order to write a quantity ecjual to
20 by using the digit 9 three times,
simply write (9+9)/.9, the method of
analysis involving the fact that two of
a number added and divided by the
same number gives 2, from which point
we simply start tinkering with the
decimal.
4. If you didn't get this one, perhaps
you'll be as disgusted with yourself as
I was when I flubbed it on a Math. 13
bluebook. Simply draw the other diag-
onal of the rectangle and note that it
is a radius of the arc. Since both
diagonals of a rectangle and all radii
of the same arc are equal, the line AB
must be ten units long.
Get lots of sleep over vacation and
see how much sharper you'll be in
January! Of course, the teasers will be
equally more difficult!

Indl StOpS. An operating room is
a quiet place, but you could hear a snow flake
drop when a living heart stops. Sometimes
only a single word is spoken, "epinephrine."
The syringe is firmly placed in the surgeon's
outstretched hand and he plunges the long
needle deep into the chest—into the center of
the heart itself. As soon as the life-giving
chemical touches the muscle of the heart, this
wondrous organ usually contracts violently
and starts to beat again.
In the human body epinephrine is secreted
by the core of the adrenal gland, and it acts
to regulate the flow of body blood in conjunc-
tion with other body chemicals.


DOW is tomorrow-minded
plant
Take just one for-instance: Plaquemine. Some five
hundred acres of Louisiana sugar cane country once.
Stately oaks and magnolias. Today they're still
there. But growing harmoniously with them are the
vivid contemporary colors of the new plant—the
Dow reds and greens, gleaming whites, Confederate
gray, businesslike black. They blend in with the
oaks and magnolias to provide one of America's
most modern and distinctive plant vistas. Along
with the forward-looking products and the people
who produce them, this tomorrow-minded Dow
plant is a part of the new face of the new South.
Plaquemine is located in one of the nation's fastest-
growing concentrations of chemical manufacture.
This now bustling Evangeline country offers abun-
dant natural resources, an excellent network of
transportation, good accessibility to great and
developing markets and communities. And, perhaps
most important of all—Old Man River—the limit-
less Mississippi, with its never-ending source of
fresh water and its gate to the ocean-going trade
routes of the world.
Today's Plaquemine is a symbol of Dow's tomorrow-
minded growth—at one of the fastest rates in the
industry. To keep pace with its output of products,
new and old, Dow plants are building nationwide.
Says the Chairman of the Board of Directors: "We
build in boom times to keep up with the demand;
we build in slump times for the future." And Dow
continues to build its plants, products and people
always with tomorrow in mind.
If you would like to know more about the Dow
opportunity, please write: Director of College
Relations, Dept. 2425FW, the dow chemical
company, Midland, Michigan.
THE DOW CHEMICAL COMPANY • MIDLAND, MICHIGAN

JANUARY, I960


In Closing
It is gratifying to sit back after four and a half years at this University and
observe the changes that have taken place. The physical appearance of the
campus hasn't changed so much—oh yes, the UGL has replaced the old Auto-
motive Labs, north campus increased in size, and twenty acres of cement sud-
denly found a home—the real change has occured in the students. People
whom I knew as shy freshmen, are now intimate friends and leaders in their
respective groups. Most of these friends, about whom I am talking, are in
student activities which points rather obviously at the value of activities.
Student activities have a two fold purpose; one is the service to the college
community, and the other is the benefit to the student participant. Service is
not the prime importance right now; it is there, easily obtainable, although in
many cases, quite debatable. The first order of importance is the benefit that
the activities offer to its student members. Opportunities in leadership, creative-
ness, and association are given to students. It is often quite amusing to watch
these students accept these challenges with both anticipation and apprehension,
mature with their new duties, and finally become indignant to suggested
assistance. Student activities build confidence, leadership ability, skill, and
harmony. In short, they give the necessary things that round out and complete
a college education.
As this is the last opportunity I shall have to express my opinions, (the
Technic will have a new editor in February) I wish to put a plug in for the
Technic. The time I have given to the Technic has been immense, but it has
been worth every minute of it. Gratifying to say the least, pleasurable to
describe the work, rewarding in character as to the climax—these all describe
my feelings for the Technic. My recommendation to student engineers is to
get into student activities so that you may benefit from the wonderful oppor-
tunities they afford.
In closing, I would like to give my appreciation and thanks to the Technic
Staff, who have worked very hard; to the faculty advisors, Professors W. Earl
Britton, Melville Stout, Richard Schneidewind, and Robert Weeks who have
lent their excellent guidance over the last few years; and last, but not least,
to you, the students of the college of Engineering, for your kind support.
Charles R. Hildebrandt

MEDICINE
Mechanically man has nearly conquered space.
Now the question is — will physicological and
psychological factors limit man's flight into
space?
by SUSAN OTT, '61E
Dummys, such as the one shown
here, have made possible great
advances in space medicine. They
have been used to test pressure
suits, rocket sleds, gravitational
and acceleration forces, as well as
a variety of other factors future
astronauts will have to face.
Since late 1957, the United States has
been frenziedly pushing its man-in-
space program. While rocket compon-
entry and fuel development have been
acknowledged for some years, little im-
portance was attached to the field of space
medicine until rather recently. No matter
how perfect the space vehicle, if man
cannot survive the rigors of swift flight
away from earth, there can be no man
in space—at least, not a living one.
As it happens, space doctors are more
nearly ready to send a man into orbit
than those engaged in the logistics of the
project. This is reasonable. Doctors lay
down the requirements for the preserva-
tion of human life in space; it falls to
the engineer to adhere to these require-
ments, to make them physically possible
and, when everything is installed and
functioning, to get the whole thing off
the ground.
Three Major Aspects
The considerations of the space doctor
fall roughly into three large categories:
the physiological aspect, the psychological
aspect, and the methods of taking data.
Researchers find that the main points of
the physiological facet are these:
1. Acceleration, noise, erratic motion
of takeoff and re-entry
2. Weightlessness
3. Ionizing radiation, energetic
particles
4. Hypobaria (low pressure)
5. Oxygen supply
6. Food-waste cycle
7. Temperature extremes
The ability of the pilot to withstand
the force without injury and the effi-
cient use of the rocket power are two
considerations that will govern the
amount of acceleration experienced dur-
ing launching and re-entry into the at-
mosphere. It may be possible for the
pilot himself to increase or decrease the
acceleration at these times, as he is dis-
posed.
The optimum position for withstand-
ing high acceleration forces, according to
experimentation with accelerations of 10-
18g, is that the back be inclined at 20-25
degrees from the horizontal (assuming
that the forces act vertically), the thighs
be vertical and the lower legs be inclined
at 5 degrees from the horizontal. Since
the force is distributed along ihe back,
the strain on the cardiovascular system
(the heart, blood vessels, lymph glands)
appears to be less in this position; further-
more, the pooling of blood and organ
displacement is minimized. The capabil-
ity of the pilot to perform what tasks
may be expected of him during take-off
is greater in this position because he is
more likely to remain conscious. To de-
rive the greatest benefit, each seat should
be custom-molded to the individual
pilot's contours. In simple centrifuge
tests of low acceleration (4-6g) with no
optimum positioning of the subject, the
JANUARY. I960

Here a beaker of water "boils"—simu-
lating what would happen to body
fluids at very high altitudes without
pressure suits.
conclusion was reached that if the sub-
ject is given some task to do during the
test, he minds the force less and, there-
fore, is better able to stand it.
Also expected during launch and re-
entry are oscillation, spinning or tum-
bling, vibration and noise. If the erratic
motion cannot be controlled in some way,
the only defense the astronaut will have
is preconditioning and experience in
earth-bound simulators. Sound insulation
can be built right into the spacesuit
helmet; this could be removable for com-
munication among the crew in space.
Zero Gravity
Once out into space, the pilot will
encounter zero gravity. Very little is
known of this condition since it does
not occur naturally on earth or in ordi-
nary airplane flight. The only data con-
cerning the effect of real weightlessness
on human beings is that taken during
parabolic trajectory flights in a standard
plane. The zero gravity effect, achieved
by flying the plane in such a way as to
counterbalance the earths gravity at that
point, lasts from 12 to 15 seconds. Long
term effects on the human body cannot
be guessed at on this basis; it is naturally
hoped that they will not be serious when
and if they are ascertained. However, a
short term consideration is motion sick-
ness because one third of all persons
tested on these flights underwent some
degree of uneasiness. Some of these later
became adapted to weightlessness, but it
14
is estimated that about 10% of future
aspirants to space travel will be rejected
due to acute motion sickness.
The "weightless regurgitation phenom-
enon" often occurred when pressure was
put on the stomach, whether a person
was motion sick or not. It usually fol-
lowed a large liquid intake. Digestion
of food would seem to present no diffi-
cult)' if food and drink may be properly
introduced into the gullet. If food is not
well chewed, particles may float up into
the windpipe and choke the eater. Since
fluids tend to remain in globules, a
squeeze bottle for drinking is recom-
mended to prevent drowning in one's
liquid refreshment.
A study of human water elimination
was made during zero gravity. The func-
tion depends very little on gravity, phys-
ically, but subjects in the tests noted a
decrease in the sense of urgency while
weightless. With practice, however, vol-
untary urination was accomplished.
Van Allen Radiation
Probably the most important physio-
logical phase is the ionizing radiation
hazard. In addition to the Van Allen
radiation belts hovering over the earth,
and the indigenous cosmic radiation and
energetic particles of space, many may
bring his own radioactive by-products
with him if he uses nuclear energy to
drive his spaceship.
It is now believed that the Van Allen
belts extend 52,250 miles into space,
the lower one beginning at 1,300 miles
above the earth and ending at 3000 miles,
being 4,000 miles wide north and south,
and the upper one beginning at 8,000
miles and ending at 52,250 miles, being
20,000 miles wide north and south. The
peak count in the belts was 25,600
counts second corresponding to 10
roentgens hour if electrons, or 100
roentgens hour if protons are the fore-
most constituents. Between the belts, the
value fell to about 0.3 roentgens hour.
The maximum radiation dosage recom-
mended by the Atomic Energy Commis-
sion is 0.3 roentgens/ week, which sug-
gests that a shielded, manned satellite
could be sent to orbit between the belts
without too much risk. Three possible
ways of combatting radiation are by
shielding, by magnetic deflection and by
using it as a source of energy. Another
means now being tried out with animals
is prevention of damage by drugs.
Hypobaria demands that the pilot wear
a fuil-pressure suit; at high altitudes, a
man's blood would boil if he were not
wearing such a suit. A frog can stand
a pressure of one millimeter of mercury
for one half hour while all its fluids are
boiling and bacteria can last for six to
eight hours under the same conditions.
Micrometeorites are another space
danger, which would pierce a space
vehicle, resulting in a leak and loss of
whatever pressure there is within. Rus-
sian data indicates that a spaceship
would encounter one gram of micro-
meteorites in 14,000 hours of flight. Rec-
ommended safety features regarding loss
of internal pressure are: multiple wall
and meteor bumper construction, self-
sealing techniques, detection of leaks,
warning of occupants, reserve high pres-
sure gases (including oxygen) to delay
decompression, use of full-pressure suits,
personnel training for emergencies, com-
partmentation, recompression chambers,
