sealing leaks.
Oxygen Cycle
Some means must be devised to insure
a constant supply of oxygen before any
really long-range trip can be planned.
The oxygen consumption for one man
sitting and awake is 240 cc/ man-hour,
which is slightly above the basal metab-
olism level. If metabolism could be de-
creased, oxygen supplies would be con-
served. The metabolic rate of the Alaskan
black bear was reduced to 50-60% of
the normal rate during hibernation, while
its body temperature was lowered nine
degrees Fahrenheit. It is assumed tf^
aging continues at 50-60% of the normal
rate, also. Hibernation could be induced
in humans with drugs, or by hypothermia
(lowering the temperature). The person
would have to be awoken periodically
to raise energy levels and to prevent
ventricular fibrillation, a condition which
occurs at temperatures below 86 F. It
is characterized by a quivering of muscle
fibers in the heart, where various groups
of fibers beat independently and without
rhythm. The condition is fatal if not im-
mediately remedied. It seems unlikely
that hibernation will be employed; it
would be a waste of time to send an
unconscious man into space.
Even if the oxygen intake could be
decreased, flights over one month in dur-
ation would require oxygen recycling.
Two ways of doing this are feasible:
employing chemical reduction to re-
verse basic processes of human metab-
olism, and photosynthesis. The latter
method is better, although presently, it
is not as well developed as the former.
The equation of the first method is:
CO; + reducing agent »so!id
carbon + 0.2 f
One drawback here is that something
would have to be done to the solid by-
products before they began to accumu-
late.
The food-waste cycle will be a neces-
sity for long flights. Man needs 1.5 tons
of food and water per year, and even if
he could carry all his food and water
with him, wastes would certainly become
a problem. One would not wish to con-
taminate outer space by jettisoning them.
On short trips, human waste could be
stored in sealed containers, or chemically
reduced to a nontoxic form. The metab-
olism of trace substances must be care-
fully examined; the loss of urea, volatile
amines, and others is important when
the occupied space is sealed.

The first man-carrying satellite will probably be no bigger than this capsule in
which an airman breathed his own private atmosphere, slept half-doubled-up, ate
condensed foods, did physical and mental work while space doctors kept watch
outside.
One cycle that has been proposed is to
process excess metabolic water so that
carbohydates in the form of glucose
water result. The solid residue of urine
could be used to feed algae in the pho-
tosynthesis method of providing oxygen.
X-ray diffraction could be used to check
these materials for poison. This cycle
requires a lot of energy and there is
some question as to the psychological
effect of depending on such a system
for food and water.
To minimize solid waste, a general
theory is that the space diet should con-
sist of highly nutritious liquids which
would be almost entirely absorbed in
the lower tract.
Finally, the temperature must be re-
liably reported to the pilot. Man is a
poor judge of temperature, noticing
changes quite well from 70-150IJ F, a
zone of little danger, while in the highly
dangerous range from 150-250° F, his
perception worsens. The vehicle will need
refrigeration and/or insulation.
Psychological Factors
The second broad aspect is the psy-
chological. The factors which enter in
are, in general:
1. Isolation and confinement
2. Weightlessness, orientation
3. Decreased sensory input
4. Fear
Isolation tests are being conducted to
find out what should be done so that a
pilot can continue to think and work
efficiently under trying conditions. In
total isolation with no assigned tasks
whatever, no subject was able to stay in
the test chamber longer than 70 hours.
Isolation of this kind, if extended beyond

no YOU BELIEVE IN
FLYING SAUCERS?
. ■
If you think this an amusing question, and are about to reply with a
hasty "No," think for a few minutes and perhaps your decision will not be
so quick and simple. Are we not on the threshold of space, rapidly learning
how to move outward from our planet? In ten years or less, man on earth
has changed from thinking in terms of the confines of the earth to thinking
in terms of the solar system and the stars beyond. Much has been discovered,
experiments have placed satellites in orbit, and research is rushing forward
to put man in space.
Science has proved that life and civilization are relatively new on the
earth. The earth is estimated as 11 billion years old and life can be traced
to beginnings only 1 million years ago. Assuming that there is the possi-
bility of life elsewhere in the universe, what has occurred on planets in
other solar systems, planets older than the earth, on which life may have
existed many centuries longer? At some point in their civilization, did they
not reach out and learn the answers to the problems of space travel? As
we expect to eventually conquer the complexities and difficulties of navi-
gating beyond our atmosphere, could not some older, more advanced form
of life have invented a vehicle that successfully overcame the problems of
time, distance, radiation, and others that we have not as yet solved? Then,
too, is it not possible that this form of life may differ from man, having
evolved in a different environment? Therefore, this life might be more suit-
able for space travel than man. Could not a race, similar to ours but exist-
ing for many more years, have evolved a more intelligent being than man,
as he is today on earth? Concerned with his earthly problems of living,
warring, and acquiring control of his earthly environment, man has yet to
turn his'talents to that which is outside his planet. Only by a competitive
need to remain strong and thus be protected, has man begun a race into
space. Might not other beings in other worlds have been quicker in turning
their thoughts to the universe? As one ponders such ideas, the existence
of "flying saucers" from other worlds becomes not a ridiculous theory, but
an unproved possibility. For this reason the Editors of the Technic urge you
to read this thought-provoking and challenging article.
by ARLEIGH J. DAGENAIS, '61E


Kenneth Arnold departed from Chehalis,
Washington, bound for Yakima, Wash-
ington, on a routine flight in his private
plane. Mr. Arnold had made many such
flights previously and was considered an
excellent mountain pilot. As he neared
Mount Rainier, the second highest peak
in the continental United States, he saw
with a start what appeared to be a chain
of unfamiliar aircraft. Observing more
closely, he distinguished a string of nine
very bright, disk-shaped objects, estimat-
ing them to be about 45 to 50 feet in
length. As they flew, the objects wove
in and out between the mountain peaks.
Regaining his composure, Arnold marked
their position on a map and noted the
time, a procedure which he again re-
peated some 102 seconds later. With this
data, a hurried computation put the
objects' speed at almost 1700 miles per
hour.1 No ai craft known at that time
could approach even half that speed.
When Arnold's story broke, it was so
unusual that papers all over the world
gave it front-page space. Thus began the
era of the "flying saucer."
It was only three months later, Sep-
tember, 1947, that the Air Force organ-
ized a formal project for UFO (uniden-
tified flying object) investigation. The
project was established under the juris-
diction of the Air Technical Intelligence
Center (ATIC), one of the most highly
specialized intelligence agencies in the
Air Force. Most of these intelligence
specialists were confident that within a
few months' time they would have the
answer to the question, "What are
UFO's?"
People who have attempted to answer
this question fall into three groups
separated according to the different the-
ories concerning those airborne phenom-
ena. There is a fourth group if one con-
siders the perennial hoaxers and the
writers of saucer lore who print more
fiction than fact. This latter group, how-
ever, will be ignored in this article. One
group consists of those who feel that
all UFO sightings can be explained as
natural occurrences. Another group.
whose position might be called neutral,
is the organization (ATIC) of the U.S.
Air Force, which gathered and investi-
gated the thousands of reports and facts
of the UFO story. A third group con-
sists of the believers in interplanetary
space craft.
Natural Occurrences?
Donald H. Menzel, Professor of Astro-
physics at Harvard University, was a
leading exponent of the group which
considered all saucer sightings as natural
phenomena. He believed that people did
see unusual phenomena but the sightings
were not alien aircraft. What the ob-
servers saw was not imaginary but could
be attributed to some event of nature
He did not place much faith in the
ability of many observers to correctly in-
terpret their observations. In the Arnold
sighting, Menzel derived from Arnold's
statement that the objects' speed was
only 50 miles per hour. Menzel con-
cluded that what Arnold really saw was
billowing blasts of snow lifted from the
mountains by turbulent air. These shift-
ing, tilting clouds of snow reflected the-
sun as mirrors.-' Many of Professor Men-
zel's explanations of other saucer inci-
dents were to be closely congruent. Haze,
reflections in fog or mist, and ice cry-
stals in the sky reflecting the sun's rays
were the majority of his conclusions.
Menzel's theories did not pass without
challenge, however. Why were not such
sightings repoited before 1947? And.
concerning the Arnold report specifically,
could billowing blasts of snow be travel-
ing at, or at leait appear to be traveling
at, a speed of 500 miles per hour?
The ATIC saucer investigation group
did not receive first-hand information on
the Arnold sighting. In fact, one might
say the Air Force investigating group
was a result of the incident. However,
when one ATIC expert was later asked
to comment on Professor Menzel's state-
ment of "wind whipping snow," his
answer was a flat, "impossible." He
asserted that he had lived in the Pacific
Northwest for many years, and that it
would be impossible to find powdered
snow so low in the mountains in June.3
Project Blue Book, as the Air Force
group was coded, labled the Arnold
report "unknown."
The Mantell Crash
Tragedy entered the picture in January
of 1948. A National Guard pilot was
killed chasing a UFO. On that after-
noon, control tower operators of God-
man Air Force Base, outside Louisville,
Kentucky, received a query from the
state police as to the possibility of any
unusual aircraft in the vicinity. A quick-
check by the operators with appropriate
agencies met with a negative answer.
Many people in outlying districts near
the air base reported an unknown ob-
ject in the sky, moving in the general
direction of Godman. A half hour later,
the tower operators sighted the object
and called the base operations officer,

the cause of many "flying saucer" re-
ports.
who came to the tower to have a look
at the object through binoculars. No
one could identify the object. Minutes
later, four F-51's, single engine fighter
aircraft, flew across the field. The flight
leader, Captain Mantell, was called by
radio and asked to take a look at the
object and try to identify it. Mantell
climbed his aircraft into the sky and
was soon lost from sight. After a few
minutes of silence, Mantell called the
tower and said, "I see something above
and ahead of me and I'm still climbing
.... I've sighted the thing. It looks
metallic and it's tremendous in size ....
It's above me and I'm gaining on it. I'm
going to 20,000 feet." Captain Mantell
never talked to anyone again. The tower

ORDER PLEASE
Although we may never have "push-button
weather" science is taking big steps to harness
and control tomorrow's weather.
by JOHN MARSHALL, '61E
"Roberta, please call up W-Central
inches of 7n-69 in my yard at 2 P.M.
\. and tell them to let us have a little snow
today?"

"I'm sorry, but we're temporarily out

"My name is Smith, 117 Huron

Street. Will you please give me three
"Thank you."
Pictured above is a possible glimpse
of the future . . . when weather will be
controlled by man. Surely one day men
will be capable of controlling the weather
but that day is very far away. Today we
are just on the verge of great discoveries
which will eventually lead us to our
final goal, weather control.
First Attempts
To see what weather may be like in
the future one must look at the first
attempts of weather modification. Before
World War II only a few scientists
thought about the idea of controlling the
weather. Active interest in weather con-
trol at this time came only from our
American Indians who offered their rain
dances as one positive method for modi-
fying the weather. This naturally was
frowned upon by the serious-minded for
obvious reasons. Then along came the
Second World War and suddenly there
was a need for further knowledge of
weather modification. For instance, many
airfields were fogged in at night. At-
tempting to land a plane in a heavy-
English fog was almost suicide since our
planes did not have radar yet. If there
were some way to eliminate the fog,
thought the Air Force, the bases could
be kept open all the time. A few British
engineers solved the problem by setting
afire two gasoline-filled troughs, one
placed on each side of the runway. The
heat developed lifted the fog to a point
where the stars were actually visible, but
the method proved to be quite costly as
gasoline was consumed at a high rate—
in fact, the total amount for the project
was a high percent of all the petroleum
shipped to England during that year.
The use of gasoline just employed
brute force to control the weather and,
for reasons previously stated, proved to
be uneconomical. The thought that if
man could use nature's natural methods
of making weather he would be far better
off was becoming prevalent in the scien-
tist's mind. After World War II many
ideas were tried throughout the world.
In this country most research was carried
on by private companies and by uni-
versities.
Committee Report
After the Korean War, the govern-
ment began to take an interest in weather
control. The Advisory Committee on
Weather Control was set up by an act of
Congress in August, 1953. This com-
mittee was to make "... a complete
study and evaluation of public and pri-
vate experiments in weather control for
the purpose of determining the extent of
which the United States should experi-
ment with, engage in, or regulate activ-
ities designed to control weather condi-
tions." This committee was not to con-
duct basic research in weather modifica-
tion.
On December 31, 1957, the final re-
port of the advisory committee was is-
sued. The report contained statistics on
and information about many attempted
projects and also much about the legal
situation involved with weather control.
A summary of the report stated: when
silver iodide was used as the seeding
agent, the seeding of winter type storm
clouds in mountainous areas produced
an average increase in precipitation of
ten to fifteen percent with heavy odds
that this increase was not the result of
natural variations in the amount of rain-
fall. In non-mountainous areas, on the
other hand, the same procedure as above
did not show any increase in precipita-
tion although some effects may have been
produced [but were not detected]. "No
evidence was found in the evaluation of
any project which was intended to in-
crease precipitation that cloud seeding
had produced a detectable negative effect
on precipitation," the report stated, and
then went on to say that conventional
seeding with generators on the ground
is a valid technique for producing ice
crystals in favorable summer and winter
storm conditions. In conclusion, the com-
mittee stated that there must be much
work done in basic research.
From the time the report was sub-
mitted, until the present, much has been
done with weather modification. Extensive
seeding projects using many different
types of ice crystal inducing agents have
been tried. The University of Michigan,
with its mobile meteorological van, has

ings formed in a subcooled cloud layer
as a result of seeding with solid carbon
dioxide pellets.
participated in a cloud modification pro-
gram in Arizona and New Mexico during
the summer, one of many such projects
sponsored by university and governmental
research agencies. As the space age began,
atmospheric scientists in the United States
took immediate advantage of a new
technique for physical measurements of
the earth by sending aloft two meteor-
ological satellites—one to register cloud
cover, the other to measure the earth's
radiation—neither possible before over so
large an area and so short a time interval.
All the meteorological effects men-
tioned so far pertain to the present status
of weather control, but in addition there
are many ideas about future weather
and weather control methods. One of
these has already become a reality, the
weather satellite, as stated before.
Satellites Will Help
With a system of weather satellites
we would be able to determine the gene-
sis, movement and breakup of storms.
One satellite in a polar orbit would map
the entire cloud system of the earth every
twelve hours. We would then know how
many storm systems there are on the
earth at any one moment, whether they
are variable, and whether there are more
in one season than in another. Improve-
ments in forecasting the weather would
not occur as quickly as the satellites are
put up, since assimilation of the material


sent back from a satellite would take a
long time. One of the quickest improve-
ments in forecasting and weather control
would happen when a satellite is capable
of carrying television equipment. This
will give meteorologists instant notice of
hurricanes, tornadoes, and other severe
storms which then can be dissipated or
diverted by some means unknown to us
today. Another group of stationary satel-
lites twenty-two thousand miles up would
generate ultra-violet light and could turn
darkness into semi-daylight.
Satellites will help us understand the
weather but they cannot truly modify it.
With methods of altering the atmosphere
such as the atom bomb, the plains states
might conceivably be freed of droughts.

SIDE-BAND
With the backing of the Strategic Air Command
and several electronic firms SSB is rapidly re-
placing standard amplitude modulation for
communication purposes.
by RAY IKOLA, '61E
During the past decade, a new method
of radiotelephony has gained
prominence as an effective mode of com-
munication. This method is known as
single-sideband, or more briefly as S.S.B.
Until recently, amplitude modulation has
been accepted as the standard mode of
communication in commercial installa-
tions. However, the development of the
single-sideband system in recent yea's
has given rise to the belief of many peo-
ple that S.S.B. is superior to A.M. for
communication purposes.
When we speak of a communication
system in this article, we are referring to
a system whose sole purpose is to convey
a message with no emphasis placed on the
audio fidelity of the signal. Such systems
as ground-air radios, taxi radios, and
police radios all come under this defini-
tion. Although single-sideband was used
AMPLITUDE
as far back as 1923, there were too many
defects to allow its use as a common
mode of communication. During World
War II, the single-sideband system found
only limited use for communication in
the armed services. Since that time, single-
sideband has seen rapid development,
due, to a large extent, to the pressure
exerted upon electronics equipment man-
ufacturers by the radio amateurs.
What is single-sideband, and why do
some hold it superior to amplitude mod-
ulation? One definition of single-side-
band is: "The suppression of an 'image
sideband' for the purpose of reducing to
a minimum the frequency band necessary
to transmit a given amount of intelli-
gence." Let us examine this definition to
see what it means, how the desired effect
is achieved, and why this effect is desir-
able.
Figure I. A carrier wave, modulated
by a 1000 cycle audio tone, may be
represented by two sidebands occurring
as mirror images of each other on both
sides of the carrier when amplitude is
plotted against frequency.
-IOOO f +1000
FRE5UEKCY
AM Theory Necessary
In order to understand the principle
of single-sideband, it is first necessary to
clarify the picture of a normal amplitude-
modulated signal. We know that any
radio frequency signal can be represented
by a thin vertical line, when frequenq'
is plotted against amplitude as shown in
Fig. 1. However, each telephony signal
contains at least two other components.
(For the sake of simplicity, we will as-
sume that we wish to transmit only a
pure tone, rather than a complicated
voice figure. We choose the frequency
of this tone to be 1,000 cycles, as shown
in Fig. 1.) One of these components,
then, is the sum of the center frequenq'
and the audio frequency, and the other
is the difference between the center fre-
quency and the audio frequency. As
shown in Fig. 1, the center frequency
is f, with the frequency of the audio
tone occuring as mirror images of each
other on each side of f. The center fre-
quency f is known as the carrier, and the
other two components of the signal art
called the sidebands. From this picture
of a radiotelephony signal, we see that
modulation is simply a pair of new sig-
nals occuring at frequencies "alongside
the carrier."
20
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


We note from the above discussion
that the carrier wave itself conveys no
intelligence. All the intelligence of the
signal is contained in the two sidebands.
Since the carrier is of no use, as far as
transmitting intelligence is concerned, it
is possible to eliminate it entirely at the
transmitter. However, this carrier must be
provided again at the receiving station if
the signal is to be intelligible. One of
the sidebands may also be omitted as
long as the other one is retained to con-
vey the intelligence of the signal. It is
easily seen that the frequency spectrum
occupied by the signal has effectively been
cut in half. This means that two stations
can operate on the same central fre-
quency, one using the upper sideband
and the other using the lower. This,
then, is the principle under which single-
sideband operates.
The first thing that must be done to
achieve this effect is to suppress the
carrier. Usualy this is achieved by using
a device known as a balanced modulator.
The length and scope of this article
does not permit us to go into detail on
the workings of this device. Let it suffice
to say that the carrier is introduced in
such a way that it will not appear in
the output. However, this process does
not eliminate the sidebands which are
still present in the output.
Eliminate One Sideband
Following the suppression of the car-

rier, we have what is known as a double-
sideband signal. The next logical step in
producing a single-sideband signal is to
eliminate one of the sidebands. The two
principal methods of accomplishing this
are the filter system and the phasing sys-
tem. In the filter system the double-side-
band signal is fed to a sharp filter which
is designed in such a way as to pass one
sideband and reject the other. Adding
radio frequency selectivity to the front
end of a receiver to reduce the image
is the same process in reverse of adding
the filter to a double-sideband signal to
reduce the "image sideband." In the case

of the phasing system, two double-side-
band signals are produced which differ
only in phase. When the difference in
phase is correct, the combination of the
two signals will eliminate one wideband
and reinforce the other. Such a system
as this generally involves more compli-
cated circuitry than the filter system.
What, then, are the advantages of the
single-sideband system as opposed to am-
plitude modulation? To answer this ques-
tion it might be well to enumerate the
disadvantages of the A.M. system, for
the inherent design of the S.S.B. system
eliminates many of the difficulties stem-
ming from the use of A.M. There are
two chief disadvantages of the A.M.
systems currently in use. They are: (1)
the large percentage of power used for
transmission of the carrier, and (2) the
interference great among signals.
Greater Effective Power
It is known that the power in each
sideband is one-fourth of the total output
power of an A.M. signal. Since there
are two sidebands in every signal, it is
seen that one half of the total power is
used in the sidebands and one half is
used in the carrier. It is also known that
no intelligence is conveyed by the carrier
signal. From this information, it is easily
concluded that a large amount of power
is devoted to transmission of the carrier

equipment now on the market is this
amateur single sideband station.

He's an internationally known mathematician
but, strangely enough, he doesn't even exist.
by IRVING SALMEEN, '63E
His name is Greek, his nationality,
French, he is one of the most in-
fluential mathematicians of the twentieth
century. His works have given mathe-
maticians a powerful reference tool and
have helped to unify many scattered
branches of mathematics. Nearly every
mathematician knows a few stories about
him, and is iikely to have made up a



few more. Although most of these leg-
ends and stories are fictitious, they grow
in number every day. But the strangest
fact of all, is that he doesn't even exist.
The name of this imaginary French-
man is Nicolas Bourbaki. Actually the
name is a pseudonym adopted by an in-
formal corporation of 10 to 20 French
mathematicians (the number varies) who
write on the various fields of mathe-
matics. They first appeared on the scene
around the mid-nineteen thirties when
they began to publish papers and notes
in the "Comptes Rendus" of the French
Academy of Science. In 1939 they began
their major work, Elements de Malhe-
maliqtte, for which they have become so
well-known. This work is perhaps the
most comprehensive treatise ever written
on mathematics. It begins with the most
elementary principles and ends with the
most advanced applications. So far twen-
ty volumes have appeared (nearly 3,000
pages) and the work is far from com-
plete.
Since the group was founded by
Frenchmen, it is an unwritten law of the
group, that only Frenchmen can be mem-
bers. There has been only one exception
to this and that was for Samuel Eilenberg
(known to his friends of youth as S2PJ,
Smart Sammy, the Polish Prodigy). The
General Bourbaki, whose name was not
Nicolas but Charles Denis Sauter, is
depicted in this drawing based on an
engraving. He was once offered the
crown of Greece.
rule was waived for him because he
speaks French like a native and knows
more about algebraic topology than any
Frenchman. It is a necessity that all
members be French for when men such
as Andre Weil, Jean Delsarte, Jean Dieu-
donne, and Claude Chevallier get to-
gether with their colleagues, the French
flows fast and furious. It is not sufficient
to just know how to speak French, but
it is a requirement to know even the
latest Parisian student slang.
Why Bourbaki?
Why the name Bourbaki was selected
is shrouded in mystery. One legend has
it that it was inspired by an army officer
of some importance in the Franco-Prus-
sian War, General Charles Denis Sauter
Bourbaki. Charlie was a very colorful
character. In 1862, after several success-
ful war exploits he was offered the throne
of Greece, but declined the opportunity.
As luck would have it the tide of battle
turned and the fortunes of war were not
kind to him. In 1871 he was forced to
flee to Switzerland with a small remnant
of his army. While in Switzerland he
must have become frustrated and he tried
to shoot himself, but apparently he
missed because he lived to the ripe old
age of 83. Supposedly there is a statue
erected in his honor at Nancy. This
might possibly explain the connection
between the group and the name because
several of the founders were associated
with the University of Nancy.
Another legend surrounding the name
concerns the students of the "Ecole
22
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


mathematicians receive their early train-
ing. About twenty to thirty years ago,
the first-year students were supposedly
exposed to an annual lecture by a dis-
tinguished visitor, Nicolas Bourbaki. Actu-
ally Bourbaki was an amateur actor whose
lecture was a masterpiece of mathematical
double talk. Since many of the founders
of the Bourbaki clan did receive their
early training there, it is possible that
the name came from him, provided there
is any basis for the story.
Scientific publication under a pseudo-
nym is not now. The English mathe-
matician William Sealy Gosset published
his first works on small samples under
the name "Student" supposedly to avoid
embarrassment to his employers, (a beer
brewery). Somewhere around the time
Bourbaki was started another group ap-
peared under the name of E. S. Pondi-
czery, reputed to be of the Royal Institute
of Poldavia. The initials E. S. P. and
R. I. P. were the outgrowth of an article-
by them on extrasensory preception.
Most of their work, though, was on
mathematical games and curiosities. They
are probably one of the first to publish
under a double pseudonym. One of their
papers, which appeared in the American
Mathematical Monthly, was on the mathe-
matical theory of big-game hunting. Be-
cause of the obviously facetious nature
of the subject, they obtained permission
to publish it under the name of H.
Petard.
Originally the name Bourbaki was
adopted half in fun and half to avoid
a long boring list of authors on the title
page. The name was intended as a cor-
porate name instead of a disguise. The
members are not sworn to an oath of
secrecy and the names of them are an
open secret to most mathematicians. Many
amusing incidents have resulted from the
name, and the members so thotoughly
enjoyed the joke, that they have gone
along with the legends and stories.
According to Legend
According to one legend, their major
work. Elements of Mathematics, was
originated as a result of a discussion be-
tween Andre Weil and Jean Delsarte on
how calculus should be taught. Whatever
its original purpose, it certainly is not
today elementary pedagogy. It is as if a
discussion on the best way to teach the
elements of music gave rise to a complete
text on harmony and musicology. Inci-
dentally, mathematicians supposedly con-
sider the calculus to be as trivial as
musicians consider the music of Victor
Herbert.
The whole work when it is complete
will consist of several parts, but the
twenty volumes that have appeared have
not even completed section I, titled, The
Fundamental Structures of Analysis. So
far this first part has six subdivisions
which could prove a mild shock to the
classical mathematician who considers
mathematics in terms of arithmetic, al-
gebra, geometry, and other "old fashion
words." These subdivisions are: 1. Set
Theory 2. Algebra 3. General Topology
4. Functions of a real variable 5. Top-
ological Vector Spaces 6. Integration.
Each volume comes equipped with a
loose insert of four pages explaining how
to read the work, the prerequisites for
reading the text (about two years of uni-
versity mathematics), a description of
the organization and specifications of the
logical, rigorous order in which the text
must be studied. The insert also explains
some of the teaching tricks, some of
which are very unique. One of these is
to warn the reader whenever the subject
becomes especially slippery, that is, when
he is likely to make an erroneous as-
sumption, by an S curve in the margin.
Other Bourbaki gadgetry includes fold-
out sheets that summarize important
definitions, assumptions, and concepts, a
dictionary for every book that includes
both Bourbique terminology and common
terminology. Also, every volume is ac-
companied by an excellent set of cleveily
contrived exercises. Many of these prob-
lems are invented by the authors, or
different versions of old problems.
Systematic and Thorough
The presentation of the material is
very systematic and thorough and often
contains a brilliant historical background
of the subject. One rather curious thing
about these historical sketches is that
only in rare instances will there be a
reference to the classics and the source
of modem contributions is almost totally
omitted. No deception is intended; after
all, Bourbaki doesn't claim to have in-
vented all of modern mathematics, but
it may result in confusing future mathe-
matical historians. His approach to new
subjects is rather radical because of his
insistence upon the right order of doing
things and his clean, economical organ-
ization of ideas. In fact, his style of
presentation is so thorough that very
little is left to the imagination of the
reader.
A typical example of the thoroughness
of the work is his treatment of the
definition of the number one. He devotes
nearly 200 pages in preliminary defini-
tions and explanations. Then the actual
definition is presented in terms of highly
condensed symbols, explaining in a foot-
note that the condensed notation was
necessary because the unabbreviated sys-
tem would require tens of thousands of
symbols.
It is a wonder how a work of such
magnitude ever gets started. A very large
part of the credit goes to Jean Dieudonne,
originally from the University of Nancy
and now with Northwestern, who has
been Bourbaki's chief writer from almost
the beginning. Since Dieudonne is also

23


his own name, confusion often arises in
attempting to distinguish between his
private work and his efforts for Bourbaki.
According to one story, the records are
kept straight in a very amazing manner.
According to this one. Dieudonne once
published a paper for Bourbaki and later
an error was found. Dieudonne corrected
the mistake in a paper entitled "On an
Error of N. Bourbaki" and signed J.
Dieudonne.
A great deal of work goes into the
preparation of a volume. Each year the
group convenes in a pleasant French
vacation spot to hash out problems and
to set the general policy of the work.
Much to the surprise of the members,
the work has turned out to be a financial
success and the royalties are sufficient to
cover transportation, housing costs, and
substantial food and wines to lubricate
the proceedings. The first few days of
the convention are spent in relaxation
and general shop talk. But after the fun
is over a great deal of work gets done.
The First Draft
Once a particular subject has been de-
cided upon, one member agrees to write
the first draft. The brave volunteer is
letting himself in for a trying experience.
After the draft is finished, copies are
made and sent to the rest of the mem-
bers. From here on in the original author
is in for merciless criticism. Chances are
that the draft will be completely rejected.
For example, the first draft written on
integration was done by Dieudonne and
soon became known as Dieudonne's mon-
ster. The monster was so strongly criti-
cised that it never reached even the pre-
liminary stages of publication.
After the first draft has run the gaunt-
let, a second draft is prepared, possibly
by another member. This goes through
the mill, is revised again, and another
draft drawn up. This process goes on
for possibly six or seven times before it
finally is accepted for publication. The
result of this painstaking effort is not a
textbook that can be placed in the hands
of a beginner, but it is an encyclopedia
of mathematics, without which 20th cen-
tury mathematics would be quite different.
Mathematics is a young man's game
and indeed that is what is found in
Bourbaki. This is indicated by the fact
that upon reaching the age of fifty,
Dieudonne and Weil, although they were
founding fathers, retired. Earlier, at the
outset of the organization, they announced
their retirement at the age of fifty, and
kept their promise. Incidentally, Weil

Nicolas Bourbaki is fancifully represented by this milling throng of French mathe-
maticians. Bourbaki appears to consist of 10 to 20 men at any one time. Any resem-
blance between these men and the individuals in the drawing is entirely coinci-
dental.
may not be known to the general public,
but he is considered by many of his
colleagues to be the greatest living mathe-
matician. His work on algebraic number
theory and algebraic geometry have had
a profound effect on the world of mathe-
matics.
The youthful exuberance of the mem-
bers is often the cause of considerable-
irritation to their enemies. The officials
of the American Mathematical Society
were not at all pleased when they re-
ceived an application for membership
signed by N. Bourbaki. Needless to say,
they rejected the application. The secre-
tary of the organization wrote a very
cold letter suggesting that they apply for
institutional membership. Since Bourbaki
did not want to admit that he did not
exist, nothing more was said concerning
the matter.
Effective Steps
Even though there is no oath of secrecy
among the members, they do not like
to have their secrets revealed. The cor-
poration has shown their ability to take
effective steps against any informers.
About 1947 the Book of the Year of
the Encyclopedia Britannica had a short
paragraph about Bourbaki in which they
referred to him as a group. The author
of the article was Ralph Boas, at that
time executive editor of the Mathematical
Reviews. Soon after the paragraph ap-
peared, the editors of the Britannica re-
ceived a very injured letter from Bour-
baki protesting the allegation that Bour-
baki did not exist. To add to the con-
fusion and embarrassment of the editors,
a member of the math department of the
University of Chicago wrote a very
shrewdly worded letter in which he im-
plied, but did not state, that Bourbaki
did exist. The matter was finally cleared
up by a letter from the American Mathe-
matical Society in which they told the
whole story about Bourbaki. Incidentally,
the letter was written by the same secre-
tary who had refused Bourbaki member-
ship. But in the end, Bourbaki got the
last laugh. He gathered together all of
his international resources and colleagues
and circulated a rumor that Boas did not
exist and that he was actually a group
of young American mathematicians that
acted jointly as the editors of the Mathe-
matical Reviews.
Whether the stories about him are true
or not, is known only by the members
and certainly they will not divulge the
truth. Stories about him are concocted
daily and old stories are stretched. Most
of them are amusing and add a little
spice to the rigorous world of mathe-
matics. One thing is not fiction, and that
is his tremendous influence on mathe-
matics. His work has brought unity for
the first time to many scattered branches.
For the first time general topology and
multilinear algebra have been put in
systematic form, which is easily available.
Many of his concepts and inventions
have had a powerful effect on the mathe-
matical world. If it weren't for him,
mathematics would be vastly different
from the way we find it today.

JANUARY, I960

AND
RESEARCH
by MURRAY PATTERSON, '60E
The successful firing of a five-stage
rocket designed and built by University
of Michigan engineering personnel, a pro-
posal on moon exploration, and some
views on international control of radio-
active wastes, all by U of M staff and
faculty, are reported this month on the
local education and research scene.
Five-Stage Rocket
The Army successfully fired a five-
stage rocket, built by The University of
Michigan, on November 10 from the
National Aeronautics and Space Admin-
istration launching facility at Wallops
Island, Va.

Based on "quick look" data, the rocket
went an altitude of 1,050 miles, the
highest ever reach from this facility.
The rocket—dubbed the "Strong Arm"
by the Army—landed in the Atlantic
Ocean some 800 miles from the launch-
ing pad.
It obtained measurements beginning at
875 miles. The rocket was designed to
obtain measurements of electron density
in the ionosphere above 500 miles, at
which altitude Russia's Sputnik III made
measurements. The project was sponsored
and directed by the Army's Ballistic Re-
search Laboratory at Aberdeen Proving
Ground, Md. It was conducted through
the U-M Research Institute.
Instruments carried by the rocket to
make the measurements were designed
by Dr. Lyman Orr of the U-M Electronic
Defense Group.
"Signals lasted 1500 seconds (25 min-
utes) here," reported William H. Hansen.
U-M aeronautical research engineer who
Illustrated here is one of the two 57
feet long five-stage rockets fired by
University of Michigan engineers. The
project was sponsored by the Army to
investigate the ionosphere.
28
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


five-stage rocket. The signals lasted an
additional 15 or 20 seconds at Aberdeen
Proving Ground.
"Everything right from the start right
through the finish was good," Hansen
said.
Observations made with stop watches
indicated all stages fired as programmed,
he said. The first radar "workings" gave
the predicted velocity at 300,000 feet
altitude as 17,250 feet per second, the
U-M engineer said.
It will take several weeks to get an
accurate trajectory, Hansen continued,
"but indications are pretty sound that all
worked well."
Asked how the Michigan engineers
felt about the firing, he said: "We feel
fine. There were no rude surprises."
Assisting in design and construction of
the rocket were Prof. Robert Howe and
engineer Fred F. Fischbach of the U-M
Aeronautical and Astronautical Engineer-
ing Department. Helping in the design
of the instruments was Pieter Cath of
the U-M Electronics Defense Group.
Moon Surface
One of the things man wants to know
before he lands an exploring expedition
on the moon is whether the moon's sur-
face dust will support the ship and
crew, or swallow them up.
It's generally conceded that the moon's
surface consists of dust but little is
known about its depth and weight-sup-
porting ability.
One method of finding out more about
the moon's surface is suggested by three
University of Michigan engineers in an
article in the November issue of the
technical magazine Aero-Space Engineer-
ing.

Engineer William H. Hansen stands next
to the fourth and fifth stages of the
rocket prepared at U. of M. It was fired
from Wallops Island, Virginia.
The three are Keeve M. Siegel, pro-
fessor of electrical engineering and head
of the U-M's Radiation Laboratory;
Thomas B. A. Senior and William E.
Fensler, research engineers of the U-M
Research Institute.
They suggest that a radar-equipped
satellite be placed in orbit around the
moon and that data from the radar sig-
nals bounced off the moon's surface be
telemetered back to earth.
By determining from this data how
"reflective" the moon's surface is to radar
signals, an accurate estimate of its den-
sity and consistency may be made, the
U-M men say. Such radar investigation
cannot now be made from earth because
the earth's ionosphere blocks that part of
an earth-originated radar signal needed
for such an investigation.
Siegel, Fensler and Senior say that
space equipment now under development
could be used for the experiment they
suggest.
Radioactive Waste
Establishing international controls over
radioactive contamination of the high
seas should be considered soon, two Uni-
versity of Michigan legal researchers be-
lieve.
Lee M. Hydeman and William H.
Berman outline their views in a paper
prepared for an International Confer-
ence on Disposal of Radioactive wastes,
which was held in November. They are
co-directors of the U-M Law School's
Atomic Energy Research Project.
Attempts to develop this kind of inter-
national control should not be postponed
until a serious threat is posed or even
until national approaches to the sea dis-
Professor K. M. Siegel of the Electrical

The field has never been broader
The challenge has never been greater
Engineers at Pratt &amp; Whitney Aircraft today are concerned
with the development of all forms of flight propulsion
systems—air breathing, rocket, nuclear and other advanced
types for propulsion in space. Many of these systems are so
entirely new in concept that their design and development,
and allied research programs, require technical personnel
not previously associated with the development of aircraft
engines. Where the company was once primarily interested
in graduates with degrees in mechanical and aeronautical
engineering, it now also requires men with degrees in
electrical, chemical, and nuclear engineering, and in physics,
chemistry, and metallurgy.
Included in a wide range of engineering activities open to
technically trained graduates at all levels are these four
basic fields:
ANALYTICAL ENGINEERING Men engaged in this
activity are concerned with fundamental investigations in
the fields of science or engineering related to the conception
of new products. They carry out detailed analyses of ad-
vanced flight and space systems and interpret results in
terms of practical design applications. They provide basic
information which is essential in determining the types of
systems that have development potential.
DESIGN ENGINEERING The prime requisite here is an
active interest in the application of aerodynamics, thermo-
dynamics, stress analysis, and principles of machine design
to the creation of new flight propulsion systems. Men en-
gaged in this activity at P&amp;WA establish the specific per-
formance and structural requirements of the new product
and design it as a complete working mechanism.
EXPERIMENTAL ENGINEERING Here men supervise
and coordinate fabrication, assembly and laboratory testing
of experimental apparatus, system components, and devel-
opment engines. They devise test rigs and laboratory setups,
specify instrumentation and direct execution of the actual
test programs. Responsibility in this phase of the develop-
ment program also includes analysis of test data, reporting
of results and recommendations for future effort
MATERIALS ENGINEERING Men active in this field
at P&amp;WA investigate metals, alloys and other materials
under various environmental conditions to determine their
usefulness as applied to advanced flight propulsion systems.
They devise material testing methods and design special
test equipment. They are also responsible for the determina-
tion of new fabrication techniques and causes of failures or
manufacturing difficulties.

Compiled by RICHARD KARPINSKI, '62LSA
Interest in Electric Car
Revives
The electric car, which passed from
the American scene in the 1920's, may be
on its way back, modernized and trans-
formed into the "car-of-the-future."
The possible renaissance of the battery-
driven automobile has nothing to do with
nostalgia for the good old days. It's
simply a matter of economics. The elec-
tric car of tomorrow, as visualized by
visionaries in automotive and engineering
circles, will be cheaper to operate than
today's gasoline-powered automobiles.
What's more, it will be practically
trouble-free, eliminating costly service
bills.
Key to the successful development of
this economical electric "dream car'' may
well be the sintered-plate, nickel-cadium
battery which is already widely used in
jet aircraft, missiles, merchant ships and
scores of industrial and household appli-
cations.
Research is in the early, exploratory
stage at this point. But if the engineers
come up with the right answers as to
vehicle size, cost, etc. indicating the
practicality of modern electric cars, man-
ufacturers expect the nickel-cadmium bat-
tery to be the heart of the proposed
power plant.
The short life of conventional batter
ies doomed earlier attempts to build i
practical, low-cost electric car. The sin-
tered-plate, nickel-cadium battery does
not have this drawback; it can be ex-
pected to last the life of the car. At the
same time, it can be charged considerably
more quickly than other batteries. Each
cell is made up of plates of carbonyl nick-
el powder, sintered on a foundation of
nickel wire mesh. The resulting rugged,
but porous, structure reliably retains the
active material, giving long life, and pro-
vides the large effective plate area
needed to permit high charge and dis-
charge rates.
The biggest hurdle on the road to a
feasible, economical electric car is to
find a way to extend the range of the
power plant and still keep the vehicle
small and light. At the present time,
batteries need recharging after less than
100 miles of travel. To overcome this
problem, engineers are exploring the
feasibility of employing a generator driv-
en by a small auxiliary gasoline engine
to constantly recharge the battery during
operation. The one- or two-cylinder en-
gine would use only a small amount of
gas to keep the battery on constant charge
during operation of the car.
Besides saving on gas and maintenance
the electric car visualized by the research-
ers would be simplicity itself as far as
operation is concerned. The speed of the
electric motor propelling the car would
be controlled by a foot accelerator. Even
operation of the gasoline motor-generator
would be automatic, requiring no action
by the driver. Controls on the car would
consist of a steering wheel, the acceler-
ator, the brake and a lever to put the
car in reverse.
Nickel oxide is the active material in
the positive plate of the nickel-cadmium
battery; metallic cadmium in the negative.
The electrolyte is a 30-percent-by-weight
solution of potassium hydroxide in dis-
tilled water. The battery requires only a
few drops of water a year. It can hold
its charge and be charged and discharged
under the most extreme temperature
changes, ranging from desert heat to sub-
zero cold. Thus, a car equipped with the
battery would start immediately in any
kind of weather.
Glycerine Has Role in I.G.Y.
Detailed information just released on
the famous "gasoline bricks" carried by
the Russians on their International Geo-
physical Year Expedition to Antarctica
shows glycerine to be one of the ingred-
ients in their formulation. Developed at
the Institute of Fuels of the U S.S.R.'s
Academy of Sciences, the bricks, bright
yellow in color, are a highly concentrated
solid emulsion consisting of 95% gaso-
line trapped in honeycomb-like cells. The
emulsion material, a distilled water solu-
tion of glycerine, ammonium chloride,
casein and polyvinyl alcohol, is combined
with the gasoline by mechanical and
ultrasonic-wave agitation for 5-6 minutes.
After addition of a 2Qr/r formaldehyde
solution to further increase the viscosity,
the mixture is allowed to thicken. It is
then pressed into long strands, cut to the
desired briquet shapes and dried. Before
use, the bricks are transformed back to
32
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


that breaks up the solid and squeezes the
gasoline from the honeycomb cells of the
emulsion. The Russians report that gaso-
line losses are less than three per cent.
Super-small Light Bulb
The smallest incandescent lamp ever
produced on an assembly line is small
enough to pass through the eye of a
darning needle.
The new microminiature lamp, called
the Sylvania Mite-T-Lite, has immediate
applications in transistorized circuits in
missiles, computers and electronic systems.
O. Howard Biggs, divisional Vice
President-Research and Engineering, said
"the development of techniques making
mass production of the lamp possible
represents a significant step forward in
the trend towards microminiaturization."
It is expected the immediate additional
applications will be found in airborne-
electronic systems, high speed punch-card
and tape readout devices, compact matrix-
displays, photoelectric logic systems, oth-
er microminiature circuits and in the
jewelry and decorative arts fields.
The body of the lamp is cylindrical
with a nominal diameter of .040 inches.
Nominal body length is 0.125 inches.
The lamp leads are platinum in a diam-
eter of 0.005 inches. The filament is
0.00025 inch tungsten wire of approxi-
mately 30 turns.
The diminutive lamp can be seen in a
normally illuminated room. Its light out-
put is in the order of 100 millilumens
at 1.5 volts input. The efficiency of the
lamp is approximately 1.5 lumens per
watt.
The very low current and voltage re-
quirements of the lamp immediately sug-
gest uses in indicating devices in port-
able equipment operating from batteries,
Mr. Biggs said.
"Because it can be operated directly
from the output of a transistor, the Mite-
T-Lite will be used in many display de-
vices consisting of a matrix of many
lamps for such purposes as computer
readout displays and arrays for anima-
tion," he added.
Eliminates Torn Streets
Sewer pipe now can be placed under
streets without digging a trench in the
street. An engineer developed a glorified
screwdriver to dig a hole beneath the
street, when Klamath Falls, Ore., resi-
dents became annoyed with the tearing
up of roads. Drilling time for pipe cross-
ing underneath a 25-foot street averages
3 minutes.
Picture Freezer for TV Editing
A video picture freezer which instant-
ly stops TV picture action and holds the
frozen image on its screen for as long
as ten minutes is now available.
The new Hughes storage monitor is
equipped with a five-inch Hughes Tono-
tron tube, which can display a continuous
television picture, and "freeze" the action
at any desired time.
The Hughes storage monitor has a
varied range of applications, including:
1. Video tape editing. The monitor
can be used as a key unit in the design
of advanced video tape editing systems.
2. Surveillance. Closed-circuit TV sur-
veillance in industrial plant protection,
as a deterrent against shoplifting, and as
an aid in general law enforcement.
3. Sports. Quick determination of per-
tinent actions in sporting events by pro-
viding an instant frozen picture of race
finishes, winners, accidents and rules in-
fractions.
4. Teaching. Closed-circuit "on the
scene" TV classroom instruction. Ideal
for capturing pertinent moments in
demonstrations, thus permitting elabo-
ration by the lecturer.
5. Flouroscopy. Capable of storing
images where short-burst flouroscopic
X-ray techniques are used, further aiding
in reducing patient irridation dosage.
Image available for immediate examina-
tion.
The storage monitor can be connected
directly to a closed-circuit television cam-
era, video tape recorder or other video
signal source. The device will monitor
the picture until the store switch is
manually or automatically actuated. This
instantly freezes the action, until normal
picture action is again started by using
the monitor switch. The unit is available
for table or rack mountings and multiple
units can be set up to freeze a number
of sequential action frames.
Modern Robin Hood
An oil company used a bowman and
a flaming arrow to relight a flare when
the flare's mechanical relighting device
failed. The flare, located at the top of
a tower, is used to burn off excess gas.

been announced.

puter in its general price range to offer

ject suffers from hallucinations and other
symptoms due to it and the accompany-

When a work-rest cycle was adopted
in conjunction with the isolation test,
the hallucinations were completely elimi-
nated, and the subjects were able to
stay in for a week or more at a time.
The cycle didn't combat fatigue very
well, because while the subject's effi-
ciency remained high in such things as
adding simple number combinations, hi:
proficiency in solving problems decreased
as time went on. The optimum dura-
tions for work and rest have yet to be
decided. While induced hibernation,
would reduce difficulties due to confine-
ment, loneliness and boredom, it would
also reduce his usefulness in space.
In the weightless state, it is believed
that man needs some "gravity" to re-
main happy. This may be in the form
of magnetic shoes, or straps on his chair
or bed so that there is at least some
restraint, and a feeling of being at rest
in relation to other objects.
The psychologists say that a man in
orbit around the earth should face in the
direction of travel with his feet toward
the earth to maintain some orientational
reference with the earth. The satellite
should not rotate more than a few de-
grees.
Due to darkness and silence, a pilot
will experience a sharply decreased sens-
ory input. It has been suggested thai
neurological stimuli received from the
viscera and skin which are too weak to
be heeded by the brain ordinarily would
compensate for the lack of the stronger
stimuli (sights, sounds) in space. Any
other undesirable psychological effect wi'I
be amplified and intensified by that often
uncontrollable human emotion, fear.
Some conclusions drawn from psycho-
logical research are:
1. Some physical activity is desirable—
ability to flex extremities, to change posi-
tion, to sit vertically seems to be a basic
requirement. A person feels content
knowing he has this ability, even if he
does not take continuous advantage of it.
2. A visual reference is needed, both
inside the vehicle and exterior to it.
Another requirement—ability to control
illumination.
3. A two-way voice communication
between the pilot and people on earth
who are as vitally interested in the suc-
cessful completion of the project as he
is would be very helpful.
4. Time orientation, time goals are
very important in space.
"). Ability to eat, sleep, carry out tasks
in a quasi-normal pattern will help a
space traveler stave off boredom and the
effects of it such as general mental
eccentricity.

ways to get that information.

Reflections.
The field of instrumentation is ad-
vancing rapidly due in part to relatively
new skills of miniaturization using
printed circuits, transistors and the like.
Thus, it is easier to attach several in-
struments to a small animal such as a
monkey without injuring it.
The effects of radiation above the
earth will have to be investigated before
we risk a human life. We should:
1. Measure the flux density and the
energy distribution of heavy primary
particles (nuclei of elements of atomic
number greater than six) above the
earth's atmosphere. Some of this in-
formation has been received from bal-
loon flights and the radio-equipped satel-
lites.
2. Devise a physical way to monitor
primary cosmic hits in biological material.
3. Measure the Van Allen radiation
using more elaborate pulse scintillator
discriminator combinations.
4. Determine the type, quality and in-
tensity of the secondary radiation within
the space vehicle.
5. Relate intensities of the Van Allen
radiation more closely to time, latitude,
longitude.
The study of Hiroshima and Nagasaki
survivors, victims of nuclear accidents
and cancer patients undergoing X-ray
treatment provides some information on
hyperradiation. This can be supple-
mented by more general study of the
consequences of radiation applied to
plant and lower animal life.
Much of the data pertaining to the
X-15 flights will ultimately be used for
space travel. The effects of cosmic radia-
tion on X-15 pilots can be determined by
measuring what is called "whole bociv
radiation", the method consisting of a
gamma counter which records the amount
of radioactive potassium in striated mus-
cle tissue. The examination takes only
three minutes; then preflight and post-
flight levels are simply compared to ob-
tain a reading. The half-life of radio-
active potassium is 12.8 hours. A pilot's
radioactivity would normalize in about
three days.
A current data-gathering package in-
troduced by Wright Air Development
Center contains the following instru-
ments to transmit information from *
pilot's body to the ground: four differ-
ential electrocardiograph amplifiers, four
thermistor bridge circuits (temperature
gauges), one bridge circuit with tempera-
ture compensation for a heated-thermistor
type pneumotachometer (a respiration
counter), and two pressure transducer
bridges. Nine channels convey physiolog-
ical information and the other two con-
cern the environment. The eleven oscillo
graphs are continuously and simultane-
ously telemetered to the groung during
test flights.

bubble blowing
This plastic bubble protects the antenna of a
radically new aerial three-dimensional radar
defense system.
Sensitive to the inadequacies of conventional radar
systems, engineers at Hughes in Fullerton devised
a radar antenna whose pointing direction is made
sensitive to the frequency of the electromagnetic
energy applied to the antenna. This advanced tech-
nique allows simultaneous detection of range, bear-
ing and altitude...with a single antenna.
Hughes engineers combined this radar antenna with
"vest-pocket sized" data processors to co-ordinate
antiaircraft missile firing. These unique data proc-
essing systems provide:
1. Speed —Complex electronic missile firing data was
designed to travel through the system in milli-
seconds, assuring "up-to-date" pinpoint position-
ing of hostile aircraft.
2. Mobility —Hughes engineers "ruggedized" and
miniaturized the system so that it could be mounted
into standard army trucks which could be de-
ployed to meet almost any combat problem—even
in rugged terrain.
3. Reliability — By using digital data transmission
techniques, Hughes engineers have greatly re-
duced any possibility of error.
Result: the most advanced electronics defense
system in operation!


Other Hughes projects provide similarly stimulating
outlets for creative talents. Current areas of Re-
search and Development include advanced airborne
electronics systems, advanced data processing
systems, electronic display systems, molecular elec-
tronics, space vehicles, nuclear electronics, electrolu-
minescence, ballistic missiles...and many more.
Hughes Products, the commercial activity of Hughes,
has assignments open for imaginative engineers to
perform research in semiconductor materials and
electron tubes.
Whatever your field of interest, you'll find Hughes
diversity of advanced projects makes Hughes an
ideal place for you to grow...both professionally
and personally.

OUTSTANDING PROFESSIONAL OPPORTUNITIES AVAILABLE
TO GRADUATING SCIENTISTS AND ENGINEERS
NASA plans, directs and conducts the Nation's
aeronautical and space activities for peaceful pur-
poses and the benefit of all mankind.
NASA's efforts are directed toward discovering
new knowledge about our universe and formu-
lating new concepts of flight within and outside
the earth's atmosphere. Through the application
of the resulting new knowledge and supporting
technology, we will gain a deeper understanding
of our earth and nearby space, of the moon, the
sun and the planets, and ultimately, of inter-
planetary space and the distant galaxies.
NASA is now engaged in research, development,
design, and operations in a wide variety of fields,
including:
Spacecraft • Aircraft • Boosters • Payloads
Flight dynamics and mechanics • Aeroelasticity
Launching and impact loads • Materials and struc-
tures • Heat transfer • Magnetoplasmadynamics
Propulsion and energy systems: nuclear, thermal,
electrical, chemical • Launching, tracking, naviga-
tion, recovery systems • Instrumentation: electrical,
electronic, mechanical, optical • Life support sys-
tems • Trajectories, orbits, celestial mechanics
Radiation belts • Gravitational fields • Solar and
stellar studies • Planetary atmospheres • Lunar
and planetary surfaces • Applications: meteor-
ology, communications, navigation, geodesy.
Career Opportunities
At NASA career opportunities for graduates
with bachelor's or higher degrees are as unlimited
as the scope of our organization. Because of our
dynamic growth and diversified operations, ex-
cellent opportunities for personal and professional
advancement are available for graduates with
majors in:
Engineering: Aeronautical, Mechanical, Electronic,
Electrical, Chemical, Metallurgical, Ceramic, Civil,
Engineering Mechanics, Engineering Physics
Science: Astronautics, Physics, Electronics, Chem-
istry, Metallurgy, Mathematics, Astronomy, Geo-
physics
For details about career opportunities, write
to the Personnel Director of any of the
NASA Research Centers listed below or
contact your Placement Officer.
NASA Research Centers and their
locations are:
• Langley Research Center, Hampton, Va.
• Ames Research Center, Mountain View, Calif.
• Lewis Research Center, Cleveland 35, Ohio
• Flight Research Center, Edwards, Calif.
• Goddard Space Flight Center, Washington 25, D.C.

Look beyond the obvious.

... as you consider your first professional job.
At Melpar, we believe that all young engineers
and scientists should develop the habit of looking
beyond the obvious.
First, what is the obvious? It's obvious that
you're in demand. You don't have to worry about
getting your material wants satisfied. And you
don't have to worry about getting opportunities
for professional growth. Since you are in demand,
you can expect to get the things you want from
any number of potential employers.
But, if you look beyond the obvious, you'll real-
ize now that you're going to want something more
than "want satisfaction" out of your career.
You're going to want pride—pride in your per-
sonal, individual contribution.
At Melpar, where we are now working on 120
advanced defense and space exploration projects,
we are interested only in young men who realize
that pride is a reward that extends much beyond
the obvious. Because Melpar is a proud Company.
We're proud of our IMAGINEERING approach
to the solution of electronic problems; we're proud
of our uninterrupted growth and controlled expan-
sion; we're proud of the communities that sur-
round our laboratories and plants in Northern
Virginia and Boston, and we're proud of our cre-
ation, design, and production of electronic prod-
ucts destined for universal application.
If you want an opportunity to be proud of your
contribution and your Company, we're interested
in hearing from you. Tell us about yourself.
Either ask your college's Placement Director to
arrange a personal interview with the Melpar
representative who will be visiting your campus, or
write to our Professional Employment Supervisor.
Tell him if you would like to hear from one of
your college's graduates who is now progressing
at Melpar.
Melpar's representative will visit your
campus on February 11, 1960. Call
your Placement Director to arrange a
personal interview.

band, it is seen that if the carrier and
one sideband is eliminated, the same
message-carrying capability is obtained
while using only one fourth of the orig-
inal power. In other words, the effective
power output of a S.S.B. transmitter is
four times as great as an A.M. trans-
mitter of the same power.
Interference Reduced
If an A.M. radio transmitter is broad-
casting a simple 1,000 cycle tone, the
minimum frequency spectrum which it
would occupy would be 2,000 cycles.
This, you will remember, can be seen
from our picture of an A.M. signal as
two signals occuring at frequencies
"alongside the carrier." This is actually
quite a "chunk" of the total frequency
band to be occupied by only one signal.
Furthermore, if two different carriers fall
near each other in the spectrum they will
"beat" against each other much as a
carrier "beats" against its sidebands. A
tone whose frequency is equal to the
difference in frequencies of the carriers
will be heard. This is called "heterodyn-


This single sideband receiver with CW and AM is typical of such amateur receivers.
It is capable of coverage of the entire spectrum between 3.5 and 30 megacycles.
ing" and is a very troublesome sort of
interference found wherever amplitude
modulation is employed. Since the carrier
and one sideband are not present in a
single-sideband signal, it occupies less
space in the spectrum. Also there are no
carriers to "heterodyne" each other if
the signals fall close together in the fre-
quency spectrum. Claims that some meth-
ods of A.M. result in narrower signals are
false. The basic theory of radiotelephony
refutes this assertion. All of these facts
point to the conclusion that S.S.B. sig-
nals are far less subject to interference
than are A.M. signals.
USAF Tests
Tests conducted by the United States
Air Force show that S.S.B. signals are
more intelligible at a distance than are
A.M. signals. Single words were sent by
both systems and copied at the receiving
station by trained listeners. Ninety per
cent of the S.S.B. signals were above
60% intelligible. Ninety percent of the
This self contained single sideband sta-
tion has an output of 100 watts on any
of four pretuned channels. It may be
operated by non-technical personnel.
A.M. signals were only above 30% in-
telligible. Maximum single word intel-
ligibility showed a score of 78% for
S.S.B. compared to 60% for AM. Be-
cause of this proven ability to resist in-
terference, almost every Strategic Air
Command plane is equipped with S.S.B.
The Strategic Air Command's command-
er, in explaining this installation, said,
"Communication is synonymous with
command. If I don't have communica-
tions, the only weapon I have is my
desk—and I can't throw it very far, and
it's not very lethal."
In spite of the decided advantages of
single-sideband, there are certain disad-
vantages which should be mentioned. In
general, the S.S.B. system is more compli-
cated than the standard A.M. system. As
a result, it takes more skill on the part
of the operator to maintain and operate
the equipment properly. The equipment
must also be manufactured to more rig-
orous specifications, since both the trans-
mitter and the receiver must have ex-
tremely good frequency stability charac-
teristics. However, the advantages seem
to far outweigh the disadvantages, and
perhaps someday single-sideband will be-
come the "standard" mode of commun-
ication.

The word space commonly represents the outer, airless regions of the universe.
But there is quite another kind of "space" close at hand, a kind that will always
challenge the genius of man.
This space can easily be measured. It is the space-dimension of cities and the
distance between them ... the kind of space found between mainland and off-
shore oil rig, between a tiny, otherwise inaccessible clearing and its supply
base, between the site of a mountain crash and a waiting ambulance—above all,
Sikorsky is concerned with the precious "spaceway" that currently exists be-
tween all earthbound places.
Our engineering efforts are directed toward a variety of VTOL and STOL
aircraft configurations. Among earlier Sikorsky designs are some of the most
versatile airborne vehicles now in existence; on our boards today are the ve-
hicles that can prove to be tomorrow's most versatile means of transportation.
Here, then, is a space age challenge to be met with the finest and most practical
engineering talent. Here, perhaps, is the kind of challenge you can meet.

SPACE
MEDICINE
(Continued from page 34)
Doctors would like, eventually, to in-
clude other instrumentation such as an
automatic blood pressure recorder, i
photo-electric plethysmograph (a device
that registers the change in size of an
organ or a limb and hence, the amount
of blood occurring there), a polarograph-
ic element sensing the partial pressure
of oxygen in respiratory gases, and 3
one-transistor recorder of transient skin
response. The latter would eliminate the
confusion of slow changes or normal
changes in skin resistance and woulc
record only those physiological responses
to discrete stimuli.
Simulation
AH the conditions of space flight ex-
cept zero gravity and ionizing radiation
can be simulated on earth. Those of
take-off and re-entry, acceleration, oscilla-
tion, spinning or tumbling, noise, heat,
and hypobaria can be approximated by
a centrifuge, cabin on three free axes
gimbals, vibrator under seat, tape re-
cording, heat elements in the walls, and
vacuum pumps. Conditions in space:
heat, cold, hypobaria, rotation, darkness,
confinement, low sensory inputs, and in-
finite heat sink can be simulated by an
artificial sun, air conditioners, turntable,
vacuum pumps, insulation, refrigeration,
and blackened walls. Some work has
been done on acceleration using the
high-speed rocket sled. Col. John Stapp
endured 42g's when the sled in which
he was traveling at 632 miles an hour
stopped in 1.5 seconds.
The psychologist, for his part, must
make up tests for the pilot which lie
will be interested enough in to perform
during the flight, whether it is simulated,
test or actual orbiting. The classic per-
formance tests would probably be ig-
nored under those circumstances.
Researchers hope not to be taken by
surprise by anything a venture into space
will hold. They hope that they will have
prepared for every contingency when
the count-down begins. But it will be
impossible to be absolutely sure until
the first man successfully completes a
flight into space . . . and lives to tell
about it.

lost sight of the UFO and later received
word that Mantell had crashed and was
dead.*
Professor Menzel's explanation of the
encounter declared that Mantell was
chasing a "mock sun," caused by ice
crystals in cirrus clouds higher than Man-
tell's plane could safely reach. Since the
aircraft was not equipped with oxygen,
Menzel theorized that Mantell went above
his limit, blacked out, lost control of the
F-51, and subsequently crashed.
The interplanetary advocates reported
that a few of Mantell's plane fragments
had strange grooves in the metal, and
more revealing, a high measure of radio-
activity caused perhaps by an intense
wake of discharging atom-forced radia-
tion energy from the huge object.5 The
Air Force strongly denied these reports.
At the time of the Mantell incident,
the ATIC UFO project was involved in
a series of shifts in policy because of
changes in leadership. First, the group
adopted an "explain them all away"
attitude and later returned to an honest
attempt at reaching unbiased conclusions.
For example, it was first announced by
the Air Force that Mantell was killed
while chasing the planet Venus. At cer-
tain times of the year, this particular
planet becomes bright enough to be mis-
taken as a foreign object approaching
the earth. The Air Force stated that
Mantell had climbed toward Venus until
he became unconscious from insufficient
oxygen. Later, after a more thorough
investigation, it was determined that
Venus could not have been bright enough
to confuse an experienced pilot. It was
also learned that a giant 100-foot diame-
ter "skyhood" balloon, sent aloft in
Minnesota for gathering weather data,
might possibly have been in the Godman
field area on that day and that it may
have been the huge object. This was the
solution finally decided upon by Project
Blue Book.
Chasing "Saucers" Over the Capital
It was in July of 1952, that the "flying
saucer" report, which won more world
attention than any other, hit the head-
lines in our nation's capital. At 11:40
p.m., July 19, the two radar sets at Wash
ington Nationl Airport picked up eight
unidentified targets. They were not ordi-
nary aircraft because they would loaf at
100 to 130 miles per hour and then
suddenly accelerate to fantastically high
speeds and leave the area. During the
night, crews of several airliners saw
mysterious lights in the same locations
that the radar pin-pointed the targets.
Tower operators also saw lights, and jet
fighters were dispatched, but the uncanny
lights seemed to be able to anticipate
the fighters' every movement and the ob-
jects were always gone before the jets
could "close."
The morning's headlines were "Inter-
ceptors Chase Flying Saucers Over Wash-
ington, D. C!" The two radar sets at
Washington National Airport were
checked and found in perfect working
order. One set was located in the con-
trol tower and the other, a long-range
radar set controlling the air lanes for
miles around, was located in the Air
Route Traffic Control Center.
A week later, the mysterious objects
again appeared. One UFO was clocked
at 7,000 miles per hour; other objects
flew through the prohibited flying are;-
over the White House and Capitol. Air-
liners were followed to within a few
miles of touchdown on the runways.
Ninety degree turns at high speeds were
executed repeatedly. Interceptors were
again called and just as the jets ap-
proached the area, the targets disappeared
off the scopes. The jets flew around for
awhile, saw nothing, and left the Wash-
ington area. In a few minutes, the un-
identified objects were back on the radar
scopes. Another jet was contacted and
this time the pilot saw a light and
started toward it, but suddenly it went
out, "as though a light bulb had been
turned off." The pilot and his radar ob-
server continued the run and a radar
lockon was established, but it was soon
broken. Two more lockons were ob-
tained but also broken after a few sec-
onds. During this time, people all over
the area were calling in that weird,
bright lights were being seen.'"'
It was not easy to find a reasonable
solution. Those who felt there was a
solution finally based their arguments on
temperature inversions. An inversion
occurs when the layer of air nearest the
surface of the earth becomes warmer
with increasing height. During such an
abnormal situation, this warmer air may
occur up to a height of 100 meters or
so. Above this height the temperature
decreases with higher altitudes. These
conflicting masses of air may cause radar
waves to be reflected resulting in a false
indication of positions of objects either
in the air or on the ground.
The believers in alien space travelers
did not buy this theory. It was easily
proved that in Washington, D.C. through
the months of June, July, and August
there was hardly a day that passed with-
out a temperature inversion. Therefore,
they reasoned, why did not fake targets
show up more often instead of just on
these very few occasions? And, if true,
how could these fake targets so shrewdly
maneuver when about to be pursued?
Project Blue Book was, of course,
pushed very hard for an answer in its
investigation of the Capitol incident.
This incident had probably aroused more
people in high governmental positions
than previous sightings, people who
had once laughed off the whole saucer
affair. The inversion theory was thor-
oughly investigated, but the one im-
pressive factor was the high caliber of
the people involved in the Washington
incident. Radar men in positions of air-
50
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


craft control deal with human lives and
are assigned accordingly. There can be
no error in their work and they are
chosen after rigorous training, supervi-
sion, and investigation. These men were
well qualified, experienced radar men
who brought thousands of people into
Washington National Airport every day.
Such responsible men could be expected
to know the difference between a real
target and a weather target. ATIC still
considers the Washington, D.C. sight-
ings as unknowns.
The Future Probability
These were only a few of the many
hundreds of qualified UFO reports. The
people who saw these strange occurrences,
who investigated the reports and who
engaged in the controversy in explaining
them were of the highest caliber. Airline
pilots, scientists, professors and many
others of the utmost reliability saw and
reported UFO sightings. The number of
unexplained sightings is great enough
to cause much speculation. There is no
tangible proof that space ships from
other planets exist, but the possibilities
are fascinating, and as time passes, their
existence becomes more and more proba-
ble. Perhaps some day we will know the
true answer to the '"flying saucer" ques-
tion. And as some believe, it may be one
of the greatest events that has happened
to man.
