Karl Pearson... on mystery versus ignorance
"Does science leave no mystery? On the contrary,
it proclaims mystery where others profess knowl-
edge. There is mystery enough in the universe
of sensation and in its capacity for containing
those little corners of consciousness which project
their own products, of order and law and reason,
into an unknown and unknowable w7orId. There
is mystery enough here, only let us clearly distin-
guish it from ignorance within the field of possible
knowledge. The one is impenetrable, the other
we are daily subduing."
—'Grammar of Science, 1892
THE RAND CORPORATION, SANTA MONICA, CALIFORNIA

MECHANICAL
ADVANTAGE
The screw is a combination of two
mechanical principles: the lever,
and the inclined plane in helical
form. The leverage applied to the
nut combines with motion of the nut
around the bolt to exert tremendous
clamping force between the two.
One of the greatest design errors
today, in fact, is failure to realize
the mechanical advantages that
exist in standard nuts and bolts.
Smaller diameters and less costly
grades of fasteners tightened to
their full capacity will create far
stronger joints than those utilizing
bigger and stronger fasteners tight-
ened to only a fraction of their
capacity. Last year, one of our engi-
neers showed a manufacturer how
he could save $97,000 a year simply
by using all the mechanical advan-
tages of a less expensive grade.
When you graduate, make sure
you consider the mechanical advan-
tages that RBaW fasteners provide.
And make sure, too, that you con-
sider the career advantages RBaW
offers mechanical engineers-in the
design, manufacture and application
of mechanical fasteners. If you're
interested in machine design—or
sales engineering, write us for more
information.

TECHNIC TEASERS
(1) A psychologist places a white
rat in a box. On each of the opposite
wails of the box there is a hole just
large enough for the rat to stick his head
through. The rat is taught to run from
one wall to the other. As soon as it
reaches one wall, it sticks its head
through the hole, then runs to the op-
posite wall and sticks his head through
the second hole. At the start, it takes
the rat one minute to get from one wall
to the opposite one. The return trip,
however, consumes half a minute. The
next trip requires only one-fourth ot
a minute, the next one-eighth of a min-
ute, and so on. Every time the rat make^
a trip, the following trip requires half
the time consumed for the previous trip.
This goes on indefinitely. Theoretically,
how long will it take the rat to have it»
head sticking out of both holes at the
same time?
(2) Three men, A, B, and C, evenly
spaced on a circular track in that order,
start walking around the track in the
same direction. A walking toward B,
etc. A overtakes B in 15 minutes and
requires an additional 5 minutes to over-
take C. How soon does B overtake C?
(3) A lottery sells ten tickets and
offers three prizes. What is the chance
of winning a prize with three tickets?
(4) Professor Matthews was asked
by a student, "How old are you?"
"Well," he replied, "how old are
you?"
When the student gave his age, Mat-
thews said, "When I was as old as you
are now, I was nine times as old as you
were. However, in seven years our com-
bined ages will be 92."
How old were the professoor and his
student?
(5) A car is traveling at 60 miles
per hour before going up an inclined
plane which rises at the rate of 10 feer
per 100 feet. The driver keeps the gas
pedal in a constant position. At the top
of the incline the car shoots into space.
The incline is 1000 feet long (horizon-
tally) and the car is a 1926 Buick. This
model of Buick has a weight equal to
20 times its horsepower which is equal
to one-half its displacement which, when
divided by the number of wheels (in-
cluding the spare and steering wheel)
equals 1200. The ground, starting at the
end of the incline and at a level equal
to that at the beginning of the incline,
drops at the rate of 10 feet per 100 feet
of horizontal distance.
How far from the end of the incline
will the car travel before it hits the
ground?
(6) A young lady who taught math
in a high school was supplementing her
income by helping to take the census.
As she came to a certain house, she rang
the bell, and, as she did so, noted the
house number and wrote it in her book.
An old man came to the door.
"What do you want?" he asked.
"I am the census taker, sir. Please
answer some questions."
"Go away!"
"Well, at least please tell me your
age," she persuaded.
He told her and she wrote the figure
in her book.
'"Now, sir, how many other people
live here besides yourself?"
"Three others. Now go away!"
"What are the ages of the three other
people?"
"Enough of this foolishness. You fig-
ure it out. The three ages added to-
gether make the house number. Multi-
ply them together, and you get 1296."
The census taker pondered this for a
moment and wrote some figures in the
back of the book.
"Tell me," she asked, "are any of
the other three people older than you?"
"Yes."
"Thank you very much, sir. That will
be all. Goodbye," she said as she wrote
the ages in her book.
"Go away!" the man responded
pleasantly as he slammed the door.
Now assuming that the ages are in-
tegral, and not in excess of 100 years,
can you figure out what they are, and
also the house number? You should also
find the approximate age of the person
giving the information.
(Teaser Answers on page 56)

340 SOUTH STATE
and
1101 S. UNIVERSITY
battles (eg. World War III). Even
today, in this country, the courts have
had cases brought before them because
weather modification in one area caused
supposed negligent damage in another
area. To see why a Third World War
might start over weather modification,
one must look back at the projects men-
tioned.
Suppose Russia did build dams and
artificial lakes in Siberia and also started
to melt the polar icecap. This would
raise the temperature in the Arctic area
to an extent that winds blowing across
the central United States, coming from
that region, would be much warmer than
usual. Since part of the icecap would be
melted, a proportional rise in the level
of the sea must be expected and the
lower level of New York's skyscrapers,
most of Florida and the Mississippi Val-
ley would be flooded. If these things
happened, one can be sure of strong
protests from this country. If Russia were
allowed to build the dam across the Ber-
ing Straits and the Japanese Current were
diverted, then the Pacific coast of this
country would have an even warmer
climate than it now enjoys.
A problem involving the whole world
in a different respect than mentioned be-
fore is the melting of the polar icecap.
This would leave an ice-free open arctic
and warm Atlantic currents moving
steadily through the 1,100-mile gap be-
tween Greenland and Norway, would
contribute immense masses of water vapor
to the polar atmosphere. This in turn
would lead to great snowstorms on the
Eurasian and North American shores ol
the Arctic, and to the formation of con
tinent blanketing ice sheets. Thus man,
rather than nature, would be the cause
of the next ice age.
Thus one can see that changing the
weather in any one place might be dis-
astrous to the whole world. That is why
the author mentioned in the second para-
graph of this article that man may be
capable of controlling the weather in the
future . . . but might not want to do so.
Until that time that man can control the
weather safely, hold on to your um-
brellas!!!

Aeronautical and Astronautical Engineering
Five-stage sounding rocket ready to launch at NASA firing site, Wallops
Island, Virginia. The all solid propellant vehicle was developed, assembled
and fired by members of the High Altitude Engineering Laboratory of the
Department of Aeronautical and Astronautical Engineering. One of two flights
was successful, carrying a 20-pound payload to an altitude of 1100 miles, on
November 10, 1959. The rocket is 54 feet long and weighs 7100 pounds at
take-off.

(Q) was low and Schmidt suffered little
lost work content in knocking him out
to infinity with a severe blow on his neg-
ative charge. Eddy made a quick come-
back with acceleration (a) stripping off
Schmidt's outer electrons; this so upset
the villain's equilibrium that he was
converted into cosomic radiation and
vanished in the realms of space, leaving
Eddy the resultant vector in the combat.
Old Cat Ion, attracted to the spot by
Schmidt's oxidation, beamed upon the
young dipole. "Brave young lad," he
emitted, "you have satisfied the bound-
ary conditions and by the theorem of
uniqueness are the only one for my
daughter."
"Our love will not be transient," said
Eddy as he formed a closed circuit about
her.
"Darling, we'll raise a one parameter
family of second order infinitesimals,"
murmured Anne happily. As time (t)
approached infinity, they lived happily.

A Frenchman was traveling around
the U.S. on a goodwill tour. The first
place he stopped was in a small town
in Virginia and in his bedroom was a
sign saying "George Washington slept
here." He asked about the sign and was
told that Washington is know as the
father of our country.
As he traveled across the country he-
found many more of the same signs. In
fact, nearly every hotel he stayed in
had a similar sign.
When he returned to Washington,
D.C., to make his report, it included
(Continued from page 46)
the candid comment: "I can certainly see
why George Washington is known as
the father of your country."

A Russian school child was asked by
his teacher, "Who is your father?"
"Krushchev," was the answer.
"Who is your mother?"
"The great Soviet Union."
The teacher smiled because the child
was so precocious and said, "Now what
is your fondest wish?"
"To be an orphan," the child replied.

The farmer had been to the big city
on business for a couple of weeks. Get-
ting off the train at his home town, he
happened to run into his hired hand.
"Hi Zeb!" What's new?"
"Not much."
"That's fine, boy did I . . ."
"'Ceptin' we buried your dog."
"You buried my dog? Why?"
"'S daid."
"I figured it was if you buried it.
How'd it die?"
"Hoss kicked it."
"Why'd the horse kick it?"
"Spark fell on it."
"Spark— Where did the spark come
from?"
"From the barn."
"From the barn? What happened to
the barn?"
"Burned down."
"How'd the barn catch fire?"
"S'pose it was sparks from the house."
"You mean the house burned too?"
"Yep!"
"How'd that start?"
"Figure the candles caught the drapes."
"Candles? What candles?"
"The ones around yer wife's coffin.''

F. Kelly, W. J. Miller, and J. P. Tobin of the Westinghouse Atomic Power Department lift the "core plate"
off the nuclear core for the first U.S.-built power reactor designed for use abroad (Mol, Belgium).
Waltz Mill Experimental Reactor helps
Westinghouse engineers solve problems
The new Westinghouse Testing Reactor at Waltz Mill,
Pa., provides engineers with complete facilities for an-
alyzing the effect of nuclear radiation on various mate-
rials, processes and designs. If a Westinghouse engineer
is working on development of atomic fuels or the design
of reactor components for an atomic power plant, he
can count on help from the men at Waltz Mill.
The Westinghouse Testing Reactor is one of only two
such privately owned reactors in the country. It pro-
vides a high radiation field comparable to that of a
working reactor, and in addition has special controlled
environment loops for the study of radiation effects at
high temperatures and pressures. Work presently being
carried out here for other departments of the company
includes studies of thermionics, crystal structure, and
thermoelectric effects as well as the work on atomic
reactor designs and fuels.
The young engineer at Westinghouse isn't expected
to know all the answers . . . our work is often too ad-
vanced for that. Instead, his abilities and knowledge are
backed up by specialists like those at Waltz Mill.
If you have ambition and ability, you can have a
rewarding career with Westinghouse. Our broad product
line, decentralized operations, and diversified technical
assistance provide hundreds of challenging opportuni-
ties for talented engineers.
Want more information? Write today to Mr. L. H.
Noggle, Westinghouse Educational Department, Ard-
more &amp; Brinton Roads, Pittsburgh 21, Pennsylvania.

Interior of Saran Wrap* plant.
DOW" is tomorrow-minded
product
Publishing a complete list of Dow products—all 700
odd of them—is an elusive project. By the time such
a list was off the press, new names would have to be
added to bring the list up to date. The reason: develop-
ment of new products is the order of the day at Dow,
every day of the working year.
These new products are developed to meet the needs
of the many industries Dow serves. Today's problems
in manufacturing and processing must be solved, and,
as these industries advance, new chemicals and materials
will be needed to implement tomorrow's technology. At
Dow, research and development aim at anticipating
these future needs . . . thus a "tomorrow-minded"
attitude toward products is always evident.
The product group of Dow Agricultural Chemicals, for
example, has expanded manyfold in recent years
through a vigorous research and developmental pro-
gram. In the early '50's it consisted of two or three
products. Today it includes many varieties of weed
killers, fertilizers, fumigants, insecticides, feed additives
and animal health aids. A new crab grass killer has
recently made its debut, first in a series of new "ag
chem" products slated for the homeowner market.
Dow's work in automotive chemistry is typical of the
"tomorrow-minded" attitude. Dow currently supplies
a number of chemicals and plastics materials to auto
makers—latex-based metal primers, antifreeze, uphol-
stery materials and brake fluids, to name a few. But a
quick tour through Dow's two Automotive Chemicals
Laboratories would reveal that Dow will be ready with
the right chemicals and plastics for the job, no matter
which way future automotive design goes! One under
development, for example, is a chemical that cools the
engine by continuous boiling.
One of the most outstanding success stories at Dow is
that of Separan10, a product developed to fit into
industry's future. This chemical is a flocculant, or
"settler" of solids in solution. Perhaps "super floc-
culant" would be a better description because Separan
takes minutes to do jobs that formerly took days.
Introduced in 1955, it has gained widespread recognition
in mining, pulp and paper and other industries.
In such a climate of creativity and tomorrow-minded-
ness, new opportunities at Dow are constantly opening
up for people who have their eyes—and their thoughts
—on the future. If you'd like to know more about the
Dow opportunity, please write: Director of College
Relations, Department 2426FW, the dow chemical
company, Midland, Michigan.
•trademark
THE DOW CHEMICAL COMPANY • MIDLAND, MICHIGAN

"Every student must take at least half bis courses in liberal
arts. Required of all are stiff, one-year courses in English literature
and rhetoric, history and development of Western civilization, his-
tory and philosophy of science, and a study of contemporary non-
western cultures. . . .
Students in engineering science will get a broad background of
mathematics, chemistry and physics and some specialties sucb as
mechanics and electronics. With the heavy schedule in liberal arts,
they will be prepared as broadly trained men able to direct massive
combinations of men and materials in engineering and scientific
problems not even dreamed of today."
(Michigan Daily, February 14, I960)
The above statement is the result of a series of unique dis-
cussions—the Meadow Brook Seminars—between twenty-eight
authorities in the fields of liberal arts, engineering, business, and
teacher education. The purpose of these seminars was the creation
of a new institution of higher learning—Michigan State University-
Oakland.
Of particular interest is a seminar that took place in Meadow
Brook Hall on the site of the new campus on August 16, 1958. Six
of the nation's leading engineering educator's were present to answer
the following question:1
"With your knowledge and experience in the field of
engineering education, how would you organize a program
in engineering science at this new institution to train en-
gineers for the half century ahead of us?"-
The answer the panel gave to this question, along with the
answers given by other panels in liberal arts, business, and teacher
education resulted in MSU-O as typified by the opening paragraph.
Of special interest to us, as engineers, is the result of the seminar
on engineering, not because we are suggesting that Michigan adopt
a similar plan, but because of the insight it gives us into the role
of engineers and engineering in the last half of the twentieth cen-
tury.
First the group concluded that engineering schools have been
doing a good job in general and must continue to do so, but that in
the future "there needs to be added new dimensions (in engineer-
ing education) if the challenge of the future is to be met with
success." Today engineers are working on large and complicated
"projects" compared with the "jobs" of years ago. This and other
changes in our society mean that engineers more frequently will
have to "have some knowledge of, and be able to communicate
with, the practitioners of law, of finance, and of politics." In other
words, while the engineer must be increasingly adept in his field,
he must be broad enough to handle himself in other elements of
society.
The Meadow Brook group felt that not one, but three types
of "engineers" will be needed to meet the challenge of the future.
The first group comprises the majority of engineering graduates,
the ones who take an idea in rough form and apply it to produce
the cars, planes and missies of today. Second is the "technician," a
1 Dr. Eric A. Walker, President, Pennsylvania State University, Dr. C. Richard

THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


type being graduated in greater numbers each year from technical
institutions and junior colleges. Third is the group termed the
"innovators and directors" which is what MSU-O hopes to produce
three years hence. According to the experts it is this group—which
will get a background of 35% natural sciences and math, 20%
social-humanities, and 45% engineering at MSU-O—who will
direct and initiate the complex engineering projects in the years
to come. But even if this category includes only a small group, it
is still true that the majority of engineers will find their jobs be-
coming increasingly complex as they relinquish many of their
duties to the technician and move on to higher intellectual planes.
As pointed out before, we are not suggesting, nor was the
Meadow Brook group, that Michigan or any other school adopt the
MSU-O plan or a similar one. Yet the conclusions and recom-
mendations made by these educators remain important to us, for
they preview the responsibilities and limitations of the engineer in
the next half-century.
According to the Meadow Brook conclusions, if our role is
to be an integral significant part of the future, we must be "extreme-
ly able men who are well educated liberally, scientifically, math-
ematically, and as engineering scientists."
Will we be able to meet this criterion?

Of more than passing interest on campus recently has been
the fine job being done by the Institute of Science and Technology
to stimulate and raise the level of scientific thinking at Michigan.
Although only in its first year of operation, 1ST has sponsored, or
is sponsoring, lecture series on Space Astrophysics, Guidance and
Control Vehicles, and the Molecular Control of Cellular Activity.
Through the efforts of 1ST nearly 50 distinquished authorities
—including at least two Nobel prize winners—from all parts of the
United States as well as Sweden, England, West Germany, and the
Netherlands, will have spoken here by the end of the year.
A glance at the titles of the various lectures indicates that they
should go a long way in stimulating scientific thought among facul-
ty, grad students and upperclassmen. If these lectures are indica-
tions of things to come we can be sure 1ST is going to be around for
a long time to come.
* * *
Reading Bernard Stollman's article in this issue on transpor-
tation problems in today's cities brings to mind the transportation
problem in the Fishbowl and the surrounding "passageways" in
Angell Hall. For an engineer on his first venture past West Engine,
it is quite a shock to battle his way through this "Lit School para-
dise," hopefully trying to make it in ten minutes. It seems that a
little bit of thought somewhere could eliminate this bottleneck.
A recent report from the Engineering Manpower Commission
brings some bad news—or good, depending on your viewpoint. If
you are graduating in the next couple of years it is probably good
news to hear that engineering enrollment dropped 11% in 1958
and 4% in 1959. But from a broader point of view these statistics
may be a bad omen for the country as a whole, especially in the
light of the 'missle gap" that apparently is widening.

WHY THIS SPECIAL ISSUE?
If we may define engineering as the
art which renders the truth of science useful
to the happiness of men, then the American
City and her future are of vital concern to
the engineer ... herein are found machines
and men en masse ... we achieve our goals
as engineers only when they are in har-
mony.
Will the city become a battlefield in
the struggle between man and his works:
his roads, machines ... or can the master
tame his serving-men? This is the question
that this special issue seeks to probe . . .
Photo Courtesy Tony Spina, The Detroit Free Press


FACE
TOMORROW
Home to millions, center of commerce, focal
point of industry, the city is one of the bastions
of our social and economic life. But all is not
well with our metropolitan areas. Old age,
malignant suburban growth, and hardening of
the traffic arteries are but a few of the many
ills with which they are afflicted. Will these
maladies be fatal? It will be largely up to the
engineers to be "urban surgeons" and restore
the patient's vigor.
by BERNARD STOLLMAN
Next to language, Lewis Mumford
has pointed out, man's greatest
work of art is the city. Compared with
the city, the other forms of art are mere-
ly subsidiary. The city represents "the
point of maximum concentration for the
power and culture of a community." As
such, it represents the human condition
in a fuller sense than does any other of
man's varied achievements. Small wonder,
then, that city planners, sociologists,
economists, and occasionally even busi-
nessmen, recently have begun clamoring
for greater progress in rectifying the
city's rapidly worsening problems. The
tremendous population expansion within
the last fifteen years, combined with the
almost inhuman progress in technology,
has put America's cities in the most
dangerous situation they have yet en-
countered.
The great cities of America are dis-
integrating; they are being dismantled
and reassembled in a fashion contrary to
human needs and desires. Though city
planning agencies have been in operation
for twenty to thirty years in some of the
largest metropolitan centers in the United
States, only in the last few years has it
become obvious that the basic assump-
tions of city planners have been, to a
large extent, incorrect. The central core
of the city is being destroyed—that area
which has always been the crux or focus
of the city. It may well be asserted that
the destruction of that focus is synony-
mous with the destruction of the city
itself, no matter how great the popula-
tion of the surrounding suburbs.
Today, the city is becoming the home
of the very poor or the very wealthy; it
has little to attract the middle-income
group. This is essentially where the city
fails. Public housing is being provided
for the lower-income group; the wealthy
class have fashionable downtown apart-
ments. It is in the suburbs, in the giant
subdivisions of anonymous rows of
houses, that the middle-income group
has found what it desires. The city can-
not continue to exist as a healthy, vigor-
ous, democratic institution if it cannot
sustain a middle class. Some type of sub-
sidy or other inducement must close this
gap in the in-city sociological pattern if
the middle class is to be brought back
from the suburbs.
16
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


do not qualify for public housing and
cannot afford suburban housing. These
people remain in the city, or on the
fringes of the city, always one step ahead
of the slums. Some form of subsidized
housing again seems to be the answer
Modern rehabilitation projects are be-
ing planned or are under way all across
the nation. Unfortunately, most of these
projects are an outgrowth of a theory
formulated in the late nineteenth century,
one which has long been misunderstood.
The "garden city" idea was presented
in England in 1899 by Ebenezer Howard.
It represented an attempt to break up the
large city into a group of smaller com-
munities, providing a life close to nature
but retaining the industrial and social
amenities of the large cities. In the 1920's
and 1930s Clarence Stein carried these
ideas even further. He built communities
such as Radburn, New Jersey, based on
the ideas of Howard. Le Corbusier, the
great French architect, changed the "gar-
den city" by replacing the small buildings
»ilh skyscrapers. This increased the popu-
lation density sufficiently so that the
'garden city" concept became adaptable
to the city itself, not only the suburban
fringes.
By far the best solution to high-den-
sity urban housing is a mixture ot high-
rise and low-rise buildings, a combination
of the ideas of Howard and Le Corbusier.
Yet these plans do not solve the city's
problem. Planners have forgotten that
planning, like architecture, is a matter
of shaping space. In rural areas the space
surrounds the building; in urban loca-
tions the building should surround the
space. The "garden city" concept tends
to encourage urban buildings that are
surrounded by space, making it difficult
to achieve sucessfully the high densities
required for the core of the city. Besides,
these projects are usually out of the hu-
man scale. Public housing tends to be
made up of monolithic slabs that compare
more closely with prison blocks than
with living quarters for free individuals.
Housing developments of this sort
are doing more harm than good. They
are destroying the core of the city, the
vital center of cultural and social oppor-
tunities. Nathan Glazer, co-author with
David Riesmann of "The Lonely Crowd"
pertinently observes that this destruction
occurs when planners are planning for
suburbs, not cities. By replacing slums
with public housing, planners have also
destroyed what value these slums had. The
stimulus for poets and politicians, of
coffee houses, grocery stores, store-front
churches, radical political headquarters,
etc., has been removed. "The greater the
suburbanization of the city, the weaker
the city's core has grown."
The value of the core of the city lies
chiefly in its heterogeneity. The variety
of stores, of types of housing, and most
of all, the variety of people, makes the
city the most interesting and easily the
most rewarding place to live. Suburbia,
as it has evolved, is a place of tiresome
repetition. Subdivisions consisting of hun-
dreds of identical homes have produced
neighborhoods of identical people—peo-
ple with the same income, number of
children, interests, and values. At the
same time, suburbia has separated itself
from the cultural centers. It may require
onl) half an hour to drive to the center
of the city, yet suburbanites tend to feel
cut off from the city and make little use
of the amenities offered there. Because
of its very nature, suburbia can never
attain the cultural and social advantages
that are offered by the city. Once they
are not available in the city, they will
nr&gt;t be available anywhere.
A look at the layouts of streets and
homes in Riverside, a suburb of Chicago,
indicates how little original thinking has
been done in subdivision planning in the
last hundred years. Riverside was de-
signed in 1869 with a gracefully curving
pattern of streets, carefully alternating
parks, open spaces and housing. Today's
subdivisions are no improvement over
Riverside. If anything, the streets are far
less graceful, the parks missing. Subdi-
viders have no desire to let the natural
contours of the land determine the final
topography of the subdivision. Usually
the land is reduced to a level plain be-
fore construction is begun.
What can planners do to save the
city? Mixed high- and low-rise housing
is only part of the answer. Planners must
realize that the city needs a core and
that this core must be the most densely-
populated area in the city. Existing facil-
ities that retain the historic, cultural, and
social characteristics of the city must not
be replaced by parks that resemble ceme-
teries. Pedestrian, not automobile, scale is
necessary. The core must be a place for
walking, not driving. If necessary, the
area may be turned into a pedestrian mall.
Chain stores must not be entirely substi-
tuted for independently-owned ones.
More light and space is needed, but not
at the expense of building monotonous
glass and steel cages.
Transportation facilities are becom-
ing outmoded faster than cities are re-
placing them. The number of cars that
is predicted to be in use by 1975 is stag-
gering. The downtown area will never
become any sort of magnet for people
if the highway system leading to the
city's center is inadequate. Any plans for
renewal or development in the downtown
area must include a solution to the city's
snarled traffic system.
Sir Christopher Wren's plan for Lon-
don in the seventeenth century is still
applicable; planners must create civic
centers that will be "multiple, manage-
able, centers of civic life." Middle-income
housing should be subsidized. The dirt
and decay of slums must be replaced but
the individuality and the spontaniety of
these areas should by some means be re-
tained. Landscape architects, not engin-
eers, should be encouraged to do subdi-
vision design. If necessary, acreage zon-
ing might be resorted to in order to
preserve "greenbelts" or areas of natural
countryside, on the outskirts of the
heavily-urbanized area.
These goals can never be accomplished
by planners alone, no matter how skilled.
The public must take an interest in civic
design if cities are to be reshaped ac-
cording to human needs. Only through
an understanding of its fundamental
advantages can we find hope for the
strong and secure future of the Ameri-
can city, and an increase in the delights
and benefits of urban life. "Designing a
dream city is easy," as one planner has
pointed out, "rebuilding a living one
takes imagination."

by BERNARD STOLLMAN

l\
That deteriorating transportation facil-
ities within the city constitute one of
the most important problems in the
changing metropolitan scene is perhaps
well known to every citizen who has ever
been caught in rush-hour traffic. Yet the
manner in which our major American
cities may extricate themselves from this
rapidly worsening situation is a topic of
heated controversy among urban planners
and city officials.
In most of the larger cities in the
United States, the streetcar has almost
disappeared whereas subways, buses and
commuter trains are proving to be far
from adequate. Expressways are pouring
traffic into the downtown area while no
means of handling these cars, once they
arrive downtown, is yet apparent. Many-
early city planners assumed that the num-
ber of automobiles would increase very
slowly with time and that most people
would continue to travel by public transit.
The opposite has proved to be true. A
recent survey by Fortune Magazine found
that auto registrations have increased
from 25,800,000 in 1945 to 54,300,000
in 1956. "Transit riding on the other
hand, has continued to decline: streetcar
passengers down 78%; bus riders down
28%; subway-elevated down 17%. To-
day the average American uses public
transit less than half as much as he did
in the late Twenties."
Perhaps the most pressing question is
whether the city will continue to serve
as a unifying core for its surrounding
metropolitan region, or whether it will be
completely fragmented. If urban trans-
portation costs—not only in money but in
time and annoyance—rise any more, they
will cancel all the advantages of the city.
The vital central core of the city may be
replaced by an ugly business and cultural
center, surrounded by endless sprawl—
Los Angeles being an excellent example
of this type of inefficient arrangement.
Just how to relieve this congestion and
preserve the core of the city becomes
the central problem.
First we must realize that the auto-
mobile at present is the fastest way of
getting out of the downtown area (with
the exception of rail commuters). The
motorist's average speed is 20 mph com-
pared with 13 mph for the busiest transit
routes. Just how long this will continue
is the important question. Fortune reports
that the forecast is for over two new
vehicles on the road for every three ad-
ditional Americans, "by 1957 the U.S.
will have over 100 million vehicles for
a population of 220 million. Nearly half

KALAMAZOO SAYS "NO"
The Technic's roving reporter discovers that the
cornerstone for the city of tomorrow has been
laid a scant hundred miles west of Ann Arbor.
By BRYAN WHIPPLE
Associate Editor
"... Ann Arbor, Jackson, Battle
Creek, Kalamazoo, Niles . . . . " These
cities of Southern Michigan sprawl along
the tracks of the Michigan Central Rail-
road with monotony seldom relieved by
sights such as a fair university campus,
or an ugly prison. Yet one of these cities,
Kalamazoo, boasts something so unique
and intriguing that we decided to investi-
gate it personally. Kalamazoo has begun
to build the city of tomorrow—not in
the sticks, nor in the suburbs, but right
in the heart of downtown.
It all started back in 1956, when the
merchants of downtown Kalamazoo be-
gan to get edgy about business trends.
In their city of 75,000, one year (1955)
had seen a million-dollar drop in the
assessed valuation of the CBD (central
business district). Retail sales were be-
ginning to fall off, and the exodus of
retail business to outlying areas was mak-
ing empty stores an all-too-frequent
sight.
To make matters worse, downtown
streets were choked with traffic. Predic-
tions for future traffic, based on the
fast growth of the metropolitan area,
made a grim picture indeed. Widening
of streets, prohibition of certain turns
and of on-street parking, one-way streets,
and the other usual means of increasing
street capacity were cither impractical or
in use. City fathers were at their wits'
end.
Merchants usually feel the bite of ad-
vancing blight more rapidly than the
tax-supported instruments of government.
In Kalamazoo they responded to the
needs of their community with a vigor
and optimism seldom equalled by such
groups. Late in 1956 they incorporated
themselves as the Downtown Planning
Committee, Inc., and several leading con-
sulting firms were invited in to discuss
means by which the Kalamazoo CBD
might be revitalized.
By spring of 1957 the DPC had

dustrial Engineering, is the asso-
ciate editor of the Technic. He
graduated from Thomas M. Cooley
High School in Detroit where he
was active in the Radio Club, school

nomic future of Alaska.

$40,000 in subscriptions from its mem-
bers and retained Victor Gruen Associates
as a consulting firm, partly on the basis
of a downtown plan executed by that
firm for Fort Worth, Texas.
In March, 1958, the long-range plan,
which depicted an auto-free central busi-
ness district, was presented to the public.
The plan and report was entitled "Kala-
mazoo 1980" after its ultimate target
date, but this by no means implied that
its contents were only some beautiful
theory pertaining to the misty future.
The plan called for construction of the
new Kalamazoo in stages, with a maxi-
mum of flexibility consistent with ade-
quate planning and control. It is in this
respect that "Kalamazoo 1980" is an
unusual city plan; it is workable. Even
more important, the first stage of this total
downtown facelift is nearly complete.
Pedestrian Mall
Burdick Street is (or was) a heavily-
trafficked, although narrow, north-south
artery bisecting the downtown area. On
June 1, 1959, workmen from the city's
Parks Department removed all of the
fourteen inches of blacktop, brick, and
concrete that had served the busiest down-
town block of Burdick Street as a pave-
ment.
Following many months of careful
study by the city planning staff and other
municipal departments, a recommenda-
tion had been adopted to tie off this
artery permanently for two blocks, be-
tween Water and South Streets, and con-
vert it into an attractive pedestrian mall,
thus restoring to the citizenry the right
to stroll about and shop at ease in the
heart of a city for the first time since the
disappearance of the Greek agora, the
Roman forum, or perhaps the Algerian
market-place.
20
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


the legality of closing a street to vehicu-
lar traffic. Kalamazoo found several legal
justifications for its action: the City
Charter specifically grants the power to
"use, control, and regulate the use of its
streets, alleys, bridges, public places, and
the space above and beneath them." It
also grants to the City Commission the
authority "to exercise all of the powers
conferred on the City." These charter
provisions are implementations of like
express powers set out in the State's Home
Rule Act. It also was pointed out that the
pedestrian mall does not propose to
vacate or abandon the public rights in a
street, but merely to limit the use made
of the area.
"Who should pay for the mall?" Since
the merchants were eager for the imple-
mentation of the Gruen Plan, they agreed
to share the cost with the city, and were
duly assessed for half the estimated ex-
penditure, or $30,000. The city trans-
ferred the other half of the required
funds from accounts for other improve-
ment projects that had run under their
budget amounts.
In addition the city sold bonds worth
$625,000 to finance 250 additional off-
street parking spaces, all within two
blocks of the mall.
The actual construction of the mall
progressed rapidly. Two blocks have been
completed to date. The north block of
Burdick Street is 264 feet long and the
south block is 660 feet long. The street
proper was 40 feet wide and the total
right-of-way 66 feet wide. The shorter
block was converted first, to see whether
any bugs would develop; it was also
better from a traffic point of view. The

cross-street between the blocks has been
left open, as can be seen in the photos.
Features added to the north block to
enhance its appearance included flowers
and other plantings, which are changed
seasonally to remain attractive, and a re-
flecting pool. The street area is a check-
erboard pattern of multicolored concrete
tiles, surrounded by lawns and gardens.
Low evergreens and shrubs are now

In the longer block there is a small
children's playground which has proved
an immense success. There is also an
outdoor stage, designed to revolve with
special displays and exhibits. Pools with
fountains and colored lights, modern
benches, and gardens similar to those of
the north block round out the features

of the long block.
Snow removal and possible fire truck
passage have been planned for. The
necessary equipment is able to pick its
way across the flagstones to reach all areas
of the mall. Delivery of goods to the
retail stores was somewhat of a problem
in the north block, which is inadequately
served by rear alleyways. Presently goods
are being brought in by hand truck in
the early morning from the cross-streets.
Since the heaviest merchandise to be
moved in is cases of beer to a beer store,
the problem is not too severe, although it
may be critical in planning future exten-
sions of the mall.
Project Successful
This naturally leads us to ask, what
does Kalamazoo think of its mall, now
that it's irrevocably in place? Are the
merchants stuck with a lemon, or are the
off-mall stores eager to get on it? Well,
they certainly are eager, and the mall will
in all likelihood march south again this
summer, and possibly even start on an
adjacent street!
Mr. William A. Ripatte, Planning Di-

BLESSING
BLIGHT?


suburbs will soon become a blight on the American landscape,
unless drastic action is taken.
Map reproduced by permission of the American Automobile Association.
by BARRY L. PEEBLES
Editor-in-Chief
Suburbia represents a dreary blight
on the American landscape, the epitome
of American standardization and vulgar-
ization, with its row upon monotonous
row of mass-produced cheerfulness, mas-
querading as home.
—American (Oct. 17, 1959)
"Dreary blight" and "epitome of vul-
garization"—these are strong words to
direct at modern man's beloved suburbs.
Are we to accept them at face value? Do
they prophesy the beginning of the end
of suburbia as we know it today? Is sub-
urbia a blessing .... or a blight?
Today the suburbs are mainly a bless-
ing— but they won't be tomorrow un-
less drastic action is taken. The reason:
in only forty years over 85% of our
population will live in urbania, megalo-
polis, subtopia, or whatever you want
to call our huge metropolitan areas. At
the same time nearly 35% of our popu-
lation will be jammed into only ten giant
supercities. Just to bring facts closer to
home, can you imagine the Detroit area's
3.4 million residents expanded to 9.5
million? Well, that's what the Urban
Land Institute says will happen by the
year 2000. But this is not just a long-
range problem—Newsweek reports that
today's 100 million metropolitan popu-
lation will jump 40 million in just ten
short years.
If these facts are true, and there seems
no reason to doubt them, the big ques-
tion is: "Can we handle this urban ex-
plosion without ending up with a massive
urban slum?" The answer is yes, if we
start now with intelligent planning and
control. "Now" is the important word
because already the "wolf is at the door"
—blight has set in and is beginning to
spread. For this reason let us examine
the situation today for both a glimpse
at things to come and clues to a solu-
tion.
First of all, there can be no doubt that
there exists a mass exodus to suburbs—
large enough to consume 3000 acres a
day in new home sites, according to the
editors of Fortune. With each passing
month the pressure from city dwellers
for new homes in the suburbs builds up.
Naturally the developers respond by
moving their bulldozers onto more and
more untouched land.
At first, it might be assumed that the
problem is a shortage of land near the
metropolitan areas. Examination reveals
this to be the result, but the underlying
cause is in the way land is used. Five or
ten acres are used where one would work,
and worse results are obtained. Accord-
ing to William H. Whyte, Jr., author of
the 1957 best seller. The Organization
Man, the big lot and helter-skelter de-
velopments, while at first attractive, are
the real troublemakers. In his words "...
a few casually placed developments rob
the community of scores of choices that
would be important to it five or ten
years from now—for parks, industrial
districts, reservoirs, .md just plain breath-
ing space." Whyte, assistant managing
editor of Fortune, recently proposed "a
plan to save the vanishing U. S. coun-
tryside" while still providing enjoyable
suburban living. We will return to
his plan later, but first several other
critical areas of concern to suburbia and
its residents need mention.
Not the least of these other problems
is who pays—the newcomers or the older
residents? With each new development,
someone must accept the financial burden
for schools, water and sewage, as well
as police and fire protection. Generally,
the greatest burden has fallen, not on
the newcomers, but on the residents of
nearby existing communities. This prob-
lem is especially acute with respect to
schools. For instance, Business Week re-
ports that if 100 acres were developed
in a typical community at four houses
per acre, there would be $175,000 of
additional school costs with an increase
in tax return of $80,000. Because of the
equal taxation principle, both old and
new residents would share the difference
in costs—a fact that displeases the old
residents considerably.
To make matters worse, the political
system and government organization in
these areas is generally inadequate. The
cause of this problem can be traced to
the lack of area-wide authority and re-
sponsibility. According to a report made
at an annual Governors' Conference, in
metropolitan areas where several local
governments operate, "metropolitan needs
have outmoded substantial parts of the
local government system." However,
metro super-governments may not be the
complete answer to this problem either,
unless they are given the power they
need. This is brought out in the Gov-
ernors' report when it states that, even
in areas where the local government en-
compasses most of the metropolitan area,
its powers are inadequate.
To sum up the situation, it can be said
that an ever-increasing tide is rolling out
from the cities, while the people from
the existing suburbs, under financial and
political pressure, are trying to hold back
the tide—but to no avail. Before going
into the plans suggested by the experts
to keep megalopolis from becoming
"mess-opolis," let us see just wnat has
been done or attempted in the past, both
by the builders and by the communities
themselves.
In general, the outlying areas have
done little planning or study in the past,
and there is little likelihood of this
attitude changing. That is, little plan-
ning until after one or two hit-and-run
developers have slapped up hundreds of
look-alike houses. Then the town fathers
go into action with zoning laws and
other restrictive procedures, most of
which are useless at this late date.
The most common way of "closing
the gate after the horse is out" is to start
"upzoning" the land—decreasing the
number of houses that can be built per
acre. For instance, if the minimum size
lot is upped from 7,500 square feet to
(Continued on page iO)
MARCH, I960
23


c
The solution to the slum problem lies in low-cost
housing and urban redevelopment.

Lurking in the shadows of every
middle-aged, run-down neighbor-
hood is that cesspool of wretched human-
ity called a slum.
"A slum is most simply defined as
housing (on whatever scale) so inade-
quate or so deteriorated as to endanger
the health, safety or morals of its inhabi-
tants. A blighted residential area is one
on the downgrade, which has not reached
the slum stage." (Edith Elmer Wood)
"A blighted area is defined as one that
has become an economic liability to the
community, that is, one on which the
taxes do not pay for public service."
(Architects Club of Chicago)
While the full-blown slum is a social
problem, blight, the progenitor of slums,
is largely an economic one. The heart
of the matter appears to be the discrep-
ancy between the value an owner places
on his property and the amount that
can be paid for appropriate develop-
ment. When land prices fall, the owner
holds on to his property in the hope
that he can still sell for a good price. He
becomes increasingly unwilling to im-
prove or even to repair the buildings
which he may own, and less able to
afford it as he waits for the value of his
holdings to go up. So the buildings rot
while the poorest classes live in them.
Ironically, such a situation can some-
times be quite profitable to the owner
who manages to crowd five or six families
into space intended for only one. This
can happen in cities where housing laws
are weak or are poorly enforced. It is
Detroit's Medical Center Project will
change a blighted area into new med-
ical center.
just as bad for a landlord to rent sub-
standard housing as it is for a butcher to
sell wormy meat.
A second basic cause of blight is the
fact that business has not expanded into
the spaces left by people who moved out
of the central region of the city, as it
was expected to do. Reasons why it has
not include the following: the skyscraper
lets business grow upward ■ rather than
outward; technological improvement in
methods of manufacturing causes indus-
try to require less space; an increasing
tendency is for companies to locate on the
outskirts of the city; and finally, numer-
ous shopping centers have been built
in the suburbs to relieve the parking
difficulty in the center of town.

by SUE OTT
The Gratiot Redevelopment Project in

But the prosperous move on to more de-

the others moved because something
happened to lower property values.
How Blight Starts
One of the things that can start
blight is a change in land use within a
neighborhood. If a family converts its
house to a grocery store, or builds a mul-
tiple-family structure on a single-family
lot, while the value to the owner him-
self may increase, the desirability, and
hence the value of the neighborhood, is
lessened to other residents, encouraging
them to move elsewhere.
Another cause is change of occupancy;
that is, if a family that moves sells to a
family of lower "standards" or of less
means, the latter's unwillingness or in-
ability to keep up or improve the proper-
ty becomes a blight promoter. Other fac-
tors are racial discrimination, unfavor-
able geography and city planning, and
unwise zoning.
Sometimes a residential area is un-
wittingly laid out in a potentially smoggy
or swampy region. When those who can
do so move out, poorer people move in
because they cannot afford to live any-
where else. Poverty is not always syn-
onymous with blight and slums, but it
is an aggravating factor. The cost to the
city of police and fire protection and
public health goes up as blight progress-
es, even as the residents become less
able to pay the city taxes. It actually
costs a city more to keep a slum than
to clear it.
The automobile and rapid transit de-
serve some blame for the situation
because they make it easier for people
to live in the suburbs and work in the
city. Expressways do not increase the
value of bordering property because ex-
pressway users are not potential customers
to someone who owns or builds a store
along one.
Of course, if enough suitable housing
close to jobs was provided which the
poorer classes could afford, they wouldn't
have to occupy substandard housing. But
private investors could not break even
on such an undertaking, so the people
who are least able to change their lot

One of Detroit's completed housing projects is the John W. Smith
Homes in the northwest section.
are put into the worst circumstances.
These, then, are the major causes of
slums and blight. To prevent this shame-
ful scarring of our cities would entail
consideration of every facet and mobiliz-
ing for positive action, even before the
city plan is drawn up. Slum prevention
is an extremely complex problem involv-
ing intangible human factors; indeed,
some have declared slums unavoidable.
Presently the major emphasis is not on
prevention, but cure.
Enter F.D.R.
American awakening to the fact that
substandard housing is a serious problem
dates largely from 1933, the year in
which Franklin D. Roosevelt first took
office. Because Roosevelt was an advo-
cate of slum clearance and low-cost hous-
ing, he included funds for such projects
in the budget of his Federal Adminis-
tration of Public Works.
The first project of this kind in the
country was Techwood Homes in Atlanta,
Georgia, dedicated in November, 1935.
Since then, public housing and urban
renewal programs have been set up in
cities across the country. These are con-
tinuous programs, for blight became so
well established that much work has to
be done in extermination, even as un-
affected sections of the city must be
guarded against the danger.
A city's Local Public Agency is the
community agency designated to work
closely with the federal government's
Urban Renewal Administration on its
plans for city improvement. This is its
foremost function. In Detroit, the L.P.A.
is the Detroit Housing Commission, es-
tablished in 1934. Its first public housing
projects were Parkside Homes and Brew-
ster Homes, both now over twenty years
old, the latter bc-ing built on land cleared
of slums.
Since then, several public housing
projects have been completed in Detroit:
Frederick Douglass Homes, the most re-
cent, finished in 1955; Charles Terrace
on the East Side; Herman Gardens and
John W. Smith Homes in the northwest
section; Sojourner Truth Homes, the
smallest development with 200 apart-
ments, and Edward J. Jeffries Homes
with 2,170 apartments, the largest one
to date.
Public housing differs from urban re-
newal in that it is financed by a federal
loan which is paid back by the city. It
provides housing for those who cannot
pay for private housing. In Detroit, at
least, rent is based on individual income
and it ranges from 28 to 88 dollars,
including all utilities. The maximum
monthly rental is S70 for a one-bedroom
unit, $76 for a two-bedroom unit, $82
for a three-bedroom unit and $88 for a
four-bedroom unit.
Eligibility to live in public housing is
based on income, too. To be admitted,
the net annual income after exemptions
of a family of one or two must not ex-
ceed $4,200, $4,300 for three or four,
and $4,700 for five or more. For con-
tinued occupancy, a family's income may
rise several hundred dollars before it is
asked to leave. Specifically, the limit for
continued occupancy for one or two is
$4,700, for three or four, $5,000, and
for five or more, $5,500. Families may
add $100 for each child in the last
category.
These figures became effective last Ek-
cember when the old limits were raised
to represent more accurately the lower
economic class incomes. The incomes of

Detroit's largest housing development is the Edward J. Jeffries Homes
with 2,170 apartments.
all residents must be checked at least
once yearly, and if residents exceed the
maximum continued-occupancy income,
they are given notice of six months in
which to find another place to live. The
family doesn't have to move if, before
the six months are up, its income drops
back to within the limit. Other reasons
for eviction are nonpayment of rent and
lease violations. Residents must maintain
high standards of cleanliness, which they
are generally glad to do.
To help fill the needs of two groups
which often can't afford decent quarters
in private housing, the Detroit Housing
Commission plans to set aside one four-
teen-story building at Jeffries Homes
solely for elderly couples and another for
families of students attending Wayne
State University and the other colleges
and universities in the vicinity. These
families will meet the regular admission
requirements.
Urban renewal is the result of the
Housing Act of 1949, through which the
government provides funds for the re-
development of certain areas which are
designated by the city as blighted. That
is, the city buys up parcels of blighted
property—in Detroit, the amounts range
from 35 to 150 acres. Then it puts in
sewers and utilities and resells it to pri-
vate redevelopers at a marked-down
price. The federal government pays two
thirds of the difference between the sell-
ing price and the cost of acquiring and
improving the land, while the city pays
the remaining third. The developers must
follow the city's scheme for the property
and build whatever the project plans call
for, such as parks, private housing, stores,
office buildings, industrial plants and the
like. In this way, the property can be
improved and the investors can make
money, at relatively small cost to the city.
A different phase of urban renewal is
neighborhood conservation which stems
from the Housing Act of 1954. This act
finances the removal of substandard
homes from blighted areas and the im-
provement of the standard homes. This
procedure stops blight before it becomes
a social and economic problem.
Those persons who are displaced be-
cause of highways, redevelopment and
other public improvement become the
responsibility of the Housing Commis-
sion; it is required to find "decent, safe
and sanitary" housing for all such peo-
ple. Roughly one-third of them go into
public housing.
One of the more interesting projects
Detroit is currently engaged in is the
Mack-Concord Conservation Project, the
first of its kind in the country. Some of
the land has already been cleared for a
four-acre park and a condemnation case
has been filed for 32 lots opposite an
industrial belt, which will be redevel-
oped as a parking facility by the indus-
tries themselves. Fifty-one other middle-
aged neighborhoods will benefit from
the experience gained through Mack-
Concord.
Another is the Central Business Dis-
trict Project No. 1, which is designed to
clean out Skid Row, replace it by light
industry suitable to the location and re-
locate the 1,400 single persons, mostly
men, living there. A third is the Medical
Center, an area including Grace, Harper,
Women's and Children's Hospitals. To
these will be added more hospital and
related medical buildings and housing
for medical personnel. This program was
begun in 1957 and will extend over a
ten-year period.
The Local Public Agency's first func-
tion is to collaborate with the federal
government; the second is to enlist the
support of the various city departments
"in an effort to replace the City's hope-
lessly blighted sections with new devel-
opment, to preserve what is worth pre-
serving, to provide for improvements in
an orderly fashion."

AND
RESEARCH
by CHARLES MASSER
The average student does not realize
how much basic research is carried on at
U-M. Almost every day the Technic
receives information on research projects
that are being studied by U-M faculty
members. In this issue will be found such
topics as the appointment of Professor
Henry J. Gomberg as the head of the
Phoenix project, development and use of
scientific principles for the design of
better protective helmets, and the arrival
of a three pole magnet that has started
research on how magnetism affects mag-
netic materials.
New Helmet Design
Has Better Protection
Racing drivers and football players,
and the drive-to-work motorist too, soon
may risk their skulls and brains less in
these activities. A medical faculty mem-
ber and an engineer at The University of
Michigan have devised scientific princi-
ples for the design of better protective
helmets. Prof. Wilfred T. Dempster
(Sc.D.) of the Department of Anatomy
and Prof. Samuel K. Clark (Ph.D.) of
the Department of Engineering Mechan-
ics recently completed a report on the
subject for a headgear manufacturer. They
believe there are certain underlying prin-
ciples that can be developed for the de-
sign of many such protective accessories,
and suspect that participants in other
risk activities such as motorcycling, fire
fighting, boxing, skiing and hockey could
benefit too.
In their search for scientific guides for
helmet design, Professor Dempster ex-
amined the human skull's strong and
weak points, and Professor Clark tackled
energy absorption and distribution prob-
lems. Skull fractures and closed head
injuries (such as concussion) were main
considerations for protection, but they
pointed out that the face should be pro-
tected too. The upper and lower jaws
are particularly vulnerable parts of the
head. As yet, a suitable face protection,
which doesn't restrict vision hasn't been
developed. They recommend each helmet
have a hard, impenetrable outer shell, an
impact-energy absorbing liner, and web-
bing to distribute the force of blows to
the strong points of the skull. Dempster
says the skulls strongest points are the
forehead on either side and the very
back.
Best for the helmet's outershell seems
to be a glass-reinforced plastic, while the
best liner material may be a slow rebound
plastic similar in consistency to a dry
kitchen sponge. "We are looking for a
liner with the best acceleration reducing
characteristics," Clark explained, "as well
as the best energy absorbing character-
istics." Increasing the time it takes—
even by as little as a small fraction of a
second—for an object striking the head
to impart its energy of motion to the
skull (thus "accelerating" the skull)
would considerably reduce the force of
impact reaching the brain and skull. A
slow rebound type of plastic would
"crush" under impact relatively slowly
and thus would reduce acceleration more
than a "springier" material. "These en-
ergy absorbing liners, unless designed
properly, can flaw an otherwise protec-
tive helmet. In the past, too little atten-
tion has been paid to the acceleration
reducing characteristics of liners."
Their recommendations may encourage
wider application of scientific principles
to the design of other types of protec-
tive clothing.
"The technique involved in this oper-
ation is applicable to any such situation—
within limits," Dempster says. "The work
is representative of what can be done in
other areas of protection."

Dick Ernsdorff studies a microwave site-layout chart atop a moun-
tain near Orting, in western Washington state. On assignments like
this, he often carries $25,000 worth of equipment with him.
Here, Dick checks line-of-sight with a distant repeater station by
mirror-flashing and confirms reception by portable radio. Using this
technique, reflections of the sun's rays can be seen as far as 50 miles.
He wears two kinds of work togs
For engineer Richard A. Ernsdorff, the "uniform of the
day" changes frequently. A Monday might find him in a
checkered wool shirt on a Washington or Idaho mountain
top. Wednesday could be a collar-and-tie day.
Dick is a transmission engineer with the Pacific Tele-
phone and Telegraph Company in Seattle, Washington. He
joined the company in June, 1956. after getting his B.S.E.E.
degree from Washington State University. '"I wanted to
work in Washington," he says, "with an established, grow-
ing company where I could find a variety of engineering op-
portunities and could use some imagination in my work."
Dick spent iy» years in rotational, on-the-job training,
doing power and equipment engineering and "learning the
business." Since April, 1959, he has worked with micro-
wave radio relay systems in the Washington-Idaho area.
When Dick breaks out his checkered shirt, he's headed
for the mountains. He makes field studies involving micro-
wave systems and SAGE radars and trouble-shoots any
problem that arises. He also engineers "radar remoting"
facilities which provide a vital communications link be-
tween radar sites and Air Force Operations.
A current assignment is a new 11,000 mc radio route
from central Washington into Canada, utilizing reflectors
on mountains and repeaters (amplifiers) in valleys. It's a
million-dollar-plus project.
"I don't know where an engineer could find more inter-
esting work," says Dick.

The field has never been broader
The challenge has never been greater
Engineers at Pratt &amp; Whitney Aircraft today are concerned
with the development of all forms of flight propulsion
systems—air breathing, rocket, nuclear and other advanced
types for propulsion in space. Many of these systems are so
entirely new in concept that their design and development,
and allied research programs, require technical personnel
not previously associated with the development of aircraft
engines. Where the company was once primarily interested
in graduates with degrees in mechanical and aeronautical
engineering, it now also requires men with degrees in
electrical, chemical, and nuclear engineering, and in physics,
chemistry, and metallurgy.
Included in a wide range of engineering activities open to
technically trained graduates at all levels are these four
basic fields:
ANALYTICAL ENGINEERING Men engaged in this
activity are concerned with fundamental investigations in
the fields of science or engineering related to the conception
of new products. They carry out detailed analyses of ad-
vanced flight and space systems and interpret results in
terms of practical design applications. They provide basic
information which is essential in determining the types of
systems that have development potential.
DESIGN ENGINEERING The prime requisite here is an
active interest in the application of aerodynamics, thermo-
dynamics, stress analysis, and principles of machine design
to the creation of new flight propulsion systems. Men en-
gaged in this activity at P&amp;WA establish the specific per-
formance and structural requirements of the new product
and design it as a complete working mechanism.
EXPERIMENTAL ENGINEERING Here men supervise
and coordinate fabrication, assembly and laboratory testing
of experimental apparatus, system components, and devel-
opment engines. They devise test rigs and laboratory setups,
specify instrumentation and direct execution of the actual
test programs. Responsibility in this phase of the develop-
ment program also includes analysis of test data, reporting
of results and recommendations for future effort.
MATERIALS ENGINEERING Men active in this field
at P&amp;WA investigate metals, alloys and other materials
under various environmental conditions to determine their
usefulness as applied to advanced flight propulsion systems.
They devise material testing methods and design special
test equipment. They are also responsible for the determina-
tion of new fabrication techniques and causes of failures or
manufacturing difficulties.

COMPLEX VARIABLES AND APPLICATIONS
New Second Edition
By RUEL V. CHURCHILL, University of Michigan
A thorough revision of a fine textbook for juniors, seniors, and graduate students in mathematics and
engineering who have completed one semester of advanced calculus. The book deals with the theory
of functions of a complex variable and its applications. The theory is noted for its elegance in logical
structure and powerful results.
The first aim of the book is to give a sound and straightforward presentation of theory through the
differential and integral calculus of analytic functions, residues, and conformal transformations and the con-
nections between analytic and harmonic functions. The second aim is to give a full introduction to some
of the important applications in applied mathematics, engineering, and physics, and to link these applica-
tions carefully to the theory.

MICHIGAN
New Three-Pole Magnet
Magnets with three poles are almost as
scarce as men on the moon. But not
quite. The University of Michigan has
one, believed to be unique. One of a
pair of magnets on campus is being used
for research for the armed services. It's
designed for basic research on how mag-
netism affects magnetic materials which
in turn affect microwaves (ultra-short
radio waves). The research is part of a
project undertaken by Associate Prof.
Dale M. Grimes (Ph.D.), of the Elec-
trical Engineering Department, under the
direction of the U-M Research Institute
(UMRI).
The three-pole magnet is being applied
particularly to lining up crystals of mag-
netic materials used as microwave cir-
cuit elements. (These are ceramic ma-
terials like those used in telephone equip-
ment, and in radio and television sets).
The crystals are really tiny magnets, but
the magnetic north-south axis of each is
not parallel to its crystalline axis. If the
crystals were compass needles, for ex-
ample, the crystalline axis would not line
EDUCATION AND RESEARCH
(Continued from page 28)
itself up north and south, but instead
would point somewhere between east and
west (in a vertical plane). The crystal-
line axis cannot therefore be lined up in
a normal magnetic field. The tri-polar
magnet gets around this "discrepancy" by
aligning the crystals in a single direc-
tion—straight up. It can do this because,
besides having an odd number of poles,
it rotates the poles at 120 cycles per sec-
ond. Thus, in effect, forces of both poles
are created all around the crystals so
there is only one direction of least resist-
ance for them to point in. That direction
is up. The three-pole magnet is about
the size of a ten-pound wheel of cheese,
about a foot and a half in diameter. It
was custom built in California for about
$800.
The second magnet, supplied with
funds from the Air Force and UMRI.
is not uncommon. It is much larger, and
looks like two solid black discs about
four feet in diameter which face each
other a foot or so apart. The poles are
twin silver-colored discs centered in the
larger discs. The purpose of this magnet,
Professor Grimes explains, is to form a
strong yet highly accurate and control-
lable magnetic field, also for research on
micro-waves and magnetic materials.
This magnet, he says, is equipped with a
voltage regulator that will hold the mag-
netic force accurate to one part to 10
million over a 10 per cent change in in-
put voltage. Its maximum power is about
18,000 gauss. (This means that the pull-
ing force between the pole faces is equal
to about four tons).
Three main uses for this magnet, ac-
cording to Professor Grimes, are:
1. To determine how microwaves be-
have in certain magnetic materials;
2. To measure the strength of pole-
seeking properties of oxygen-containing
magnetic ceramics at temperatures near
absolute zero; and,
3. To measure magnetic anisotropy—
or how much force it takes to turn the
polar axis within the crystals.
Professor Grimes expects to have these:
experiments well underway within six
months.

by TAMMY KIRK
Brazil will realize a 152-year-old
dream early this spring when her new
inland capital city is dedicated. Brasilia
is unique among cities in that it will be-
come the only major city to have been
built entirely according to a single mag-
nificent plan. Ultramodern in every re-
spect, Brasilia will be home to a half
million citizens as well as the govern-
ment of the largest South American re-
public.
All photos courtesy Miss Esther McCoy, Santa Monica, California


Modern architecture and engineering makes Brazilia both
beautiful and practical.
The Senate Building and the bowl-shaped House of
Representatives are located on the Plaza of
the Three Powers of Government.
m

mh
■
-
if?
1551!
riiiirrrrrrP

Designed by Brazilian architect Lucio
Costa, the initial plan for major arteries
and centers within the city consists of
two intersecting axes, one straight and
one curved, giving the appearance of a
giant bird in flight. At the head of the
bird is a triangular plaza at whose corners
lie the buildings housing the three
branches of government. Beyond these
buildings will rise other governmental
and commercial buildings. The curved
axis is to become a residential area. An
artificial lake has been created surround-
ing the new city on three sides.
Only a glimpse of these pictures
will convince one that this is to be one
of the truly outstanding cities of the
world. Both beautiful and functional,
Brasilia should serve as an inspiration
to men of all lands, for here is proof
that overgrowth and decay need not
doom the city. Here is a manifest exam-
ple of the exalted beauty in which man
may live, and through which he might
at last discover peace and dignity for his
own life and for his race.

This layout of Brazilia shows the great influence of the
air age through the close resemblance of the city
to an airplane.

Nosing its way down to earth, X-15's skin of a high-Nickel-containing alloy will glow with the dull cherry red of a tossed rivet.
Inco-developed alloy to help X-15
carry first man into space
Alloy perfected by Inco's continuing research program
will help new rocket plane withstand destructive heats
When the first manned rocket plane
streaks in from space, temperatures
may build up to as high as twelve
hundred degrees.
The ship's nose and leading edges
heat to a dull glowing red in seconds.
At this destructive temperature,
X-15's metal skin could weaken,
could peel off.
Aircraft research personnel found
the answer to this high-temperature
problem in one of a family of heat-
treatable nickel-chromium alloys
developed by Inco Research. It with-
stands even higher temperatures
than 1200°F!
Remember this dramatic example
if you're faced with a metal problem
in the future. It may have to do with
product design, or the way you make
it. In any event, there's a good chance
Inco Research may help you solve it
with a Nickel-containing alloy.
Over the years, Inco Research has
successfully solved a good many
metal problems, and has compiled a
wealth of information to help you.
You may be designing a machine
that requires a metal that resists
corrosion, or wear, or high tempera-
tures. Or one that meets some
destructive combination of condi-
tions. Inco Research can help supply
the answer. Help supply the right
metal, or the right technical data
from its files.
When you are in business, Inco
Nickel and Inco Research will be at
your service.

earth, accomplish their missions and return without disposing of parts of
themselves en route. This breakthrough depends on the rapid development
of both nuclear rocket engines and the space vehicles capable of using
them. Douglas is putting forth a major research effort in the area of manned
nuclear space ships. Every environmental, propulsion, guidance and struc-
tural problem is being thoroughly explored. Results are so promising that
even if the nuclear engine breakthrough comes within the next five years,
Douglas will be ready to produce the vehicles to utilize this tremendous new
source of space powerl Douglas is seeking qualified scientists and engineers
for this and other vital programs. Write to C.C. LaVene, Box 600-W, Douglas

DOUGLAS
MARCH, I960
37


of all motor-vehicle mileage is accumu-
lated on the 373,000 miles of streets
that are within city limits. All the vehic-
les registered since 1945 would stretch
more than 125,000 miles bumper to
bumper. In this same period the amount
of city-street mileage has increased by
only about 60,000."
Some recent events and pronounce-
ments by railroad officials and transpor-
tation experts have brought city officials
the specter of a day when commuter
trains might be forced to stop running.
The chaos of present traffic jams would
then pale by comparison.
To alleviate the situation somewhat,
the greatest public-works program in
modern history has begun. Under the
new Federal-Aid Highway Act, a 41,000
mile superhighway network that will
crisscross the U.S. will be built. The na-
tion will spend $100 billion on roads
in the next 10 years. About half of the
Federal-Aid Act money will be used to
build some 5,500 miles of high-capacity
urban expressway. Some officials feel that
new expressways will relieve downtown
congestion. It is difficult to believe, how-
ever, that enabling more cars to enter
the downtown area will relieve down-
town congestion.
Obviously, the measures so far taken
are mere stop-gaps. Some experts esti-
mate that some form of rapid transit is
needed by all metropolitan areas over
750,000 population, which means that
some 20 U.S. communities are, or should,
be in the market for modernized rapid
transit.
The most persistently proposed new
transit system, and thus far the most
radical, is monorail. One of the most
ambitious proposals put forth recently
came from Detroit's Rapid Transit Com-
mission. They recommended a 54-mile,
$250 million monorail system, with a
later 240-mile extension into the sub-
urbs. According to Architectural Forum
(January 1959), the reason is simple:
"monorail is lighter, faster; less obstruc-
tive of right of way, light, and air, and
cheaper (cost $4 to $5 million per mile),
than subways ($12 to $15 million per
mile), rails on expressway malls ($8
to $9 million per mile), or modern ele-
vated ($6 million per mile). With top
speeds of 80 mph and average trip speeds
of 30 to 40 mph, monorail would be 3
to 4 times faster, than Detroit's present
(Continued from page 19)
bus service, and up to twice as fast as
private automobiles. One rapid transit
track can move up to 40,000 people past
a given point in an hour, the equivalent
of 16 lanes of modern expressway."
Meanwhile developments in more con-
ventional commuter systems have not
been lacking though they are only slight-
ly more successful in sales than monorail.
Even subways are being planned. Archi-
tectural Forum (January, 1959), claims
that the program is going to be of
longer range than many planners realize:
". . . if rapid transit is to be
financially feasible and serve the
future, the cities are faced with
the problem of building new transit
systems, specialized for really rapid
service, from the ground up, a situ-
ation hardly met within a half a
century."
Yet these are far from being solutions
to the crisis. Recently many job oppor-
tunities have been occurring at the fringes
of the metropolitan area and in the sub-
urbs. Mass transit would seem to be an
in adquate solution for the present home-
to-work pattern of traffic. The commuter
railroad was perfect for traffic between
low-density housing and high-density
working areas. The subway has been
adequate for high-density to high-density
movements within the city. However,
efficient mass transit for low-density to
low-density movement is impossible.
Imaginative Redevelopment
This brings us back to the automobile
as the cheapest and most rational way to
circulate people in and around tomor-
row's low-density metropolis. But our
cities need not become as fragmented as
Los Angeles; the core can be preserved
by intelligent, imaginative redevelop-
ment.
One fact must be faced. No matter
how numerous the expressways, parking
space must be provided for cars entering
the metropolitan area. Statistics point
toward more cars arriving in areas where
parking is insufficient even at the present
time. This might prompt some thought
about pedestrian malls to replace certain
congested areas as in the Gruen plan for
Fort Worth. Few realize that Gruen's
proposal is based on the assumption that
half of the people traveling to the center
of town will travel by rapid public tran-
sit. Thus we are still in need of a re-
vival of mass transit.
Similarly, the proposed building of
double-level streets and parking garages
will only add to the congrestion. What
is needed is to convince people not to
bring their cars. The answer to this, of
course, is mass transit.
Thus a realistic approach to the prob-
lem of future transportation needs must
be one in which rapid transport is seen
as inevitable. The car will no doubt be
used more and more, but an effort must
be made to avoid monstrous "auto-cities",
grotesque nightmares which have no
human scale. If this major problem is
to be solved a new and dynamic balance
must be struck between rapid transit,
automobile and pedestrian traffic.
