RCA SERVES
YOU THROUGH
ELECTRONICS

One of the sharpest photos ever taken of
sun's surface. It, and hundreds of others
taken by stratoscope, may answer mystery
of violent magnetic disturbances on earth.
Exact position of photograph in relation
to the total sun surface is shown here. Plotting
and photography of precise areas was made
possible by airborne RCA television.
RCA REPORTS TO THE NATION:
Going up for "good seeing." Un-
manned balloon-observatory starts its
ascent to take sunspot photos. "Project
Stratoscope" is a continuing program
of the Office of Naval Research and
the National Science Foundation.
REMARKABLE NEW PHOTOS UNLOCK
MYSTERIES OF SUN'S SURFACE
Special RCA Television, operating from stratosphere,
helps get sharpest photos of sun's surface ever taken
Scientists recently took the first,
sharp, searching look into the center of
our solar system. It was achieved not
by a missile, but by a balloon posted
in quiet reaches of the stratosphere.
The idea was conceived by astrono-
mers at the Princeton University Ob-
servatory. They decided that a floating
observatory — equipped with a tele-
scope-camera— would offer a stable
"work platform" from which sunspots
could be photographed free of the distor-
tion caused by the earth's atmosphere.
But "Project Stratoscope" encoun-
tered an unforeseen and major obstacle
on its initial flight. A foolproof method
was needed for aiming and focusing
the telescope of the unmanned observ-
atory. Princeton asked RCA to help.
A special RCA television system was
devised which enabled observers on the
ground to view exactly what the tele-
scope was seeing aloft. This accom-
plished, it was a simple matter to
achieve precise photography—directed
from the ground by means of a separate
RCA radio control system.
The resulting pictures reveal sun-
spot activities in unprecedented detail.
They provide the world with important
information regarding the magnetic
disturbances which affect navigation
and long-range communications.
The success of "Project Stratoscope"
is another example of RCA leadership
in advanced electronics. This leader-
ship, achieved through quality and
dependability in performance, has al-
ready made RCA Victor the most trusted
name in television. Today, RCA Victor
television sets are in far more homes
than any other make.

would then have as much as the other
two sons. But if he had given it to the
second son, he would then have twice

had given it to the youngest son, he
would have three times as much as the
other two. Now, if the man left a total
of SI800, can you calculate how much
each son and the hospital received as
their share?

A fellow was pretty sick and the
doctor ordered him to take a long vaca-
tion in Arizona. He went there and at
the end of two months he died.
They brought the corpse back and
his wife and her brothers were review-
ing the remains.
She said: "Oh, Joe, doesn't he look
nice.
And Joe replied: "He sure does.
Those two months in Arizona certainly
did him a lot of good."

A fraternity man promised his girl
he would cut down on his drinking.
About to call for his femme on a date
he found himself a bit looped.
"I'll sit down in the living room and
read," he thought. "Whoever heard of a
drunk reading a book?"
His date came down the stairs and
heard a noise from the living room.
"What in the world are you trying to
do?" she asked.
"Just reading, sweetie," he replied
happily.
"You drunken bum!" she yelled, as
she looked into the room. "Close that
suitcase and get out of here!"
During mock maneuvers an army com-
mander ordered a notice to be displayed
on a bridge stating: "This bridge has
been destroyed by air attack." But to his
chagrin, he noticed through his field
glasses that a foot regiment was crossing
the bridge despite his orders. He sent his
adjutant to the officer in charge post-
haste to find out how he dared to defy
his orders. An hour later the adjutant
was back. "It's all right, sir," he re-
ported. "The troops are wearing signs
saying 'We are swimming'."

A chef discovered that he had sent
spiked watermelon to a minister's con-
vention when it was due to go to a
salesman's convention. He sent a waiter
to correct the situation if the ministers
had not eaten the watermelon. The
waiter returned to tell the chef that he
was too late.
"How did the ministers like the water-
melon?" asked the chef.
"I don't know how well they liked it,
but when I went in they were putting
the seeds in their pockets," replied the
waiter.

Two duck hunters were sitting behind
their blind, one drinking from a thermos
bottle of coffee, the other from a jug
of whiskey. After some hours of sip-
ping they spotted a lone duck winging
through the sky. Taking quick aim, the
coffee drinker rose, let fire, and missed.
The whiskey drinker rose, let fire, and
brought the duck down. His companion,
properly amazed, complimented him on
the shot. He replied, "Aw, it's nothing.
I usually get five or six out of a flock
like that." * * ,

1 of 5 divisions at
Vought where the
young engineer
can move ahead!

For the young engineer or scientist with a creative
bent, few places offer both the challenge and the
professional satisfaction to be found in Vought
Electronics, a division of Chance Vought Aircraft,
Incorporated. Here, the emphasis is on imagination.
Under the guidance and supervision of some of the
top men in their fields, the young engineer is given
an opportunity to explore the full range of his creative
capability. Whatever your specialty or interest in the
electronics field, there is likely a place for your
training and talents in one of the varied programs
at Vought Electronics.
TYPICAL PROGRAMS
Typical programs in this division include the design,
development and production of ground support elec-
tronics systems, missile servo-actuators, advanced
antennas, and support electronics for navigation and
inertial guidance systems.
GSE equipment now under development ranges
from pre-flight test sets for piloted aircraft to complete
missile testing and launching complexes. Systems for
which the division is providing support equipment
include: radar guidance, flight stabilization, warhead
arming and fuzing, missile jet and rocket engines,
and telemetering.
Missile servo-actuators and power controls include
the design and development of all servo-actuators for
all three stages of the Minuteman ICBM and the
servo-actuator for the Saturn booster rocket.
Work on advanced antenna systems includes the
study and design of Retarded Surface Wave antennas
and high Mach-number antennas as well as conven-
tional antenna systems for both airborne and sur-
face application.
New navigation and guidance equipment and tech-
niques are taking shape under the direction of scien-
tSTfCUJICS ELCTOCS

tists and engineers of this division. Projects include
the development and production of guidance and
aiming systems for field missiles and drone aircraft,
and a study contract for the design of a twin-gyro
control system for satellite application.
In addition, this division is supporting other Vought
divisions in the development of new methods and
devices for submarine detection and defense.
OPPORTUNITIES IN OTHER DIVISIONS
Programs and projects offer opportunity in other
Vought divisions as well:
Vought Aeronautics, designer and producer of four
versions of the Navy's F8U Crusader, is now research-
ing on an Air Force study contract a Supersonic Low
Altitude Missile (SLAM), to be equipped with a
nuclear engine as well as a nuclear warhead. Other
work in this division includes the development of
new devices and techniques in antisubmarine war-
fare. Vought Astronautics, supplier of NASA's Scout
research rockets, has designed a simulator to dupli-
cate more than a dozen stresses of space and is
currently at work in advanced study of the human
factors of space flight. The Range Systems Division
is tracking NASA satellites, in addition to other
Pacific Missile Range duties. The Research Division
is planning a new, integrated research center to be
devoted to basic research.

native arteries were built—other cities
could reroute traffic with no loss of
flow or inconvenience. We were ac-
tually able to reroute traffic from our
main shopping street to two parallel
streets and gained better traffic flow.
"What has been the result of our Mall?
1) Pedestrian traffic on the 3 block mall
area has increased 30% according to
police department estimates and sam-
ple traffic counts;
2) downtown parking lot patronage has
increased approximately 10% over
the same period last year;
3) cars stay slightly longer in parking
lots than previously;
4) sample surveys indicate a 7 to 10%
increase in number of out-of-town
customers using downtown store
charge accounts;
5) rental rates have increased in some
sectors of downtown, especially near
or on the mall;
6) the number of vacant first floor stores
in the heart of downtown has de-
creased from 8 to 3;
7) surveys indicate some other interest-
ing factors—people tend to walk
more slowly on the mall than on ad-
jacent and similar streets and 37%
of the people walking on the mal!
will cross from one side to the other
at least once while going one block;
8) fourteen of the 40 stores on the mall
have done some remodeling of their
store fronts, two others have done
extensive remodeling and 3 more are
planning extensive remodeling. All
but one of these stores attribute their
decision to remodel primarily to the
development of the mall;
9) chain store real estate offices now
maintain that the previous 100%
location (on east side of street) now
applies to both sides of the mall;
10) our compilation of changes in gross
sales for all the downtown stores
show that for the 5 months since the

The Burdick Mall features flowers, pools, and a children's playground.
mall was completed, downtown sales
have increased 12.5% over the last
year, yet retail sales for the county
have increased only 5%. (Only one-
store on the mall showed a decrease
and only 5% in the entire down-
town.) Stores both on and off the mall
have increased more, on the average,
than the county average. On the mall
stores showed a somewhat higher in-
crease, however. This increase is
also significant because the last quar-
ter of 1958 was a very good year for
the Kalamazoo area retailwise—the
recession was apparently over here
by June of that year. December 1958
was, for example, a record month in
many respects.
11) In addition, we have upwards of
$30,000,000 in new office and retail
buildings in preliminary stages of
planning. One is an 18 story office
building with retail space on the
first floors."
Plan for 1980
By 1980 downtown Kalamazoo will be
unrecognizable. All private motor vehicles
will be banished to the peripheral ex-
pressways. Vast new parking areas will
sprout from the stumps of ancient fac-
tories and warehouses. The architecture
will have the look of science fiction
about it. Such a plan is so fabulous that
it seems fantastic, but then we have con-
crete proof of Kalamazoo's sincerity and
determination in the present mall.
What sort of a city is Kalamazoo,
that it boasts the nation's first perma-
nent (Toledo had a temporary mall)
installation of this type? Well, with
three colleges (Western Michigan Uni-
versity, Kalamazoo, Nazareth), substan-
tial industrial development (Upjohn,
several large paper mills, Shakespeare)
the city has a healthy economic base,
supported by a highly productive hin-
terland and a relatively large trading area.
Kalamazoo, in revitalizing its downtown,
was not striking back at suburban shop-
ping centers, but at loss of trade to
Grand Rapids, Battle Creek, and South
Bend. A pre-mall inquiry revealed that
500 Kalamazoo families had charge ac-
counts at a single large Grand Rapids
department store.
In a recent month (October 1959)
Kalamazoo posted the following eco-
nomic statistics: bank clearings, $200,-
000,000; postal receipts, 5200,000;
KWH consumption, 33,000,000; non-
farm labor force 63,000; 1,100 unem-
ployed; consumer price index, 125.5;
county retail sales, $21,000,000; railroad
freight carloads, 3,200 in, 1,400 out.
However, the most unusual Kalama-
zoo fact is not a statistic, nor is it history.
It is the remarkable future that this re-
markable city is forging for itself.

HE GETS COMPUTERS TO
DIAGNOSE THEIR OWN FAULTS
With the increasing size and complexity of modern computers, one
of the most interesting problems that engineers face is the rapid
and efficient location of failures within the system.
The method which they have found most practical is to use the
speed and logical abilities of the computer itself to make the
diagnosis. Programming computers to perform this function is the
job of Robert M. King.
The Diagnostic Technique
He prepares programs for the computer which actually simulate
the deductive processes of a man investigating the faults of the
machine. Each program instructs the computer to exercise various
segments of its circuitry in a logical order.
The result of each test is checked against the correct result, stored
in the computer memory, of previous tests of the same circuitry
when in proper working order. If the results do not agree, a mes-
sage is automatically typed which indicates the failure and which
component caused it.
A computer is particularly adept at this job. It can take into con-
sideration simultaneously a large number of factors. It can also
work at very high speeds. Once a program is properly written, the
computer makes no errors. Appropriately enough, diagnostic pro-
gramming often aids in designing better computers.
A Programmer's Background
Computer programs are the result of ingenious applications of
many intellectual qualities. Computer design and language are
based on sound laws of logic. Therefore an important prerequisite
is the ability to analyze complex problems and to deduce from them
useful methods of solution consistent with machine requirements.
If you think you might be interested in working in one of the many
fascinating areas of computer programming, you are invited to
talk it over with an IBM representative. The future can be as un-
limited as the future of the computer itself.

(Continued from page 2})
20,000, the value of the house to be
built on the land will jump from $17,500
to $27,500. The result of this procedure
is to decrease the gap between new ex-
penses and new taxes. Before, we men-
tioned that subdividing 100 acres at four
houses per acre resulted in $175,000 of
expenses and $80,000 in taxes. By up-
zoning the land so that only one house
per acre can be built, the result is $28,000
in new taxes but only $44,000 in ex-
penses. This can make a big difference
in a growing community's pocketbook.
A second plan used by some commu-
nities is to increase building-permit fees
to a high enough level to pay most of
the extra costs. However, this method
seems to be of dubious value, both
legally and financially. For example, the
Michigan Supreme Court recently tossed
out a building permit fee increase from
$26 to $91.50 by St. Clair Shores.
A third idea that has been tried is to
force the developers to set aside land
in the development for parks, schools
and other public areas. Most of the de-
velopers are against this plan and feel
they should be fairly compensated for
the land. The developers already provide
curbs, streets, water mains, etc., and
will almost certainly take the "land do-
nation" issue to court.
Admittedly these three methods of at-
tack are generally of dubious value and
are put into effect with little thought
or planning. Probably they would slow
up any urban blight but, in the long
run, they might make the mess-opolis
worse.
What then do we have to look for-
ward to? With a massive population
growth now in process, the answer is
almost certain to be an unhappy one,
unless some concentrated thought and
planning is done. Already we can see the
forerunners of what is to come in the
New York-Philadelphia area, the Balti-
more-Washington area, and mess-opolis
in its most advanced state, the Ios An-
geles area. And this is just the start. The
worst is yet to come. The situation de-
mands ACTION, not by the city planners
alone, but by citizens from all wdks of
life as well.
What action should be taken? It
seems that three important areas need
urgent consideration. The first is a re-
evaluation of metropolitan goveinment
with the aim of establishing super-gov-
ernments or at least super-agencies or
authorities to handle area-wide problems,
including overall planning. The second
is serious consideration of Whyte's "open-
spaces" proposal, which is discussed be-
low. The third is the assuming of an
active role in this realm by professional,
political and service organizations as well
as by individuals.
As far as super-governments are con-
cerned, we are not likely to go too far
in this direction. Most people feel they
can "reach and control" local government
Barry Peebles, a graduate of
Blissfield (Michigan) High School,
is the editor-in-chief of the Tech-
nic. He assumed the duties of this
office after serving as associate
editor and articles editor. A senior
in Industrial Engineering, he plans
to do graduate work in Business
Administration and eventually get
into management consultant work.
During his four years at the
University he served as vice-presi-
dent of the Executive Board of
the Class of I960 in his sophomore
year and President of the board in
his junior and senior years.

and don't want it removed from their
reach. On the other hand, people in
general seem willing to accept regional
government for such things as flood con-
trol, traffic systems, sewage systems, and
smog control. For this reason it seems
that any trend toward regional authoiity
will be in the area of special-purpose
agencies.
Several times William Whyte's "open
space" proposal has been mentioned but
never really defined. As discussed before,
it is his feelings that we have plenty of
land if we intelligently plan its use so
that the "urban sprawl" effect is mini-
mized and the original natural beauty
is maintained. He cites as an example,
maintaining a stream and its valley as the
logical centerpiece of an area, while still
allowing developments on the fringes
and in the surrounding hills—a plan
beneficial to farmers, conservation and
watershed groups, and even the devel-
opers.
Of course, the big problem is how to
keep, the open-space area from being de-
veloped. Whyte suggests the use of a
nearly-forgotten legal tool—the easement.
Seldom used in the East, the easement-
buying rights to a property—is gaining
wide acceptance on the West Coast. For
instance, in the example of the valley
mentioned, the neighboring owners might
buy up the rights to subdivide the valley
and thus prevent an eyesore development
or an industrial invasion. The easement
means that the valley property owner is
free to sell or do as he pleases with the
land, except that he and subsequent own-
ers will not be able to subdivide the
land into a development.
Whyte points out that careful plan-
ning by both professional groups and by
lay people can result in maintaining the
countryside and still provide room for
suburbs without giving them a crowded,
helter-skelter look.
This group of suggestions—govern-
mental re-evaluation, the open-space
plan, and widespread thought, is not in-
tended to be complete nor is it certain
to be the best way of attacking the prob-
lem. Nevertheless, the fact remains that
the events of today are shaping the results
of tomorrow. Similarly, the action and
planning that we, the people, take today
will largely determine if suburbia is to
be a blessing .... or a blight.

Imagine that 100 people pass Hans
walking North at 4 miles an hour, and
100 pass him walking South at 4 miles
an hour.
Then Renzi, if driving North at 4
miles an hour, wouldn't pass any walk-
ing North at the same rate, but he would
pass 200 walking South! or the same
number in all. What he said was wrong.
Egbert, if driving North at 8 miles
an hour, would pass 100 people walk-
ing North and 300 walking South. Hence
he'd pass 400 in all. His statement was
right.
Pedro, driving North at 12 miles an
hour, would pass 200 walking North
and 400 walking South. That is, 600 in
all, or 50 % more than Egbert. What
he said was wrong, but he has the right
idea.

The answer to this teaser involves the
use of two equations with three un-
knowns. The student therefore must
guess one of the unknowns.
Let A equal the number of clubs to
be bought.
Let B equal the number of club covers
to be bought.
Let C equal the number of golf balls
to be bought.
Two equations are found to be:
A plus B plus C = 100
10A plus 3B plus l/2C = 100
Now you can buy 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5 golf
clubs, since you must buy at least one
and buying six would not give you
enough money to buy up to 100 pieces
of equipment. Substituting these values
into the equations and solving them for
the covers and balls, only gives you an
answer which is in whole numbers for
the cover and balls. Therefore you should
buy 5 clubs, 1 cover, and 94 balls.

three into the eight and pour the two in
the five into the three. Now fill the five
out of the eight, then from five fill the
three, which requires one, leaving four
in the five. Then empty the three into
the eight.

Take advantage of the
MECHANICAL
ADVANTAGE
The screw is a combination of two
mechanical principles: the lever,
and the inclined plane in helical
form. The leverage applied to the
nut combines with motion of the nut
around the bolt to exert tremendous
clamping force between the two.
One of the greatest design errors
today, in fact, is failure to realize
the mechanical advantages that
exist in standard nuts and bolts.
Smaller diameters and less costly
grades of fasteners tightened to
their full capacity will create far
stronger joints than those utilizing
bigger and stronger fasteners tight-
ened to only a fraction of their
capacity. Last year, one of our engi-
neers showed a manufacturer how
he could save $97,000 a year simply
by using all the mechanical advan-
tages of a less expensive grade.
When you graduate, make sure
you consider the mechanical advan-
tages that RB&amp;W fasteners provide.
And make sure, too, that you con-
sider the career advantages RB&amp;W
offers mechanical engineers—in the
design, manufacture and application
of mechanical fasteners. If you're
interested in machine design—or
sales engineering, write us for more
information.

"What's the matter, miss?" he inquir-
ed. "Ain't we got colors you like?"

the terminals and pull the switch. If the
motor runs, we take our readings. If it
smokes, we sneak it back and get another
one."

I AM AN ENGINEER. In my profession I take pride, but without vain-
glory; to it I owe solemn obligations that I am eager to fulfill.
As an Engineer, I will participate in none but honest enterprise. To
him that has engaged my services, as employer or client, I will give the ut-
most of performance and fidelity.
When needed, my skill and knowledge shall be given without reser-
vation for the public good. From special capacity springs the obligation to
use it well in the service of humanity; and I accept the challenge that this
implies.
Jealous of the high repute of my calling, I will strive to protect the
interests and the good name of any engineer that I know to be deserving;
but I will not shrink, should duty dictate from disclosing the truth regard-
ing anyone that, by unscrupulous act, has shown himself worthy of the
profession.
Since the Age of Stone, human progress has been conditioned by the
genius of my profesional forbears. By them have been rendered usable to
mankind Nature's vast resources of material and energy. By them have
been visualized and turned to practical account the principles of science and
the revelations of technology. Except for this heritage of accumulated ex-
perience, my efforts would be feeble. I dedicate myself to the dissemina-
tion of engineering profession in all its arts and traditions.
To my fellows I pledge, in the same full measure I ask of them, in-
tegrity and fair dealing, tolerance, and respect, and devotion to the stan-
dards and the dignity of our profession; with the consciousness, always,
that our special expertness carries with it the obligation to serve humanity
with complete sincerity.
Published by Engineers' Council for Professional Development
29 West 39th Street, New York 18, N. Y.

HONORARIES: An
Each spring not long after the species Collegium StuAtnth
and other forms of wildlife return to the Northland from a Florida
sojourn, campus life is momentarily disrupted as red-faced, black-
gowned, or tree-bearing bands of students come forth from their
inner sanctums on moonless nights to pull quivering, half-dad
undergrads from their beds. Thus with ringing bells, secret chants,
and symbolic campfires the tapping of new members for the
activity honoraries is in full swing.
One or two days later the Diag erupts with more red bodies,
dunce-capped heads, or soot and grease-covered bodies, all proclaim-
in no uncertain words their allegiance to this or that and the fact
that they can drink forty beers. Then with honor fully bestowed
upon their humble souls the neophytes, now full grown blood
bothers, retire to the secret chambers and once again quiet returns
to the campus.
And so it has been since 1904 or some other year long, long
ago.
Quite likely, this year will be no different. The next several
weeks should see this annual spring rite come and go as it has
down through the ages. But as underclassmen wait hopefully and
upperclassmen look forward to their revenge it might be beneficial
to pause briefly to consider the activity honoraries and ask a few
questions that probably haven't been asked for a good many years.
First of all, why should we have activity honoraries? Are they
desirable? Necessary? It seems impossible to deny that honoraries
have become a part of our campus culture and, baring something
unforseen, are here to stay. Yet, one wonders at times why they
were started and for what purpose. The logical answer to this
seems to be "to honor those students who have excelled in extra-
curricular activities." Similarly, the scholastic honoraries honor
those students who have excelled academically.
There can be little argument with the idea of honoring those
who excel in a particular area. In fact, much of our society is
based on this idea of reward and honor for our achievements. Grant-
ing this, it will probably be generally agreed that the activity hon-
oraries are desirable and do fulfill an objective but there may be
some doubt whether or not they are necessary. They certainly aren't
necessary for the functioning of the University nor would the
activities themselves cease to flourish without the honoraries. The
"necessity" of these groups seems to be put in further doubt if
there only purpose is to perpetuate themselves.
This fact leads us to a second question—should honoraries
have any purpose other than the self perpetuation of the organ-
ization? Do they, as a group of student leaders, have any obli-
gation to the University and the College? Some honoraries con-
stitutions state that they do, others allude to this idea? But how
many of these groups ever show any interest outside of the "inner
circle" (except to make money)? Of course, there are instances
of sincere interest and service but they are few and far between. It
seems that the honoraries, as the "chosen few" do have an obligation
of service to their college (and the student body) and that they
should have some purpose other than just to perpetuate themselves.
Without some more basic purpose than self-glorification of the
10
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


members the whole idea seems too much like a childish waste of
time.
Finally, it might be asked if the traditional tapping and
initiation ceremonies are a fitting method for a college-educated
professional group of men to honor their successors? Certainly
it will be agreed that the various ceremonies are traditional and
have become an intergal part of some groups but one wonders some-
times just how much honor is added by these ceremonies? Are
they really consistent with the behavior and attitudes of college
seniors?
In the preceding paragraphs a number of questions have been
asked, some of which may appear to be anti-honorary. This is not
the intent—they are not anti-honorary. It is hoped, however, that
the)- will provoke some serious thinking among students, faculty,
and among the honoraries themselves about the honoraries: their
purpose, their reason for existance, and the role they should play on
our campus in the mid-twentieth century.
—B. L. P.
&lt;)nk Spots
Once again this spring the SGC election turnout hit a new
low for the umpteenth time. We wonder how much longer this must
go on before the people connected with "Stu G" realize that this
is a direct reflection of student dissatisfaction with the results of
SGC's efforts in the last couple of years. Most people agree with
the concept of a student government but it seems that few agree that
SGC is a good implementation of this concept. We've urged before,
and we will again, that engineers and engineering organizations
take an active hand in making student government a useful and
worthwhile organization.
* * *
Congratulations are in order to several people for election or
appointment to positions in campus activities, including Roger
Barnes who was recently elected President of the Senior Class for
the coming year. Rog has been President of the Engineering Council
during the present semester.
Also deserving of credit is Tom Dejonghe for making the Arch
an up-and-coming publication. Tom took over as Editor after the
Arch had been "defunct" for a semester and, along with an ener-
getic staff, has made it into a worthwhile paper.
* * *
Don't forget to be on the lookout for Engineers Weekend on
May 13-15. All indications point to a fine and rewarding schedule
of events and group of exhibits.
* * *
We wonder how many of the engineering groups and societies
have been having trouble getting announcements and news items
in the Daily lately. At least two groups we know have been getting
the cold shoulder while almost identical items from Lit school
groups have been published. It seems like it's about time for the
engineering groups to voice, in no uncertain terms, our dissatis-
faction with this "discrimination."

METALS
New hairlike metal crystals are showing re-
searchers how to extract maximum strength
from metal structues. One result could be inter-
planetary vehicles whose weight is reduced by
eighty per cent.
By PAUL M. DOUGLAS
This electron micrograph shows
the microstructure of martensite,
the chief constituent of quenched
steel. The magnification is 15,000.
Photo courtesy of American Society for
Testing Materials and the General
Motors Corp.
Metallurgists are continually striv-
ing to achieve the highest possible
strength in metallic structural materials.
The usual approach, of course, has been
the experimentation with alloys and pro-
cessing methods. The newest approach,
however, has excited considerable in-
terest because it deals with the atomic
cohesion within a pure metal.
Experimentation on atomic cohesion
in metals is focused today on tiny, single
crystal filaments called whiskers. It is
within these hair-like strands of metal
that atomic cohesion has been found to
be nearly perfect, that is, nearly as strong
as has been theoretically calculated. So
enthusiastic are researchers about whis-
kers that they are predicting the utili-
zation of whisker composites for struc-
tural purposes (sheeting, cables, etc.)
with possible reductions in weight to
one-fifth of that found in today's modern
designs. One can readily see the advan-
tage of their inclusion in aircraft and
missiles.
But why is atomic cohesion the key
to great strength? This can best be
answered by a look at the atomic struc-
ture of metals, called a lattice. Referring
to the diagram of a crystal lattice, picture
an atom at every line intersection. The
lattice then is seen to be a three dimen-
sional stacking of cubes (or cells) in this
most simple structure of metal. Obvious-
ly these cubes must be held together to
form the metal. This is what atomic co-
hesion is—the bonding force between
atoms within a cell, and cells within a
lattice.
In the usual forms of metal (beams,
sheets, etc.,) this bonding force between
atom-cell-lattice is imperfect. This faulty
bonding, and thus weakness in the entire
metal structure, is a result of lattice
imperfections such as missing atoms, de-
formed lattices due to crystal crowding
during solidification, or dislocations—
more atoms in one row than in the ad-
joining row.
Due to their methods of growth or
formation, whiskers, on the other hand,
have lattice structures which are nearly
perfect, permitting the full value of
atomic cohesion to be realized. This re-
sulting strength can be one thousand
times that found in ordinary metals.
That whiskers are single crystals elim-
inates the crowding and subsequent
deformation of their lattice. The single
crystal structure of whiskers can be
shown by x-ray inspection as well as by
the fact that the electrical conductivity
in most cases equals that found in single
crystals of ordinary metal structures. To
demonstrate the size of these tiny metal
hairs, a sapphire whisker might meas-
ure one to three millimeters in length
and from three to fifty microns in
APRIL, I960
13


When the crystal lattice is imperfect, there is weakness in the entire metal
structure. Here the imperfection is due to missing atoms.
width.4 (Consider the period at the end
of this sentence to be about one thousand
microns in diameter.)
With this general idea of just what a
whisker is, and why it is comparatively
stronger than metals of other forms, let
us study their mechanical formation. Let
us begin by assuming we have just one
of the cells (cubes) of a future lattice.
Due to their growth from a vapor, the
new cells which will pile up to form
the crystals, can align themselves with-
out interference from solid material.
Now, like anything else which is easier
to do because it is already partly done,
these new cells will form where there
might already be part of a cell. And if
the one cell we are starting with has a
slight dislocation, this will provide an
excellent position for the new cell to
grow. Let us also assume that as these
cells add on to the original cell, they
more greatly correct the dislocation the
farther from it they grow. As new cells
continue to build where dislocations are
more predominant, the resulting struc-
ture will surround the original disloca-
tion, spiraling upward from the first
layer of cells. This causes a spiraling
growth at the whisker tip around one
screw dislocation (called screw probably
because of the resulting spiral, or screw-
ing growth). This type of growth elim-
inates the weakening edge dislocations
found in ordinary crystals.
Turning now to the chemistry of their
production we find that whiskers of var-
ious metals, silicon, and germanium, are
grown from their own vapor by chemical
reactions which occur, at least partially,
in the vapor phase. A foreign gas is also
usually introduced into the reactions. Let
us consider the growth of sapphire
whiskers: small amounts of aluminum
are heated to 1300-1450 C, in a stream
of hydrogen for from two to twenty-four
hours, and the formation of relatively
large, downy deposits of transparent and
translucent crystals surrounding the
charge for about 2 cm. is observed. These
crystals, needle-like in appearance, are
sapphire whiskers. This reaction is es-
sentially an oxidation of aluminum, in-
volving the volatile molecule Aeo. The
stability of their chemical composition
was proven when the tip of one of these
crystals was melted with the electron
beam under the electron microscope. The
melted A1203 resolidified to a single
crystal. The crystallographic orientation
differed from that of the needle, how-
ever, due to the difference in formation,
or growth.1 Zinc and cadmium, plus
other metal whiskers, are grown from a
controlled supersaturation of the vapors
of these metals or their compounds in
the presence of a foreign gas. This is the
precipitation or vapor deposition meth-
od.3 Silver, iron, and copper whiskers
have been grown by electrolytic deposi-
tion from molten salt solutions of these
metals. The chemical reduction of metal
halides, chlorides, iodides, and bromides,
by means of the passage of hydrogen or
some other reducing agent such as zinc,
will also result in filamentary whisker
growth. A third method has been ob-
served: Some metals when subject to
extremely high stress will produce whis-
kers from their base, i.e., from the bulk
of the metal. This phenomenon was first
observed in tin, cadmium, zinc, and other
soft metals. A fourth possibility, though
not in use yet, is the hot drawing of fila-
ments from their liquid phase. Consid-
erable strength has been obtained in some
materials, such as fibers of glass com-
pounds, by this method.1
Strength in small crystals was rec-
ognized in the nineteenth century, but
not until the past decade has this strength
been observed to go up steeply as crystal
sizes were reduced to less than .0001
inches. (The probability of forming more
perfect crystals probably increases tre-
mendously with further reductions in
size.) Within the last three years whisk-
ers have been tested at levels near the
atomic cohesion strength.1 To gain an
idea of this progress, the following dia-
gram is presented:
The postulated theory that whiskers
have only screw dislocations along their
longitudinal axis, and almost no edge
faults, together with the restraining
forces on the crystal surfaces due to the
low incidence of edge dislocations, gives
rise to a method of predicting the
strength of whiskers. The method in-
volves the reflection of light from the
crystal surfaces. If this is irregular
it indicates the occurence of surface
fractures, thus reduucing the whisker's
strength. A prediction of strength can,
of course, be made from observing a uni-
form surface reflection of light. The
sapphire crystals mentioned earlier re-
tained their smooth appearance even
under great magnification, indicating
their capacity to withstand tremendous
tensile stresses. Of course, any condition
on the surface of the crystal, such as
pits, overgrowth, and whisker branches,
products of corrosion, or grain boun-
daries, if they should occur, would
greatly influence the whisker's strength.2
It should also be mentioned here that
the length of a whisker will affect its
strength. The smaller the whisker, the
greater will be its tensile strength some-
times by as much as a factor of four.
Before entering into some examples
of whisker strength, we should realize
14
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


field. Strength is defined as the maximum
stress the whisker sustained before frac-
ture occurred. Let us also examine the
method of comparing the strength of
whiskers to that of present structural
materials. This is usually done by taking
the ratio of the value of stress to the
value of the material's modulus of elas-
ticity. As an example, consider iron and
its present breaking strength, taken to
be around 60,000 psi. Its modulus is
30,000,000 psi. The above ratio becomes
1/500. Taking the same ratio, with re-
spect to an iron whisker having a tensile
strength of 1,900,000 psi, we have a
fraction of about 1/15, obviously depict-
ing a much higher strength.
Various theoretical calculations of the
upper strength limit of perfect materials
utilizing full atomic cohesion yield an
ultimate tensile stress anywhere from
1/10 to 1/40 of the modulus of elas-
ticity, depending upon the material in
question.
The following chart of some of the
strongest whiskers that have been ex-
perimentally tested includes this ratio of
stress to modulus, showing the degree of
strength to which these crystals have been
perfected.

(reference 1, p. 595)
In the above chart, it has been shown
that the strongest iron, copper, and silver
whiskers have exhibited tensile strengths
which are either close to or above the
lower estimate of the strength of perfect
crystals. This stress-strain behavior is
taken as a sign that the theoretical
strength of perfect whiskers has been
closely approached.
Other tests have shown a strength in
NaCl whiskers of 110 Kg/mm2, and a
silicone strength of 390 Kg/mm2, which
approximate the above table value.2 Re-
search is also being done at the National
Carbon Research Laboratories in Parma,
Ohio. Here a graphite whisker has been
stressed to 40,000 psi, by means of a
copper bead electroplated onto the whis-
ker. Other graphite whiskers have sus-
tained stresses of up to 500,000 psi.
These filamentary crystals had cross-sec-
tional dimensions of 4.5 by 0.55
In addition to strength in tensile stress,
many other notable properties of whis-
kers have been observed or inferred from
the assumed absence of edge dislocations.
Some of these follow:
1. In experiments, metallic whiskers
have shown a much larger plastic de-
formation range, as opposed to the elas-
tic strains which most compounds are
able to withstand up to their point of
yielding.
2. The modulus of elasticity of a
whisker has, in some cases, been shown
to differ radically from that of larger
polycrystalline amounts of the same
material, due to the uniform orientation
of the whisker crystal axis. In various
instances the value of the modulus has
been halved or doubled.
3. A final and extremely important
property of whiskers is the absence of
creep below the normal recrystalization
temperature. This would imply the re-
tention of considerable strength at ele-
vated temperatures, even close to the
melting point.1
As might be indicated by the tremen-
dous stresses which whiskers are able
to sustain, together with the other prop-
erties just mentioned, the future possi-
bilities of whiskers, or structural com-
posites of whiskers, are unlimited.
George A. Hoffman, aeronautical engi-
neer at the Rand Corporation, refers to
whiskers as the possible "building blocks
of the astronauts."1 There is of course
much more interest in weight reduction
in the fields of aviation and space travel
than elsewhere. The properties of whis-
kers, included in supposed material to be
made from them in the future, permit a
comparison of the weights of tension
structures made from them, and that of
structures made from conventional ma-
terials. The possibility of a reduction to
one-fifth of today's normal structural
weight seems feasible, and is of great
interest in the design and construction
of astronautical vehicles, where weight
reduction can mean a considerable per-
formance improvement.
Furthering this idea, the loading of
space ships and planes results in struc-
tures designed from tension criteria.
Whisker tensile strength could well be
utilized in the construction of tanks,
cabins, and other items which are or
might be tension loaded as the result of
pressurization and other factors. If each
of these structures could be reduced to
one-fifth of its present design weight,
the saved four-fifths might be reinstated
as fuel, or payload of the last stage in
the case of rockets. This would increase
the payload, or the range, without

Whiskers exhibit a perfect crystal lattice, allowing the full value of atomic co-
hesion to be realized. The resulting strength can be as much as one thousand

Experiments have shown empirically that ESP
is not just a creation of the science fiction writ-
er: it's a startling reality.

Out of reach of man's conscious
mind lie strange and mysterious
forces of the mind. For centuries people
have tried to use these forces, the sorcer-
ers of Medieval times, the gypsy fortune
tellers, even the great philosophers of
ancient Greece toyed with the idea of
putting them to use. It was thought that
only a few selected people could posses
these powers of the mind. These forces
are what psychologists of today call psi
phenomena. Until the beginning of the
great scientific revolution, most people
would not think of questioning the
existence of psi, but the great advances
in science made during the nineteenth
century caused people to change this
attitude. Science could offer no proof or
explanation for the phenomena, there-
fore it was assumed that they did not
exist.
Despite this negative attitude, case
upon case of strange experiences were
reported by people from all over the
world. Someone would dream of a dis-
aster and pass it off as a bad dream,
only to have it occur exactly as he saw it
in the dream. Everyday occurences, such
as two people saying exactly the same
thing at the same time or the woman
who goes to call her neighbor on the
phone only to have the friend call her
just as she reaches for the phone, were
all passed off as mere coincidence. But
were they coincidence? From a highly
reputable source comes the story of the
mother who was at a bridge party, when
she was seized by an uncontrollable urge
to call her maid to see if her baby was
all right. She felt that she could not
continue the game until she called. After
struggling through the hand, she dashed
to the telephone and called the maid
who assured her that everything was
okay. Two hours later, when she arrived
home, there was a small gathering of
people in the front of her home. Apolo-
getically the maid explained that about
two hours before (at approximately the
same time the mother had the strong urge
to call) the baby had fallen from the
carriage and had caught his feet so that
he was hanging head down from the
carriage. The baby had been there for
quite a while when a policeman came
along and released the crying child from
his precarious position. A few more min-
utes in that position would have meant
death for the child. Because the baby
was not seriously injured, the maid with-
held the information from the mother
at the time of the call to avoid spoiling
the party. Can this nearly exact coinci-
dence of time be due to chance?
The vast majority of people preferred
to call these events coincidence. How-
ever, to a few undaunted psychologists
and other interested men the question
lingered: were there really such forces
as these psi phenomena? Man's behavior
had always been associated with the
physical world. All of his actions were
thought to be responses to physical stim-
uli such as sound, sight, smell and touch.
But one thing could not be explained by
such stimuli—the thinking process. What
was the mind? What brought about the
thinking process? Was it possible that
the mind was not a physical thing? Was
there a means of contact between men
without a physical awareness? Within
the last 75 years man has finally started
to seek answers to these questions. Final-
ly, after centuries, an explanation is being
sought.
In answer to these questions, a new
branch of psychology has developed,
known as parapsychology, which is de-
voted to the study of psi, or psychic,
phenomena. Psi has two main aspects:
mental and physical. The mental effects
are those which are scientifically known
as extra-sensory perception, or ESP, and
include: telepathy, which is the aware-
ness of the thoughts or the mental state
of another person, clairvoyance, or ESP
16
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


By IRVING SALMEEN
of an object or event, and precognition,
or the prediction of events which have
not happened. The physical effects are
known as psychokinesis or PK and are
concerned with the influence of mind
on matter.
Early Experiments
The first attempt to experimentally ver-
ify the existence of ESP was made by a
non-academic society which was founded
with the intent purpose of conducting
experiments on various psi phenomena.
This society, known as the Society for
Psychical Research, was founded in 1882
in England and became one of the first
organized groups to investigate ESP.
Their experiments were concerned with
telepathy; they did not try to explain it,
but rather, prove its existence thereby
showing that the mind was more than a
physical thing. At the time of their ex-
periments, the common idea was that
telepathy was associated with hypnotism;
hence the tests were carried out on sub-
jects placed under mild hypnosis.
One of the more well known experi-
menters was a French physician, Dr. E.
Azam, whose experiments were con-
cerned with the identification of sug-
gested physical things while the subject
was under the influence of hypnosis. It
was known that a person in such a state
was very susceptible to the power of
suggestion. For example, if the scent
of perfume were passed under a sub-
ject's nose and the experimenter told the
subject he could smell nothing, then
the subject would not respond to the
stimulus. This is what Dr. Azam's ex-
periments consisted of, but instead of
telling the subject he would think about
it and test the subject's reaction to his
transmitted thoughts. He would place
a subject under hypnosis and then think
of a smell. The subject was told to
respond when he was aware of the stim-
ulus. He also tried the experiment
thinking of a pain in a certain part of the
subject's body. The subject would re-
spond by attempting to relieve the dis-
comfort. The results, though not con-
clusive, indicated that it was possible,
in many cases, to transmit thoughts with-
out physical means. He succeeded in a
large number of trials in getting positive
responses to his thoughts.
One of the most dramatic of the
early experiments which pointed toward
the existence of ESP was an early telep-
athy test carried out by Dr. Pierre Janet
or Sorbonne University in Paris. Dur-
ing this experiment he succeeded in
hypnotizing a number of subjects at a
long distance and in separate rooms.
Again the results were not sufficient to
build a solid case for ESP, but they did
indicate that the existence of ESP was a
very strong possibility.
Later experimenters, working with the
identification of random numbers and
cards, discovered that hypnotism was
not necessary. Experiments were carried
out where subjects were to identify cards
and numbers that the experimenters were
thinking of. The number of correct
identifications far exceeded the number
that would have been accepted if identi-
fication were governed only by chance.
Despite this evidence in favor of ESP,
public opinion was still negative. It was
too far fetched for the people of the
time. Some contended that the experi-
ments were fixed and others said they
weren't accurately controlled, but the
men who conducted them had little to
gain from fraud, and all were highly
respectable and reputable men of the
academic world.
The attitude of indifference and skep-
ticism held until the early 1920's. The
pinnacle of American gaiety during the
Roaring 20's brought a sudden rise in
such things as spiritualism and seances.
The great magicians of the time such as

Ion exchange is making possible many new
chemical processes, and bettering existing
ones.
By DON WITHERS
Ion exchange, although recognized for
several hundred years, has recently
become one of the major processes of
chemistry and chemical engineering. Ele-
ments can be industrially separated more
conveniently than by other chemical
means, water can be desalted and made
extremely pure, rare earths and radio-
active elements can be recovered from
low-grade ores, and many processes arc-
made possible which previously were
too expensive. Even unwanted excesses
in the body can be controlled to an
extent by means of ion exchange.
History
The ion exchange properties of the
natural zeolite minerals have been known
for several hundred years. In the Mid-
dle Ages it was known that when hard
water, i.e. containing magnesium, iron,
calcium, etc., was run through a bed
of zeolite these hardness-producing ions
were removed from the water and "soft"
sodium ions put in the water in their
place by the zeolite. Eventually the zeolite
would give up all its sodium ions and
become saturated with the hard ones,
becoming useless.
Eventually it was discovered that the
zeolite could be regenerated by running
a strong salt solution through the ex-
hausted bed. The excess of sodium ions
forced out the hard ones and took their
place, thus making the bed ready for
another cycle. This process, with several
refinements was first proposed for in-
dustrial use back in 1905 on a large
scale for industrial water purification.
Many other minerals and soils were
studied for their exchange properties in
the 1800's. But these materials were
limited in usefulness and practical appli-
cations, usually serving in specific pro-
cesses.
The big breakthrough in the use of ion
exchange came with the synthesis of
resins of controllable exchange properties.
The large amount of research into these
synthetic resins has resulted in many
new applications as well as allowing a
higher purity than found in the natural
minerals. Some of the more interesting
applications will be discussed later on
in this paper.
Ion Exchange Mechanism
As the name implies, ion exchange
resins exchange ions, trading certain
exchangeables resin ion groups for ions
of like charge in a solution passing
through the resin. During manufacture
a polymer, or plastic, is saturated with
many easily exchanged ion groups (in
this case, H'). When a solution con-
taining ions to be removed is passed
through a resin column the new ions,
being more strongly attracted to the
resin than the H" groups, trade places
with them on the resin. The H' ions
are washed out of the resin as an acid
solution. (Ex. — NaCl solution +
HRESIN = HC1 solution + NaTesin).
Refer to Figure 1. On elution, or regener-
ation of the resin, a solution of surplus
H* ions is passed through the resin

THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


leaving the original solution and the
original resin. Note that the above ex-
planation makes no mention of the con-
ditions for one ion to be attracted to
the resin in preference to another. pH, or
concentration of the H' solution, choice
of eluting solution and many other fac-
tors must be considered.
The above example considers a cation
exchange resin (positively charged ions).
The resin exchanges positive ions and
can be considered to be a large negative
resin with an equilibrium number of
positive H' ions attached. Similarly, an-
ion exchange resins exchange negatively
charged ions and radicals. (Ex—OH-
resin + H'acid = acidic resin + H20).
Cation exchange resins mostly ex-
change the oxidized forms of metals and
earths while the anion forms exchange
negative acid radicals and metal com-
plexes. Cation resins are usually regen-
erated by acids while anion resin re-
quire bases.
Of what use is such a phenomenon?
One common use is the concentrating of
solutions, especially when the desired
ion is present in only a few parts per
million. This is often the case in the
preparation of radioactive elements in
an atomic reactor, where the very rare
elements are produced in minute amounts.
A resin is chosen to absorb the desired
ion directly from the working solution.
As the volumes of solution are run
through the column, the ion will be
stockpiled on the resin. When eluted
with only a few bed volumes of the
proper solution the ion will be washed
out in a concentration usually over a
hundred times greater than in the orig-

inal solution. Chemical precipitation is
usually now economical to complete the
recovery.
Separation of Elements
The following is an example of how
three solutions can be separated from
each other by controlling the HC1 con-
tent of the solutions. Consider a solution
of cobalt, nickel, and iron chlorides.
It is desired to separate them into three
chloride solutions.
Let us first use chemical means to
obtain the desired results. One element
must first be precipitated out of solution
selectively and filtered out. A second
element must be similarly removed
from the third element. The three ele-
ments are now separated, but they are
not in the form desired. Proper chem-

ical reactions must be chosen to put the
three elements in chloride solutions and
prevent other chemicals from contam-

taken at least seven steps and most like-

Now let us use an ion exchange resin
for this purpose. The three graphs below
show the percent absorption of the three
elements as a function of the percent
HCI in the solution. Add HCI to the
solution until about 4 to 5 molar. As
can be seen from the graphs, Iron (III)
will be absorbed while the nickel and
cobalt will pass on through the column.
Now elute the iron with a very weak
solution of HCI. The iron is in the
form desired. When the remaining solu-
tion is made more than six molar and
passed through the column, the nickel
comes out as the desired solution while
the cobalt is retained on the resin. An-
other elution with very weak HCI re-
moves the cobalt as the desired solution.
Note that seven steps were also required,
but the solutions are in the form desired.
This process itself is not economically
feasible since precipitation is cheaper,
but it serves to illustrate separations by
ion exchange. But when a solution of
rare earths is to be separated, as many
as several hundred precipitation and
crystallization steps may be required. In
such a case, ion exchange is often the
only means of large scale production at
a reasonable cost.

Ion exchange finds much use in
water treatment, especially in the deion-

has been stated before, the use of zeolites

PROBABILITY
All day long! . . . yes? . . . no? . . . cross the
street? ... go to class? ... hamburger or grilled
cheese? . . But how do we do it?
By RICHARD KARPINSKI
Decisions are said to be the results
of rational logical thinking pro-
esses. But thinking processes are notori-
ous for sometimes being neither rational
nor logical. However, recently, some
revealing studies have been made on the
topic, notably Theory of Games and
Economic Behavior by John von Neu-
mann and Oskar Morgenstern. After
the field became a reputable area of study,
many others entered and added their
discoveries, sometimes contradictory,
sometimes useless, but often meaning-
ful, adding insights into the nature of
man.
Perhaps the easiest and most instruc-
tive area to begin with is gambling: One
might assume that a person would enter
into a wager only when he had a rea-
sonable chance of winning. Thus if I
were to stake $1.00 that I would turn
up the Ace of Spades on one cut of a
standard deck, 1 would require my
opponent to stake $51.00 or more that
I would not. However, there are several
types of cases where this does not happen.
Richard Karpinski, a transfer
student from Michigan Tech, is a
sophomore majoring in math.
While at Tech he was named to
Phi Eta Sigma, a freshman honor
society.
As a student at Mumford High
School in Detroit, he was active
in the Math and Chess Clubs.
Among his interests he includes
coin collecting, archery, science
fiction, and cycling.

In fact, the exceptions include the great
majority of the events in question. Let
us consider these exceptions to appar-
ently rational thinking.
First, suppose I am a very rich man
(so that $50 or $100 means little to
me), but at the moment I have only
$1.00 in my wallet which I intend to
use as cab fare for the two mile trip
home. A man approaches me and offers
to pay me $100 if I can call a card and
then turn it over correctly, on the con-
dition that if I lose I pay him $1.00.
Obviously, on a purely logical level I
should accept the wager immediately. I
think, however, "if I win, it will mean
little to me, but if I lose, I shall have
to walk home. Under these conditions
I do not accept the wager.
On the other hand, if I have only one
dollar to my name and it is important
to me that I get to Milwaukee as soon
as possible, (by air: $25.00), I accept
the wager even at $25 or $30 when
statistics and probabilities say I get the
worst of the deal.
A third type, which might be called
a limited information situation, is ex-
emplified by two men wagering over the
outcome of an election: the Democrat
thinks sincerely that Stevenson has a
60/40 chance of winning, while the
Republican feels that Eisenhower has a
20
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


cept bets slightly against their favor, each
thinking that he is more likely to win.
The New Development
Since in each of the three above cases,
simple mathematical probability theory
will not suffice to predict or even explain,
the actions of the people involved, we
need some other explanation. One the-
ory which has developed begins by
asserting that we can measure feelings in
units of pleasure and regret. Thus in the
first case above, $100 might be worth
ten units of pleasure to the rich man,
while having to walk home would cause
one unit of regret. Since the odds of win-
ning the wager are less than one in ten,
the decision not to enter is reasonable.
The second case is similar in that the
loss of the dollar is not important while
the chance to get to Milwaukee is.
It is only in the third case, however,
that the real use of the theory is dis-
played. Here, since we have no data to
the contrary, we may for the moment
suppose that dollars and pleasure-regret
units correspond to each other, at least
roughly. This is not the problem. Despite
the fact that one of the participants
(or both) must have been wrong in his
evaluation of the true probabilities in
the election, if indeed there were any
"true probabilities," that is not the
problem we are concerned with either.
At the moment, we are concerned with
how we do make decisions, not how we
should. Here, the pleasure-regret units
are of real value, since they allow us to
evaluate pertinent but non-numerical cir-
cumstances. Both participants of the
last example, by virtue of being party
members, have alliances to uphold. This
means that whether or not they really
believe that their respective candidates
will win, they have an unspoken obliga-
tion to support them. In other words,
conditions outside the wager itself, and
not affecting the value of the outcome
are an integral part of the decision. Each
participant must decide how much the
scorn of his party members and the dis-
approval of his opponent and associates
means to him (in terms of pleasure re-
gret units) before he can begin to con-
sider the mathematical probabilities.
Professional Gambling and the Gambler
In professional gambling, Las Vegas
and Monte Carlo, horse racing and the
numbers racket to mention a few, the
odds are always against you: in craps
or roulette, only by four or five per-
cent; in the numbers game it may run
two or even ten to one against you. But
people keep on betting! In many cases
this may be completely rational and ex-
plicable. As in case two above, n dollars
may be worth more in pleasure units
than n times one dollar expressed in
pleasure units. For instance, as so often
the case is with numbers players, a man
may have a very poor income and live
under slum conditions. In such a situa-
tion, one thousand dollars would be
considerably more valuable than the one
dollar he might bet each week for twenty
years ($1041). Also, in the case of once
in a lifetime or occasional gamblers, there
is the entertainment value. The thrill
of watching the little ball decide whether
you win or lose may be worth accepting
the odds against you once in a while.
Then there is the gambler; he is the
first, so far, whose rationality is ques-
tionable. He is prone to believe in sys-
tems, and while there are a few win-
ning systems, they require that you have
at least more cash than the casino and
an exceedingly great amount of time to
throw the odds in your favor. We can-
not reasonably charge it to recreation
since he spends entirely too much time
and money at it, and generally is very
guilt ridden after realizing what has
happened.
One of the most general delusions,
among normal people too, is a misinter-
pretation of probability theory. When
we say, that in the long run, a coin will
fall heads half of the time, many people
think that after a long series of tails, it
becomes more and more probable that
the next toss will result in a head. This
is not so—the odds remain the same,
50/50. If you started out with one hun-
dred tails in a row, eventually there
would be so many tosses that one hun-
dred would be a very insignificant part
of the total; that is the meaning of the
statement" in the long run . . . ."
Practical Applications
What we have said so far may be of
interest but it really isn't too useful to
the average person. We may then ask:
(Continued on page 42)
To card players, the element of chance is an extremely
important factor. In poker, there is one chance in 4,164
of getting four of a kind, but only one in 649,739 of
receiving a royal flush. These seem insignificant when it is
known that the odds against a perfect bridge hand are
635,599.599 to one.

James Elam (M.S., Purdue '59) is studying various techniques of speech analysis at IBM.
The objective of this work is voice-machine communication.


^y* nmmvmnM
He's breaking through
sound barriers to
find new applications
of human speech
It is believed that once clear, distinct signals can be obtained from
human speech sounds, the human voice can be used for direct com-
munication with machines. James Elam is working in this direction.
Voice-Machine Communication Problems
The problems involved are formidable. Machine "understanding"
of human speech will be limited by both the sensitivity and the
number of electronic "recognizers" of speech-sound patterns that
can be built into the machine. To further complicate matters, the
human voice is capable of making an almost infinite variety and
subtlety of sound patterns. Only in theory could a machine be built
that could recognize all of them.
A Solution in "Phonemes"?
To further this work on voice-machine communication, James
Elam is studying various techniques of speech analysis. In one
scheme, recordings are made of voices reading words. These are
then examined in their frequency spectrum, and a power within
discrete bands is plotted. The plots, or spectrograms, are used
to break down words into basic sounds called "phonemes." Each
phoneme has a separate and distinct pattern and is capable of giv-
ing a clear signal. It is hoped that these signals can be used to
communicate directly, through an audio input, with machines.
Fascinating Assignments
Because of its exciting future possibilities, James Elam finds his
work fascinating.
If you would like to employ your talents in areas where exciting
future possibilities are all part of a day's work, then you might
consider the opportunities offered by IBM. When our representa-
tive comes to your campus, he will be glad to give you information
about opportunities in research, development, manufacturing and
other areas at IBM.

changing the gross weight at take-off.
It is only natural to consider at this
point the feasibility of the mass produc-
tion of whiskers and their composite
materials, if they are to be utilized in
the manner suggested. There must be no
insurmountable obstacles in the manu-
facture of the quantity, quality, and
forms of whiskers necessary for struc-
tural purposes. Consider, then, their
growth, alignment and collection, and
final binding into usable shapes or forms.
It is presently thought by those in
the field that under sufficient economic-
incentives all the methods of growth pre-
viously discussed in this paper will be
adaptable for plant mass production.
Furthermore, it is possible to devise
means for making the growth of whis-
kers orderly, thereby improving their
collectibility. Such factors as align-
ment, thinness, and length, can all be
controlled by proper temperatures, sat-
uration composition, and magnetic or
electrostatic fields. The harvesting or col-
lection of whiskers might be accom-
plished by vibratory or mechanical scrap-
ing techniques.1 Up to this point, the
whiskers would simply be in loose
bundles, perhaps held by friction or
electrostatic forces.
The first step in deriving a usable
whisker form would possibly be spin-
ning them into longer strands much like
textiles or glass fibers. These in turn
would be woven into cables or sheets,
still weak, however, for the lack of a
shear bond between fibers. There seems
to be two possibilities for achieving this
bond:
The first is the pressing and heating
of the woven mats or cables, similar to
the powder and fiber metallurgy known
today. However, this process is not
without restrictions. The compacting
pressures must not reach a point where
the whisker's strength would be dam-
aged, and the temperature must be held
below some critical value, for like rea-
sons.
The second possibility is the impreg-
nation of the cables and sheets with a
binder or matrix, analogous to today's
fiber glass methods where plastics such
as phenolics, silicones, and polyesters
are used to impart good cohesion to fila-
ment composites. The maximum temper-
ature at which these can now be used is
around 600 F. Researchers are, however,
working with fibers in a metal matrix,
and hoping for boron polymer resins to
be used at 1000 to 1200 F. in the near
future. It must be realized that in this
latter process, the modulus and strength
of the resulting material has been re-
duced by as much as twenty percent.
This reduction is a penalty for the
weight of the non-load-carrying binder.
Thus the enclosed fibers will carry most
of the tension load, while the matrix
will be very lightly stressed in shear.1
Thus the production of structural ma-
terials possessing great strength due to
the whisker constituent can be accom-
plished if the necessity arises.
George Hoffman provides an interest-
ing comparison of the cost of these new
materials in relation to that used in pres-
ent structures. He derives their potential
value from the weight reduction to one-
fifth that of materials now in use. One
current estimate of the cost of whisker
material is from $200 to $400 per in-
stalled pound, as compared to $40 per
installed pound of aluminum. But since
one pound of whisker composite might
replace five pounds of conventional ma-
terial, the actual cost has been prac-
tically equalized. Hoffman tells us, how-
ever, that the value of saving one pound
of structural weight in aircraft, for in-
stance, is anywhere from $100 to $1000,
and, of course, much higher where mis-
siles and astranautical vehicles are con-
cerned. Thus the value of the utilization
of one pound of whisker material cost-
ing $400 might well approach $4000.
Throughout the latter part of this ar-
ticle, the potential value of the exploi-
tation of whiskers and their composite
materials has been discussed and shown
to be entirely feasible. Research in this
field is comparatively new and there are
still many topics and questions to be stud-
ied and answered. The economic value
of whiskers dictates that further research
be conducted, even though the fruits of
it may still be ten to twenty years in the
future. When man has extracted the full
strength value from the perfect arrange-
ment of the atoms within crystals the
increase in strength that he will achieve
in structural materials could easily sur-
pass that achieved with the development
of steel from iron.

The girl is taking a matching test of clairvoyant ESP in the Parapsychology Labo-
ratory of Duke University. She points to the symbol she thinks identifies that on the
card held by the experimenter. He then lays it down opposite. The test continues
until the deck of 25 cards is thus distributed and the number of hits is counted
Houdini and others tried to converse
with the dead using telepathy. This rise
in public interest prompted two univer-
sities to undertake experiments: The
University of Groningen in Holland and
Harvard University. The Dutch experi-
ments, under the direction of Dr. H. G.
F. W. Brugmans, consisted of the iden-
tification of squares by a subject while
he was blindfolded. The experimenter
would think of a square and the sub-
ject was to point to the corresponding
square on a board which was placed in
front of him. Precaution was taken to
avoid physical contact between subject
and experimenter, yet out of 187 trials,
60 successes were obtained. On the basis
of chance, four correct would have been
expected. Unlike the Dutch experiments,
the Harvard tests, under the direction of
Prof. William McDougall and carried
out by Dr. G. H. Estabrooks, were con-
cerned with the identification of cards.
The experimenter would think of a card
and the subject would write down the
name of the card he thought it was.
Tabulation of the percentage of success-
es showed that the odds were one mil-
lion to one against the results being due
to chance.
These first experiments served but
one purpose: they built a strong case
for telepathy and opened the way for
extended investigations into telepathy
and other psi phenomena. Unfortunately
these experiments by the universities
were short-lived. Members of the psy-
chology profession frowned upon the
investigation of ESP and discouraged
any further investigation. In spite of
this discouragement, however, the facts
remained: ESP was possible and the
mind was not purely physical.
First Duke Experiments
1930 brought the establishment of
one of the most famous laboratories for
parapsychology. Today it is the lead-
ing laboratory for research in psi phe-
nomena. This institute is the Parapsy-
chology Laboratory of Duke University-.
Here, the majority of modern work has
been done in attempting to understand
psi phenomena. The first investigations
were under the direction of Professor
William McDougall. Previous experi-
ments had been haphazard with little
standardization so the first project was
to set up a system of standardized pro-
cedures which could be easily duplicated
by other investigators. One result of this
was a special pack of cards designed to
facilitate investigation of clairvoyance,
telepathy, and precognition. The pack

(Continued from page 26)
consisted of 25 cards, each having one
of five various geometric designs. These
designs, a star, circle, wavy lines, square,
and a cross, were selected because of
their distinctiveness. Two ways were used
to make up a pack: first was an equal
number of each card and was known as
an open pack, the other was a random
selection of the cards and an uneven dis-
tribution of each. If these cards were
used properly, the odds were 5 to 1
against selecting the correct card.
In previous tests, the experimenters
had failed to take into account the pos-
sibility of interference of various other
psi phenomena with the particular one
they were testing for. This was espec-
ially true with the telepathy experiments
because the experimenters looked at i
card and it was possible, through clair-
voyance, for the subject to directly per-
ceive the correct answer from the card
instead of from the experimenter. In
the new experiments for telepathy, the
sender was not given any object and
did not even write down the symbol he-
was thinking of until after a signal in-
dicated that the receiver had written
down his response. A similar precaution
against telepathy entering into clair-
voyance experiments was taken. In these
tests the cards were placed face down
by the experimenter so that no one knew
the order of the pack until after the
test. It was the duty of the subject to
write down the order. Using these pre-
cautions and the standard ESP deck,
experimenters again verified that the
existence of telepathy and clairvoyance
were very strong possibilities.
The Final Test
Up to this point experimenters had
merely proven that laws of chance were
being violated in the tests. Of course the
logical assumption was that something
such as ESP assisted in identifying the
cards. However, no conclusive test had
been performed which eliminated every-
thing but ESP as an explanation for the
results. After satisfactorily standardizing
procedure, the next step was to design
an experiment which would prove beyond
a doubt that psi phenomena did exist.
This experiment took the form of the
now famous Pearce-Pratt series carried
out at Duke in 1933.
As in previous tests, the receiver was
to identify cards, but this time there was
a change in the procedure. First, since
the object of the test was to prove the
existence of ESP, it was inconsequential
whether or not various psi phenomena
interfered with each other, so no pre-
caution was taken to eliminate the possi-
bility of such interference. Second, this
experiment was performed with the
sender and receiver separated by several
buildings and about 100 yeards. The
cards were handled by J. G. Pratt, at that
time a graduate student in psychology at
Duke. In another building, located about
one hundred yards away, was stationed


were made. The number of correct identi-
fications, based on chance would have
been 60, but Pearce successfully identi-
fied 119. Such results would not be
expected once in more than one trillion
trials! Other experimenters, notably Dr.
S. G. Soal of Queen Mary College in
London, carried out a similar series with
far more elaborate controls. The results
corresponded very closely to those ob-
tained by the Pearce-Pratt tests.
ESP vs Time
With the existence of ESP now on
firm ground, new questions began to rise.


Cards similar to these are used in tests to facilitate investigation of clairvoyance,
telepathy, and precognition.
