SPOTLIGHTS
PROGRESS
By CHARLES MASSER
Successful Firing of
Nike Zeus Accomplished
A completely successful firing of the
Army's Nike Zeus has been accomplished
by Douglas crews at White Sands Mis-
sile Range.
The Army said the Zeus is the only
anti-missile missile currently under devel-
opment in the free world. The launching
was another in the series of firings
planned to perfect the development of
the U.S. defense against a possible enemy
ICBM.
Objective was to evaluate the aerody-
namic characteristics of the anti-inter-
continental ballistic weapon. The launch,
boost, separation and sustainer opera-
tions all were successful, the Army said.
The Nike Zeus travelled an unguided
ballistic course. To accomplish this, the
guidance fins were locked in zero-degree
position. Both the booster and the sus-
tainer motor were fired successfully.
Developing about 450,000 pounds of
thrust, the booster is the largest single-
grain solid propellant motor ever fired.
The Army Rocket and Guided Missile
Agency, Huntsville, Ala., is the develop-
ing agency for the Nike Zeus. ARGMA
is an agency of the Army Ordnance mis-
sile command.
Nike Zeus, when developed, will be an
anti-missile missile intended to intercept
enemy intercontinental ballistic missiles
—ICBM's—before they can reach their
targets.
Prime contractor for the system is
Western Electric Company. System de-
velopment is the responsibility of Bell
Telephone Laboratories, and responsibil-
ity for the missile and missile handling
equipment is in the hands of Douglas
Aircraft.
The rocket motors were produced by
Grand Central Rocket Company and Thi-
okol Chemical Corporation.

Photo courtesy of Corning Glass Work
Special, heat-resistant glass—four panes
thick—will go into viewports for the
National Aeronautics and Space Admin-
istration's Mercury space capsule, shown
above.
High Temperature Glass
for Mercury Capsule
The Viewports for the National Aero-
nautics and Space Administration's Mer-
cury space capsules will be made of pol-
ished, high temperature glass, four panes
thick. They are designed to remain intact
through the heat and shock re-entry.
The rectangular panels are being pro-
duced by Corning Glass Works for
McDonnell Aircraft Corporation, de-
signer and builder of the nation's first
man-carrying space vehicle. The view-
ports will enable the pilot to determine
the vehicle's attitude and to take astro-
nomical photographs. The glass panes
must withstand the same environmental
stresses as the capsule's triple-layered
metal walls.
The windows will include two outer
panels of a 96 per cent silica glass and
two inner panes of heat resistant alumi-
nosilicate glass. Air spaces between the
panes will retard heat transfer to the in-
side of the space capsule. The two in-
nermost panels will be tempered for
greater strength. The outer pane of glass
will be curved to the outside contour of
the capsule.
The glass must survive re-entry tem-
peratures and remain water-tight in an
ocean landing. The multi-layered con-
struction of the window provides a high
safety margin during re-entry and land-
ing.

THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


"Solar hydrogen bombs"—a term for
a phenomenon on the sun—are not use-
ful for predicting communications—dis-
rupting solar flares, report astronomers
at The University of Michigan McMath-
Hulbert Observatory.
Professors Robert R. McMath, Orren
C. Mohler, and Helen W. Dodson made
observations of the "bombs" in the hope
that they could find a way to predict
solar flares.
Using new techniques, they found the
"bombs'* occur more generally than had
been believed. Hence they don't foretell
flares. The findings are described in the
February Proceedings of the National
Academy of Sciences.
Solar flares are immense gaseous re-
gions, brighter than the surrounding sur-
face of the sun, which "boil up" sud-
denly. They are important to us because
they shoot out streams of charged par-
ticles and radiation which can disrupt
radio, telephone, and telegraph commu-
nications on earth for periods varying
from an hour to several days.
Being able to forecast them obviously
would be advantageous.
The solar bombs, which the U-M as-
tronomers hoped might foretell solar
flares, also are disturbances on the sun—
but, in contrast to flares, extremely small
and local brightenings. They can be de-
tected in the solar spectrum, or the
breaking down of sunlight into its dif-
ferent wave lengths or colors. ("Solar
hydrogen bomb" was the name given to
the phenomenon in 1917 by the astron-
omer Perdinand Ellerman.)
Somewhat as a rainbow breaks sun-
light down into the various colors, solar
spectral analysis provides a method to
precisely divided sunlight so that it can
show a single "color" line characteristic
only of solar bombs.
The McMath-HuIbert astronomers ob-
served occurrences of bombs—and of
solar flares—from 1955 through last
year, looking for a correlation between
the two.
While they found there is no way to
use the "bombs" to forecast the commu-
nications disrupting solar flares, they did
find that the bombs are associated with
sunspots. In contrast to solar flares, sun-
spots are large areas of relative cooling
of the sun's surface.
They found further that the bombs
originate in what had been described by
the French astronomer Bernard Lyot as
the solar phenomenon called "petit
points." The so-called bombs and the
"petit points" describe the same physi-
cal feature on the sun, the U-M astron-
omers assert.
The trio also report that detecting El-
lerman's solar hydrogen bombs by spec-
tral analysis is not as difficult as had
been believed. Formerly it was thought
that ideal viewing conditions were neces-
sary to detect the phenomena.
But special spectroscopic techniques
discovered by the authors provide high
contrast "pictures" of the bombs. Con-
trast is increased, they report, by using
a special filter (showing the K-line of
calcium).

This is concrete pipe, poured by a new
continuous process in a freshly-cut
ditch. Lengths of 50 to 300 feet with
diameters ranging from 12 to 48 inches
have been successfully made. Develop-
ment of a machine to lay 60-inch pipe
is under way.
Instant Concrete Pipe
Construction machinery that builds
"instant concrete pipe" in a freshly-cut
ditch at a rate of eight to twelve feet a
minute has been developed by Fuller-
form Continuous Pipe Corp.
Currently being used to build con-
duits for irrigation water on farms near
Phoenix, the new construction process is
being adapted to build storm sewers and
other types of concrete pipe.
Inflatable rubber and fabric forms,
designed by Goodyear Aircraft Corp. en-
gineers from blimp-type materials, are
part of the continuous-operation system.
Using two 300-foot inflated forms
with only three pounds per square inch
of air pressure, one can pour as much as
600 feet of concrete pipe at a time with-
out interruption.
Developed over the past nine years,
the construction process consists mainly
of a double-hoppered forming machine
that is pulled along the rounded bottom
of a ditch, while enveloping an inflated
inner form.
The inflatable "inner" form is picked
up by the "outer" form so tamping de-
vices can literally tuck concrete under it.
Half of the double hopper, activated by
electrically driven tampers, shoves con-
crete into the bottom of the ditch, while
the other half is forming the top of the
pipe.
The hose-like, inflatable form, con-
structed of two plies of cotton fabric
coated with neoprene rubber at Good-
year's aircraft plant near Phoenix, is open
at both ends to hold airtight bulkheads
through which air pressure is applied
for strength.
Machinery containing the "outside"
form for concrete pipe is set in the
ditch and one end of the inflatable form
is passed through it with bulkheads at
both ends. As concrete is poured into the
machine's double-hopper, the forming
machine is drawn forward by a cable on
a winch. An electric motor on top of the
machine operates the tamping devices
that distribute concrete uniformly and
tightly around the inner form.
About 20 different machines were
built before the right combination was
hit. Experimental tests by the dozens
were made on Fuller's Arizona ranch.
The tests were pure trial and error. Pipe
was laid, then broken out to check for
uniformity and strength.
Finally, Arizona Testing Laboratories
found the system and the finished prod-
ucts would meet Bureau of Reclamation
standards for Arizonia. The concrete
conduit, made with the first inflatable-de-
flatable pipe form, exceeded bureau
weight-test requirements by four tons
and compression strength by 520 pounds
per square inch.
Although the first commercial instal-
lations have been limited to irrigation
pipes, Mr. Fuller is convinced the new
pipe-building process is not confined to
this field.
He is currently working with the city
of Phoenix on plans to lay storm sew-
ers with his new system and perfecting
methods to go after the vast sanitary
sewer and other concrete pipe markets.

base, between the site of a mountain crash and a waiting ambulance—above all,

NEW ELECTRONIC "BRAIN" CELLS
FIT IN THE EYE OF A NEEDLE
Basic building block for compact,
electronic "thought savers" will
serve you in your office, in
defense-someday, in your home
• Today, science not only is working on labor-saving
devices—but on thought-saving devices as well.
These "thought savers" are electronic computers
—wonder-workers that free us from tedious mental
work and are capable of astoundingly rapid compu-
tations. Naturally, the more compact these computers
can be made, the more applications they can have.
Not only in industry, defense and research—but in
the office and ultimately in the home.
"Squeezing" exacting components
A big advance has recently been made by RCA
research towards making these "thought savers"
smaller than ever before, for broader than ever use.
Take, for example, the new "logic" circuit which
actually fits in the eye of a needle. It is a new
computer component developed by RCA.
Today, the electronic /unctions oj this micro-
miniature device require a whole fistful oj wires,
resistors, transistors and condensers.
These tiny units will calculate, sort, "remember,"
and will control the flow of information in to-
morrow's computers. Yet they are so small that
100,000,000 of them will fit into one cubic foot!
Cutting computers down to home size
This extreme reduction in size may mean that some-
day cigar-box-size electronic brains may help you in
your home—programming your automatic appli-
ances, and keeping track of household accounts.
Remarkable progress in micro-miniaturization is
another step forward by RCA— leader in radio, tele-
vision, in communications and in all^ electronics—Jor
home, office, and nation.

after he correctly predicted many news
events including the World Series out-
come.
These spontaneous cases were not any
proof of the existence of precognition,
therefore the first step in the investiga-
tion of it was to prove its existence. This
was first attempted using the standard
deck and asking the subject to predict
the order of the cards after they were
shuffled. At first the deck was shuffled
by hand, then mechanically, then cut
according to a pattern determined by
temperature readings published in a spe-
cific newspaper on a particular date. It
was found that the subjects scored at
about the same rate as they did on the
cards during the telepathy and clair-
voyance tests. Indications were, after sev-
eral repetitions of the test, that this psi
phenomenon did exist; however, the
Duke experiments were the only ones
ever conducted on precognition and as
yet the case for precognition is not on
sound ground. Before precognition can
be positively identified, new and differ-
ent experiments must be designed; until
that time, it will remain only as a strong
possibility.
PK
After studying the results of many of
the experiments, the question arose
whether or not the mind could influence
the shuffling of the cards. For the first
time, the question of PK, or psychoki-
nesis, seriously entered the picture. The
answer to this question was also sought in
experimentation. The idea for this test
was suggested by a gambler who con-

tended that the throw of the dice could
be influenced by direct action of will.
The test which was developed was de-
signed to see if the subject could control
the throw of dice. Mechanical methods
were devised to handle the dice so as to
eliminate the possibility of manipulation
by hand. The results of these first ex-
periments seemed to indicate that PK
was a factor.
After eight years of investigation by
many different experimenters, a report
was finally published by Duke Labora-
tories. The conclusion of this report was
based on an analysis of a large body of
experimental records which had been
gathered during the eight year period.
For each of these different experiments
different subjects were used, different
dice, and variations in the means of
handling the dice. The one thing in
common with each investigation was that
the subject attempted to control the fall
of the dice. Upon examination of the
data sheets it was observed that the per-
centage of successes of each page de-
clined as one went from the left to the
right and from the top to the bottom. To
compare the percentages, each page was
divided into quarters. It was observed
that the upper left corner had the high-
est percentages, while the lower right had
the lowest percentages. It was only ne-
cessary, therefore, to evaluate the total
difference in the percentage of these two
quarters for each sheet of each series, and
then to compare this percentage to the
one which would be expected by chance.
Final evaluation showed the results to
be one million to one against occuring
by chance!
This test appeared to be the crucial
one; the results seemed to be indisput-
able. To eliminate the possibility of error
in misinterpreting the data, another psy-
chologist, associated with Duke but not
with the experiment, re-evaluated the
data, and with the exception of two mi-
nor errors found it to be correct. The
conclusion drawn by the Duke Lab in
favor of PK has been verified in other
experiments with added refinements in
technique. In each case, the data seemed
to justify the fact that PK was a factor
in controlling the fall of the dice.

How Inco Nickel is helping develop
the new gas turbine car of tomorrow
It will be power-packed: the gas turbine

Only one spark plug-

This new engine is much lighter, smaller.
It has far fewer parts. No pistons. No water

Not yet in production!
Before the car is a showroom reality, engi-
neers fare a number of problems.
One problem—the one Inco is helping with
- is metals. Strong and economical metals
to resist heat and corrosion.
Cas turbines operate at up to 1600°F. These
temperatures step up corrosion of metals,
promote troublesome distortions. So the
job is to develop practical alloys able to
carry the load—alloys that can, at the same
time, offset the corrosives, resist the distort-
ing forces found at jet-high temperatures.
How far has Inco research gone
in its search for practical alloys?
Difficult as they are, the problems of metal
performance at high temperature are a
familiar story at Inco. Inco research has
dealt with them for years. And come up

many other fields. In conventional, atomic,
and thermionic power. In petrochemistry.
In heat treating. In jet aviation. In mis-
silry. Even in Hollywood's 8000°F carbon-
arc "suns."

as a haphazard gathering of facts and
disorganized experiments, has grown into
a rich new field of human and scientific
endeavor. The experiments performed to
date strongly indicate that something else
besides the physical influences man's ac-
tivities. Telepathy, clairvoyance, precog-
nition, and PK can no longer be dis-

pendent of space, time, and matter, but
it is lawful and orderly in its operation
and affects each and every man, woman
and child.
Of course anything so radical and revo-
lutionary is slow to gain acceptance. But
people should not be so willing to dis-
card new ideas. Why is it not possible
for there to be new forces besides those
that are known? The practical applica-
tions of such forces are unlimited. They
range from predicting future events, find-
ing lost objects, communication, location
of underground deposits of minerals, to
obtaining military secrets of potential
enemies. Before such application can oc-
cur, however, the science of ESP must be
understood. The next step by parapsy-
chologists is an attempt to find out what
ESP and PK are and how they work. It
will be a long time before the infant
science grows up, but when it does man
will have answered one of the fundamen-
tal questions concerning himself: what is
his mind?

in water softening is a common process
familiar to most people. Hard water
containing magnesium, calcium, iron,
etc., is run through a bed of zeolite. The
resin gives off soft sodium ions as it
absorbs the hard ones. The conditions for
the zeolite to absorb the hard ions are
met by the raw water itself, and for-
tunately the zeolite may be regenerated
simply by passing a salt solution through
the bed. The excess concentration of
sodium is enough to force out the hard
ions.
Zeolite in the home is usually found
in replaceable tanks serviced by a water
softening company. When the tank is
exhausted, it is returned to the factory
for regeneration while a fresh tank is
put in its place. Also, synthetic resins
may be seen in the home in the form of
cartridges used to soften small amounts
of water for use in steam irons. These
can be regenerated in the home without
much trouble.
Not so well known is the use of ion
exchange resins to treat already softened
(Continued from page 19)
water to remove the last traces of im-
purities from water such as used in the
coating of television rubes, high press-
ure boilers and pharmaceutical products.
Both a cation and an anion column are
used in tandem. This procedure removes
the ions from the water and replaces
them with pure water. The use of a
zeolite would leave sodium ions in the
water. The two reactions below show
such an exchange process. Although cal-
cium has been chosen for the example,
the other ions are of similar reactions.
Ca'ions + H'resin =H*acid + Ca**resin
H'acid + OH-risin = H20-(- acid resin
Purity of several parts per billion of im-
purity can be obtained under special cir-
cumstances. Water at a continuous level
of several parts per million is now ob-
tained regularly in most elevated temper-
ature and pressure steam boiler systems,
where even a minute amount of impurity
could foul the tubes by forming scale.
Such a process would work very well
for the desalting of seawater but for the
fact that the ion exchange columns are
too expensive to run when the impurities
of the feed water are over 1000 parts
per million, a concentration extremely
less than that of sea water. A different
approach to ion exchange of seawater is
being studied, and shows much promise.
Ocean Wafer Survival Kits
Although ion exchange for sea water
conversion is at present completely un-
economical on a large scale, ion exchange
resin briquettes were developed during
the war for ocean survival. When such
a briquette was dropped in a container
holding ten times its volume of sea
water, it disintegrated and exchanged
the salts of the water, forming an insolu-
able precipitate easily removed. The
briquettes were fairly expensive and could
only be used once, but the important
consideration was furnishing fresh water
with little emphasis on the price.

of uranium from very low grade ores,
a process extremely costly by other means.
Uranium ore is put into solution, giving
a large volume of solution with a small
amount of uranium. The concentration
of the uranium may be as low as .1 per-
cent. In addition, the solution is rich
in impurities such as titanium and alum-
inum.
For this particular use an anion ex-
change resin is employed, since the
uranium can be put in an anion com-
plex form. A sample recovery operation
is described below.
A. The ore is leached with sulfuric
acid to put it into solution.
B. The solution is passed through a
resin column, chosen to absorb the uran-
ium only, until the first trace of uranium
appears at the outlet.
C. The column is washed with water
to remove the extraneous solution from
the column.
D. The uranium is eluted out of the
column with an appropriate salt solu-
tion.
E. The uranium, now in a concen-
trated state, is precipitated out and re-
covered.
Sometimes the ore is difficult to put in
a clear solution and filtering is too diffi-
cult to be practical. In such cases, the
resin is placed in porous baskets which
oscillate through the pulpy solution.
When the resin is saturated, the pulpy
solution is simply washed out with water
and the uranium eluted as before.
Gold Recovery
The ion exchange mechanism for re-
covering gold and silver is slightly differ-
ent from that of uranium, in that all im-
purities as well as gold are absorbed by
the resin. The impurities are then eluted
out, leaving the noble metals on the resin.
The following flow sheet shows the
process.
Since the concentration of the desired
metals are so slight, the gold and silver
from the first cycle are left in place and
another cycle repeated. This procedure
stockpiles the two on the resin. When
the concentration reaches about 9 percent
by weight of the resin they are eluted out
and recovered by precipitation.

this case are usually of very similar pro

perties and attraction to the resin. The
eluting solution is chosen to have an

ION EXCHANGE
(Continued from page 19)
ions may be very similar, a slow rate of
elution will greatly emphasize the differ-
ences and permit clean separations. Rare
earths and amino acids, because of their
similarity, are ideally suited to such i
process. As many as several hundred
precipitations and crystallizations were
needed to separate some of the rare
earths by other means.
Recovery of Photographic Silver
Each year the photographic industry
discards many thousands of dollars worth
of silver in solution because the very
low concentration makes recovery un-
economical. Ion exchange is being tried
out as a practical means of treating the
large volumes of solution to recover the
silver at a relatively low cost. Such a
process is expected to pay for itself in a
few short years.
Separation of Streptomycin
Before 1948 the cost of streptomycin
was very high. Separation from the cul-
ture broth could be accomplished only
after long and expensive chemical steps.
In 1948 the pharmaceutical industry tried
ion exchange. The results were success-
ful and the price correspondingly
dropped. Since that time the pharmaceu-
tical industry has been one of the major
advocates of ion exchange, using it in
many processes and separations.
Medical Applications
One of the most interesting applica-
tions of ion exchange is in the field of
internal medicine. Resins taken orally
are able to absorb excess stomach acids
without the usual side effects of anta-
cids, can remove excess pepsin from the
stomach thereby lessening irritation of
stomach ulcers, and can lower the body
supply of sodium or potassium. Also,
ion exchange resins have enabled arti-
ficial kidneys to become so efficient in
removing substances from the blood that
they may be used in place of a human
kidney for short periods of time. Many
new kidney operations are now possible.

In the previous discussion, the opera-
tion of the resin column was batch, or
intermittant. The solution to be ex-
changed was shut off during the wash-
ing and eluting operations. Several con-

SUBJECTIVE PROBABILITY
(Continued from page 21)

Figures and drauing courtesy of Facit, Inc.
Statisticians have removed some of the guesswork from life expectancy figures.
The average man of 20 is odds-on to live 54 more years, while at 30 he can ex-
pect another 44 years. When he reaches 40 he can expect 35 more years, and
at 50 he can expect to live past 75.
How does this help me? The answer is
based on the theory that it is better to
consider what you are doing beforehand
than afterwards.
The process is this: First, consider all
the alternatives before you. It might be
simply yes or no as in the case of whether
or not to make the bet, or it might be
a multiple choice as in deciding where
to spend summer vacation. In any case,
try to examine all of the alternatives;
don't forget the possibility of doing
nothing, it could turn out to be the best
choice.
Next, consider the possible results of
each choice and their probability of
occurence to the best of your knowledge.
Not just perhaps it will rain or perhaps
it won't, rather there is a 30 percent
chance that it will rain, a twenty per-
cent chance that it will be cloudy and a
fifty percent chance that it will be clear.
You may wish to get more information,
but don't spend more time than it's
worth—a bad guess isn't generally fatal.
Third, evaluate your pleasure or dis-
pleasure with each result in pleasure-
regret units as closely as practicable and
multiply by the probability of it's occur-
ence.
Finally, add each set of results for
each choice. Generally one choice will
outshine all others; if, however, the
values are close to one another, you
might check to see if you did, in fact,
include all the alternatives.
For instance take the decision of
whether or not to cross the street, a rela-
tively simple decision.
Choice A: Do not cross:
Result Probability Pleasure
Get run down. None —10,000
Get to class. None + 3
Choice B: Cross here in the
middle of
the block:
Result Probability
Pleasure
Get run down. 1/100,000
—10,000
Get a J-walking
ticket 1/100
-10
Get to class. 99/100
-3
Choice C: Cross at the corner
Result Probability
Pleasure
Get run down. 1/500,000
—10,000
Get to class. 499,999/500
000 +3
The tally: A—0
B—2.8
C—2.98
Thus, we dicide to cross at the corner.
The beauty of this type of decision is
that it takes into account all the informa-
tion you have, how you would feel in
each instance, and your confidence, (not
a small factor.)

(Continued from page 40J
tinuous processes have been developed
to attempt to overcome the short time
lag between cycles.
The first of these incorporates the
resin in small packets woven into a belt.
The belt moves alternatively through the
solutions continuously. Similarly, a fab-
ric belt with interwoven resin particles
has been developed which is run con-
tinuously through the proper solutions.
Another process entails pumping the
resin up through one column and allow-
ing it to cascade down through a second
one. A resin of sufficient settling density
must be used.
One other process involves baskets of
resin equally spaced around the rim of
a wheel. The solutions are run in at the
top and out the bottom in a continuous
flow as the wheel slowly turns. The so-
lutions are kept separate by rubber dams
around the outside of the baskets.
Future of Ion Exchange
Although a comparatively new pro-
cess, ion exchange has opened the door
to many processes previously impractical
and has simplified many others. But the
field is by no means depleted of appli-
cations. A great breakthrough in the
purification of seawater is expected with
the use of ion exchange membranes, and
resins are being designed for more selec-
tive properties in the separation of
rare earths and radioactive elements. The
future may see a resin able to exchange
one element only, available for every
element! Much research is needed in de-
signing optimum resin columns. Yes,
the future looks promising for ion ex-
change, greatly increasing the chemical
industries' contribution to everyday life.

ENGINEERS CORN TEST
Connect 20,000 volts across a pint.
If the current jumps it, the product is
poor.
If the current causes a precipitation of
lye, tin, arsenic, iron slag, or alum, the
whiskey is fair.
If the liquor chases the current back
to the generator, you've got good whis-
key.

frens'll be sorry, too. They were seeing

Cover Story
The evolution of life as we know it
is the theme of this month's cover. Jim
Berson. our cover artist, has tried to de-
pict the beginning of life starting with
the energy of the sun and the basic
chemical building blocks of hydrogen,
ni-rogen, oxygen, and carbon symbolized
by the red, large blue, small blue, and
black mo'ecules seen on the cover. Sim-
ple molecules formed first and evolved,
fiinally reaching the state of a one-
celled animal. The process doesn't stop
here of course, but our cover space
does; a more complete explanation can
be obtained by reading the cover ar-
ticle, "Chance of a Lifetime."

APATHY: Don't
In the past month a great deal has been written in campus and
college publications about the apathetic student and his lack of
realization of the value of extra-curricular activities Nearly all of
these articles have harrangued the student for not running for, work-
ing with, or attending meetings of all or some of the more than 100
student organizations. The point was that students are apathetic and
don't realize the immense value of activities to the individual.
In our opinion, this is a false conclusion. Students are not
apathetic. College students are intelligent enough to realize, and
do realize, the value participation in activities can play in pre-
paring a person for life.
Upon hearng a statement such as this people who support the
student apathy viewpoint will be glad to cite statistcs to support
their position. For instance:
—The steady decline in the number of people voting in
the S.G.C. elections, culminating with a new low in
March.
—The lack of candidates and voters in the Senior class
elections (Engineering included).
—And on the engineering scene, the lack of interest the
Engineering Council and its projects (i.e.—Engineer's
Weekend); the spasmodic attendance at technical and
honorary society meetings.
From these and other statements comes the conclusion that students
are apathetic.
Once again we say this is a false conclusion. Admittedly, there
is a lack of interest in activities on the part of students. It is our
firm conviction, however, that the lack of interest is caused, not by
the students, but by the organizations themselves. Too many organi-
zations drift along with no real reason for existence, others spend
so much time trying to find something to do that they have no time
to accomplish anything, still others carry out some busy work job
that the administration has allowed them to do.
How then does this thesis apply to the College of Engineering
and the so-called engineering activities? First of all, it is generally
felt that a majority of engineering groups get little support from
the student body. A great deal of this lack of support stems direct-
ly from the fact that the organizations have little or no purpose for
existing. An example are the class boards (with one exception—
See Ink Spots) who spent so much time trying to decide what to
do that they ended up doing very little. This fact was reflected so
strongly by students failing to run or to vote in the elections that
two classes don't even have boards now.
The Engineering Council is another group that seems to have
great potential but has consistently failed to win the support of the
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


Blame the Students
student body, and all too frequently, of its own members. Why has
this group, which has accomplished such concrete projects as the
Lounge and the Dean Brown Memorial Plaque, held in such low
esteem by the students? To find the answer to this question, and
thus the solution, the Council should determine for what purpose
it exists. Only when this purpose is justified in light of student's
needs and desires will the support, that has been lacking in the past,
be forthcoming in the future.
This leads us to an overall answer of how the thesis applies to
the College of Engineering. Just as with the Engineering Council,
the other organizations in the College—technical societies, honor-
aries, governing bodies, and publications—must justify their exist-
ence by the value of the functions that they fulfill. More basically
they must decide if they do fulfill any purpose, and if so, if this
purpose is contributing to the benefit of the students, the College,
or the profession.
It is hoped that the new officers of the engineering groups, most
of whom will be taking office in the near future, will face this
question in regard to their own organization. If the answers are
unsatisfactory it is time to reevaluate the reasons for the organiza-
tion's existence.
In any event, only when the answers are compatible with the
world of today can we expect "student apathy" to disappear.

Although class boards were singled out in the editorial as a
group that has been of little or no value, we are happy to say that
one exception does exist—the Executive Board of the Class of '6IE.
Earlier this year the Board compiled, distributed, and evaluated a
freshman questionnaire, making the results available to the Col-
lege's Freshman Counseling Committee.
More recently the Board sponsored the first of a projected
series of plant visits for undergraduates. The aim in the future is to
make it possible for undergrads to visit two or three plants in their
field of specialization.
To us this seems so beneficial and desirable that we would like
to see it be a required part of the sophomore or junior year. As it
is now many students never get into a plant until they are seniors
on plant interview visits. By this time the experience is too late
to be of any help in course work.

MAY, I960


PLUTO
Recent developments have led many scientists
to believe that the discovery of Pluto was a
fantastic coincidence.
By CHARLES MASSER

This photograph is the one from
which the discovery of Pluto was
made. Pluto's image is shown be-
tween the two small dash marks
near the center of the picture.
As one entered the darkened room,
all that could be seen was a fig-
ure illuminated by an eerie light, which
blinked on and off. That light, caused
by a "blink microscope," was to find a
special 15th magnitude object located
somewhere in 170 square degrees of
sky. This was the final operation in.
searching for a new planet that had
been theoretically found by the use of
celestial mechanics.
The Discovery
In the first operation, photographs
were taken, each one covering a small
portion of the area in question. Then six
days later another-photograph was taken
of each area. If that special object was
in the area the movement of the Earth
would cause it to move from one posi-
tion in the first plate to a new position
in the second plate. In using the "blink
microscope" the two plates are precisely
aligned so that light can be beamed by
means of a mirror alternately to each
plate. The observer can pick out an ob-
ject in the first plate, flick the mirror and
observe the same object in the second
plate. If there has been a movement of
the object it would appear to jump to a
new position. And so the work contin-
ued, week after week,, month after
month; then after more than a year Clyde
Tombaugh was rewarded. He had lo-
cated an object far beyond the eighth
Planet Neptune, which had the charac-
teristic movements of a new planet. And
so on March 13, 1930, the discovery of
a new planet was announced to the
world. Many names were suggested for
the new planet, but the three most pop-
ular were Coroners, PJuto, and Minerva.
However, Pluto was better known be-
cause his two brothers Jupiter and Sat-
urn already had planets named after
them. So early in May the name Pluto
was given to the new planet. It revolves
about the sun at a mean distance of
3,675,000,000 miles. At aphelion Pluto
is 4,589,000,000 miles from the Sun,
while at perihelion it is only 2,761,000,-
000 miles from the Sun. This gives an
eccentricity value of 0.249, largest of all
the planets. Pluto wanders so much that
at perihelion it is 16,000,000 miles closer
to the Sun than Neptune ever comes, but
due to its eccentricity its closest approach
to Neptune is 240 million miles.
High Point for Celestial Mechanics
With the discovery of Pluto classical
celestial mechanics had reached its maxi-
mum glory. With the help of celestial
mechanics perturbations in the orbits of
Uranus and Neptune led to the mathe-
matical prediction of a new planet. In
fact, there calculations showed where to
look for the new planet. Astronomers
MAY, I960
II


Clyde W. Tombaugh examining planet search plates In an
attempt to find Pluto. He sat 7,000 hours at this instrument
before he found the new planet.



The 13-inch Lawrence Lowell telescope of the Lowell Observ-
atory, Flagstaff, Arizona. The image of Pluto was detected
and discovered on photographic plates taken with this tele-
scope.
looked and found it, thereby fulfilling
the predictions that celestial mechanics
made. But as the years pass and more in-
formation is compiled on Pluto, doubt
enters the mind of leading astronomers
of the accuracy and effectiveness of celes-
tial mechanics at such great distances.
Many astronomers declare that the dis-
covery of Pluto was an accident and
back up their theory with convincing
data. In fact, many scientists believe
Pluto is not even a planet, but that it
is an escaped satellite of Neptune. Who
is right; what are the correct answers?
One can only present the facts now, but
the future may bring the answers.
First Triumph for Celestial Mechanics
It was Urbain Jean Joseph Leverrie
who studied the small irregularities in
the orbit of Uranus, and from his com-
putations pinpointed the position of Nep-
tune within a degree of where it was
found in the constellation Aquarius.
With the discovery of Neptune in Sep-
tember, 1846 hopes heightened that a new
planet beyond Neptune could be found
by using the same process. Even though
Uranus had been observed for two com-
plete revolutions around the Sun, time
had to pass in order to observe the
planet Neptune for irregularities in its
orbit. By 1900 celestial mechanicians
had acquired their data and a fresh at-
tack was launched in the search for the
ninth planet. W. H. Pickering of the
Harvard College Observatory, while work-
ing on his data and data of other ob-
servers, predicted a trans-Neptunian
planet near the foot of the constellation
Gemini in 1919. However, the planet
was not found when photographs taken
of the area were examined. At the same
time Pickering was working on his cal-
culations, Percival Lowell of the Lowell
Observatory in Flagstaff, Ariz, was hard
at work on a new approach for pinpoint-
ing the ninth planet. Since the ninth
planet, if there was one, would be beyond
Neptune, it would disturb Neptune more
than it would disturb Uranus. Therefore
Lowell based his findings more on the
irregularities in Neptune's orbit. Using
this approach Lowell found two areas in
which the new planet should be located.
One of these areas was the same as pre-
scribed by Pickering in 1919. Then the
process of taking the photographs was
undertaken. Two pictures of each area
taken several days apart were obtained,
but the sensitivity of the film used proved
inadquate, for no planet was uncovered
in the search. Not until 1929 did Lowell
Observatory receive cameras of necessary
quality. The search was again taken up,
but this time by a young assistant named
Clyde Tombaugh. It was through him,
and his long hours of work, examining
over two million photographs ,that the
ninth planet was found.
Reinvestgation of Pickerinng
and Lowell's Work
Since the proper equipment was not
available until 1929, a reinvestigation
was conducted of Lowell's photographs
made from 1914 to 1916, and the Mount
Wilson plates made in 1919 by Picker-
ing. The new planet had been over-
looked because it appeared unexpectedly
faint, in fact it was 1,000 times fainter
than Neptune. The faintness of Pluto
was very strange, and astronomers were
at a loss for an answer. If Pluto were
so faint it would follow that Pluto would
be small in diameter. And if it was small
in diameter it would not likely be very
massive. But if this is all true, the dis-
turbances in the orbits of Uranus and
Neptune could not have been caused by
Pluto. On the other hand, if Pluto were
small and its mass high, its density would
be unreasonably high. Still another an-
swer is that Pluto is large in diameter
but its albedo reflectivity is unexpect-
edly low. The question now is which
answer is correct.
Determination of Pluto's Mass
The first thing was to determine the
mass of Pluto. In the case of the planets
Uranus and Neptune their satellites ac-
curately revealed their masses. With
Pluto, however, this was impossible be-
cause it apparently had no satellites. The
mass of Pluto was then measured by the
displacement of Uranus and Neptune
from their orbits. The displacement of
six seconds of arc in Neptune's celestial
longitude could be caused by Pluto if
its mass were about equal to that of the
Earth. The mass of Pluto would be small
compared to Uranus and Neptune, which
have masses of 14.5 and 17.2 Earth
12
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


mass led to the announcement by sever-
al astronomers that the discovery of Pluto
was an accident. But then why did Low-
ell and Pickering pick the same region
in the sky to look for the new planet?
An explanation of this came from Vladi-
mir Kourganoff. He found that both
Lowell and Pickering relied on a group
of observations in 1710 on Uranus be-
fore it was declared a planet. Unfortu-
nately these observations were crude and
much error was involved in the observed
displacement of Uranus's orbit. Recent
observations and use of computers, which
used the calculated positions of the
outer planets from 1653 to 2060, have
calculated the displacements in the orbits
of Urnus and Neptune and have given
Pluto a mass slightly less than that of
the Earth.
New Observavtions Bring a Change
Everyone seemed happy with the re-
sults until a set of observations made in
March 1950 by Gerard P. Kuiper were
published. At the Mount Palomar Ob-
savertory he used the 200 inch telescope
as a visual experiment. He was compar-
ing the si2e of Pluto's image with a stand-
ard set of disks. With the help of Mil-
ton Humason they agreed that Pluto had
an apparent diameter of 0.23 seconds of
arc. This corresponds to 3,600 miles or
about half the diameter of the Earth. If
Pluto's mass were about equal to that of
the Earth, the calculation using 3,600
miles as Pluto's diameter would cause it
to have a density five times that of lead.
This is highly unlikely. A point was then
made about the accuracy of Pluto's di-
ameter, which was determined by the
disk method. Dinsmore Alter of Grif-
fith Observatory, Los Angeles, stated that
if Pluto reflected light like a polished
ball, the observed diameter would only be
a portion of the true diameter. However,
this was thrown out because Pluto's sur-
face has surely undergone changes such
as erosion, evaporation, and bombard-
ment by cosmic material. Which theory
is right? Celestial mechanics states that
Pluto's mass is about equal that of the
Earth. The other theory given by Kui-
per, which is reinforced by visual data,
states the diameter of Pluto is 3,600
miles. The answer that was chosen was
Kuiper's because his measurements could
not be argued, whereas the determina-
tion of Pluto's mass by methods of celes-
tial mechanics was too weak. Using 3,600
as the value for Pluto's diameter, the
mass is calculated to be about 0.03 that
of the Earth. Such a small mass as this
could not have produced the perturba-
tions in Uranus in 1710 the Lowell and
Pickering so heavily relied on.
Escaped Satellite of Neptune
Now astronomers attacked the state-
ment that Pluto was a planet. This led
to many questions and new theories about
the origin of Pluto and of the universe.
The large eccentricity of Pluto's orbit,
and the fact that its orbit has an inclina-
tion of over 17 degrees to the plane of
the ecliptic, led Issei Yamomoto of the
Kyoto Observatory to speculate in 1933
that Pluto was originally a satellite of
Neptune. A little later, calculations by
R. A. Lyteleton of the University of
Cambridge showed that Pluto had a
close encounter with Triton, the largest
satellite of Neptune. This encounter
might have ejected Pluto from the gravi-
tational system of Neptune. The two
present known satellites of Neptune had
been recaptured. Triton's orbit is retro-
grading (The movement in its orbit is
opposite to that of the movement of
Neptune around the Sun.) and Nereid's
orbit is highly eccentric. Just recently
more proof has been obtained to sub-
stantiate the theory that Pluto was a sat-
ellite of Neptune. In 1956, Merle Walk-
er and Robert Hardie measured the
changes in light reflection by Pluto. The
small fluctuations in brightness occurred
in cycles of 6.39 days. This would indi-
cate that Pluto rotates in a period of 6.39
days. This value is much slower than the
other outer planets, which rotate once
in 10 to 15 hours. Kuiper stated that
Pluto could have been revolving around
Neptune in a period of 6.39 days, and
when it escaped from Neptune it kept
rotating with the same value.
Celestial Mechanics Useless
Since Lowell and Pickering could not
have theoretically located Pluto by celes-
tial mechanics the laws of celestial me-
chanics have become useless in searching
for other unknown bodies that lie be-
yond Neptune. In the future we must
turn to astrophotography and hope for
another fantastic, accidental discovery
using this method. A systematic search
covering three quarters of the sky on
each side of the ecliptic has been made
since the discovery of Pluto. Over 90
million star images have been examined
by Tombough, and although no trans-
Plutonian planet has been found nearly
9,000 asteroids have been plotted. Other
by-products of the search were 1,807
variable stars, and 29,548 galaxies, but
only one comet was discovered by the
search.
The escape of Pluto from Neptune,
however, raises the hopes that more ob-
jects, larger and more interesting than
Pluto will be found on the fringes of
our solar system. Several other Neptunian
satellites could have escaped and are
traveling at even higher elliptical orbits
than Pluto. If photography can uncover
some of these wandering bodies more
questions will be answered concerning
the origin of our solar system.

this article possible:
The Solar System beyond Neptune, by

April 1959, Pps. 86-100.
Reminiscences of the Discovery of
Pluto, by Clyde W. Tombaugh; Sky and
Telescope. March I960, Pps. 264-270.

IFE
The nature of physical things is much more
easily conceived when they are beheld coming
gradually into existence, than when they are
only considered as produced at once in a fin-
ished and perfect state.

The blackness of night and the
brightness of day are joined by a
transient bridge called dawn. In a simi-
lar way, our world is divided into living
and nonliving parts, joined by a gray
area of life. Quantities on this life scale
such as living man at one extreme and
inert stone near the other, are well de-
fined. But inhabitants of the intervening
gray are as elusive as their dwelling place.
For example, a tobacco blight, known as
mosaic disease, is caused by a virus which
infects the plants, grows within them and
propagates throughout the crop like a
living pathogenic organism. Yet, in the
laboratory, this same living virus was
recently (1955) split into nonliving
parts, one consisting of a protein mole-
cule and the other of nucleic acids. These
parts were then recombined to form the
original active, infectious virus. The in-
determinate character of such substances
lends credence to the concept of a life-
'nonlife continuum and also points up
!,the difficulty of coining a rigorous defini-
Ition of life.
For that reason, let us confine our-
selves momentarily to a brief investiga-
tion of those things, which we intuitively
Consider alive, at the more extreme end
Of the scale. Here the term "living" can
be readily applied to organisms which
are able to grow, reproduce and be self-
sustained by a dynamic process involv-
ing the continuous influx and outflow
of matter and energy. Although they are
clearly defined by their living character-
istics, the true nature of these life forms
is still obscured by their complicated ar-
chitecture. Carbon, oxygen, nitrogen and
hydrogen are the chemical common de-
nominators of an enormous family of
substances known as organic compounds.
These compounds, in turn constitute the
brick and mortar of which living things
are made. In order to appreciate the
complexity of even the simplest living
structures, consider just one of the or-
ganic building blocks which they con-
tain. For example, a class of substances
called proteins is found in every living
cell. B-lactoglobulin, which is one of the
most elementary proteins, contains: 1,868
atoms of carbon, 3,010 atoms of hydro-
gen, 468 atoms of nitrogen, 583 atoms
of oxygen plus some thirty-odd atoms of
sulphur—all combined in a unique ar-
rangement. Complex as these proteins
are alone, it must be emphasized that in
a biological organism they are but one
small part of the living whole. Numerous
other compounds such as carbohydrates,
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


OF -A.
TIME
By ROBERT ERICKSON
lipids, nucleic acids, organic acids, min-
eral salts, and water share equal roles in
shaping earth's myriad forms of life.
Obscure Origins
The origin of life has puzzled man for
ages. Until the middle of the 19th cen-
tury, there were two beliefs in vogue.
One traced life's beginning to an original
supernatural creative act; the other found
its expression in the theory of spontane-
ous creation. The latter was a product of
simple observations. For example, mag-
gots seemed to appear from nowhere on
exposed meat. Likewise, mice arose out
of garbage and refuse. The conclusion
drawn from these observations was that
the maggots and mice were spontaneous-
ly generated out of the nonliving sub-
stances of their surroundings. The idea
might be humorously summed up by the
old nursery rhyme, "Sugar and spice and
everything nice, that's what little girls
are made of." In spite of its long stand-
ing, the crude spontaneous theory faded
in the wake of careful observations. It
was discovered that covering fresh meat
with a net or screen, so that flies couldn't
by eggs on it, ended the appearance of
maggots. Similarly, sealed garbage con-
tainers ended the creation of mice. It
remained for Louis Pasteur, however,
to settle the matter decisively. He demon-
strated, in his laboratory, that even the
process of decay could be prevented, that
perishables could be preserved indefinite-
ly when protected from external con-
tamination. In short, he shattered any
beliefs that the nonliving could give rise
to the living. At about the same time, old
ideas and attitudes were further jarred
by the publication of Darwin's The Ori-
gin of Species. Aside from its loudly crit-
icized monkey-man implications, the evo-
lutionary theory carried with it a less
obvious but nonetheless important con-
cept. Its underlying thread was to evoke
in man a new awareness of the impor-
tance of time. Suddenly the effect of
millions and billions of years, upon the
world and life, became highly significant.
The period immediately following was
one in which scientific inquiry into the
origin of life essentially ceased. Pasteur
had left no paths to follow. The concept
of a primary supernatural act, though
possibly sound, was by its very nature
impossible to investigate scientifically.
Disregarding the issue entirely, science
surged ahead throughout the remainder
of the 19th and into the 20th century,

(fcafi&amp;tte
Few people realize the present and future
importance of graphite in modern industry.
By PAT SOROKIN
Have you any idea how many times
you daily come in contact with
products made of or processed by graph-
ite? Few people know that there are
well over a thousand such products.
Dishes, adding machines, lamps, cars,
concrete, pencils, glass, batteries, and
rubber are just a few of the countless
number of products which are processed
with or made of graphite.
Why does graphite serve such a wide
variety of uses? The reason why graphite
is so diversified is because of its unusual
and numerous physical and chemical
properties. Its physical properties alone
afford many uses for this ore. All natur-
al graphite occurs in crystalline forms,
but industrial nomenclature classifies it
into three groups: "amorphous," "crys-
talline," and "flake." The "crystalline"
and "flake" forms come under the gen-
eral term of "cryptocrystalline masses."
The distinguishing factor between these
two classifications is that crystalline forms
can be seen by the naked eye, whereas
the structure of amorphous graphite is
only visible by x-ray diffraction.
Combinations of these forms are com-
monly found in nature. Though these
forms differ in appearance, they have the
same chemical properties. The "flake"
and "crystalline" varieties retain their
fish-scale-like property even after being
pulverized. "Amorphous graphite" can
easily be ground into fine particles. In
industrial applications, the "flake" and
"crystaline" forms can be used for all
purposes while the "amorphous" form is
limited to applications in specific fields.
These forms are found in particular
parts of the world. "Amorphous graph-
ite" is chiefly found in Mexico and Cey-
lon, other sources include Korea, Cana-
da, and China. "Flake" forms occur
mainly in Madagascar but are also found
in Kenya and Germany. The "crystalline"
form is found in Ceylon, Germany, Ko-
rea, and Norway. The United States has
a fair supply of natural graphite. How-
ever, it is of a low grade and importing
it from a foreign country is cheaper
than mining and processing it here. Or-
dinarily, only high-grade graphite min-
eral which contains 70 to 90 percent
graphitic carbon is imported.
The mining and benefication of graph-
ite varies with its forms. The ore is
mined from underground mines and
open pits. Crushing, screening, flotation,
budding, winnowing, and air separators
are the means which are usuallly used to
remove impurities. Cheap labor in for-
eign countries also affords manual pro-
cessing. This work is usually done near
the mine for this main reason and then
shipped to be further processed and put
to use.
Properties
Before the use of graphite can be dis-
cussed, consideration of its chemical and
physical properties should be taken be-
cause certain products are dependent on
these properties.
Natural graphite is an allotropic form
of carbon which is usually found in a
mixture of clay, iron, oxide, mica, and
other minerals. When compared with
carbon's other allotropic forms, striking
contrasts are found. The diamond is
transparent and harder because of its
atomic stucture. The distance between
each carbon atom in a diamond molecule
is symmetrical throughout. On the other
hand, the unequal distances between the
atoms in graphite account for its physical
properties of being black and crumbly.
Diamond dust would scratch and gouge
machinery, whereas graphite is unctuous.
Graphite's plate-like microstructure can
also be attributed to its crystalline form.
In its valence-bond structure, graphite
has one double and two single bonds
between each carbon atom. Resonance
between the bonds results in the bonds
possessing a 1/3 double bond character
and a 2/3's single bond character. Cleav-
age between the layer of sheets in a
crystal occurs readily, for the sheets are
weakly held together by van der Waals
forces. This crystalline bondage is the
major reason why graphite is a good
lubricant.
The structural state of the crystals
also accounts for other properties. Graph-
ite burns slowly, marks readily, and is
almost chemically inert. Other proper-
ties of major importance are: the flexibil-
ity of its temperature range, its high
conductivity of heat and electricity, its
negative temperature coefficient for re-
sistivity, its excellent weathering proper-
ties, its tendency to produce water-in-oil
type emulsions, and the fact that it readi-
ly dissolves in iron.
Manufacturing
Natural graphite's major function is
in the manufacture of refractory crucibles
which are used for melting nonferrous
16
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


The ore provides the following properties
which are necessary in a good refractory
crucible:
(1) high thermal conductivity
(2) high electrical conductivity
(3) low thermal expansion
(4) highly refractory
(5) high resistance to metal and flux
attacks
(6) thermal plastic properties at ele-
vated temperatures
Graphite is bonded with clay or pitch
by a dry or wet mixing of water. If
clay is used, so is the wet mixing and the
materials are usually mixed in a Mueller-
type mixer. It is important that the graph-
ite flakes do not crumble, and this
mixer does not tend to break them up.
Next the plastic material is aged for
several days. After that it is pressed,
spun, extruded, or hand-formed into
shape.
If pitch-bonded refractories are to be
made, the mixture is placed in a blade-
type mixer, which is heated. Both types
are fired under reducing conditions at
temperatures varying from 750 to 1350
degrees C. The product's ability to with-
stand low temperatures gives it resistance
to thermal shock. Its refractoriness al-
lows it to be continually used at elevated
temperatures with fusion.
There are many other refractory graph-
ite products. Graphite is used in stoppers
and nozzles to be used in metal process-
ing. Here it affords resistance to heat
shock, erosion and corrosion, withstands
deformation at high temperatures with-
out cracking and minimizes heat conduc-
tivity. It is also used in retorts, stirrers,
and cements.
Pencils
The most widely known use of graph-
ite is in pencils. Graphite, clay, and other
materials are baked at temperatures rang-
ng from 1,500 to 2,000 degrees Centi-
grade for several hours. Proportions of
the ingredients vary with the hardness of
the "lead" to be produced. Graphite of
high carbon content which is finely
ground is used in the better, more ex-
pensive pencils. Either "flake" or "amor-
phous" graphite is used.
The greatest amount of graphite is uti-
lized in the production of numerous
foundry facings. Amorphous graphite is
usually employed. Graphite is the mate-
rial most extensively used in this field of
manufacturing, though others are also
used. Mica, sand, clay, and talc of ex-
treme fineness are combined and pro-
cessed. Very little processing is needed,
because as long as the compound has
the proper fineness, there is no other
special requirement for facing products.
The combination is pressed into parts
and heated. Sometimes brass finishings
are added to a high grade of graphite to
obtain a superior finish.
Carbon Brushes
An article on graphite would be in-
complete without mentioning that it is
used in making electrical contact brushes.
Brush grades are usually classified accord-
ing to the manufacturing processes in-
volved and the nature of graphite and
carbon used. These classifications gen-
erally include:
(1) carbon and carbon-graphite —
high hardness, high mechanical
strength, and a pronounced clear-
ing action.
(2) electrographic-amorphous carbon,
when submitted to high tempera-
tures in an electric furnace, phys-
ically changes to a more graphit-
ic structure.
(3) graphitic-crystalline graphite is
mixed with a binder and pressed
into blocks and fired. Desired
physical properties are depend-
ent on the degree of the firing
temperature.
(4) metal-graphite — metallic pow-
ders, usually copper, and graph-
ite are sintered below the melt-
ing point of the metals involved.
The greater the metal content,
the higher the current densities
which can be used and the great-
er the mechanical strength of the
brush being produced.
The list of graphite products could be
extended indefinitely. Lubricants, metal-
lurgies graphite, paints, roofing com-
pounds, fillers for batteries, steam and
pump backings, and furnace linings are
some of the other applications of graph-
ite in the commercial arts.
Artificial Graphite
General Electric discovered that dia-
monds plus heat yielded graphite, but
there was no profit in this. Actual artifi-
cial graphite was accidentally discovered
as a result of a mistake by E. G. Ache-
son. Today, more artificial graphite is
produced by a Niagara Falls corporation
than is imported from foreign countries
annually. But artificial graphite is very
inferior to natural graphite as a lubricant,
because it contains only 0.5 percent sili-
con carbide, whereas the silicon carbide
content of natural graphite is 5.0 percent.
The silicon carbide plus petroleum
coke, anthracite coal and other carbon
compounds are bonded together with a
pitch binder and graphitized in an elec-
tric furnace of 1,000 horsepower rating.
Industrial products which are made of
articfiial graphite include packing mate-
rial for delicate electric-lamp filaments,
electrodes, in atomic piles as moderators,
and electro-plates.
Recent Discovery
Late in November last year, the Ray-
theon Company developed a new graph-
itic material called "pyrographite." The
material vaporizes at 6,350 degrees Fahr-
enheit—the same as ordinary graphite
(which is the upper limit for any elemen-
tal material). This new product's thermal
and electrical conductivity is strongly
anisotropic. It has a high density and im-
permeability to gases. It is hoped that
this new material will be useful in mis-
sile nose cones and rocket engines to
operate at greater temperatures. Its use-
fulness in missile nose cones is afforded
by its extraordinary ability to conduct
heat 100 times better along certain sur-
faces than perpendicular to them.
It seems that the atoms in the crystal
of this substance align themselves almost
parallelly, providing a much stronger
structure than ordinary graphite. It is
being used for military purposes now and
research is being done to see how well it
would serve as a light-weight insulation.
Few (and in some cases no) substi-
tutes exist for that small but very impor-
tant mineral, graphite. Natural supplies
are abundant and there is no concern
about a shortage of it. However, the
United States imports the greatest ma-
jority of its graphite from other countries
and if we were cut off from our supplies,
it would necessarily be produced at great
expense and its value would greatly in-
crease. The only Canadian producing mill
closed down in 1954, so we could not
turn there for a source. But since depos-
its lie in such a great many places which
are distant from one another, a supply-
seems assured.

TING
The heart of the success-failure determination
of guided missile flight, the double-integrating
accelerometer, determines rocket thrust, missile
velocity, and distance with errors as low as one-
tenth of one percent, and all in one package.
By JOHN P. PALMER
Everyone who drives an automobile
knows that the speedometer is an
indispensable instrument for good, ac-
curate, and lawful driving. Although a
good driver can develop a certain "feel"
for the handling of his automobile, this
by no means compensates for the speed-
ometer itself. Even if we were to equip
our automobiles with automatic "chauf-
feurs," there would still be the need for
a physical device to indicate the speed of
the vehicle.
Similarly, ships, airplanes, and guided
missiles need a means for measuring not
only instantaneous velocity, but accelera-
tion and distance as well. In the case of
the guided missile, the instantaneous ac-
celeration at all times must be known as
an indication of the thrust of the rocket
motors. The instantaneous velocity is
necessary at all times for confirmation
of the missile trajectory, or path to be
followed by the missile. Distance indica-
tion is a convenient means of denoting
the proper time at which the missile's
warhead should be armed, since in most
cases, explosive warheads are not armed
until the last minute before they are to
be triggered. The device commonly used
to determine these quantities is the ac-
celerometer.
In order to visualize more clearly just
what the principles of an accelerometer
are, let us consider what is meant by
acceleration. Now, the average velocity of
a body is defined as the change in dis-
placement of the body divided by the
corresponding period of time, and, simi-
larly, the average acceleration of a body
is defined as the change in velocity of that
body divided by the period of time. Thus
if at any given instant in time we know
how the displacement is changing with
time, we know the velocity at that in-
stant, and, if we know how the velocity
is changing with time, we know the ac-
celeration at that instant.
Now, in the course of firing a guided
missile, it is necessary to have a knowl-
edge of these three quantities: displace-
ment, velocity, and acceleration. Let us
see how they can best be determined. Sir
Isaac Newton, around the year 1700,
came up with a truly remarkable discov-
ery which supplies a very convenient
method for determining acceleration first-
hand in terms of much more readily
measured factors: namely, that the ac-
celeration of a body equals the force on
it divided by its mass. This is commonly
known as Newton's second law of mo-
tion. As a simple example of how New-
ton's method works, consider the shoot-
ing of an arrow with an ordinary bow.
During the period between the time the
drawn bow string is released and when
18
THE MICHIGAN TECHNIC


maximum velocity, the arrow is being ac-
celerated. Now, Newton's method of
determining acceleration says that if we
know the mass of the arrow and the
force exerted on it by the bowstring, we
can calculate the acceleration of the
arrow while it is being pushed by the
string. The mass of the arrow is deter-
mined by weighing it and dividing that
weight by a constant gravity factor, g.
We know the force exerted by the bow
string on the arrow, because it is speci-
fied by the manufacturer. Thus a simple
division gives us the average acceleration
of the arrow.
In order for us to use Newton's sec-
ond law as the fundamental working
principle of an accelerometer to deter-
mine the acceleration of a vehicle, and
thereby determine its instantaneous veloci-
ty and distance from take-off, we must
apply the reverse procedure. (The mathe-
matical term used to describe the process
used in these definitions above is, of
course, differentiation.) The reverse pro-
cess, i.e., the process we are to use, is
known as integration. We shall integrate
the initially determined acceleration with
respect to time to determine velocity-,
and we shall integrate velocity with re-
spect to time to determine distance.
There are two entirely distinct proce-
dures we can use to determine the first
and second integrals of acceleration, and,
in fact, both are commonly employed.
One procedure has been devised more
recently than the other, and has definite
advantages over the original. The origi-
nal procedure is to employ an accelerome-
ter which gives an electrical impulse cor-
responding only to the acceleration of
the vehicle. This type of accelerometer
is known as the non-integrating acceler-
ometer. The impulse corresponding to
the acceleration is fed to a computer
which then performs both integrations.
If the accelerometer gives an output sig-
nal accurate to 0.1 per cent or better of
full scale, i.e. at maximum acceleration,
the electrical integration processes pro-
duce as much as 3 per cent overall veloci-
ty error and five per cent overall distance
error. The more recently-developed pro-
cedure is to employ what is known as the
double-integrating accelerometer. As its
name implies, the double-integrating ac-
celerometer delivers electric signals cor-
responding to acceleration, velocity, and
distance. There is no need for an inte-
grating computer, and the errors involved
in such operations are removed. Indeed,
only the errors of the accelerometer re-
sponses are introduced, and these are as
low as 0.1 per cent for each of the three
responses, acceleraton, velocity, and dis-
tance. Consequently, the two major ad-
vantages of the double-integrating accel-
erometer are the reduction in space con-
sumption and the reduction in overall
error.
In this paper we shall examine the
operation of the double-integrating ac-
celerometer to see how the acceleration,
velocity, and distance of the vehicles are
determined, and how this information is
relayed to the proper vehicle components.
It must be noted that there are several
configurations of double-integrating ac-
celerometers produced by different manu-
facturers, and the particular specimen
we shall examine is called a torsion-reac-
tion double-integrating accelerometer.
The torsion-reaction accelerometer is
essentially composed of two coaxial fly-
wheels, one built inside the other, and a
d-c electric motor, as shown in figure 1.
The internal flywheel is mounted rigidly
on its shaft, which is also the driveshaft
of the d-c motor. The d-c motor housing
is in turn secured to the external fly-
wheel, both of which are mounted on a
second shaft which is freely supported by
the accelerometer housing assembly. The
motor rotor and driveshaft and the in-
ternal flywheel constitute the rotor assem-
bly. The external flywheel and the motor
housing constitute the stator assembly.
Thus, the rotor, stator, and fixed housing
assembly are designed so that the rotor
can rotate within the stator, and the
stator can rotate relative to the acceler-
ometer housing.
The objective of this system is to pro-
vide the information necessary to deter-
mine, first of all, the acceleration of the
vehicle. Therefore, the system must pro-
vide a force-mass ratio. Let us see what
arrangements must be made so that we
can choose the stator of the above con-
figuration as the "arrow" of our system,
i.e. the effective mass. If we can now
find a force exerted on the stator which
is directly proportional to the accelera-
tion of the vehicle, we may be able to
harness the results of this force together
with the mass of the object exerting this
force to give us an indication of the
acceleration. Let us attach a counter-
weight to the stator near its circumfer-
ence. The effect of this counterweight
will be to unbalance the stator, and
thereby convert it into a pendulum. Now,
let us consider the case of a pendulum
consisting of a string with a loop at one
end through which we place a slender
rod. To the other end is attached a fairly
heavy ball. Now, let us take hold of the
rod with the string and ball, or pendu-
lum, hanging beneath. As we move the
rod in a horizontal direction at right
angles to the rod from an initial state
of rest to a certain velocity, the pendu-
lum will move through a certain arc. In
other words, the ball will tend to trail

MAY, I960
19


two, and the position of the string be-
fore the motion is started and after the
given velocity is reached will define an
angle. The magnitude of this angle is
determined by the change in velocity,
whereas the rapidity with which the
angle is inscribed is determined by the
acceleration we give to the rod. This is
exactly analogous to the motion of our
stator assembly under an acceleration of
the vehicle in a direction normal to the
axis of rotation of the stator, neglecting
the rotor. At an initial velocity, V,, the
stator with its counterweight will assume
a given position. As we change this
velocity, i.e. accelerate the vehicle, to an-
other velocity, V2, the stator rotates
through an angle proportional to the
change in velocity, and the speed at which
the angle is changing at any instant is
proportional to the acceleration of the
vehicle.
However, we have not yet suggested
a way to measure this force and transfer
it into an electrical signal for the proper
components of the vehicle. This is where
the rotor comes into play. Let us attach
an electric switch to the accelerometer
housing so that as the stator turns
through a very small arc due to accelera-
tion of the vehicle, it closes this switch.
Let the switch be connected to the d-c
motor so that when the switch is closed
power is supplied to the motor, and the
motor applies a torque to the rotor.
When the switch is open, the rotor coasts
to a stop. Let us suppose that the stator
is deflected through a clockwise angle
and closes the switch to the motor. If
the motor applies a starting torque in the
clockwise direction to the rotor, the same-
torque will be applied to the stator in
the opposite or counterclockwise direc-
tion, since one is connected to the shaft
of the electric motor, while the other is
connected to the motor housing. As an
example of this action-reaction pheno-
menon consider holding the drive-shaft
of an electric motor in your hand without
touching the motor housing, then turn
the motor on. The shaft will remain
stationary in your hand while the rest
of the motor rotates about it, say in a
clockwise direction. Now, release the
drive-shaft, and hold onto the motor
housing, the shaft spins in the counter-
clockwise direction. If you hold onto
both the shaft and housing with both
hands, you feel a torque in one direction
in the left hand, and a torque in the
other direction with the right hand. They
are necessarily equal and opposite (ac-
cording to Newton's third law of mo-
tion). Now, the acceleration of the
vehicle has caused the stator to rotate
clockwise and close the switch. This
energizes the d-c motor, which applies
a starting torque to both the rotor and
stator in opposite directions. The torque
applied to the stator is counterclockwise
and moves the stator away from the
switch against the force of the accelera-
tion. As soon as the switch opens, the
torque is no longer applied by the motor,
and if the vehicle is still accelerating,
the stator again moves clockwise and
closes the switch. Now, this process can
happen as often as 200 times a second.
We now have a means of determining
the force of the counter-balance on the
stator due to an acceleration normal to
its axis of rotation, and this is just what
we were looking for. In fact, the rate at
which these pulses increase is in direct
proportion to the force due to accelera-
tion exerted by the counterbalance on
the stator, divided by the mass of this
counterbalance, or in other words, the
rate of increase of the pulses is in direct
proportion to the acceleration of the
counterbalance, which is the acceleration
of the vehicle.
We may also note that the accelera-
tion has already been integrated to the
velocity measurement, for the velocity is
simply in direct proportion to the rate of
occurrence of the pulses or the number
of pulses per unit time. Finally, the ac-
celeration has been integrated a second
time, because the distance traveled by the
vehicle is merely proportional to the
total number of pulses at any given
instant.
We have not yet considered the case
where the missile is decelerating. But,
this is a simple matter, since we need
only place an identical switch at the
other side of the arc sudtended by the
stator. That is, if the vehicle decelerates,
rather than accelerates, the stator will be
forced to move in a counter-clockwise
direction until it closes the switch on this
side of the swing. This switch must be
connected to the motor in the reverse
manner of the former switch so that the
motor will exert a counterclockwise,
rather than clockwise torque to the rotor,
and thus apply a clockwise torque to the
stator until the switch is opened. We can
see the analogy with the string pendu-
lum used previously. Once the rod above
the pendulum is in motion, and we begin
to slow it down, the pendulum swings
out in front of the rod, rather than be-
hind the rod as in the case of accelera-
tion.
As the output signals from the accel-
erometer are accumulated, they are re-
layed to various components of the
missile that need this information, such
as the automatic arming device for the
explosive warhead, and they are trans-
mitted to the ground station for a full
analysis by the ground crew. Thus, both
the missile intelligence built into the
missile and the ground base have an
excellent concept of how the missile is
handling.
I would like to express my gratitude to
my chief sources of reference: "Horizon-
tal Integrating Accelerometers" in the
Sperry Engineering Review, March, 1959,
and, "New Double Integrating Accel-
erometer" in Control Engineering, No-
vember, 1958.

John P. Palmer, a native of Pomo-
na, California, wrote The Double-
Integrating Accelerometer as a fi-
nal paper in English 35. His
interest in guided missiles and con-
trol mechanisms is further reflected
in his studies and job choice. After
he obtains his B.S. in Science Engi-
neering, he will shoot for a Mas-
ter's in Instrumentation Engineer-
ing. For the last three summers
John has spent his time working
at the Convair Division of General
Dynamics.
Palmer's hobbies include model
trains and rebuilding autos. He is
presently a member of Zeta Psi, a
junior, and married.

I found I could be an engineer
—and a businessman, too"
William M. Stiffler majored in mechanical
engineering at Penn State University—but he
also liked economics. "I wanted to apply en-
gineering and economics in business," he says,
"and have administrative responsibility."
Bill got his B.S. degree in June, 1956, and
went to work with the Bell Telephone Com-
pany of Pennsylvania at Harrisburg. During
his first two years, he gained on-the-job ex-
perience in all departments of the company.
Since June, 1958, he's been working on trans-
mission engineering projects.
Today, Bill is getting the blend of engineer-
ing and practical business-engineering he
wanted. "The economic aspects of each proj-
ect are just as important as the technical
aspects," he says. "The greatest challenge lies
in finding the best solution to each problem in
terms of costs, present and future needs, and
new technological developments.
"Another thing I like is that I get full job-
responsibility. For example, I recently com-
pleted plans for carrier systems between
Scranton and four other communities which
will bring Direct Distance Dialing to cus-
tomers there. The transmission phase of the
project cost almost a half-million dollars and
was 'my baby' from terminal to terminal.
"Telephone engineering has everything you
could ask for—training, interesting and varied
work, responsibility, and real management
opportunities."
Bill Stiffler and many college men like him have found inter-
esting careers with the Bell Telephone Companies. There
may be a real opportunity for you, too. Be sure to talk with
the Bell interviewer when he visits your campus—and read
the Bell Telephone booklet on file in your Placement Office.
